Implement a new annual survey of satisfaction of users of the justice system. Food Health: Reduce food-borne illness by 20%. Salmonella in UK-produced farm chickens should be halved by the end of 2004-5. BSE should be reduced from 4,312 cases in 1997 to 650 by 2004, on track to 30 cases by 2006. Europe: Deal on common agricultural policy to be complete by March 2004. Fishing: Reduce fishing capacity by the end of 2001 by 20% from 1997 levels. BSE: By 2004, identify the latest offspring of suspect BSE cases and exclude them within two days of the case being reported. Department for International Development By 2006, increase the proportion of EU development assistance going to poorest countries from 50% to 70% in 2006. Ministry of Defence Meet full manning requirements in March 2004 with RAF in 2001, navy in 2003 and army in 2005. Set new tour-of-duty limits and increase airlift capacity, as well as establish joint rapid reaction force. By 2005, ensure a minimum of 90% of rapidly available miliatry units at required state of readiness. Foreign Office Nuclear weapons: By March 2004, ensure 90% of the 38 remaining parties sign the comprehensive test ban treaty. Environment: By 2004 negotiate global regulation of the oceans and an international commitment to combat climate change. Crime: Each year sign four memorandums of understanding on drugs and crime. By 2002, implement action plans with EU accession countries.

fields.headline: Jobs out for the lads
fields.standfirst: As the case of Irvine's chum demonstrates, women suffer discrimination when it comes to top posts
fields.trailText: Yvonne Roberts: As the case of Irvine's chum demonstrates, women suffer discrimination when it comes to top posts.
fields.body:
It's a rum situation. Thanks to our lord chancellor, Lord Derry Irvine, we have a situation in which the laws of the land apply - unless you happen to be a very important person hiring an equally notable individual for a highly esteemed appointment. In which case, you don't have to give a toss. It's laissez-faire for the lads. The old boys network is given a status all of its own.

In early 1998, Derry Irvine appointed his friend, Gary Hart, as his special adviser on a salary of £73,000. Jane Coker, a respected solicitor with experience in areas useful for a special adviser, objected, as did Martha Osamor, a legal adviser. Coker is white, Osamor black. They took the lord chancellor to an employment tribunal on the grounds that by not advertising the post, he had practised sexual and racial discrimination.

Coker won her case. Lord Irvine then successfully appealed. Yesterday, the two women were given the right to appeal against that judgment. Four out of six tribunal members have now decided that our leading legal figure has broken the law. Should he remain victorious then a remarkable precedent will be established. If a job is considered important enough - say head of Railtrack - legislation will be ignored, accountability overlooked and a large pool of talent will be automatically excluded. Why? Because in New Labour's new Britain, what matters is the right of powerful people to pick whom they please from their own (usually) white, male, middle-aged circle of mates. Plus ça change.

"If you want the best person," says Coker, "you recruit in a non-discriminatory fashion. Otherwise how will anyone know if public money is being spent on the right person for the job?"

There is a pattern of discrimination in the lord chancellor's office. Three years ago, Philip Sales, another friend, was appointed to give legal advice across Whitehall after "secret" soundings were taken. Last year too, it was revealed that barristers from the lord chancellor's former chambers had earned more than a million pounds since the election from government work.

Lord Irvine's management methods are discriminatory, elitist, an abuse of power. They also provide another less obvious but equally wretched indicator that New Labour's attempts to modernise Britain are doomed - unless there is a radical overhaul of the "new" establishment's abysmal quality of leadership.

In April, under the Access to Justice Act, the Criminal Defence Service comes into force, part of the shake-up of the legal aid system. Barristers may lose their independent status and become salaried defenders in legal aid cases. Irrespective of the wisdom or otherwise of this change, the way in which Lord Irvine has gone about this reform hardly makes him Boss of the Year material. His critics are quoted as saying that he is "arrogant... "impatient and intolerant... he's known as a bully... it's his method...."

Beverly Alimo-Metcalfe is professor of leadership studies at Leeds University. She and three colleagues have just completed a study in the public sector called Leadership Development in British Companies at the Beginning of the 21st Century. What they have concluded is that we lack modern leadership on a depressingly large scale. But what we do appear to have is the Irvine model in bucket loads. This is the transactional, command and control form of autocracy - solving problems without consultation, issuing orders, feeding off status, brooking no criticism, avoiding transparency.

The study of what characterises leadership began in the US in the 1930s in the military. Leaders are defined as individuals who have an "extraordinary positive effect on the motivation, job satisfaction and performance of staff". In the 1980s, transformational leadership was identified as having a much greater impact than the transactional style. More importantly, it generated bigger profits.

Transformational leadership requires charisma, concern for other's well being, delegation, integrity, transparency, approachability and an encouragement of critical thinking. The transformational leader seeks advice, works in collaboration, rules by praise not intimidation and shuns nepotism, self-serving agendas and status.

In their study of 36 companies, Alimo-Metcalfe and her colleagues, found that none had highly developed leadership skills at all levels; only 43% believed they had them at some levels while 11% admitted to having inadequate skills at all levels. "Organisations are interested in making change because they realise that without it, they won't survive," Alimo- Metcalfe explains. "Leaders aren't born, they are made."

Billions of dollars are now invested in acquiring transformational leadership skills in the US. These skills are also considered closer to a female style of management. "Female" not for any biological reasons - women certainly aren't naturally nicer - but because these are the best techniques for outsiders trying to come up from under.

Our lord chancellor has appointed a commissioner to help with appointments but old habits die hard. He is a law-breaker, stuck in the past, renowned for his self-glorification and cronyism, happy to exclude, in talented women, the very individuals who have the ability to save his office from himself. And they call this the new Britain?

yroberts@dial.pipex.com

fields.body:
For more information on the regions, here are eight websites to have a look at.

Regions map - shows the boundaries of the English regions and the regional development agencies that cover them.
www.local-regions.detr.gov.uk

North east consitutional convention - a short summary of the convention's early work on a regional government model for the area.

The Campaign for the English Regions - a lobbying organisation dedicated to devolution.

Guide to regional development agencies - find your local regional development agency, and learn more about what they do.

Charter 88 - constitutional reform group pushing for action on regional government.
www.charter88.org.uk

Labour's 1997 general election manifesto - read the party's pledge to devolve power to the English regions.
www.politicos.co.uk

fields.headline: A vision in a dream
fields.trailText: Week 8: Kuching Whether tramping Livingstone-like through the luxuriant rainforest or watching a man possessed by the spirit of the elephant god force a steel hook through his cheek while in a trance, Sue finds that Malaysia more than lives up to her expectations
fields.body:
I have done so much this week that it's going to be difficult to fit it all in, but I'll try.

Saturday was my last day in Singapore and I crammed in as much as possible. First it was off to Sentosa Island. Theme parks aren't really my scene, but I wanted to go on the cable car ride from Mount Faber to the Island which gave an aerial view over Singapore. I walked the neat nature trail halfway round the island, then took the monorail - with the inevitable synchonised commentary - round the rest. This was enough and I caught the ferry back. Off then to Jurong bird park which was enjoyable, with flocks of pink flamingos and aviaries of brightly coloured forest birds, although I didn't relish seeing huge eagles and a condor in cages, however big. I had my first taste of magueritas out of jam jars with Dan that evening - powerful stuff.

On Sunday I flew to Kuching in Sarawak to be met by Steven, my son's girlfriend's uncle. Steven, Jennifer (his wife) and their four children have been the most wonderful hosts, helping to plan trips for me, ferrying me about, and giving me a real taste of Malay life and food. Noodles with meat and soup for breakfast took a bit of getting used to but I managed it as well as many of the local Chinese dishes with unfamiliar ingredients. Playing Monopoly with the streets of Kuala Lumpur on the board was also interesting.

Kuching is a lovely city with a delightful riverwalk adorned with coloured fountains and flower beds. We took a 'tambang' - a little ferry - across and down the river. Across the road is a line of shops stuffed with Borneo artifacts. The city is full of Chinese and Malay food markets with fruit and vegetables I have never seen before. I visited some of the excellent museums although unfortunately the unique Cat Museum was shut on the day I was wandering about.

On Tuesday it was off for an overnight stay at the Bako National Park. A real adventure. Accessible only by boat, I was somewhat taken aback to be given a life jacket. There followed a 20 minute ride crashing through high waves with sea horses on them, and being drenched by spray. Exciting stuff! The park was beautiful, with stunning empty beaches, the forest at times meeting the sea. This is what I had come for. I chose a trail of five kilometres or so that looked manageable and set off. Within minutes I was deep in the rainforest, drenched with sweat, completely alone (except for Bruce, of course) splashing through streams and clambering over tree roots. The only sound was the continuous hum and whine of insect life. I was lost in wonder, feeling like Dr Livingstone, Margaret Mead and Harrison Ford all in one. OK, the trails were marked and there were wooden planks across swampy bits, but it still felt totally real and raw. When I reached high points the views took my breath away. The only problem was that I had drunk half my water by the time I was only a quarter of the way and had to begin rationing it. In the deepest part of the forest it was so dense that it became dark. Water dripped everywhere and the rocks and trees were covered in thick moss. Here even the insects stopped their noise. I have never experienced such complete silence, felt so close to ancient nature at its richest, or so far from civilisation. I will never forget that feeling. Late afternoon I was rewarded by the sight of proboscis monkeys swinging high in the trees. Magic. Dirty, drenched to the skin, tired and a little dehydrated, I arrived back at the lodge after six of the best hours of my life.

That evening there was a terrific thunderstorm with torrential rain. I sheltered in the canteen spending a pleasant evening talking to a couple from Cairns in Australia. I returned to the lodge to find my bag of rolls empty, despite meshed windows and a locked door, I can only guess that a very tiny macaque monkey had squeezed through the narrow slats above the windows, neatly untied the plastic bag and enjoyed my breakfast. The next morning for the first time, I met an English couple who had actually seen the Netjetters website back in England. It felt exciting and strange, especially as there were only about half a dozen tourists in total at the park! After a short walk in the morning, spotting more monkeys, and another hair-raising boat ride, it was back to Kuching.

The following day I was off again - this time to the heritage park where they have rebuilt examples of the different tribal longhouses, which are fast disappearing from East Malaysia. People from the different tribes were cooking or weaving or making musical instruments in the traditional ways. Although it was manufactured, the combination of the setting and the enthusiasm with which the people demonstrated what they were doing made the experience fascinating and informative. webTitle: CD of the week: Ruders: The Handmaid's Tale

fields.headline: Be afraid - be very afraid...
fields.standfirst: The Handmaid's Tale is a masterpiece of operatic terror.  Tim Ashley  is disturbed
fields.trailText: The Handmaid's Tale is a masterpiece of operatic terror. Tim Ashley is disturbed
fields.body:
Ruders: The Handmaid's Tale
Rorholm/Fischer/Dahl/Resmark/ Elming/Henning-Jensen/Haugland/ Royal Danish Opera Chorus/Royal Danish Orchestra/Schonwandt (Dacapo, 2 CDs)
*****
£25.99

I almost wish I had not heard this. That is intended as a compliment. I sat through this recording of Poul Ruders's adaptation of Margaret Atwood's The Handmaid's Tale in something like shock, a screw turning in the pit of my stomach. That alone is testament to the work's terrorising impact. It's also, I think, what we are meant to feel when we hear the opera, or read the book. The inevitable question is why? What is it about The Handmaid's Tale that makes it such a uniquely distressing experience?

Atwood's 1985 novel is a grimly dystopian prophecy that envisions a totalitarian society based on fundamentalist religious principals. Christian revolutionaries have taken over the US, renaming it the Republic of Gilead, overriding its democracy and enforcing codified biblical laws on sexual conduct. All fertile women who have expressed what is perceived as trangressive desire are brainwashed into becoming Handmaids - surrogate mothers to elite childless couples, their babies conceived during ritual Ceremonies in which husbands (called Commanders) have sex with the Handmaids in the presence of their wives.

What pushes the book into territory way beyond polemic and really hits raw nerves, however, is Atwood's emphasis on the collusion of some women in the oppression of others, and on the dire similarities between the languages of right-wing reaction and radical sexual politics. During the Ceremony, the Handmaid is held down by the wife. So-called Aunts emotionally batter women into submission and preside over the communal execution of offenders. The Handmaids are "only containers, walking wombs", who may not arouse desire. "To be seen is to be penetrated," shrieks the fanatical Aunt Lydia, steering perilously close to the radical feminist perspective that equates male desire with rape.

The novel charts the thoughts of one Handmaid, Offred (named after the Commander whose property she is), as she begins both to find her voice and identity in opposition to the regime, and gradually to recall the murder of her husband and her separation from her daughter during the revolution. Atwood's cliff-hanging finale offers little way out of the nightmare beyond the eventual collapse of Gilead over time, and it's not surprising that when Hollywood filmed the novel in 1989, a redemptive ending was tacked on. Ruders and his librettist, Paul Bentley, offer us no such hope.

The opera's genius lies in Ruders's ability to find a sound world that mirrors the novel's oppressive tone. The strictures of tonality and minimalism are broadly equated with totalitiarian suppression, while atonality is aligned with individuality - but emotional dissonance is rarely absent for long, and the cumulative impression is of an impending eruption that never happens.

The effects are crushing, forcing us to share Offred's experience. Pulverising percussion pins the listener down. Obsessively repeated phrases sting like the cattle prods the Aunts use to persecute their victims. Amazing Grace threads its way through the score like some wonky Bach chorale, combining with ejaculatory glockenspiel trickles to form an obscene accompaniment to the Ceremonies. The whole is relentless. Only once, at the work's climax, does Ruders let the pace slacken. He uses not one, but two singers for the principal character, representing Offred the Handmaid and the woman she was in "the Time Before". As memories obliterate the Aunts' conditioning, the two women join in a duet of Monteverdian simplicity as they mourn the loss of Offred's child. Horror suddenly finds release in grief, and the effect is devastating.

The casting of both roles is telling. Marianne Rorholm, very much a singing actress, is the Handmaid, her voice clotting throughout with exhaustion and anguish. Hanne Fischer, voluptuous in tone, is the sensual, emotionally fulfilled woman she once was. Her lovers are two contrasting tenors. Poul Elming, virile and athletic, is the husband who exists in her memory, while Gert Henning-Jensen, elegant and lyrical, plays Nick, the Guard she comes to desire in the present. The late, much-missed Aage Haugland is a slimy, hypocritical Commander, with Susanne Resmark as his possessive, Gospel-singing wife. Anne Margarethe Dahl voices Aunt Lydia's stratospheric vituperation with sickening vividness. In the pit Michael Schonwandt astounds, as always.

The recording was made during the premiere run in Ruders's native Denmark last March, and there is a considerable amount of stage clatter, though you can live with it. Curiously, however, a bit of the piece is missing. Taking his cue from Atwood, Bentley frames the opera with a narration, delivered after the fall of Gilead by a lecturer presenting the tapes on which the Handmaid tells her tale. The spoken sections have been cut, which is a pity, since the sound of a woman's voice stuttering into song after male speech must have been overwhelming in the theatre. You need to hear this, if you think your nerves can take it - but you must prepare to be disturbed and very, very afraid if you do.

fields.headline: Indians deny Channel 4 'all-clear' to film
fields.trailText: 4.45pm update: Indian officials have denied Channel 4 has been "given the all-clear" to film at the Kumbh Mela bathing site, writes Anna MM Vetticad.
fields.body:
Indian officials at the Kumbh Mela in Allahabad, India, have denied that Channel 4 has been "given the all-clear" following a meeting.

Refuting a press statement issued by Channel 4 today, Jeevesh Nandan, a senior official at the mammoth gathering of Hindu devotees, said: "The status quo continues. It is true that Channel 4's press passes are still valid, but a final decision is yet to be taken. The decision will be taken in a day or two."

A panel consisting of two Indian officials and a local journalist viewed footage of the channel's daily coverage today.

The move came following what MR Nandan described as "information we got here from various sources that there were a lot of protests from Indians in the UK about Channel 4's coverage of the event".

Several press representatives were injured in a police baton charge in media centre at Kumbh site this evening.

The two groups clashed over the ban imposed by the administration over filming of the pilgrims at the bathing areas.

Asked whether they had received any complaints, a Channel 4 spokesperson said: "I've not had any complaints."

She further insisted: "Our producers have taken our footage to the administrators at the mela and were given the green signal."

The spokesman later admitted that there had been a complaint from the National Council of Hindu Temples.

fields.headline: Oversubscribed...
fields.standfirst: ... Hussein Chalayan at Autograph
fields.trailText: ... Hussein Chalayan at Autograph
fields.body:
Hussein Chalayan is having something of a tumultuous year so far. While the rest of the world was still bleary-eyed with New Year hangovers, news arrived of financial problems at his label, swiftly followed by an announcement from New York house Tse that they would not be renewing his design contract. Chalayan went to ground, but this week has reappeared in the most unlikely of places - M&S.

Life, as Ronan Keating so aptly put it, is a rollercoaster, just gotta ride it. The high street superpower has announced that Chalayan is the latest signing to its club class Autograph range: the new collection features the designer's signature understated-yet-sculptural looks in the draped separates and "waterfall" georgette evening dress. Wear your support for one of London's unique fashion talents on your sleeve (or back or legs) from £55 for a camisole, £120 for a dress.

fields.headline: Regional government explained
fields.trailText: Regional government is an issue that every voter may well face in the near future. Labour has promised to give directly election regional government to the areas that want it. But what would that actually entail? Simon Parker explains
fields.body:
Why all the fuss about regional government?

Because we could soon be voting on whether or not we want it. The government's 1997 election manifesto promised to move "in time" to directly elected regional government for those areas that vote for it in a referendum. Scotland and Wales got their assemblies, and now campaigners in some of the English regions want to follow suit.

The government is, however, divided on the issue, with the prime minister against moving to English regional government in the near future and John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, strongly in favour. Activists in groups such as the Campaign for the English Regions hope Mr Prescott will win through, and that Labour will commit itself to further devolution in a second parliamentary term.

What are the English regions?

The government has carved England up into nine administrative regions: London, the north-east, north-west, west midlands, east midlands, south-east, south-west and the eastern region. The capital already has a form of regional devolution in the shape of the Greater London Authority, headed by mayor Ken Livingstone.

Are people in the English regions likely to vote for regional government?

Maybe. The north-east is the most enthusiastic region, and polls there have shown a slim majority in favour of an elected assembly. The region has a fully fledged regional government campaign, and has held a constitutional convention to establish what an assembly might look like.

The debate is less developed in the other English regions, although five of the eight outside London have set up constitutional conventions, or are in the process of doing so. The south-east, eastern region and east midlands have yet to move on the issue.

Some ministers are against holding referendums because they believe there is little demand for regional government.

Has the government already put any regional arrangements in place?

Yes. Ministers have introduced regional development agencies, designed to improve economic performance. The civil service also has outposts in the provinces - the Government Offices for the Regions.

Each region has an unelected assembly made up of local councillors as well as representatives of the voluntary and private sectors. They have few formal powers.

What would a regional assembly add to that?

If it were anything like the model proposed by the north east constitutional convention, it would be a directly elected assembly with 30-40 members, which would set policy on planning, the regional economy, transport, infrastructure, training, arts and culture. Much of its infrastructure would be taken from existing regional bodies, such as the government regional office, which would become a secretariat. Regional development agencies could become agencies of the assemblies.

What are the drawbacks?

The Conservatives believe that the government's regional policies are the first step on the road to a federalized "Europe of the regions". They see this as an unacceptable attack on English culture and traditions.

The Tories are also among those who claim voters do not identify with the government's regions, making them unlikely to support regional assemblies.

Proposals for regional devolution have sparked disagreements within some regions. In the south-west, for instance, the Cornish want to exclude their county from any regional assembly, and hope instead for a parliament dedicated to Cornwall.

Some in local government fear that regional assemblies would take their functions from councils, making local authorities less powerful.

The deputy prime minister has, however, dropped plans to scrap two-tier local government and replace it with unitary authorities before devolution is extended to England.

webTitle: Britain, 2005: vision of a brighter future - or hostage to fortune?

fields.headline: Britain, 2005: vision of a brighter future - or hostage to fortune?
fields.standfirst:
As election approaches, Labour draws up portrait of how the UK is likely to look after a second term in office

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: As election approaches, Labour draws up portrait of how the UK is likely to look after a second term in office.
fields.body:
An intricate and ambitious portrait of Britain at the end of a second-term Labour government has been drawn up by ministers and civil servants over the past six months. It covers every aspect of government, ranging from asylum policy and the extent to which inequality will be reduced, to the birthweight of newborn babies.

In what will be seen as Labour's hidden manifesto for the general election, the government has set out more than 200 targets, backed in the last few weeks by a growing number of comprehensive agreements on how the targets are to be defined and delivered.

Critics claim the preciseness of the targets will prove to be a big hostage to fortune. The furore over Labour's failure so far to meet two of its five election pledges underlines the political pitfalls of making measurable promises. Most of the targets are due to be met by 2004 or 2005, the likely date Labour will go to the polls seeking a third term.

Health

Heart disease: Cut deaths from 69,000 in 1997 to 51,500 by 2005.

Cancer: Reduce deaths by 69,000 to 61,000 in 2005.

Suicides: Cut from 4,500 in 1997 to 4,000 in 2005.

Outpatients: By 2005, all appointments will be prebooked.

Waiting lists: By the end of 2005, maximum waiting time for outpatient appointments down to three months and for inpatient treatment to six months. Figures for third quarter of last year show 25% of patients are still waiting more than three months for an outpatient appointment and more than six months for inpatients.

Community care: As many as 130,000 elderly people people to be helped in the community, rather than hospital.

Crime

Vehicle crime: Reduction of 30% by 2004 from the baseline of 1998-9. Will need cut from 1,071,000 to around 700,000.

Burglary: Cut of 28% by 2005 from baseline of 464,000. Latest figures show burglaries at 417,400.

Robbery: By 2005 robbery of personal and business property in London to be cut by 15% from 1999-2000 figures. Cut of 34.1% by 2004 in West Midlands; by 20% by 2005 in Greater Manchester; 15% by 2004 in Merseyside; 21.4% by 2004 in West Yorkshire. Robbery in England's big cities would fall by 14%.

Fear of crime: By 2004, should be lower than levels to be recorded in the British Crime Survey in 2001.

Cost of crime: A target, yet to be agreed, will be issued. The figure is currently estimated at £60bn.

Charges: By 2002, the number of recorded crimes brought to justice would be increased from the 1998-9 figure of 1,202,037 crimes cleared up out of 5,109,110.

Reoffending: Cut of 5% against the predicted rate by 2004; 30,000 offenders to complete accredited programmes and the number of prisoners getting jobs to double.

Asylum

By March 2004, 75% of asylum applicants will be decided within 61 days. The number of removals will rise from 7,850 in 1999-2000 to 37,000 in 2003-4.

Education

Key stage 2: By 2002, 80% of children taking English to achieve level 4; 75% taking maths to achieve level 4. David Blunkett, the education secretary, has already promised to resign if these targets are not met. September 2000 figures showed 75% had reached level 4 in English, up 4% on the previous year, and 72% had reached maths level 4 - up 3%. Figures in 1996 were 52% English, 54% maths. New targets will be set for 2004. No local education authority should have an, as yet unfixed, percentage of pupils failing to reach the new target.

Key stage 3: By 2004, 80% should achieve level 5 or above in maths; 75% in English and IT; and 70% in science. Figures in September 2000 showed 65% reaching the level in maths (up 3%), 63% in English (down 1%) and 59% in science (up 4%). At least 65% of pupils in each education authority to reach this target in English and maths.

GCSE: By 2004, 92% of pupils to obtain five or more GCSEs at grades A to G. In the 500 worst performing schools, 75% should obtain five or more GCSEs at A to C. The current figure in these schools is 18%.

Truancy: A reduction of 10% by an unfixed date on the level achieved in 2002.

Adult literacy: By 2004, the number of adults who have literacy or numeracy problems should be cut by 750,000.

Childcare: A million extra places by March 2004.

Ofsted: Half of schools should have been inspected between April 2001 and March 2004; 500 schools to be monitored because they are lower attaining or in an education action zone. Thirty local education authorities to be inspected every year. Ten special reports, including secondary schools and the usefulness of targets for 14-year-olds.

Children and poverty

Child protection: By 2004, proportion of children aged 0-3 in 500 sure start areas who are re-registered on the child protection register within 12 months should fall by 20%. The measure is designed to see if emotional and social support is improving. No baseline has been established.

Smoking: The number of mothers who smoke during pregnancy in sure start areas to fall by 10%. Baseline to be established in December 2002.

Speech therapy: By 2004 number of children aged 0-3 with speech and language problems requiring specialist intervention will have fallen by 5 points. Baseline to be ready by December 2002. Target also to be prepared for the use of libraries by parents in sure start areas.

Unemployment: By 2004, fewer children aged 0-3 in sure start areas will live in households where no one is working.

Childminders: By 2002 a national register should be established and in the following year daycare providers to be inspected annually.

Welfare

Children: Number of children in low- income households to be reduced by a quarter by 2004. Households with incomes 60% or below the median to be covered. The level of compliance should be at least 75%.

Pensions: Reform second tier by 2004 so stakeholder pensions give more people access to good value funded second pensions. Access will be measured by surveys.

Two million carers and 2m disabled people with broken work records have for the first time started to build up a second-tier pension. Fourteen million low and moderate earners have started to build up a better second-tier pension than would be possible under the old state earnings-related pension. Low and moderate earners are defined as anyone earning between £3,432 and £21,600.

Benefits: By 2005 85% of claimants should have their benefits paid into bank accounts. The figure in October 2000 was 33%.

Fraud and error in income support and jobseekers allowance should be reduced by 25% by March 2004. The baseline is £1.38bn fraud and error in September 1998.

Care: By March 2004, anyone leaving care should be 75% as well off in terms of jobs and skills as other 19-year-olds in local authority areas.

Adoption: By 2004-5 the number of looked-after children adopted will be increased by 40% from the 2,700 in 1999-2000.

Acute care: By the end of 2004, the cost of acute care commissioned will have fallen to the level of the currently cheapest and best-performing trusts.

Jobs and the economy

Employment: Over the cycle, increase employment, defined as seasonally adjusted International Labour Organisation employment figure. A baseline will be set in spring 2001. The cycle is judged to have started in mid-1999.

The number of children in households with no one in work to be reduced. A baseline will be set in spring 2001 and progress monitored every six months

Over the three years the relative employment rates of disadvantaged areas and groups should be increased taking account of the economic cycle. The pledge is aimed at people with disabilities, lone parents, ethnic minorities and the over-50s, as well the 30 local authority districts with the poorest initial labour market position. The baseline is spring 2001.

The 30 districts are Hackney, Islington, Newham, Southwark, and Tower Hamlets in London; City of Glasgow, Dundee, East Ayrshire, North Lanarkshire, and West Dunbartonshire in Scotland; Blaenau Gwent, Caerphilly, Merthyr Tydfil, Neath, Pembrokeshire and Rhondda in Wales; Easington, Halton, Hartlepool, Hull, Knowsley, Liverpool, Manchester, Middlesbrough, Newcastle upon Tyne, Nottingham, Redcar and Cleveland, Salford, South Tyneside, Sunderland.

Environment and transport

Air quality: Improvement should be made against seven indicators between 2003 and 2008 with a baseline of 1998. By 2010 reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 12.5% from 1990 levels and move towards a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions by 2010. Emissions in 2000 were already 13.5% below 1990 levels. With existing policies, UK emissions will be 15% below 1990 levels in 2010 and emissions of CO2 8.5% lower.

Household waste: By 2004, 17% to be recycled or composted.

Energy efficiency: Improvement in energy efficiency by 2004 in 600,000 homes so no more than 10% of household income is spent on fuel.

Social housing: Between 2001 and 2004 the number of households living in social housing that does not meet decency standards should be cut by a third. Current estimate is that 29% of housing is not is in a decent state, with 43% in the 841 most deprived wards.

Roads and rail: The government has still not established targets or a system of measurement for the reduction of traffic congestion in cities and trunk roads.

Rail use should be increased by half by 2010, measured in passenger kilometres, at the same time as improvements in punctuality and reliability. Buses: Bus use should rise by 10% from the 1999 level of 3.736 million passenger journeys.

London Underground : Journey times should be cut, but no targets set.

Countryside: By 2005 open up public access. By 2010 bring into favourable condition 95% of nationally important wildlife sites compared with the current 60% of sites.

Housing: By 2008, 60% of new housing will be built on previously developed land or through conversion of existing buildings, up from 57% in 1998.

Local government: All local councils to have a new constitution by June 2002.

Fire and traffic deaths: Cut number of people killed or seriously injured in accidents by 40% compared with the average for 1994-8, when 47,656 were killed or injured.

By 2004-5 reduce by 15% the days lost from work-related ill-health or injury per 100,000 workers. As a result 3.5m fewer working days will be lost because of work-related ill-health or injury.

By March 2004 reduce by 10% the number of building fires from a base line of 1998-9. By March 2004 annual accidental fire- related deaths will fall to 303 from the current 379.

Culture

By March 2004, introduce at least 12 creative partnerships targeted on deprived areas.

Museums and galleries: By 2004 increase by a third the number of visits by children - a rise from 4.59m in 1999-2000 to 6m by 2003-4.

By 2004 raise by 500,000 the number of people experiencing the arts.

Industry

Business and enterprise: By 2004 narrow the UK productivity gap, measured as output per hour, with France, US, Germany and Japan.

Monitor annually the number of people considering going into business.

By 2010 increase enterprise in disadvantaged communities measured by VAT registrations.

By 2002 ensure lowest cost access to the internet in Europe.

Regions: By 2005 improve the economic performance of all regions measured by the trend in growth of each region's per capita GDP. Core indicator will be the regional variations on GDP.

Energy: By 2004 ensure that gas and electricity prices are in the lower half of the EU average.

By 2003 obtain 5% of UK electricity from renewable sources.

Drugs

Usage: Reduce the proportion of people aged 16-24 reporting the use of class A drugs in the last month by 25% by 2005, suggesting drug use will fall in the age group from 8.3% to 6.2%.

Offending: By 2005, reduce the level of offending twice or more a month among crack- or heroin-using offenders aged over 17 by 25% by 2005 and by 50% by 2008. No baseline exists, but estimates suggest the target will apply to 15% of all people arrested.

Treatment: Increase the participation of problem drug users in drug treatment programmes by 55% by 2004, by 66% by 2005, and by 100% by 2008. No baseline exists.

Reduce the availability of class A drugs by 25% by 2005 and by 50% by 2008.

Criminal courts: By 2004 reduce the time from charge to disposal of all defendants, first by dealing with 80% of youth court cases within their time targets. Guilty pleas to be dealt with in 70 days; not guilty pleas to be dealt with in 150 days; committals to be dealt with in 125 days.

In addition, halve the time taken from arrest to sentence for persistent young offenders from 142 days - the average for 1996 - to 71 days. This is one of the government's five key manifesto targets.

Civil courts: Between 2001-4 increase the enforceability of civil judgments through a 10% increase in the amount recovered per pound under execu ed warrants in the county courts.

Implement a new annual survey of satisfaction of users of the justice system.

Food

Health: Reduce food-borne illness by 20%.

Salmonella in UK-produced farm chickens should be halved by the end of 2004-5.

BSE should be reduced from 4,312 cases in 1997 to 650 by 2004, on track to 30 cases by 2006.

Europe: Deal on common agricultural policy to be complete by March 2004.

Fishing: Reduce fishing capacity by the end of 2001 by 20% from 1997 levels.

BSE: By 2004, identify the latest offspring of suspect BSE cases and exclude them within two days of the case being reported.

Department for International Development

By 2006, increase the proportion of EU development assistance going to poorest countries from 50% to 70% in 2006.

Ministry of Defence

Meet full manning requirements in March 2004 with RAF in 2001, navy in 2003 and army in 2005.

Set new tour-of-duty limits and increase airlift capacity, as well as establish joint rapid reaction force.

By 2005, ensure a minimum of 90% of rapidly available miliatry units at required state of readiness.

Foreign Office

Nuclear weapons: By March 2004, ensure 90% of the 38 remaining parties sign the comprehensive test ban treaty.

Environment: By 2004 negotiate global regulation of the oceans and an international commitment to combat climate change.

Crime: Each year sign four memorandums of understanding on drugs and crime. By 2002, implement action plans with EU accession countries.

fields.headline: Carling boots out Premier League deal
fields.trailText: Friday 6pm: Carling has abandoned talks about renewing its sponsorship of the Premier League, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Carling has abandoned talks about renewing its sponsorship of the Premier League, blaming "protracted" negotiations.

The shock decision ends an eight-year association between the two parties, with Carling's current four-year deal worth £36m.

Bass, the brewery that owns Carling, made the decision after a meeting of Premier League club chairmen yesterday failed to give a verdict on a renewed deal.

US beer giant Budweiser is now the hot favourite to clinch a deal.

"Bass has re-evaluated their options in light of the protracted negotiation process and believes its other marketing plans have a greater value for Carling," said Bass in a statement.

The company added that it could not let further indecision affect its plans for Carling, and it would now concentrate on "other initiatives".

fields.headline: Premier League denies deadlock over pay-per-view rights
fields.trailText: 5.15pm The Premier League is still seeking a buyer for pay-per-view soccer rights following talks with clubs, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The Premier League is still seeking a buyer for the pay-per-view rights to Premiership football matches, after a meeting of club chairmen failed to seal an agreement.

A Premier League spokesman denied there was a deadlock over the price, which is understood to be far below the £328m offered by cable company NTL in a deal abandoned last year.

"There is no hitch in negotiations, it is just work in progress and they are very complex talks. No single factor is holding things up, but we have to work out the best deal for the league and negotiations will take time," he said.

He added that yesterday's meeting broke up without a definitive decision because the league's broadcast team, led by Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore, had yet to make a recommendation to the chairmen.

"We are staggered by the amount of interest in the rights, and there are lots of possibilities and options," said the spokesman.

He added that the delay in finalising an agreement would not affect clubs' balance sheets, due to the massive windfall they will enjoy from the £1.2bn live broadcasting rights deal between BSkyB and ITV.

The winners of the pay-per-view licence will be able to select their match after BSkyB.

The bidders for PPV rights are known to include current favourite U>direct, NTL, BSkyB and ONdigital.

The Premier League is weighing up the options of giving the broadcast rights to a single bidder who will then sell them off to a four separate buyers; or hiving off the cable, internet, digital and satellite franchises to individual companies.

None of the companies involved in the bidding were available for comment, although U>direct is seen as the surprise favourite despite its heavily criticised coverage of England's World Cup qualifier with Finland in October.

fields.headline: Body Shop loses marketing chief
fields.trailText: Susan Falk has resigned as product and marketing director of Body Shop, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Susan Falk has resigned as product and marketing director of Body Shop, as the struggling retailer seeks to turn around its fortunes.

In a drastic move, chief executive Patrick Gournay will take on Ms Falk's job "for the foreseeable future".

He will add this role to his task of pulling the cosmetics company out of a sales slump.

A Body Shop spokeswoman refused to give specific reasons for Ms Falk's departure and would not say if Mr Gournay's dual role would be permanent.

"It is all part of our ongoing restructure," she said. "Mr Gournay is assuming responsibility for the role for the foreseeable future and that is all we can say."

The spokeswoman added Mr Gournay's burden would be lessened by the appointment of a logistics, sourcing and technical chief, who will start work soon.

Anita Roddick's company, which only sells ethically sound products, recently issued a profit warning after a predicted Christmas sales boom failed to materialise.

Ms Falk joined Body Shop in March 1999, having previously worked as chief executive of designer marketing company Diane Von Furstenberg LP.

She was on a basic annual salary of £350,000 but Body Shop would not confirm details of her pay-off.

webTitle: Met in race row as top officer suspended

fields.headline: Met in race row as top officer suspended
fields.standfirst:
Met suspends senior officer
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: One of Britain's most senior ethnic minority officers was suspended from duty yesterday over a host of allegations, including that he had attempted to pervert the course of justice.
fields.body:
One of Britain's most senior ethnic minority officers was suspended from duty yesterday over a host of allegations, including that he had attempted to pervert the course of justice.

Ali Dizaei, a superintendent with the Metropolitan police, was one of the force's most vocal internal critics and legal adviser to the National Black Police Association.

Last night a black member of an independent advisory group told the Guardian that he had refused a request from the Met last year to review the investigation because the allegations he was told of were trivial.

Scotland Yard said Mr Dizaei had been suspended pending an inquiry into "a significant number of counts of misconduct". In a statement the force said: "This follows information received relating to a range of alleged disciplinary and criminal issues that cover matters of dishonesty, attempting to pervert the course of justice, personal misconduct and integrity."

It refused to give more details but the investigation surrounding Mr Dizaei had run for more than six months under tight secrecy and involved intrusive surveillance. Only four people in the Met had known of the complex operation: the Met's commissioner Sir John Stevens, his deputy Ian Blair, assistant commissioner Mike Todd and the officer heading the investigation.

Mr Dizaei, who is based at Kensington and Chelsea station, was summoned yesterday morning to Cannon Row station. There Mr Todd handed him a 163 disciplinary notice detailing the allegations and ordered him to hand over his warrant card.

A Scotland Yard source said: "We are fully aware of Ali Dizaei's position and profile. We would not have taken the action we did today without reasonable grounds."

The investigation will be supervised by the police complaints authority.

Mr Dizaei, 37, whose father and grandfather were senior police chiefs in Iran, had been fast-tracked for promotion since joining the Met two years ago from the Thames Valley force. He was due to take a strategic command course in April which could have led to his reaching the rank of assistant chief constable or above.

Today Mr Dizaei was to have stood for the chairmanship of the National Black Police Association, who yesterday stressed their full support for their suspended member.

A senior Met source said: "This is the biggest challenge the force has faced in the post-Macpherson era."

Scotland Yard is still reeling from the Stephen Lawrence scandal, where institutional racism was found to have ham pered the investigation into the black teenager's murder.

Mindful of continued serious questions over its record on race, the force asked selected members of the Metropolitan police authority and its independent advisory group to review the investigation of Mr Dizaei to try to neutralise any claim that he had been victimised.

But Ben Bowling, a member of the independent advisory group and a law lecturer, said: "I was approached over six months ago to become involved in the investigation and declined.

"The officer mentioned some of the allegations to me and asked: 'Is this something to do with the culture, how people from his background behave, or something we need to look into more deeply?'

"The officer said there was concern that Mr Dizaei had been seen at a social gathering in a restaurant off duty in his police uniform, and this seemed unusual for a senior police officer.

"The kinds of allegations that were raised at that time by the police officer who approached me did not appear to me to be substantial enough to justify a covert investigation, including intrusive surveillance, of the nature that was being proposed."

Among black and Asian police officers, there was disbelief at the suspension.

Ravi Chand, chairman of the National Black Police Association, said: "He was very high profile in a number of areas and had always been seen as a person of integrity. If the Met gets this wrong, it will be disastrous. It will be a serious dent in their relations with the black community and black staff."

For the Met, the suspension of Mr Dizaei opens a potentially dangerous chapter, following the case of Gurpal Virdi. He was an Asian officer sacked for sending racist hatemail, to whom the Met had to pay £150,000 after it was found by an employment tribunal to have treated him in an unfair and discriminatory manner.

Last night Mr Virdi told the Guardian: "The tendency in the Met, if you speak out, is that you either get suspended or you get accused of some sort of crime.

"The Met can't investigate allegations against black or Asian officers properly. I have no faith in them."

Mr Dizaei was one of eight Asian and black officers of superintendent rank or above out of a total of 1,407 in England and Wales.

He was a controversial figure who last year accused the police service of the "ethnic cleansing" of black and Asian candidates for promotion through "culturally biased" testing procedures.

The Iranian-born law gradu ate recently criticised the home secretary, Jack Straw, for reinstating a PC who called a teenager a "black bastard".

Police were also investigating attacks on Mr Dizaei's car.

A senior officer who was a former colleague of Mr Dizaei's at the Thames Valley force said: "I liked him, but he made enemies because of his direct style.

"If he thought you were talking rubbish, he would tell you.

"He thinks differently to other police officers and is challenging to have around. He's bright but managerially he had a mixed reputation."

fields.headline: Hague's race claims demolished
fields.standfirst:
Home Office report says there is no evidence of a link between crime rates and decreasing use of stop and search by police

Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Home Office report says there is no evidence of a link between crime rates and decreasing use of stop and search by police.
fields.body:
Tory leader William Hague's claim that violent crime has risen because police have stopped using their stop and search powers against black people for fear of being branded racist was demolished by Home Office figures published yesterday.

The annual statistics on race in the criminal justice system show that the drop in the use of stop and search, particularly in London, has in fact been greatest for white suspects . Black people are still five times more likely to be stopped on the streets of the capital than white people.

The drop in stop and search incidents, from 1m to 800,000 a year, confirmed that the police had started to use their stop and search powers far less in the wake of Sir William Macpherson's report into the death of black teenager Stephen Lawrence. But they also showed that in the Metropolitan police the number of stop and searches involving white and Asian people fell by about 40% last year and 35% for black people.

For forces outside London the average fall in the use of stop and search was 14% for white people and Asians and 10% for black people.

But the report said that there was no evidence of a link between crime rates and the decreasing use of stop and search. In fact, the falling number of stop and searches had led to more arrests - 17% of those stopped were arrested last year compared to 13% for the previous year. At the same time a report from the inspectorate of constabulary showed that most forces had heeded Macpherson's "wake-up call" with a much greater commitment by police in tackling racism.

One indication was the 107% rise in the number of racist incidents recorded by the police in the past 18 months which reflected not an upsurge in racial violence, but a rise in their reporting and a greater willingness by police to treat such attacks as racially motivated.

The inspectorate, however, said there is still resistance by some officers, including managers, to come to terms with the recommendations of the Macpherson report and there was still complacency about the discriminatory use of stop and search powers.

The Home Office figures also showed that black people suffered discrimination as victims of crime and were more likely to become victims of a burglary, car crime or violence than their white or Asian neighbours. They were also more likely to be over-represented in prison as 18% of the male and 25% of the female prison population was black.

They were also less likely to be have been sent there by a black judge. There were only seven black QCs out of 1,074 in England and Wales and only one black circuit judge out of 568.

Among the most controversial figures published yesterday were the ethnic breakdown for arrests, particularly in the London area, which showed that black people, particularly those under 17, were more likely to be arrested for robbery and fraud and forgery offences while white people were more likely to be arrested for burglary, criminal damage and drugs offences.

The politically sensitive street robbery figures published yesterday confirmed 58% of those arrested for robbery by the Metropolitan police were black.

However, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said yesterday that while it was a fact in London that a higher proportion of black people committed street robberies it was not because they were black. "It is because of their social background, their educational attainment and factors of that kind," he said. He also pointed out that street robberies had risen sharply in the past year in areas such as central Newcastle upon Tyne, where they were almost all committed by white people.

Paul Cavadino of the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, also stressed that the figures showed that the type of crimes committed by young black men in London were largely committed by white young men in Lancashire but were used by some to support a racist agenda. He added: "The much publicised claim that political correctness has driven the police to cut stop and searches is not born out by the figures. Black people are still five times more likely to be stopped and searched than white people which hardly suggests that political correctness holds sway over the police. The fall in stop and search has nothing to do with the rise in street robbery. That is far more related to the spread of mobile phones."

fields.headline: Tories woo students on loans
fields.trailText: The Conservatives today wooed students with the promise of lower loan repayments and pledged golden goodbyes for universities to set them free of government interference
fields.body:
The Conservatives today wooed students with the promise of lower loan repayments and pledged golden goodbyes for universities to set them free of government interference

Outlining the partys higher education proposals fore the coming general election, education spokeswoman Theresa May said the next Conservative government would raise the earnings threshold at which graduates would have to start paying back student loans from £10,000 to £20,000. This would mean graduates going into careers like nursing and teaching would not start paying off their loans for many years.

A Tory government would sell off student loan debt to banks and financial institutions who would be able to charge real rates of interest (at present graduates repay only the money they borrow plus inflation) but it would introduce tax relief worth around £3,500 a year on repayments.

Universities would be endowed with the money raised from selling student loan debt - an estimated £1.6bn a year - and the sale of state assets like radio wavelengths.

Some commentators have estimated the value of the analogue spectrum, large parts of which will become free once television switches over to digital transmission, could be upwards of £50 billion. Universities UK, the sectors umbrella body which said it would study plans from all political parties, has estimated that the total cost of endowing all of Britains higher education institutions would be £80 billion.

But although the Conservatives say universities would be freed from state interference, they would not be free to set their own tuition fees - something vice-chancellors at elite institutions are debating.

Top-up fees are seen as a potential vote-loser by the main parties, although some of the top universities insist they need more money to maintain the quality of students education, and David Blunkett, the education secretary, has hinted the government might reconsider its opposition after the election.

The Conservatives' endowment fund for universities would be kick-started with a one-off payment of £3.5 billion of taxpayers money.

Over a fixed 10-year period, the average graduate would pay back £18,759 on a £10,000 loan, offset by £7,000 of tax relief, meaning the net repayment was £11,759. That compared with current average repayments of £12,811 over eight years, giving a saving of £1,052, say the Tories.

Higher education minister Baroness Blackstone declared: "The Tory plans to privatise universities are uncosted and unworkable - they will mean a huge hike in fees for students and parents without giving a penny more to the universities. In contrast, Labour will invest nearly £1 billion extra in higher education over the next three years, increasing the funding per student for the first time in well over a decade."

Mrs May dismissed her criticisms, saying: "Frankly, she needs to go to one of her own Government's numeracy classes. "We believe that this will be attractive to students because we have made a conscious effort to meet the concerns that they have been raising about top-up fees."

fields.headline: Nice advocates expensive drug
fields.trailText: Controversial new drugs to treat Alzheimer's disease should be more widely available on the NHS, a government body ruled today.
fields.body:
Controversial new drugs to treat Alzheimer's disease should be more widely available on the NHS, a government body ruled today.

People with mild to moderate forms of the disease - the most common form of dementia - should be given Aricept, Exelon or Reminyl, the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice) said.

But the ruling could cost the NHS up to £42m a year in prescriptions for the £1,000-a-year treatments.

Previously the expensive drugs have been denied to patients in some parts of the country on grounds of cost.

The government and campaigners welcomed the decision by Nice, which was set up two years ago to evaluate medicines and decide who should get them on NHS prescriptions.

The ruling affects England and Wales and although it is not legally binding, health authorities will have to justify their policy if they opt not to make the drugs available.

Around 400,000 people in England and Wales suffer from Alzheimer's disease, 250,000 of whom have a mild to moderate form. The Nice recommendations say the drugs should only be given following assessment in a specialist clinic and continuing appraisal of the patient to ensure the treatment is benefiting them.

The three drugs work by blocking an enzyme in the brain that destroys a chemical involved in memory.

A recent study carried out by researchers at London's Maudsley hospital found that half of health authorities were not providing funds for the drugs.

Health minister John Hutton said: "Nice's guidance on the clinical and cost effectiveness of these drugs should lead to them being widely available to all those who can benefit from them and will mark the end of an era of postcode prescribing in the treatment of Alzheimer's.

Harry Cayton, chief executive of the Alzheimer's Society, said: "We feel that the decision is sensible and realistic. Health authorities which do not currently fund these drugs should now be putting in place plans for the implementation of the Nice recommendation."

fields.headline: Reprieve for Letsbuyit.com
fields.standfirst: Jan 19: Showdown looms for Letsbuyit.com
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: Letsbuyit.com has been granted a stay of execution following a bankruptcy hearing in Amsterdam, reports Amy Vickers.
Jan 19: Showdown looms for Letsbuyit.com
fields.body:
Letsbuyit.com has been granted a stay of execution following a bankruptcy hearing in an Amsterdam court this afternoon.

Instead of being declared bankrupt as expected, the moribund online retailer has until Thursday January 25, 8am GMT to secure a rescue package of £2.7m. It then has to raise a further £19m within two weeks to stay in business.

Trustees of the cash-strapped internet retailer now have to report back to the court by Wednesday January 24 at 5pm GMT.

The latest saga suggests that Letsbuyit.com is close to securing some sort of lifeline and could just be haggling over a price with reported interested parties, CoShopper and Dealpartners.com.

The week's delay could give Letsbuyit some badly needed breathing space.

Letsbuyit was given protection from creditors at the end of December and the court appointed legal firm Van Doom as trustees. But this week the trustees, opposed by Letsbuyit's management, filed for bankruptcy.

webTitle: Style: Are tennis stars the new supermodels?

fields.headline: Smash hits
fields.standfirst: Are tennis stars the new supermodels?  Charlie Porter on a revolution in centre court fashion
fields.trailText: Are tennis stars the new supermodels? Charlie Porter on a revolution in centre court fashion
fields.body:
" I don't know if it's one of her creations or what," said Martina Hingis this week, after seeing rival Venus Williams struggle to keep herself inside a bi-level tennis top at the Australian Open. "She just got this deal with Reebok, so they had to come up with something new. I don't know if I'd be able to wear something like that."

While passing sentence, Hingis sported an outfit by Adidas with one sleeve shorter than the other because, she believes, it improves her racket control. Williams was obviously listening because a day later, some quick stitching had covered over her gaping cleavage.

This once sensible, sober sport is gearing up to be the new fashion, but even Galliano wouldn't come up with a collection theme as loopy as all this. Clearly, Cliff Richard had better keep his eyes firmly on the net.

The dress sense of the players has become the topic of the tournament. "I get to meet the designers at Nike a few times a year," says Mary Pierce, who is seen as one of the most stylish competitors - in Melbourne, the optical prints on her pink Nike top echoed Hussein Chalayan's final collection for Tse New York. "We talk about different style and designs, cuts and colours and things like that. I think it's great to see everybody really getting into what they're wearing. It's a lot of fun."

Indeed, fashion insiders heading to Paris tomorrow for the start of the haute couture season wish the shows were as entertaining as the garish world of the grand slams. In the ateliers, where style slip-ups are rare, they long for some of the fashion no-nos and bitchy skulduggery that are currently fighting their way through to championship point.

Female tennis players have been sexualised ever since that Athena poster, as parodied by Kylie Minogue on the cover of GQ last year. And only recently have their outfits been liberated from the Benny Hill fantasy of white vests and pleated knicker-flashing skirts, allowing them to play with colours, styles and shapes to become less overtly sexual and more assertively individual. But because of the functions their clothing needs to fulfil, their looks are never quite right. It's like fashion, only more so - more outlandish, more catty and more style-over-sense than any maven in her open-toed Manolos on a January morning.

In the parallel universe of the courts, we can see all of this season's trends warped out into another dimension. Venus's strap-over-strap tank, a little like a flyover in Birmingham's Spaghetti Junction, is very similar to the bandage dresses shown by Helmut Lang for spring/summer. Anna Kournikova, radiating neon yellow, could have come from Luella's 80s pop club, and the asymmetry of Hingis's lopsided sleeves has the messed-up air of Jean Paul Gaultier's much praised tough-chic look. On this trend parade, it is amazing there are no coned heels or tight-boned corsets on display, and a missed opportunity that none of the players is doing old-school white with Balenciaga's ripped prom dresses or Gucci's suited vamp.

The sporting stars of Sydney 2000 are replacing Goldie Hawn's daughter (Kate Hudson) and Brazilian models (Gisele, Ana Claudia) on the covers of glossy magazines. The Williams sisters are the stars of January's American Elle, dressed in Calvin Klein. Inside, Venus is leaping around in a Galliano tea-dress while Serena slouches in some Chloe towelling. On American Vogue, sprinter Marion Jones is the covergirl, also shrouding her muscles in Calvin Klein. Both magazines seem to signal that, with the current lapse in big-name stars, athletes may become the fashion world's next talent pool to tap.

As the outfits increasingly steal the limelight, sportswear labels attempt to out-shock each other. "I think tennis clothing companies are trying to get more bold in what they are getting the girls to wear," says defending Australian Open champion Lindsay Davenport, who is wearing the same Nike print as Pierce, but on her skirt rather than as a top. "Some maybe go extreme to get some recognition for the company." Indeed, Melbourne is acting as a handy catwalk substitute for the label's spring/ summer ranges, providing massive worldwide publicity for clothing that will go on sale over the coming month.

But some of those playing, like Davenport, are keeping a certain distance from the fashion circus. Anyone would think they were at the tournament just to excel at their sport. "When I went to Nike, they told me the outfit was something really eye-catching," she says vaguely. "I think it's after the Pucci design, but I don't have anything to do with it. I just wear it."

fields.headline: Overheard
fields.standfirst: "A Billie"
fields.trailText: "A Billie"
fields.body:
Coined in honour of Chris Evans' new girlfriend, teen pop star Billie Piper.

To be totally blind to the ugly truth of someone or something, or to behave in a completely inexplicable manner. For example: "Don't be such a Billie! That dress is horrible and no one in their right mind would wear it!"

fields.headline: Channel 4 in Kumbh Mela controversy
fields.trailText: 3.45pm:Indian officials have banned filming at the Kumbh Mela bathing site, writes Anna Vetticad.
fields.body:
Filming at the bathing site during the Kumbh Mela, India's largest religious festival, has been banned.

The move follows allegations that photographs and TV images of holy men, or sadhus, running naked into the river Ganga, have offended Hindus in India and the UK.

Channel 4 has found itself at the centre of the controversy. Its film crew is broadcasting daily spot reports from the venue in Allahabad, in addition to half-hour programmes on Sundays.

Today, Channel 4 representatives showed tapes to a panel of Indian officials in a bid to ensure they were not banned from the event, which concludes in February.

However Channel 4 is not the only media organisation to have caused offence.

The entire media coverage, including that of Indian press, has been condemned by Indian officials.

"The ban on bathing has nothing to do with us," said a Channel 4 spokesperson.

"It covers the entire press. We have shown our tapes to the Indian officials and they've deemed our coverage to be completely okay."

fields.headline: Which? sued by Dyson
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Electrical consumer goods whizz James Dyson is to sue the Consumers Association magazine Which?, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Electrical consumer goods whizz James Dyson is to sue the Consumers Association magazine Which? after it claimed his washing machine was not worth its £1,200 price tag.

Mr Dyson has instructed his lawyers to begin legal proceedings against the magazine, which in its January edition reported that the Contrarotator was no better than a rival machine for half the price.

A Consumers Association spokeswoman stood by the findings of Which?, and said that Mr Dyson was over-reacting.

Mr Dyson has accused Which? of rushing the results of the report out too soon, and claimed that the magazine had not showed him the reports first.

fields.headline: Belgium faces asylum seeker crisis
fields.standfirst: Brussels is struggling to deal with a massive influx of refugees, as Europe editor Ian Black explains
fields.trailText: Brussels is struggling to deal with a massive influx of refugees, as Europe editor Ian Black explains.
fields.body:
Brussels has been bitterly cold for the last few days, so the people queuing patiently outside an office near the Gare du Nord were grateful when the army put up a couple of big tents where they could wait before doing battle with Belgium's notoriously slow-moving bureaucracy.

Since early January, hundreds of foreigners - from Armenia, Iran, Russia and elsewhere in the former Soviet Union - have been arriving early every morning at the Aliens Office on Boulevard Simon Bolivar to meet a deadline imposed by the government for imposing stricter terms on benefits for refugees.

The result is that asylum claims have tripled from the usual number for this time of year despite the temporary re-introduction of border controls - normally removed under the EU's Schengen lesgislation.

Outside Belgium, this story has attracted little attention.

But it is another vivid illustration of a massive, Europe-wide phenomenon of people from poor or oppressive societies across the globe seeking a better life in the heart of a wealthy and democratic continent.

Belgium, with a population of around 10m, received over 40,000 asylum applications in the last year alone, the highest number per capita of any of the EU's 15 countries.

Europe-wide, numbers will certainly get bigger - probably much bigger - when the union starts taking in new members in a few years time and the frontier between Poland and Russia, and between Poland and Ukraine, form its external border.

Existing problems such as people-trafficking, drug smuggling and other forms of organised crime are also expected to become even more difficult.

Last year's horrific incident, when 58 Chinese suffocated to death in a Dover-bound lorry that crossed the channel from the Belgian port of Zeebrugge, tragically illustrated the hazards that open borders and lax controls can bring.

The queues on the Boulevard Simon Bolivar are because of the government's decision to end cash benefits for asylumseekers waiting for their cases to be decided.

Aid for a single adult of 20,000 Belgian francs (£320) a month will be replaced by assistance in the form of food, housing and other social services.

Volunteers from Medecins Sans Frontieres and the Red Cross have been on hand at the Aliens Office dispensing welcome cups of hot soup and coffee to keep off the winter chill.

But an unseemly row broke out when the Brussels city council ordered the tents removed. Two days later, they were put back up again - but this time in the office's inner courtyard.

Just after Christmas, as the deadline for registraton loomed, the asylum issue received an unusual burst of publicity, when 19 statues of the baby Jesus were removed from mangers across the country after a spectacular mass "kidnapping" designed to dramatise the plight of latter-day refugees.

"How would Jesus, fleeing persecution in his homeland, have been received in Belgium in the year 2000?" asked the activists behind the stunt in a message posted on their website.

"These peaceful 'kidnappings' are the work of citizens  who want to alert public opinion to the reception in Belgium of refugees from around the world."

The statues were later returned, unharmed, to their mangers.

Belgium officials repeatedly complain that the number of illegal aliens entering the country has become unmanageable and say they want EU-wide policies to share the burden.

Not suprisingly, this will be a high priority for prime minister Guy Verhofstadt when he takes over the EU's rotating presidency in July.

In recent years, there have been a series of widely reported incidents, including the forced deportation of Slovak gypsies and the death of a Nigerian woman, while being restrained by police during deportation back to Africa.

"Sans-papiers" - scores of thousands of foreigners without ID papers - are part of the landscape. Begging is rife.

Unsurprisingly, extremist groups like the Flanders-based Vlaams Blok have turned immigration into a hot political issue - just as it has become in Austria, Italy and France.

Across the EU, nearly 250,000 people applied for asylum last year, though many countries have taken steps to stem the influx.

Most are eventually rejected because governments say the refugees are looking for better economic conditions, not fleeing genuine political persecution.

Critics of Belgian policies complained this week that the federal ministries of the interior and social affairs had abandoned responsibility to voluntary organisations, while refugee reception centres failed to coordinate the despatch of asylum seekers to government offices, thus leaving them - literally - out in the cold.

"Foreign TV stations were on hand to show the world how Belgium receives - or rather mistreats - asylum seekers," observed Le Soir commentator Martine Vandemeulbroucke.

"But seeing so much chaos and incompetence, one has the painful impression that that is exactly what was intended."

webTitle: Dunn to replace Pollard at Express

fields.headline: Dunn to replace Pollard as Express leader writer
fields.standfirst:
Jan 11: Express may sue former columnist
Jan 8: Stephen Pollard loses job at Times
Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Sunday Express deputy editor Paul Dunn is being lined up to take over the job of chief leader writer on the Express, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 11: Express may sue former columnist
Jan 8: Pollard loses job at Times
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Sunday Express deputy editor Paul Dunn is being lined up to take over what could be described as the most poisoned chalice in Fleet Street, the job of chief leader writer on the Express.

Mr Dunn was unwilling to give specific details about the deal, but it is believed he will take on the role of commentary and chief leader writer.

But he said he would relish the role of taking the job vacated by Mr Pollard, who lost his job on the Times after he concealed a rude message to the new Express newspapers boss Richard Desmond in a leader.

He joined the Sunday Express two years ago from the Observer, where he was home editor.

fields.headline: Mail on Sunday's Ironside joins ASA Council
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Mike Ironside, managing director of the Mail on Sunday, has been appointed a member of the ASA Council, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Mike Ironside, managing director of the Mail on Sunday, has been appointed as a member of the Advertising Standards Authority Council.

Mr Ironside replaces Len Sanderson, managing director of sales at the Telegraph Group, who is stepping down after six years on the council.

The ASA Council is made up of 12 people who decide whether an ad breaks the ASA's codes. A third of the council is made up of industry members.

Outgoing chairman Lord Rodgers, who appointed Mr Ironside, said: "We are fortunate to have been able to appoint someone of Mike Ironside's standing and knowledge.

"He will bring hands-on experience of advertising and newspaper publishing to the ASA Council," he added.

Mr Ironside is a former advertising executive who has worked for several major ad agencies including FCB and TBWA.

He said: "I am delighted to be joining the ASA Council and look forward to playing my part in ensuring that the very high standard of advertising is maintained."

webTitle: IPC to launch pilot astrology weekly

fields.headline: IPC to launch pilot astrology weekly
fields.trailText: 3pm: IPC is testing its readers' hunger for astrology and celebrity with a pilot astrology weekly called It's Fate, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC is testing its readers' hunger for astrology and celebrity with a pilot astrology weekly called It's Fate.

The magazine will be launched from the IPC Connect stable - which publishes the popular women's magazine Chat and spin-offs from the Chat brand including Chat Juicy Fiction and Chat Crime and Passion.

It's Fate will cover the usual popular weekly themes of true life, celebrity, sex, relationships and career advice, but promises to bring an astrological overview.

The editorial will be overseen by a "panel of young and sexy psychics", and will be edited by Keith Kendrick.

Staff confirmed that the initial launch will be a pilot, but IPC will consider launching it as an ongoing project if it is successful.

Mr Kendrick said: "Every young woman I've met wants to know whether she's going to find a lover, keep a lover or lose a lover. They want to know if Mr Right is waiting round the corner, or if they're sharing their bed with Mr Wrong."

The news comes in the week after it was announced that the astrologer Jonathan Cainer has defected from the Express to the Mirror.
