webTitle: British couple vow to fight twins' removal

fields.headline: British couple vow to fight twins' removal
fields.trailText: The British couple at the centre of a transatlantic internet adoption scandal, today vowed to fight the decision by social services to take the twin babies from their care.
fields.body:
The British couple at the centre of a transatlantic internet adoption scandal, today vowed to fight the decision by social services to take the twin babies from their care.

Alan and Judith Kilshaw told ITV's GMTV how they were already missing the twin sisters, removed yesterday evening by police and social workers who swooped on the North Wales hotel where the family were staying.

The twins, Kimberley and Belinda, were taken from the Beaufort Park Hotel, near Mold, after an emergency protection order was served on the couple. The sleeping sisters, swaddled in blankets and wearing matching pink fleece hats, were carried out of the hotel in baby carriers and bundled into a waiting car.

The fate of the twins will be considered by the High Court within the next nine days, according to Flintshire County Council's chief executive, Philip McGreevy. In a statement, Mr McGreevy said: "The twins are safe and well in the council's care."

He called last night's action a "careful, considered and proportionate response" to the situation and said that the council had obtained the protection order from a magistrate of the Flintshire Family Proceedings Court. Mr McGreevy added: "Further legal steps are now in hand which will place all of the issues, including the complex legal, practical and international dimensions, before the High Court prior to the expiry of the emergency protection order on January 26." The council refused to comment further on the case.

Ms Kilshaw, 47, whose screams could be heard as the children were taken away, said that she had no chance to say goodbye to the babies as the authorities "crept in, in the dead of the night, and snatched them. This has ripped my family apart," she said.

Her solicitor husband Alan added: "We don't feel too good this morning, but, having said that, we feel determined to fight on with this case. I think, at the end of the day, right will prevail."

"I think the social services had a bloody cheek," Ms Kilshaw added. "They came in with no clothes and no dummies for them."

Ms Kilshaw said that she was "personally hurt" by the comments of friends and neighbours, and told how she had grown close to the twins since she and her husband had brought them to Britain on a visitors' visa.

"I couldn't have given them more if I'd given birth to them myself. I am public enemy number one and Alan public enemy number two, but people haven't seen us together as a family.

"They are trying to say we are not right people."

Meanwhile, Californian couple Richard and Vickie Allen, who claim they were duped into handing back the twins after caring for them for two months and paying an adoption broker a reported £4,000, repeated their offer of "a good home" for the twins.

Ms Allen said, from California, that she sympathised with the Kilshaws after last night's events, adding: "My heart goes out to them and it does make me upset.

"I've got nothing against them and I can understand the pain they must be feeling having the children taken away from them."

The twins' natural mother, Tranda Wecker, 28, said yesterday that she wanted the children back.

In another move, a senior Arkansas adoption judge told BBC Radio 5 Live that there was likely to be legal action in the state courts over the case, which could render the twins' adoption invalid.

Judge Ellen Brantley, who is believed to have been in contact with social workers in Wales to provide them with details of the case, also denounced the selling of babies as "disgusting", and described many of those involved in the current case as "villains".

"The big issue is that the children, if they are to be adopted, are adopted by parents who can give them a loving and stable home," she said. "That ought to be regardless of the monetary amounts that anybody is able to provide," she said.

Many Americans choose to adopt under the Arkansas legal system, because of its relaxed rules, which allow adoption within just 10 days.

But parents who give children up for adoption must live in Arkansas for at least 30 days, and there have been suggestions that the twins' biological mother might not have fulfilled the residence qualification, invalidating the adoption.

The Californian baby broker at the heart of the scandal, Tina Johnson, meanwhile insisted that her Caring Heart agency was a legitimate "adoption facilitation" business.

Her spokeswoman, Jennifer Coburn, told a news conference: "Caring Heart does not sell, trade or engage in the trafficking of babies. This is illegal and is not what is happening in this case."

The agency specialised in African-American and mixed-race children, and charged a non-refundable fee for Ms Johnson's expenses and time, she said. She did not disclose the amount.

fields.headline: Police to get increased powers
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Measures to increase police powers against crime - from yobbish behaviour to rape and murder - are at the heart of a new law and order bill published by the government today.
fields.body:
Measures to increase police powers against crime - from yobbish behaviour to rape and murder - are at the heart of a new law and order bill published by the government today.

Unveiling the Criminal Justice and Police bill, home secretary Jack Straw announced new police powers to deal with drink-related disorder, plans for the increased use of fingerprints and DNA, and proposals to improve the training and organisation of the police service.

Under the draft legislation, fixed penalties will be introduced for a wide range of offences such as being drunk and disorderly, making hoax 999 calls and damaging property. The plans, a version of the instant fines first suggested by prime minister Tony Blair, would enable police to issue on-the-spot fixed penalties for offences including being drunk and disorderly and buying alcohol for under 18s. The level of fines was not specified.

Other measures will require bar staff to request proof of age from drinkers. It will also be an offence for bar staff, as well as the licensee, to sell alcohol to drunk or disorderly customers

The bill also provides scope for massive growth in the national DNA database, allowing lawfully taken DNA samples to be held indefinitely, even if acquired from volunteers during mass testing sometimes conducted during murder investigations.

The bill controversially proposes raising the age for child curfews from 10 to 15, following Mr Straw's admission he was "in error" when he introduced the original law imposing curfews on misbehaving children under 10.

Not a single order has been issued since the legislation was introduced in 1998. Children's groups have called on the government to scrap the curfew measure altogether, claiming it will only serve to alienate young people.

The bill would also allow the confiscation of drug traffickers' passports and make it easier to arrest hit-and-run drivers, kerb-crawlers and those trying to import child pornography.

New legislation aimed at animal rights extremists, announced by the home secretary on Wednesday, are not included in the bill but are likely to be introduced at the amendments stage.

Publishing the bill in parliament today, Mr Straw said: "These measures are designed to help tackle crime and disorder by ensuring that the police service has the powers, training and organisation it needs to perform effectively and tackle criminal behaviour.

"Drunken yobs cause misery to individuals and blight communities across the country every weekend, showing no regard for the rights of others to live in peace. It is essential that police officers have adequate powers to deal with these thugs."

The bill formed the centrepiece of government initiatives to target law and order, prioritised in December's Queen's Speech outlining the legislative schedule for the year.

The Criminal Justice and Police bill - key points:

 Extra police powers to tackle disorder in public places, including:
- Issuing fixed penalty notices
- Closing licensed premises where disorder is occurring
- Closing unlicensed drinking clubs
- Banning drinking in certain public places

 Child curfew scheme extension, to include children of up to 15 years old

 Modernisation of police powers and procedures, including:
- "Adequate" powers to remove material from premises for examination
- Allowing the police to arrest kerb crawlers and hit and run drivers
- Enabling the retention and use of all lawfully taken fingerprints, samples and DNA profiles, including those given voluntarily for elimination purposes, with written consent
- Pilot schemes to videotape suspects' interviews

 Confiscation of drug traffickers' passports

 Improved police training and organisation, including:
- Setting up a new central police college, a mandatory curriculum and qualifications
- Reintroducing the ranks of deputy chief constable and chief superintendent
- Removing the right to silence in police disciplinary hearings
- Improving the operations of police authorities

webTitle: Ad market sees AltaVista shed workers

fields.headline: Ad market sees AltaVista shed workers
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: US internet search company AltaVista said today that it would lay off 200 employees, or about a quarter of its staff, in reaction to a persistently weak online advertising market.
fields.body:
US internet search company AltaVista said today that it would lay off 200 employees, or about a quarter of its staff, in reaction to a persistently weak online advertising market.

This is the third round of job cuts at the company in two years. In September, AltaVista laid off 225 employees after cutting 40 jobs earlier in the year.

"AltaVista has not been immune to the softness in advertising," Peter Mills, an executive adviser to the company said in a statement.

Most of the job losses will happen at company headquarters in Palo Alto, California, with few employees in Europe affected. The move leaves AltaVista with approximately 600 employees worldwide.

Despite the popularity of its internet search engine, AltaVista has been dogged by trouble over the last year. Last week, the company pulled its IPO plans for the third time, and the former chief executive, Rod Schrock, left the company in October, saying it had suffered from neglect and under-investment.

AltaVista, majority owned by Internet development company CMGI Inc - is increasingly focusing on its search software business - which licenses its technology to other companies.

But the company said that the consumer search business remains a core part of its operation.

Earlier this week, AltaVista UK was in court defending itself against a £215m breach-of-contract claim still pending from its abandoned plans to provide an unmetered internet access service last summer.

webTitle: Two Way TV cuts staff quarter

fields.headline: Two Way TV cuts staff by quarter
fields.trailText: 2pm: Interactive games firm Two Way TV is to axes staff, blaming the delayed roll-out of enhanced TV technology, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Two Way TV, the interactive TV games company in which NTL has a 48% stake, has taken a reluctant decision to slash its workforce by a quarter.

The move is being attributed to pessimistic market conditions. "Like many companies we want to conserve cash during this tough market," said Simon Cornwell,Two Way TV chief executive.

A month-long consultation period has began with staff across the board being offered redundancy, unpaid sabbaticals, part-time and freelance work.

While the situation looks bleak, it is not as bad as expected given initial reports that suggested a third of staff might be cut. Some 50 jobs are in the firing line.

Marketing plans are also being scaled back, despite the imminent appointment of a new ad agency. Delaney Lund Knox Warren, BDS Beechwood and 23Red have already made the shortlist to create what will now be a modest campaign for the launch of enhanced TV services.

Mr Cornwell was keen to stress that these are just cost-cutting measures until Two Way TV is able to launch a wider range of enhanced TV services in around six months time.

"Although reducing staff numbers is deeply regrettable, it is very much business as usual as we continue to move towards the roll-out of new games and services on all the key digital distribution networks," he said.

"We will be launching our ONdigital games channel in the spring and are still on course for the launch of our enhanced television programme services (ETV) later in the year."

Two Way TV, which operates games channels on Telewest and NTL's interactive TV services, has been held back from launching its flagship enhanced TV products because of cable's delayed roll-out of an enhanced TV technology platform.

The drastic measures reflect the major restructure currently going on at major shareholder NTL, which cut 1,300 jobs at the end of last year.

NTL has recently appointed Stephen Carter, its managing director, as non-executive director of Two Way TV to develop NTL's interests within the interactive games company.

The cutbacks at Two Way TV come despite a recent $7m loan from technology firm Liberate.

fields.headline: Adoption
fields.standfirst: The harrowing journey of Belinda and Kimberley, finally winding up in council care, has gripped the nation's attention. How could the six-month-old twins have been traded like playthings? Derek Brown explains.
fields.trailText: The harrowing journey of Belinda and Kimberley, finally winding up in council care, has gripped the nation's attention. How could the six-month-old twins have been traded like playthings? Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
How were the babies 'bought'?
Alan and Judith Kilshaw, from Buckley in north Wales, wanted to complete their family by adopting a baby daughter. They found what they wanted through the internet: babies Belinda and Kimberley were being offered for adoption by Tina Johnson of the Caring Hearts [sic] agency in California. They paid £8200 in fees and whisked the little girls off to Arkansas for a 'quickie' adoption.

What went wrong?
The babies had already been 'bought' for some £4000 by California couple Vickie and Richard Allen, who say they were tricked into parting with them by their natural mother, Trenda Wecker, who then handed them over to the Kilshaws.

Any further complications?
Ms Trecker now says she wants her babies back. And a third couple, Amy and Eddie White, has emerged to say that they too were offered the twins, for £5800.

Why are the little girls in care?
Flintshire social services waded through the herd of reporters and photographers covering the story, to pluck the babies from the Mold hotel, where the Kilshaws were staying. They say they are making "further assessments of the well-being of the children".

What reaction has there been to the unsavoury saga?
Revulsion. Fury. Disgust. And that's just the government. The prime minister and home secretary have promised to step up the pace of adoption law reform, and tighten the rules for couples adopting abroad. There have also been predictable calls for more regulation of the internet, as if that had anything to do with it.

Hold on, wasn't it the internet that made the whole thing possible?
No, it was simply the medium through which the Kilshaws contacted the adoption agency. They might have done so in any number of other ways.

How difficult is it to adopt a child in this country?
Prospective parents have to be exhaustively vetted for suitability. The process can take six months, and involves detailed social services assessment, police and medical references.

What are the rules for adopting a foreign child?
The government would prefer all such adoptions to be from 'designated' countries with laws compatible with the UK's. But there are lots of grey areas, and no defined law against 'private' (ie paid-for) adoptions.

Is adoption high on the government's list of priorities?
Judging from the Department of Health's adoption web pages, it's the tops. Tony Blair is particularly keen on reform. He commissioned a review of adoption in February last year. A report was published in July. Now the prime minister is committed to new adoption legislation, a white paper, a task force, a national adoption register, and national adoption standards.

fields.headline: Ghastly man
fields.standfirst: Why revere Auberon Waugh? He was a reactionary fogey whose sneers damaged this country
fields.trailText: Why revere Auberon Waugh? He was a reactionary fogey whose sneers damaged this country
fields.body:
De mortuis nil nisi bonum is a good enough maxim if it means you should not stamp on the libel-free grave of someone you never dared rubbish face to face in life. But I did. And he retaliated - often. Auberon Waugh's death has been eulogised at phenomenal length, not least in two pages in this organ, (five pieces in the Telegraph.) He was a "genius" who "will surely be seen as the Dean Swift of our day," writes his old friend AN Wilson. Someone else cites Dr Johnson, forsooth. "The greatest journalist of my generation," writes Lord Gowrie cringingly of the man who hounded him mercilessly for years. "All prigs and puritans will sleep easier in their beds tonight," opines the Telegraph leader.

In the Guardian obituary Geoffrey Wheatcroft says Waugh's foes were "baffled by the boyish camaraderie of old Fleet Street, not to say its tradition of ecumenical friendship". And baffled we remain. I remember it well - the old world of El Vino's wine bar in Fleet Street where leftwing lambs and rightwing lions downed their differences in bottles of champagne - (no women allowed at the bar). It was all just a game, old boy, at the end of the day once the copy had been filed. What did it matter what you wrote or who you wrote it for so long as it was witty, clever and preferably wicked? Everyone in Grub Street had their saleable trade mark, right or left, but was anything really serious?

The world of Auberon Waugh is a coterie of reactionary fogeys centred on the Spectator and the Telegraph who affect an imaginary style of 1930's gent - Evelyn was the icon. Battered brown trilby, chalk-stripes, sit-up-and-beg bike with a basket full of books from the London Library are the accoutrements. The mind-set is all Evelyn Waugh too - the smells and bells of aristocracy and old Catholicism (recusant priest-holers only - God forbid any happy clappy stuff). Effete, drunken, snobbish, sneering, racist and sexist, they spit poison at anyone vulgar enough to want to improve anything at all. Liberalism is the archenemy - Shirley Williams was Waugh's bete noire . While do-nothing conservatism is their mode, they enjoy extremism of any complexion and excoriate the dreary toil of incremental improvement - bor-ring, sin-cere and social workerish. The worst thing is "doing good". Their snobbery is of a vulgarity beyond belief - yahoos capering in genteel suits.

Their language is as self-consciously class-identifying as their voices - Waugh sounded like something out of the BBC sound archives. Their words cling to the prep school and nursery of the 1940s and 50s - hence that bizarre conservative epithet "nanny" or "nanny state" applied to the Labour women they especially loathe, as if every voter had a starched Norland nurse lurking in their mental attic. Many of the obits refer to Waugh's boast that he was "a practitioner of the vituperative arts", but the limited vocabulary of this little tribe of scribes is reduced to those blasé upper-class generalities - ghastly, boring, silly, disgusting, odious, repulsive, bogus, hideous or goody-goody - house style passim in most of the Spectator and Telegraph, lazy in-words of an exclusive clique.

We might let Auberon Waugh rest in peace were it not for the mighty damage his clan has done to British political life, journalism and discourse in the postwar years. They have perpetuated the myth of the superior cultured English gent as an archetype. Although Waugh's loathing of American culture made him uniquely amongst this bunch a pro-European, (he loved to be a "maverick"), this coterie has lead the spirit of anti-Europeanism that pervades Tory party and country. Christopher Booker, Richard Ingrams and the rest posit a brave little England of crusty country-living upper-class eccentrics versus the dread (another of their words) bureaucracy of Brussels. It's the old world charm of Whisky Galore mischief-making and John Buchan plucky patriots against the humourless foreign swine. They have contributed to a nation afraid of change or modernity, peddling false, sentimental tradition and an upper-class yesterday unavailable to virtually everyone else. While pretending to debunk cant, they demolish every attempt at reform. "Political correctness" is the tired, lazy little label attached to all change for the better. Oh, how naughty of Waugh to compare a wine to "a bunch of dead chrysanthemums on the grave of a still-born West Indian baby". Swiftian? Knickers.

As a style of journalism, theirs is empty and destructive. All that matters is a joke or two. Swift was serious, used humour as a deadly weapon of conviction and risked jail for his opinions. It was not, as he pretended, a badge of some kind of honesty but quite the contrary, an idle unwillingness to engage with any politician's attempt to make life better for anyone else - least of all "the workers" he used to mock in order to shock. The pens of these lofty jeerers drip with universal indiscriminate malice over good and bad people alike, with as much interest in the difference as Jonathan Aitken's "sword of truth".

Don't imagine that the breed is dying out. Boris Johnson, editor of the Spectator, is only 36, a writer of just this humourous stamp, with mannerisms to match. The fact that the obits proclaim Waugh "the most courteous and loveable of friends", or that Boris Johnson is also a charming and affable fellow is neither here nor there: by their printed words we shall judge them (and be judged). Johnson and I are currently arguing weekly on television.* After our first encounter he pressed me to write a piece for the Spectator about why the right is so nasty and why liberals are on the whole nicer - his idea and something he disarmingly thought true: good medicine for his complacent readership, he said. I doubt he wanted them converted, just aroused.

It was tempting but I refused. He grew indignant. Why not? I explained it concerned exactly that "ecumenical tradition" in old Fleet Street which Wheatcroft so extolled yesterday. Why would I want to write in a rightwing magazine graced by Bruce Anderson as political commentator, the unspeakable Taki and a fusillade of writers of the ilk described above? Politics in the Spectator, I said, is just an Eton Wall Game between left/right tribes. Joining in the mud-slinging fun only adds to the general idea that the Spectator is right - it's all a jolly jape and none of it really matters. Consider William Hague - tax cuts for the rich, public service cuts for the rest, pulling out of Europe, stuffing yet more into prison, installing Bush's missile system. Where's the joke? I never understood why Michael Foot and AJP Taylor wrote for Beaverbrook as his trophy lefties, satisfying the right's perennial wish to think that in the end there is no real difference between civilised Oxbridge-educated people sitting cosily around the same dinner table.

"The greatest journalist of my generation," writes Lord Gowrie cringingly of the man who hounded him mercilessly for years. "All prigs and puritans will sleep easier in their beds tonight," opines the Telegraph leader. It was all just a game, old boy, at the end of the day once the copy had been filed. What did it matter what you wrote or who you wrote it for so long as it was witty, clever and preferably wicked? webTitle: Film critic Peter Bradshaw on starring in a sitcom

fields.headline: 'You cannot be serious'
fields.standfirst: He hasn't acted in 10 years and makes his living as this paper's film critic. So what on earth made  Peter Bradshaw agree to co-write a sitcom - and star in it?
fields.trailText: He hasn't acted in 10 years and makes his living as this paper's film critic. So what on earth made Peter Bradshaw agree to co-write a sitcom - and star in it?
fields.body:
Sometime just before Christmas, I happened to be hanging about outside a Soho screening room talking to Cosmo Landesman, my opposite number on the Sunday Times, and he introduced me to Gilbert Adair, the distinguished film critic and scholar. Just as I was shyly congratulating Mr Adair on his Penguin collection, Movies, and hoping perhaps to inaugurate an elegant discussion of film theory, Cosmo broke in and guffawed "D'ya hear what Bradshaw is doing? D'ya hear about his sitcom ?"

In response to Mr Adair's expression of polite inquiry, I explained that I had written a sitcom. Cosmo guffawed even more gleefully and gave me an Eric Morecambe-style punch on the shoulder that almost laid me out. "It's not just that! Bradshaw 's actually in it !"

Adair looked at me quizzically. "A cameo?" he asked. "Er, no," I said hesitantly, "I act in it... all the way through." With a mixture of suavity and natural delicacy, Gilbert Adair moved the conversation onto something else.

But it's true. I am co-writer and actor in Baddiel's Syndrome, the new sitcom starring David Baddiel, which began on Sunday night on Sky One, with David as an architect struggling with an anthology of neuroses, Morwenna Banks as his Slovenian cleaning lady, Dimitri Goritsas as his American lodger, Kim Thomson as his ex-lover, Stephen Fry as his therapist, and me as his eccentric posh mate, Lord Peter Harrington, a hereditary peer evicted from the Lords by the Blair government and now unable to find anything to do.

For the last few months, news of this last casting has elicited responses ranging from polite bemusement to open incredulity from other journalists.

"You're what ?" they say. "When you say you're in it , you surely don't mean...?" Yes, I do mean. Not unnaturally, everyone thinks that it's like the cinema advertisements for used-car dealerships where the owner insists on being in it himself; perched on the bonnet of a Vauxhall Nova, shouting about competitive prices. Or comparable perhaps to Fred Pontin's decision to appear in the 70s ad for Pontin's Holidays intoning a stately "Book early!" to the public.

I haven't really done any acting for over 10 years, not since university, when I acted in the Cambridge Footlights (where I first met David Baddiel), and also, in serious rollneck-jumper-wearing thesp mode, I played Paris in Romeo And Juliet, Touchstone in As You Like It and Malvolio in Twelfth Night. I'll have you know that I was in a Fringe First-winning promenade production of the Circe episode of Ulysses at Edinburgh! Towards the end of my Cambridge existence I distinguished myself in the process, demonstrating an unerring talent for failing to spot greatness by gormlessly turning down an invitation to audition for the young Sam Mendes.

Perhaps the writing was on the wall. So I exchanged my tights for the journalist's mackintosh and stayed in it. I stuck to writing, although it's true that I read in small parts for the Radio 4 comedy show The Skivers, in the mid 90s, and recently wrote and narrated a late-night Radio 4 serial, For One Horrible Moment. But actual acting, actually appearing in make-up and costume and making a grotesquely undignified spectacle of myself in front of a studio audience - and expecting to get paid for it - well, this was the very first time.

Coming out from behind the comforting protective shield of the computer screen and the newspaper office and facing one's public in the way a journalist never has to do, well, it was stressful. Nigel Planer's tortured satiric creation Nicholas Craig says in his intensely private memoir I, An Actor: "The stress experienced by an actor is equivalent to being within one mile of a 2.83 megaton explosion. Acting is like climbing Mount Everest in the dark. It is like painting the Sistine Chapel with a shark on your back." Actually, I now believe all that. Perhaps because of my inexperience, or my awe at working for 13 weeks last summer in the legendary Teddington Studios, home of Magpie and The Benny Hill Show, I shared Nicholas Craig's pain.

David himself modestly claims not be an actor - well, he doesn't cry on cue, or recite the Queen Mab speech, or do stage fighting with épées - but he is a natural and brilliant performer , eerily and utterly free from the nerves, hiccups, fluffs and re-takes that affected me. The other actors themselves were so charming and so unassumingly professional, it reinforced my view that the time has come to call time on the journalist's clichéd, charmless, unthinking and philistine jeer at "luvvies".

And as it happens, I am not the only journalist making an acting debut in Baddiel's Syndrome. Observer TV critic Kathryn Flett has a stylishly played small role as a confessional newspaper columnist with whom my character falls in love. Who knows? Perhaps Kathryn and I will get our own spin-off series - the Chachi and Joanie of the 21st century.

 Baddiel's Syndrome, Sunday, 10pm, Sky One

1.45pm: Journalists at the Express have publicly condemned the 'shameful betrayal' of the staff at Express Digital Media, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 16: Express website staff to sue for redundancy
More Express stories
fields.body:
Journalists at the Express have publicly condemned the "shameful betrayal" of the staff at Express Digital Media by the newspaper's owner Richard Desmond and the investment firm that acquired the new digital assets.

NUJ members have given their full support to the 46 staff who have been dismissed.

NUJ national organiser Jeremy Dear condemned the paper's previous owner, Lord Hollick and said it was "shameful" that Lord Hollick "should have spent more money giving backhanders to a few friends than it would cost to meet the outstanding redundancy payments owed to the 46".

He added that the NUJ would "leave no stone unturned to demonstrate that this was a deal cooked up in a bid to avoid paying people what they are owed".

Lord Hollick was lambasted when it emerged after the sale of the Express to Northern & Shell boss Mr Desmond that he had sent cheques for £40,000 to his favourite journalists and executives on the newspaper.

fields.headline: Still doing the decent thing
fields.standfirst: His charmed career has spanned decades. Even at the age of 92, he adores acting. But the greatest love of his life is his wife Mary, with whom he has just renewed his marriage vows.  Emma Brockes talks to Sir John Mills, an incurable romantic
fields.trailText: His charmed career has spanned decades. Even at the age of 92, he adores acting. But the greatest love of his life is his wife Mary, with whom he has just renewed his marriage vows. Emma Brockes talks to Sir John Mills, an incurable romantic
fields.body:
Sir John Mills is asleep when we arrive at his house in Denham, Buckinghamshire, a village unmolested by progress since he moved there in 1942 to be near Denham film studios. In those days his neighbours were David Niven and the glamorous Oliviers; it is ghostly now, a reminder to Sir John that he is one of the last actors of his generation, a man held in awe as a survivor of a more graceful age.

The 92-year-old is tired because the previous day he and his 89-year -old wife, Mary, renewed their marriage vows in a blaze of press attention which, his assistant lets on, the actor "just loved". In the post that morning was a card from the Queen and the house is thick with the smell of lilies, crammed into every available receptacle and bearing messages from the great and the good of British theatre.

Surveying Sir John's living room is like waiting for your eyes to adjust to a sudden change of light. In outline, it looks like the aggregate of any elderly couple's life together, a jumble of discordant chairs, paintings and trinkets amassed from every decade since 1910. After a few minutes, however, the room focuses into the weirdest conflation of the banal and the extraordinary that I have ever seen. On the grand piano in the corner are arranged a set of typical family photos: John and Mary when they married in London during the war; their three children, Juliet, Jonathan and Hayley, instantly recognisable from her child-acting roles in such films as Whistle Down the Wind and the Parent Trap. Tucked behind these is a shot of the Mills' late, great friend, Vivien Leigh, in her Gone with the Wind era, and behind that, obscured by clutter, a photo of Noel Coward bearing a scribbled inscription. A 90th birthday card from the Queen Mother hangs on the wall and every cigar box, every trinket, bears some kind of engraved tribute: from the British Film Industry World Sporting Club, the Greater London Fund for the Blind, the St James Gentleman's Club. By the time you start leafing through a book called John Mills, A Life In Pictures, the echoes from bygone Hollywood make his continued existence almost impossible to countenance.

He is, none the less, very much alive and very much in love with Mary, who has Alzheimer's disease, and who he refers to instantly in terms of how beautiful she looked at the wedding. "She did, didn't she?" he says, his distillate blue eyes showing no sign that he is almost totally blind. "It was a marvellous day. Mary was very, very with it. She usually uses a chair, but she insisted on walking down the aisle and the congregation just went mad. The rector cleverly arranged it so that I could say 'we' during the vows and speak for both of us. I took her a carnation in with breakfast this morning and she was smiling away. She'll never forget it."

An unabashed romantic, Sir John chose their diamond wedding anniversary to restage the ceremony they had to hurry the first time round so he could return to the war. (There is something of the old soldier still in him, he loves precision - the walk from his house to the station is exactly eight minutes, he says; on a good day, the drive from Denham to his club in London's St James is 24 minutes.) He felt he had "done her out" of a white wedding and should make amends in Denham's beautiful St Mary's church, with the media platoon cooing outside.

"The first time round, I was on 48-hour leave. It was a rush job. We went for our honeymoon in Dukes Hotel, Jermyn Street, which a month later was flattened by the blitz, so it was rather lucky we weren't killed. We used to stay there before we were married and one night we were standing under the lamp-post having a cuddle, and the manager, who was a great friend of ours, looked at us and said, 'You know, it's lovely to see you two together, when are you getting married?'"

Doing the decent thing, of course, is how we have come to characterise Sir John Mills, whose roles in all those dashing war films - In Which we Serve, We Dive at Dawn, Ice Cold in Alex - established him as an actor of almost mythical English qualities, before such things were agonised over for jingoism. (His daughter Hayley, he says, is "determinedly English", which he is pleased about).

"I just love the country. I turned down very big, lucrative film contracts, because it meant leaving England and I just didn't want to. I've worked in LA for six months at a time, but I've never signed for two or three years, which I'm glad about. When I was 20, I was offered a huge deal with Twentieth Century Fox and Noel Coward took me off to dinner and spent three hours persuading me it wasn't a wise thing. He said, 'You're a very good actor, but you will become a sort of Johnny Garfield or a Jimmy Cagney - a personality. You'll never play anything else. I think you should learn your trade here and then start making movies.' I am delighted that I did that, because that life wouldn't have suited me or Mary. I think my favourite part of all was playing William Mossop in Hobson's Choice. Now, you see, you wouldn't have done that in Hollywood."

It wasn't an easy decision to make, however. He was in a film called Royal Cavalcade, earning £15 a week which would have leapt up to £150 a week if he had gone to Fox. "But you see, the counties here are all different, the accents are all different. You can go to Cornwall, and it could be another country. You are near all the other capitals too, Rome and so forth."

"America," says Sir John, with divine sniffiness, "is rather stuck out from things."

In the 30s, Denham, in spite of its size, was most definitely not stuck out from things. Some of the most successful British films were made in the studios there: Brief Encounter, the 49th Parallel, Goodbye Mr Chips. "David Lean lived right in the village," says Sir John. "The Oliviers lived a couple of miles up the road. David Niven was here. It was fun. It was like a little Beverly Hills of England."

That is all long gone now, he says sadly. Even his great friend "Dickie, Sir Richard Attenborough", must scramble for funding, a fact Sir John finds distasteful in the extreme. He is generous to his acting successors, however, and is not nostalgic for some glory period of British acting. "Darling, I think good actors are good actors. I can think of two: one is Tony Hopkins, who is exactly like any other big actor I've known. Kenneth Branagh is the same. You can't really change good acting."

I ask if he is fully retired now. "Oh God, no!" he says, indignantly. "I've got a script here, which I've got to give an answer to in three days time. It's a series with Nigel Havers. I still enjoy it, touch wood. Learning's not so easy - I have to do it by tape - but I am an optimist and firmly believe in MOM - mind over matter."

He is certainly still feisty. Last summer, a friend of my mother's was strolling through Denham and started taking photos of the wisteria growing on the outside of Sir John's house. He charged out, waving his cane and telling her in no uncertain terms to piss off.

To explain his continuing verve, Sir John relates the story of a late friend of his "a marvellous actor called AE Matthews, who at the age of 80 took on a new role in the theatre. He was running for the tube in his plus-fours one day and a young reporter was trying to keep up with him. 'Mr Matthews,' he said, 'you're quite extraordinary, doing eight shows a week and here you are running for the tube. How do you explain it?' Matthews turned around and said, 'Quite simply dear fellow, I take the Times.' 'What do you mean, Mr Matthews?' asked the reporter.

"Matthews said, 'I open it up, I read the obituaries. If I'm not in it, I get up.' "

"That's a good idea, isn't it?" says Sir John. "You keep getting up."

fields.headline: Sky's Temptation Island steals viewers from E4
fields.standfirst: Verdict on E4 launch night
fields.trailText:
12.45pm TV overnights: Sky One's Temptation Island ambushed Channel 4's E4 launch night but both sides are claiming a ratings victory. By Jason Deans.
Verdict on E4 launch night
fields.body:
Sky One's Temptation Island robbed Channel 4's E4 of valuable viewers last night but both sides are claiming an overall ratings victory.

The BSkyB-owned channel's decision to use the controversial US reality show as a spoiler on E4's launch night paid dividends.

The show, in which couples are left on a tropical island and tempted into indiscretions with a single people, pulled in 557,000 viewers and a 7% share, according to unofficial overnights.

Temptation Island, screened at 10pm, beat the second half of ER's season premiere, which pulled in 280,000 viewers between 9.30pm and 10.30pm.

Channel 4's new Japanese-style game show, Banzai, which was up against the second half-hour of Temptation Island, got an audience of just 120,000 viewers.

Channel 4 bosses were today glossing over the damage wraught by Temptation Island, declaring the station had "launched with a bang".

The first episode in a Friends double bill pulled in 498,000 viewers, easily seeing off a Sky One repeat of the Simpsons, which was watched by 250,000. Up to 600,000 viewers tuned in to the second instalment of the US sitcom.

The average audience for the show was 563,000, giving it a comfortable lead over Sky One's As Extreme as it Gets, which was seen by 410,000 between 9pm and 10pm.

However, Sky One did better overall, posting an average share of viewing of 5.1% in multi-channel homes last night.

E4 notched up a 3.3% share despite a marketing blitz over recent days.

Nevertheless, Channel 4 declared the launch a huge success - E4 was the third most-watched pay-TV channel after Sky One and UK Gold.

And between 8pm and 12.45am, it was second only to Sky One.

"We are flattered that Sky is taking a new channel so seriously, especially when it is only available in two-thirds of Sky One homes," said a Channel 4 spokesman.

E4 is only available in 60% of multi-channel homes, while Sky One is distributed to around 90%.

"This was a stunning performance for a new channel," said Gerry Bastable, Channel 4's managing director of pay-TV.

fields.headline: Cash-strapped council splashes out £50,000 on new logo
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Lambeth council has come under fire for spending over £50,000 of taxpayers' money on a new logo, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Lambeth council, one of the poorest in London, has come under fire for spending over £50,000 of taxpayers' money on a new logo.

Tory councillor John Whelan described the move by the notoriously inefficient Labour-led council as a "grotesque waste of money".

"How can they spend money on this in the middle of a cash crisis. We have a budget gap of £10m. This is a case of fiddling while Lambeth burns," he added.

The council hired design consultants Felton Communications to create a single Lambeth logo for the first time because it felt its image was too disparate.

Council leaders paid Felton a fee of £25,000 and also spent an estimated £25,000 on consulting the public about the new identity.

But experts believe the true price of the new logo could be well in excess of £50,000 because of the cost of changing signs, notepaper and letterheads.

A spokesman for Lambeth defended the decision, saying it was actually designed to save taxpayers' money. "This makes sound business sense," he said.

"We had around 150 different business units all with different logos and different letterheads and we are already saving money by rationalising those. We are very cost-conscious and will not be changing signs until they need repairing anyway."

The amount of money organisations spend on changing their identities has been in the media spotlight in recent weeks after the Post Office announced it was changing its name to Consignia.

fields.headline: Robert Robertson
fields.trailText: The Scottish actor who was best known for his role as Dr Stephen Andrews in TV's Taggart has died at the age of 70
fields.body:
The actor Robert Robertson often joked that he was the most unlikely choice to play a pathologist, since he hated the sight of blood. Yet for 17 years - until his death, aged 70, after collapsing as he was reciting Holy Wullie's Prayer at a Burns night in the Perth theatre - it was as the morbidly jolly Dr Stephen Andrews, in Scottish Television's Taggart, that he found most fame.

A warm and courteous man who brought gravitas and humour to the Taggart set, Robertson was born in St Andrews, and began his career in Manchester rep shortly after the second world war. As a jobbing actor, he moved to London, then returned to Scotland in 1973 to appear in Dundee. Impressed by the mid-70s revival in Scottish theatre, he stayed and became artistic director of Dundee rep in 1976. He held the post for 16 years, and was one of the driving forces in the company's move to a purpose-built theatre. He also continued to direct and act, winning critical acclaim as Willy Loman, in Death Of A Salesman, and Frank, in Educating Rita.

In 1983, he was picked to play Dr Andrews in the TV detective drama, then called Killer. After a three-part pilot, it was renamed Taggart and became a hit with audiences worldwide, the jocose manner of Robertson's character contrasting wonderfully with the gruff surliness of Mark McManus's Jim Taggart. Created and often written by Glenn Chandler, Taggart became famous for its labyrinthineplots and murder weapons - from snakes to sabotaged parachutes - and garnered audiences of up to 18.3m.

Robertson was the last surviving member of the original Taggart cast, following the death of Mark McManus in 1994, and of Iain Anders, who played Superintendent Jack "The Biscuit" McVitie, in 1997. Despite appearing in 51 episodes, Robertson's character was never centre stage, but he was vital nonetheless. His voice boomed around the tiled post-mortem suite in which he cheerfully spent much of his time, the findings of the pipe-smoking pathologist invariably sparking the kindling of a murder inquiry.

Robertson was divorced. He is survived by Monica Nesbitt, his partner of 21 years.

 Robert Robertson, actor, born 1930; died January 17 2001

webTitle: Day when social services said 'that's enough'

fields.headline: Day when social services said 'that's enough'
fields.standfirst: Sudden intervention as political furore grows over internet trade in babies amid heightened concern about couple's suitability as parents
fields.trailText: Last night's dramatic seizure of the internet twins by police and social workers at a north Wales hotel came amid growing political furore about the cynical trade in babies and increasing concern over the suitability of Alan and Judith Kilshaw as adoptive parents.
fields.body:
Last night's dramatic seizure of the internet twins by police and social workers at a north Wales hotel came amid growing political furore about the cynical trade in babies and increasing concern over the suitability of Alan and Judith Kilshaw as adoptive parents.

Social workers were also worried about the publicity surrounding the twins, and appeared dissatisfied with assurances from the Kilshaws that the children would be readily available for inspection to ensure their well-being.

With fresh doubts about the couple's characters emerging, the twins' natural mother demanded their return and a third couple came forward to say they had been offered the children.

Mr Kilshaw, a solicitor, drew criticism for suggesting that the story of how the couple obtained the girls could be sold to Hollywood.

In the US the girls' natural mother claimed she did not feel they were fit parents. This raised suggestions that the twins are likely to become part of a protracted legal tussle involving Britain and America.

Tranda Wecker, a 28-year- old receptionist, told CBS Television: "I really want my girls back. I really do. I feel like I was betrayed - I feel that they need to come back to the States to settle this adoption."

She told ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald Show that she wanted her daughters to have "the best possible parents", adding: "Financially I cannot give them the world, but I love my girls."

Whatever happens now, it seems clear that the twins are likely to become part of a bitter legal tussle. Asked whether she would continue to fight for custody, Mrs Kilshaw replied firmly: "Yes."

Speaking on the same programme as Ms Wecker, Mrs Kilshaw asked: "Why did she give them up in the first place? If she did have them back would she put them up [for adoption] again with a different agency or the same agency?"

A third couple, Amy and Eddie White, stepped into the row to say that they had also been offered the children.

The Kilshaws' actions - paying £8,200 for the twins, who had already been handed to another couple who had paid half that amount - have caused huge controversy in Britain. Tony Blair has promised early legislation to halt what he called the "deplorable" practice of trading children for adoption.

Mr Kilshaw, a specialist housing lawyer, was forced to resign as legal and home affairs spokesman for the Eurosceptic Democratic party yesterday. His determination to adopt the girls had embarrassed the fringe party.

The Kilshaws' 18-year-old daughter Caley also remained defiant saying: "What my parents have done isn't illegal. They looked at various options, including Romania and China, but they were not really viable. The babies are not going to be taken from us. Those people don't stand a chance of getting them back. They are part of our family now. It is all legal."

Speaking from the hotel where the Kilshaws were spending the day, Caley Kilshaw repudiated accusations that the family home was an unfit place for children because it was dirty.

Perhaps the most embarrassing revelation yesterday was that the Kilshaws called in paranormal investigators after they and their children thought they saw, heard or felt unexplained phenomena in their north Wales farmhouse.

Mr Kilshaw claimed that Hollywood film makers had already been in touch.

He said he had told them: "Let's get it on." This has fuelled criticism that the couple are publicity hungry.

webTitle: EC urges lower drink drive limit on Britain

fields.headline: EC urges lower drink drive limit on Britain
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: The European commission yesterday told Britain to tighten its drink driving laws and cut the maximum amount of alcohol allowed in the bloodstream by almost 40%.
fields.body:
The European commission yesterday told Britain to tighten its drink driving laws and cut the maximum amount of alcohol allowed in the bloodstream by almost 40%.

The Home Office has fiercely resisted Brussels's attempts to legislate on the matter and will be irritated by the commission's call for the legal limit of alcohol in the blood to be reduced to 0.5mg per millilitre from 0.8mg, in line with most member states.

The European parliament in Strasbourg also backed the 0.5mg threshold by a huge majority.

British diplomats argued that the commission was issuing merely a recommendation.

The commission wants the legal limit to be even lower, 0.2 mg, for certain categories of drivers, including those whose licence is less than two years, motorcyclists and lorry and bus drivers. It wants every driver to be breathalysed at least every three years.

The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, accused Brussels of interfering in matters which did not concern it.

"The EU's one size fits all approach to tackle drink driving would not have a marked effect in Britain. Decisions on matters like this should be left up to member states, and the Labour government should have the courage to take decisions by itself for once.

"Reducing the blood alcohol limit in this country would not tackle the real problem of hardened drink drivers, in particular repeat offenders."

Government officials played down the issue. "The debate continues, but this has no legislative force," one said. "The commission has the right to pass comment on different subjects." The UK had a road safety record second only to Sweden.

But Sweden, holder of the EU's six month rotating presidency, has signalled its intention to press for further harmonisation, and the issue is likely to surface again in the coming months.

Ten of the 15 member states have a 0.5mg ceiling, and Sweden's is 0.2mg. Only the UK, Ireland, Italy and Luxembourg maintain a limit of 0.8mg.

The commission acknowledged that it would have to rely on its powers of persuasion. "We're not going to force this on anyone, but this is what could and should be the European standard," said a spokesman, Gilles Gantelet.

"Everyone is getting worked up about depleted uranium shells but 40 people don't die every day because of them, as is the case with drunk driving."

The commission estimated that 50 lives a year could be saved in the UK - about 1.5% of all road fatalities - if its advice were followed. Around 10,000 people a year are killed across the EU in alcohol-related road deaths.

Britain's 0.8mg limit was introduced in 1967. Brussels did say yesterday that UK drink driving deaths had fallen by 70% in the past 20 years.

fields.headline: West Wing wins UK vote
fields.trailText: 1.30pm TV overnights: The West Wing, the US drama import about a fictional US president, made an impressive debut on Channel 4, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Critics choice The West Wing, the US drama import focusing on a fictional president and his White House staff, made an impressive debut on Channel 4 last night.

The West Wing, which stars Martin Sheen as the US president and Rob Lowe as one of his advisers, went out on Sky One last year.

But this did not stop the UK terrestrial premiere pulling in 2.3m viewers on Channel 4 last night. The show took a 12% share of the available audience between 10pm and 11pm.

It beat BBC2 opposition from a repeated Have I Got News for You, which got 2.2m viewers; and Newsnight, which attracted 1.2m.

The West Wing enjoyed a healthy inheritance from 1940s House. The factual show in which a modern family live in second world war conditions aired from 9-10pm. It drew 3.3m and a 14% share.

Shipwrecked, in which a group of 17-year-olds are dumped on a South Pacific island for 11 weeks, returned to Channel 4 for a second series last night from 6-7pm.

The reality show pulled in 2m viewers and a 10% share.

webTitle: Time for BT to phone a friend

fields.headline: Time for BT to phone a friend
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Oftel's decision to force BT to break up its monopoly of the local telephone network is good news for everyone, except the beleaguered telecommunications giant itself, writes Online editor Vic Keegan.
fields.body:
Oftel's decision to force BT to break up its monopoly of the local telephone network is good news for everyone - except the beleaguered telecommunications giant itself.

The debate over bringing "broadband" telecommunications links into the home goes back at least 15 years - but it still hasn't arrived. In the mid 1980s the government decided to leave it to market forces rather than authorise BT to go ahead with a massive investment in fibre optic cables in exchange for being allowed to deliver "entertainment" (mainly video) down the line.

The trouble was that BT was left with a virtual monopoly of the profitable "local loop", the last mile or so of wire that connects the home to the local exchange. Understandably, from its own point of view, it wants to hang on to these monopoly profits as long as possible - so it hasn't exactly been busting keen to open up the local loop to competitors who have been complaining bitterly about BT dragging its feet.

Competition in the local loop would almost certainly have accelerated the introduction of broadband.

BT has been under pressure from the government and the regulator for some time to allow competitors to deliver a broadband (high capacity) telephone line into homes so it isn't just the preserve of businesses.

The government is concerned that slow access doesn't become an issue in the general election campaign.

BT's response was to start opening the loop in less densely populated areas which obviously are not as attractive to competitors as the built-up areas.

Yesterday Oftel announced an agreement to accelerate the existing timetable for unbundling the loop which ought to bring access quicker to densely populated areas.

The widespread availability of broadband access to the internet is vital if Britain is to be at the leading edge of delivering films, video, conference vision and other digital products to the world's exploding internet population.

Those countries that are early adopters of new technologies are in a good position to enable their own businesses to piggyback on their success by selling their expertise abroad.

Although BT has been dragging its feet, Britain is still doing reasonably well on adoption of broadband options like ADSL compared with most countries on the Continent. BT claims that Britain will be out among the leaders when the local loop is finally opened up.

However, the concentration on densely populated areas, while attractive to the companies involved, raises the danger of opening a "digital divide" between richer and poorer parts of the country.

BT claims that there isn't much point in providing broadband access, at enormous expense, to outlying areas that won't use it much and which could obtain access to the internet through their television screens or mobile phones.

Britain's approach - relying on market forces goaded by the regulator - is in marked contrast to the policy adopted in Singapore where the government decided to build fibre optic connections to most homes, a task that has largely been accomplished.

webTitle: Congo admits at last that Kabila is dead

fields.headline: Congo admits at last that Kabila is dead
fields.trailText: The government of the Democratic Republic of Congo finally dropped the fiction yesterday that Laurent Kabila was still alive and confirmed that he was killed by an assassin on Tuesday.
fields.byline: James Astill  in Brazzaville , Andrew Meldrum  in Harare  and  Chris McGreal
fields.body:
The government of the Democratic Republic of Congo finally dropped the fiction yesterday that Laurent Kabila was still alive and confirmed that he was killed by an assassin on Tuesday.

The government in Kinshasa officially informed other African states that Mr Kabila had been murdered by one of his own military officers but gave no explanation as to why it had lied for two days about the president's fate.

Diplomats believe that the authorities wanted to ensure that the assassinated ruler's son, Joseph Kabila, was firmly installed as Congo's new leader before confirming the killing.

Officials had continued to deny his death even though foreign governments said they were certain of it and Zimbabwe's defence minister, Moven Mahachi, announced that the corpse was lying in a Harare morgue.

Mr Mahachi said the assassinated president died on a flight to Zimbabwe after doctors were unable to save him in Kinshasa.

Joseph Kabila, 31, who is head of land forces in the war against Rwandan and Ugandan-backed rebels, was expected to broadcast a message last night to the Congolese people, who are the last to be told officially of the demise of their president. The message was also likely to be an appeal for support.

The new leader commands little support among the Congolese people who generally did not like his father and are suspicious of the son's relative youth and the manner of his coming to power. Neither is he particularly respected in the military he commands, as a result of both his lack of experience and his notorious brutality.

But Joseph Kabila presumably succeeded his father with the blessing of Zimbabwe and Angola, Congo's two principal backers in the war.

Rebels yesterday called on the new president to seize the opportunity presented by his father's death to end the civil war.

The main rebel group, the Congolese Rally for Democracy, pledged that it would not take military advantage of Laurent Kabila's assassination but said it would keep fighting if the country's new leader did not begin to implement the Lusaka peace accords his father had blocked.

"It is a pity to see Kabila's son the head of state. We are not a monarchy," said a rebel spokesman, Kin-Kiey Mulumba. "But we hope he is going to accept the peace accord. If not, we will continue to defend ourselves."

To the ire of some of his allies who are keen to end the war, Laurent Kabila had stalled the implementation of the 1999 peace deal, which provides for UN peacekeepers to monitor a ceasefire during talks on powersharing.

Laurent Kabila's body is expected to be flown back to Congo at the weekend amid conflicting reports about plans for his burial.

Government officials said there will be a state funeral in Kinshasa on Tuesday. But preparations are also apparently under way for Mr Kabila's burial in his home province of Katanga.

webTitle: A country pays as foreigners fight for the spoils of war

fields.headline: A country pays as foreigners fight for the spoils of war
fields.trailText: Just about the only people not making money out of the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo are its long-suffering citizens.
fields.body:
Just about the only people not making money out of the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo are its long-suffering citizens.

Either side of an 1,800 mile frontline, a country the size of western Europe with a population no larger than England's has been carved up by warring factions and foreign armies. Hundreds of thousands of people are dead; more than 2m are homeless. What little infrastructure Mobutu Sese Seko did not wreck during his three decades of misrule - hospitals, schools, power plants - has mostly been destroyed by fighting, or has finally succumbed to neglect.

The country's riches - diamonds, cobalt, copper, gold and timber - have been mortgaged and plundered by what passes for a government in Kinshasa, and by foreign soldiers and local warlords. As always, western businesses have stepped in to exploit the upheaval. But they have been outclassed by more ruthless players.

The scramble to exploit the turmoil began even before Mobutu was overthrown four years ago. A US firm, America Mineral Fields, signed a £680m deal to mine copper, cobalt and zinc in Congo. A large down-payment to Laurent Kabila to fund his rebellion doubtless helped to secure the deal.

The company had been negotiating with Mobutu a few weeks earlier, but as soon as it realised that his days were numbered it switched its allegiance. It flew Kabila around what was still Zaire in its private jet and found other ways to curry favour. The loser was the South African mining giant, Anglo American.

Tenke Fungurume Mining, a Canadian firm, snapped up a £170m investment in a privatised mine near Lubumbashi. An Israeli company gained control of much of the diamond trade, which still accounts for more than half of Congo's export revenues.

A slew of other companies fought to get a foot in the door. Many came to regret it. Kabila took their money and failed to honour contracts. Foreign businessmen who objected were locked up.

Some firms are still waiting to see if it is worth putting more money into Congo, in the hope of getting a return on the cash they have already sunk in.

The real beneficiaries have been the foreign belligerents in a war that has drawn in tens of thousands of troops from nine countries.

At the start of the latest conflict, in October 1998, Kabila bought the backing of Zimbabwe's army with a promise that its intervention would be "self-financing". That opened the door to a number of companies fronting for President Robert Mugabe and his military chiefs. A state-owned firm run by retired army officers, Zimbabwe Defence Industries, was contracted to provide arms and munitions to Kinshasa. In return, a Zimbabwean mining firm, Ridgepointe, got a one-third share and management control of the dilapidated but potentially highly profitable Congolese state mining company, Gecamines. About half of the profits were to go to Harare to pay for its war machine.

But the Gecamines experience has not been a happy one. Mr Mugabe installed a Zimbabwean businessman, Billy Rautenbach, to turn the company around in the face of £700m in debts. Mr Rautenbach was not a success, in part because Zimbabwe did not invest the tens of millions of pounds required to revive full production. But he did serve Mr Mugabe's purpose of ensuring that the Zimbabweans got their cut of revenues from cobalt and copper mining. Mr Kabila sacked Mr Rautenbach, to Mr Mugabe's chagrin.

Another company run by Zimbabwe's army, Osleg, is heavily involved in buying diamonds and gold, and a Zimbabwean state farm has been given 500,000 hectares of land in the southern Congolese province of Katanga.

Zimbabwe's defence minister, Moven Mahachi, has long denied that his forces are in Congo for profit. "You don't go where people lose lives just because you want to make a few dollars," he said. "But as a result of our presence, a number of Zimbabwe businessmen are taking advantage of the goodwill there. If they don't, others will."

North Korea has sent troops in return for a promised share in the Shunkolobwe uranium mines.

Foreign forces on the rebel side have also been "self- financing" their intervention, and making a tidy profit, too.

Uganda's gold exports have risen almost tenfold since its involvement in Congo, and its £400m trade deficit has been erased. President Yoweri Museveni's brother, Major General Salim Saleh, until recently had valuable gold mining concessions in Congo, and runs a profitable air cargo business to rebel-held territory. fields.bodyText: Just about the only people not making money out of the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo are its long-suffering citizens. Either side of an 1,800 mile frontline, a country the size of western Europe with a population no larger than England's has been carved up by warring factions and foreign armies. Hundreds of thousands of people are dead; more than 2m are homeless. What little infrastructure Mobutu Sese Seko did not wreck during his three decades of misrule - hospitals, schools, power plants - has mostly been destroyed by fighting, or has finally succumbed to neglect. The country's riches - diamonds, cobalt, copper, gold and timber - have been mortgaged and plundered by what passes for a government in Kinshasa, and by foreign soldiers and local warlords. As always, western businesses have stepped in to exploit the upheaval. But they have been outclassed by more ruthless players. The scramble to exploit the turmoil began even before Mobutu was overthrown four years ago. A US firm, America Mineral Fields, signed a £680m deal to mine copper, cobalt and zinc in Congo. A large down-payment to Laurent Kabila to fund his rebellion doubtless helped to secure the deal. The company had been negotiating with Mobutu a few weeks earlier, but as soon as it realised that his days were numbered it switched its allegiance. It flew Kabila around what was still Zaire in its private jet and found other ways to curry favour. The loser was the South African mining giant, Anglo American. webTitle: A son with no shining qualities

fields.headline: A son with no shining qualities
fields.trailText: Joseph Kabila Mulubakat, 31, is not the youngest military ruler to come to power in Africa. But he is the first African ruler to succeed his father, other than in the smattering of monarchies on the continent. And the large numbers of other members of the Kabila family in positions of power suggests a quasi dynasty in the making.
fields.body:
Joseph Kabila Mulubakat, 31, is not the youngest military ruler to come to power in Africa. But he is the first African ruler to succeed his father, other than in the smattering of monarchies on the continent. And the large numbers of other members of the Kabila family in positions of power suggests a quasi dynasty in the making.

Laurent Kabila made one cousin his home affairs minister and another the minister of justice. A third was his chief military aide and a brother-in-law was inspector general of police. Nephews were given high military posts, and other relatives permeate a system whose only purpose was to keep Kabila as president of Congo.

Now it falls to his son to keep the family in control. And it is not only his youth that counts against him. He spent so much of his life outside the country's borders, mostly in Tanzania, that he hardly speaks French, Congo's official language, or Lingala, the most widely spoken language in Kinshasa.

To add to the suspicion, Joseph has a Tutsi mother. To many Congolese that makes him a foreigner.

Laurent Kabila was not noted for his intellect or leadership qualities, but he is said to have shone brightly beside his son, who has come to believe he is a great military commander, despite an experience limited to three months of training with the Beijing military academy.

Joseph has even been publicly derided by some of the soldiers he supposedly commanded. A day or two after the Rwandans and Ugandans marched into the southern Congolese city of Lubumbashi four years ago, on their way to overthrowing Mobutu Sese Seko, the younger Kabila turned up to claim credit for the victory. He was, ostensibly, his father's military chief and so technically in charge of the rebel forces on the ground.

It was a nonsense made clear by a Ugandan officer who publicly derided him as the "little chief". But that did not stop his father making him commander of land forces in the present war, to the disgust of the few real soldiers.

But whatever Joseph's limitations, he has inherited his father's acumen for deals. He has made a lot of money in business with one of the relatives of Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe.

fields.headline: Saddam's happy Arab family
fields.standfirst:
Among the patrons of the Palestinians caught in the current conflicts, the Iraqi leader's bullish support can only have pernicious motives, says Middle East editor Brian Whitaker

Special report: Iraq
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Among the patrons of the Palestinians caught in the current conflicts, the Iraqi leader's bullish support can only have pernicious motives, says Middle East editor Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
The commemoration of the tenth anniversary of the Gulf war in Baghdad this week was a subdued affair.

Saddam Hussein's speech, in which he hailed Iraq's military defeat as a victory, cannot have carried much resonance for the average Iraqi.

Even his son Uday has warned parliament that people are becoming disaffected - especially with government officials who blame sanctions for their own incompetence and corruption.

It was a different story in Gaza, where hundreds of Palestinians marked the anniversary with an enthusiastic demonstration in praise of Saddam.

"The Palestinian and the Iraqi peoples are in the first trench against Zionism, imperialism and aggression," one of the banners said.

Some Palestinians are so enthusiastic about Saddam that they name their babies after him and small children in the streets chant: "Saddam, Saddam, come and bomb Tel Aviv."

A Guardian journalist recently visited a family in Gaza who had lost a son in the intifada. On the wall above the boy's empty bed hung a large picture of the Iraqi leader; on the opposite wall, a certificate of martyrdom bearing an Iraqi flag and another picture of Saddam.

Iraq had given the family $10,000 compensation for their loss, which they planned to spend on home improvements and medical treatment for one of the boy's brothers.

It is understandable, of course, that Palestinians should welcome help from wherever it comes, but I wonder if that is entirely wise.

Last week I was talking to an Arab ambassador who is far from lukewarm on the Palestinian question, and I found him furious about Iraq's behaviour.

"Saddam is an embarrassment," he said. "What he's doing won't help the Palestinians at all. It's for his own benefit, not theirs."

One example is Saddam's demand that more than $800m be diverted from the UN's Oil for Food programme to aid the Palestinians. There is little doubt that the real motive behind this is not to help the Palestinians but to put the UN on the spot and drive another hole in the sanctions regime.

One might nevertheless argue that if the Palestinians benefit as a result, then good luck to them. But the motivation of benefactors does matter - as we have seen in Britain recently in a controversy over donations to political parties.

Suppose that bereaved families in Gaza started receiving gifts of $10,000 from the Kentucky Fried Chicken company, together with certificates of martyrdom signed by the genial Colonel Sanders. Would anyone have qualms about it?

The idea is not totally ridiculous. Both Pepsi and McDonalds (or at least some of their franchise holders in Arab countries) have been donating a share of profits to provide medical aid for Palestinians.

In both cases the motive was perfectly clear: to protect their businesses by dissociating themselves from American policy towards Israel. Many people were delighted and marketing experts praised this as a brilliant example of enlightened self-interest. Nobody seems to have condemned the move as an exploitation of other people's misfortune for cynical commercial reasons (which would be another way of looking at it).

It could also be argued that the Palestinians have no alternative to accepting support from Saddam, Pepsi, McDonalds, or whoever, because others - especially in the Arab world - have let them down so often in the past.

Support from other Arab leaders has, of course, increased since the intifada began, though it is widely regarded as weak and insincere, prompted by Arab leaders' fears of losing credibility with their own people if they failed to make a stand. Another case of enlightened self-interest, perhaps.

At the Arab summit in Cairo last October, Crown Prince Abdullah did Saudi Arabia's reputation a lot of good by initiating the $1bn al-Aqsa Fund and making some carefully-worded criticisms of American policy in his speech.

There was no great cost, political or financial. The Saudis have plenty of money and the prince's complaints against the US were far from strident. But the Saudis are close allies of the US and the prince's words were more likely to be taken seriously in Washington than anything that Saddam Hussein says.

In comparison with the largely non-existent statements on Palestine made by another American ally - Britain's Tony Blair - the prince's remarks look positively courageous.

Last Tuesday, Saddam Hussein met the head of the PLO's political department, Farouk Kadoumi in Baghdad and called - once again - for the destruction of Israel and for a "Palestine from the river [Jordan] to the sea." He urged Jordan and Syria to let his army pass through their countries and attack Israel.

Saddam can safely say this because there is no chance of being allowed to carry out his threat. It does, however, enhance his prestige on the street.

Whether it helps the Palestinians is another matter. Possibly he imagines the Israelis will be so terrified that they will quickly sue for peace - though that seems unlikely.

Iraq's Scud missile attacks on Israel during the Gulf war served to muddy the waters over the main issue (the invasion of Kuwait) but actually caused only token damage in Israel.

Saddam's threats against Israel are almost certainly little more than rhetoric - though with Saddam we can never be entirely sure. The trouble is that they provide ammunition for those Israelis who claim that the Arabs do not really want peace, and that any settlement with the Palestinians would be a trap, leading only to more conflict.

webTitle: Kabila's son to be sworn in as president

fields.headline: Kabila's son to be sworn in as president
fields.trailText: Acting head of state Joseph Kabila is to succeed his assassinated father as president of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Communications minister Dominique Sakombi said Mr Kabila had been named interim head of government while his father was still alive, but now "assumes the permanent responsibilities as head of the government and the army."   It is not clear when the swearing-in will take place.
fields.body:
Acting head of state Joseph Kabila is to succeed his assassinated father as president of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Communications minister Dominique Sakombi said Mr Kabila had been named interim head of government while his father was still alive, but now "assumes the permanent responsibilities as head of the government and the army." It is not clear when the swearing-in will take place.

Congolese authorities only confirmed President Laurent Kabila's death on Thursday, two days after he had been shot, despite reports that he died of his injuries soon after 30 minutes of gunfire at his residence in the capital, Kinshasa.

Mr Sakombi provided few details in a statement broadcast on state-run television, saying only that Kabila, 59, died at 10am on Thursday. "Congo is in mourning," he said. "He gave the best years of his life for the freedom of the Congolese people."

Kabila's son was made temporary head of government on Wednesday to fill the power vacuum that has threatened to increase the turmoil in this central African state.

UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan said he hoped the peace process in Congo "would not be derailed further; and that "the political and security situation in the country and the region would not be destabilised further."

The elevation of Joseph Kabila angered many Congolese, who believe he is half-Tutsi. Many in Kinshasa despise the Tutsis, who now dominate the government in neighboring Rwanda - Congo's main enemy.

"We are not a monarchy," said 24-year-old Madeleine Mapolo, a student. "Kabila is dead. It's not for his son to replace him. Elections must be organised by a government of national unity."

A 25-member delegation of Congolese officials, led by foreign minister Yerodia Ndombasi, arrived in Harare on Thursday night to pick up the body of Kabila, who died on his way to Zimbabwe for medical treatment after the shooting by one of his bodyguards.

President Robert Mugabe's government has pledged continued support for the Congo, but has yet to issue a promised statement on the crisis following Kabila's death. Zimbabwean officials could not say whether Mr Mugabe, one of Kabila's key allies in his civil war with rebels backed by forces from Uganda and Rwanda, would attend his funeral.

But they said the Zimbabwean leader was consulting Kabila's other allies, Namibian president Sam Nujoma and Angolan president Jose Eduardo dos Santos, on when to convene an urgent summit.

Mr Nujoma and Mr Dos Santos were due to meet in Luanda today.
