webTitle: Second unmanned Chinese spacecraft returns to Earth

fields.headline: Second unmanned Chinese spacecraft returns to Earth
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: China's unmanned Shenzhou II spacecraft has landed in the country's northern grasslands, returning its passengers which included a monkey, a dog, a rabbit and snails.
fields.body:
China's unmanned Shenzhou II spacecraft has landed in the country's northern grasslands, returning its passengers which included a monkey, a dog, a rabbit and snails.

The spacecraft orbited the earth 108 times, state television has reported, as Beijing prepares for a manned flight in the next five years.

State media have said only that "various life forms" including animals, plants, aquatic creatures, microbes and cells made the journey, but gave no other details.

An official from the Jiuquan launch centre in northwest China laughed when asked to confirm the news, saying it was a state secret.

Officials from the Beijing Space Control Centre, which operates under the military, could not be reached for comment.

China Central Television said the Shenzhou space capsule successfully carried out a battery of instrument tests and scientific experiments in communications and science, without providing details.

"The second space test was a complete success," CCTV said in its brief report.

Western experts believe the flight of the Shenzhou II puts China a step closer to becoming only the third nation, after the United States and the former Soviet Union, to launch a person into outer space.

China has extolled its space ambitions as a sign of its rising might and influence, although so far it has provided scant details on the flights or its secretive space program, code-named Project 921.

CCTV reported the capsule landed in the central part of barren Inner Mongolia, apparently the same area where the first Shenzhou flight landed in November 1999 after orbiting Earth for 21 hours.

Previous reports by the official Xinhua News Agency said the Shenzhou was conducting experiments in physics, voice transmission, astronomy and the environment of space.

Newspaper reports on last Wednesday's launch said the space capsule also carried cell and tissue samples of 87 animals, plants and micro-organisms.

Western analysts believe the Shenzhou tested systems essential to manned flight, namely life-support, guidance and re-entry. Chinese scientists quoted by state media have said three or four more unmanned test flights will be needed.

Western experts said a successful second test could bring a manned flight within two years.

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-one
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Surely this week ...
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £159.69, Sean Ingle = £52.75, Football Unlimited punters collective = £44.60, Paul MacInnes = £33.35
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £159.69, Sean Ingle = £52.75, Football Unlimited punters collective = £44.60, Paul MacInnes = £33.35

Scott Murray: Tottenham v Southampton - Southampton to win £5 @ 4/1

Tottenham's home record looks good in print. Well, I have only one word to say to that, although it's not so much a word as a noise: pah.

Solid home results haven't convinced me that Spurs are invincible at the Lane: they've struggled against Manchester City and Middlesbrough, both of whom are poorer sides than today's fast-improving visitors.

And are Tottenham a more intimidating proposition at home than, say, Sunderland or Liverpool? I'd say they're not - and Southampton could have easily taken all three points at both the Stadium of Light and Anfield this season.

Additionally, while Saints may have lost by a five-goal margin the last time they came here, there's the small matter of Tottenham's more recent spineless 2-0 surrender at the Dell to consider.

If this bet doesn't come off, I shall be experimenting with the sounds "gah", "cah" and "eff".

Tim Sainty of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Coventry v Everton - 0-1 goals @ 9/4

Coventry are so desperate to try and hit the proverbial barn door that they have even tried to sign John Hartson. Whilst Everton are so short of players that they would probably try and sign Ali Dai if he was available.

So expect an action-packed, absolutely belting match between two terrible sides to be decided by an own goal off someone's backside. Now that would be long odds.

Anyone wanting to follow this should remember I'm a poor man.

Paul MacInnes: Risky £5 treble - Gillingham to beat Crystal Palace @ 5/2, Leeds to beat Newcastle @ 4/7, Man Utd to beat Aston Villa @ 1/3

Question: When is a value single not a value single? Answer: when it's in the First Division. That's right, while the bookies may be on slightly less familiar ground in the First Division, they're still smart enough not to allow punters to bet on individual games. So that's why I'm having to mix my 'high-value' away victory with a couple of 'sure-fire' home wins.

Gillingham are on a good run of form at the moment (unbeaten in five) and did Palace 4-1 over Chrimbo. The Eagles, meanwhile, are indifferent in the league (only one win in the last five), are coming off the back of an energy-sapping FA Cup tie against Sunderland, and will be without their most consistent defender, Fan Zhiyi. Hence the plump for the away win.

However, that isn't enough for those Blue Square bloodsuckers, so I've had to back a resurgent Leeds to beat an injury-ravaged Newcastle, and those men in Red to, yawn, win again. Anyway, we all know I'm going to lose anyway, so who cares?

Get well soon, Sean Ingle!

webTitle: In brief: Cruise and Spielberg team for Minority Report

fields.headline: Cruise and Spielberg team for Minority Report
fields.standfirst: Plus: Judi Dench back with Lasse Hallstrom for The Shipping News; Peter Falk to star in BBC version of The Lost world
fields.trailText: Plus: Judi Dench back with Lasse Hallstrom for The Shipping News; Peter Falk to star in BBC version of The Lost world
fields.body:
 Tom Cruise and Steven Spielberg appear keen to slot in another film quickly to avoid being hit by the possibility of strikes in Hollywood. According to Variety, Cruise, who is currently working on Paramount's Vanilla Sky for Cameron Crowe, will take just two weeks off after the film is completed in early March. He will then move directly to Fox's Minority Report, to be directed by Spielberg, who is now editing AI on an almost-impossible schedule so that he can put Minority Report into pre-production on time.

 Lasse Hallstrom has signed up Oscar winner Judi Dench to join Kevin Spacey and Julianne Moore in his film version of the Pulitzer Award-winning novel, The Shipping News. Variety reports that Hallstrom has recently returned from Newfoundland, where the film (based on the book by E Annie Proulx) will be shot. Hallstrom recently directed Dench in Chocolat, which is up for four Golden Globes. The winners will be announced this weekend.

 Columbo star Peter Falk is reported to have signed a £2.5m deal with the BBC to star in a major dinosaur thriller. The Daily Mirror reports that the 73-year-old American is to play the Reverend Theo Kerr in The Lost World, based on the book by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.

fields.headline: Rescue package boosts QXL shares
fields.standfirst:
Jan 5: Telewest's Singer joins online auctioneer
Nov 30: QXL shares plunge
Special report: Dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.trailText:
11.45am: Shares in online auctioneer QXL Ricardo have risen as it finalised plans for a rescue package, reports Dan Milmo.
Jan 5: Telewest's Singer joins online auctioneer
Nov 30: QXL shares plunge
Special report: Dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.body:
Shares in online auctioneer QXL Ricardo have received a much-needed boost after the stricken firm finalised plans for a financial rescue.

QXL confirmed that it was seeking shareholder approval for the staggered issue of £30m in shares and convertible bonds, sending its shares up 21% to 18.5p.

A QXL spokeswoman said the cash should take it through to April 2003, when analysts expect the company to break even. She shrugged off speculation that QXL is a prime takeover target, saying: "For us it's business as usual."

The company's calamitous fall from grace has seen it join the "99% club" - an exclusive group of dot.coms which have seen their share prices lose 99% of their value.

QXL's stock was worth 800p at the height of last year's dot.com boom, but slumped to just 6.5p in December.

Nonetheless, analysts say QXL's future as a standalone company is uncertain, and the share and bonds issue will be used to shore up the company's finances ahead of a takeover.

The company's value has slumped from £2bn to about £75m, with £65m cash in the bank.

QXL's troubles began with the acquisition last year of German rival Ricardo, which caused losses of £67.7m between June and September last year, on turnover of just £5.9m.

Analysts fear that US-based eBay will be too strong a competitor in the battle to dominate the European online auction market.

QXL recently appointed Telewest chief Adam Singer as a non-executive director, hoping that the cable company boss would help restore the company's fortunes.

webTitle: Clinton's farewell speech sets out stall for Bush

fields.headline: Clinton's farewell speech sets out stall for Bush
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: As his successor, George W Bush, celebrated with a rally at the Lincoln memorial in Washington DC, President Clinton last night delivered his farewell speech from the Oval office.
fields.body:
As his successor, George W Bush, celebrated with a rally at the Lincoln memorial in Washington DC, President Clinton last night delivered his farewell speech from the Oval office, calling the last eight years a time of "dramatic upheaval" and an "era of great American renewal."

Mr Clinton - who has one of the highest popularity ratings of any outgoing president - recalled the accomplishments of his administration during the televised address and highlighted the same issue that saw him elected in 1992: the economy.

"Our economy is breaking records with more than 22m new jobs, the lowest unemployment in 30 years, the highest home ownership ever, the longest expansion in history," he said.

The speech carefully avoided any reference to the humiliating sex scandal or the bitter impeachment battle that overshadowed his second term in office. But the president did not bow out without a parting shot for the next administration.

He called on president-elect Bush to continue the Clinton administration's work to pay off the national debt, to continue to intervene overseas to advance American interests and to tackle racism across the country.

He said: "America must maintain our record of fiscal responsibility. Through our last four budgets, we've turned record deficits to record surpluses and we've been able to pay down $600bn of our national debt, on track to be debt-free by the end of the decade for the first time since 1835."

Obviously fearing that Mr Bush will put foreign policy on the back burner, Mr Clinton made a plea for continued involvement overseas.

He told the nation, "Global poverty is a powder keg that could be ignited by our indifference. In his first inaugural address, Thomas Jefferson warned of entangling alliances. But in our times, America cannot and must not disentangle itself from the world. If we want the world to embody our shared values, then we must assume a shared responsibility."

Mr Clinton's future career has been the subject of much speculation, especially as he will continue to live in Washington. He made no announcements about his future in the speech, saying only that he would "never hold a position higher or a covenant more sacred than that of president."

Outside the White House, Pennsylvania Avenue was lined with thousands of bleachers and a gleaming white presidential reviewing stand for the inaugural parade. Mr Bush was in residence at the Blair House, the presidential guesthouse.

Mr Clinton has issued a blizzard of executive orders and environmental actions in recent days, and presidential pardons are due to be issued today. Also anticipated is removal of economic and trade sanctions against Yugoslavia and the release of remaining money - about $100m (£70m) - in a $1.3bn Colombian anti-drug aid package.

fields.headline: More jobs go at Talkcast
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Online media and telecoms business Talkcast has confirmed a further round of job cuts, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Online media and telecoms business Talkcast has confirmed a further round of staff cuts.

The business is bracing itself for more negative sentiment in the business-to-consumer market.

Gone are the "e-magazines" and the planned internet health operations, leaving the company to focus on wireless applications and its media rights business.

To bolster its wireless services, Talkcast has just launched Games Engine, an SMS-based interactive game. This is being offered as a marketing tool for brand owners.

In the past two weeks, Talkcast has reduced its staff base by 30. The company now has just 40 staff - a far cry from the 140 employed last July.

The fresh departures add to the 25 that left when Sharecast, a financial website, was sold to Talkcast shareholder Durlacher in November.

All 25 are believed to have been taken on by Durlacher.

The streamlining efforts are also expected to affect the senior management team, although, at this stage, it is not certain who will leave.

Former News International marketing director Ellis Watson resigned as Talkcast's joint CEO in July last year after the company decided to focus on technology.

"We have structured our company to enable it to take advantage of any opportunities that present themselves, but with a cost base and a focus that make it nimble," said Philip Ranger, corporate communications director at Talkcast.

"Our wireless applications have always been at the core of the company," he added.

"The network operators have to find ways of making money out of data transmission - we believe this is the focus that will succeed."

Texer.com, the company's SMS service that was used for Channel 5's Jailbreak show, will now only be used as a showcase for the application itself.

fields.headline: Showdown looms for Letsbuyit.com
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: John Palmer, founder of the troubled online retailer Letsbuyit.com, reacted angrily yesterday to reports that the trustees were planning to claim in court today that the company had been deplorable and chaotic, and should be closed down.
fields.body:
John Palmer, founder of the troubled online retailer Letsbuyit.com, reacted angrily yesterday to reports that the trustees were planning to claim in court today that the company had been deplorable and chaotic, and should be closed down.

The Dutch court-appointed trustees, Van Doorne, are reported to have said that boardroom squabbles were among the reasons for Letsbuyit's demise, with estimated liabilities of 20m euros (£12.8m).

A furious Mr Palmer said the trustees' claims of management problems were inaccurate but did not surprise him. "They wouldn't have a clue," he said last night.

He added that he had not given up hope of persuading them that Letsbuyit, which pools consumers in order to buy goods in bulk at low prices, was a viable business and could survive if given time.

Van Doorne said in a statement: "The coming two weeks up to January 31 will be key factors in determining up to what extent creditors .. will be settled." Letsbuyit's largest creditor is thought to be US technology support company, Sykes, which is owed a total of 7.5m euros (£4.8m).

Other major creditors are understood to include Hewlett Packard, Icon Media and WinEasy, as well as several marketing and hardware companies.

Shares in Letsbuyit all but evaporated yesterday, plummeting 43.48% to 0.26 euros (£0.17) after a trading suspension was lifted by the Frankfurt Neuer Markt. Trade in the stock had been halted on Wednesday when Van Doorne announced it was filing for bankruptcy.

This gives Letsbuyit a market capitalisation of just 4.6m euros (£2.9m) compared with a high in July last year of 115m euros (£74m).

Although Van Doorne has been collaborating with Mr Palmer in an effort to attract a rescue bid for Letsbuyit, the stage now looks set for a showdown between the the trustees and management at the district court in Amsterdam this morning.

webTitle: TV's Buffy to star in Scooby-Doo movie

fields.headline: TV's Buffy to star in Scooby-Doo movie
fields.trailText: Sarah Michelle Gellar will star with real-life partner Freddie Prinze Jr in the film version of the famous animated television series
fields.body:
Sarah Michelle Gellar is to play Daphne in the forthcoming live action version of Scooby-Doo, the latest in a plethora of planned films based on cartoons (others include Spider-Man and Hulk).

According to Ananova, Gellar, the star of TV's Buffy the Vampire Slayer, will juggle her schedule to work on both the cult series and the film version of the television cartoon.

Daphne's boyfriend Fred will be played by Gellar's real-life love interest Freddie Prinze Jr, while Scooby will be played by a host of special effects.

Rumours that Gellar was in the running for the role of Daphne have been flying around for months, but other casting suggestions for the film, including Christina Ricci (who was once mooted for Daphne) or Ricki Lake as Velma, seem unlikely to come true.

Linda Cardellini (known in the US for playing geek-turned-freak Lindsay Weir on the television series Freaks and Geeks) has been confirmed as Velma, with Scream star Matthew Lillard playing Shaggy.

The film, to be directed by Raja Gosnell (Big Momma's House and Never Been Kissed) is due out next year. Scooby-Doo remains one of the most popular cartoon characters on television with tribute pages galore.

 More about Scooby-Doo.

fields.headline: Hall takes top job at Hello!
fields.trailText: 12pm: Hello! is set to confirm the appointment of Phil Hall, former News of the World editor, as editor-in-chief, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Hello! magazine will confirm today that Phil Hall, former editor of the News of the World, is to join the magazine as editor-in-chief.

And Maggie Kuomi is to stand down as editor.

Hello! publishing director Sally Cartwright confirmed that "in the short term", Ms Kuomi would not continue with the editorship.

Ms Cartwright was unwilling to discuss whether Ms Kuomi would be replaced.

Ms Cartwright said: "Maggie is going to have a very well-earned sabbatical." But she added that Hello!'s owner, Eduardo Sanchez, wanted Ms Kuomi to continue to play a role within the organisation.

The move ends heated speculation about the future role of Mr Hall, who has repeatedly assured the press he would not be taking the job.

Since leaving his position as editor of the News of the World, Mr Hall has worked with PR guru Max Clifford and has taken an active role in the overhaul of Punch magazine for his client, Mohamed Al Fayed.

The stakes have been raised for Hello! by Richard Desmond's acquisition of the Express newspapers and the prospect of cross-fertilisation between the titles.

webTitle: Is now the time to join the buy-to-let bandwagon?

fields.headline: Is now the time to join the buy-to-let bandwagon?
fields.trailText: Soaring rents in UK hotspots such as London, the Thames Valley and parts of the west country, are fuelling the buy to let mortgage market.
fields.body:
Soaring rents in UK hotspots such as London, the Thames Valley and parts of the west country, are fuelling the buy to let mortgage market.

But, while first rate returns and capital growth can be achieved, those wanting a piece of the action the need to do their homework. If not, the novice landlord can be left with an unwanted and unprofitable property that could create huge financial problems.

Owning a second home that is let out to good tenants can be a fantastic investment.

According to Bradford & Bingley letting agencies, average returns on rented properties are 8%. It says nationally average yields range from 6% for a detached four-bedroom house to 8% for a two-bedroom flat.

It is predicted that demand for rented property will grow because of the high divorce rate, job mobility and the fact that many people can't afford to buy a home.

But buying to let is far from risk free. At the same time, many people who have opted for the supposedly safer route of investments and pensions and been disappointed by the returns, may be looking for an alternative.

The disastrous situation at Equitable Life, which has closed to new business and could leave hundreds of investors out of pocket, has cast a shadow over the whole pensions industry and a rented property can return a higher and regular income.

Yet, while renting may continue to bring in an income, landlords also have to be prepared for pitfalls. These could be that rent is withheld or that tenants cause damage.

A property could also be left vacant if there is too much rented property on the market meaning the landlord could potentially have to pay for two mortgages. A property slump could also affect the property's value and make it hard to resell.

Then there are costs. Heavy repair bills are a possibility and a property is also likely to need decorating and furnishing. Insurance is also required.

Then there is the cost of a letting and managing agency. A reputable agency can help with finding quality tenants, dealing with any problems and ensuring there are no voids. Any landlord who also has a full time job or does not live locally may find using an agency essential. Any agency used should always be registered with ARLA (the association of residential letting agents).

Agents tend to charge around 10 to 12% of the gross annual rent for finding tenants and 6% for managing the property.

All these costs add up and landlords could lose up to 30% of their projected income through these.

Buy to let mortgages also cost more than those aimed at buyers who simply want to own and live in their home.

But, there are now far better deals on the market. Bristol & West has recently improved its terms and is offering rates at below 9% - something unheard of several years ago.

Lenders have different criteria when it comes to weighing up the potential of a buy to let property. Among the factors likely to be taken into consideration are the borrower's income and what the property is likely to bring in compared to the mortgage outgoings. Bristol & West requires the expected rent to be 125% of the rate being paid.

If you are considering investing in property, you need to provide the lender with a sizeable deposit - most will require at least 25% as a down payment, although a few will accept 15%.

There is also far more choice of lenders with over 50 buy to let mortgage providers on the market. For inexperienced landlords it is worth taking advice from either an independent financial adviser or a mortgage introducer who follows the Mortgage Code.

Pink Home Loans, for example, allows borrowers to take payment holidays and reduce the term. Reserves built up in the account can be used to finance school fees or the purchase of car, for example, at the mortgage rate instead of higher personal loan rates. It requires the rental yield to be at least 130% of the interest rate at the non-discounted or capped rate.

The Woolwich offers a range of buy to let mortgages. Its Open Plan mortgage allows those with equity in an existing home to be released and a second property bought with this. A spokeswoman said this could prove a popular option with parents looking to buy flats for children going to university.

Once the deposit is secured, the next challenge for the aspiring landlord is to select the right area. The aim is to choose somewhere that will not only mean there will be a plentiful supply of tenants but where the value of the property will also rise. London rents are highest, but so are property prices, which means looking outside the capital can yield a better bargain.

Areas with large student populations are popular with landlords, since less can be spent on furniture and rooms can be let out on an individual basis. Student rents vary, but are typically around £50 a week.

Landlords also need to be aware of tax implications. These apply should you wish to sell a property that is not your main residence. But, if you plan to keep the property as an income-generating investment for retirement, this may never affect you. Interest on a buy-to-let mortgage can be offset against tax, but the capital repayments cannot. Repairs can also be offset against the tax, but new furniture and fittings cannot.

fields.headline: How can you spot a Michelin inspector?
fields.standfirst: The truth is, we'll never know, reports  Victoria Moore
fields.trailText: The truth is, we'll never know, reports Victoria Moore
fields.body:
This morning, hundreds of chefs up and down the country will be rifling with sweating fingers through the new edition of our gastronomic bible, the 2001 Michelin Red Guide, desperate to find out whether they have managed to hang on to, or be awarded, a precious Michelin star.

Yet despite its tremendous cachet, the machinations of the Michelin guide and its prized star system are as mysterious as those of MI6. There might be an annual ruckus around its publication, but one can no more phone Michelin and question one of its inspectors than waltz into MI6 and ask to speak to one of its best spies.

It's true that while the MI6 building sits amid a cloud of radio-interference just one mile from Westminster, the HQ of the Michelin Red Guide lies in rather less grand surroundings, a few doors down from the office of the Inland Revenue in Watford. But it is said that Michelin inspectors' identities are as carefully guarded as state secrets.

The status of these near-mythical creatures is such that restaurants will always keep half an eye out for one. Those in the know say that the best way for the rest of us to ensure tip-top service in a restaurant that aspires to excellence is to: (a) dine alone (Michelin inspectors eat two full-scale meals a day for three weeks out of every four - the guide could not possibly afford to pay for dining companions as well); (b) order the specialities of the house (to be avoided at all costs are little-effort-required kitchen staples such as smoked salmon - inspectors always choose the most testing dishes, homemade terrines, for example); (c) be a man (it is generally believed that Michelin inspectors are men).

So what is known of these inspectors who can make or break a chef's career? Well, they number 10 (eight men, two women), are in their 30s and 40s, and are all British. That is all.

And despite what you might think, theirs is not an easy life. Unlike a spy, a Michelin inspector is permitted to reveal his (or her) occupation to his friends and family, but his visits to restaurants, aside from one "announced visit" every year, must be done incognito. His time is spent, for the most part, on the road, sent off for two or three weeks to a specific area of Britain or Ireland, his working day starting at 8am, visiting six hotels and eating at two restaurants before he goes to bed at around 11pm.

It is up to the inspector to ensure that no stone in his allocated area is left unturned. Every establishment that has won a place in the current guide receives a visit. Beyond that, the best way for an inspector to ferret out good places is by asking locals, but the Yellow Pages, newspaper, tourist offices, other guidebooks and readers' opinions are also canvassed.

Nothing is written down inside the place being inspected. "Having a notepad beside you would give things away straight away," says the current editor, who, wishing to remain nameless, shall be referred to as M. "That's why you need very good concentration and a good memory." Instead, the Michelin inspector will slip to the toilet with his notebook or scribble down the details of his meal as soon as he gets back to his car.

A Michelin inspector must be highly accomplished. "We look for people with an appreciation for the finer things in life," says M. "A knowledge of architecture, or furnishings, for instance, is very useful. If they're going to say somewhere is antique furnished, they need to know that it is."

An inspector must also be a good decision-maker, and a good observer. "You need to be able to walk round a hotel, say, appearing fully absorbed in the conversation you're having with them, while taking in every detail."

What is not necessary is to be able to dissect the contents of a restaurant dish. A Michelin inspector need not be able to identify, say, that a tomato has been grown in France and ripened on the vine. "The question is: does it taste good? You can get too tied up with asking if the bread was homemade on the premises or not. If it's delicious, but made somewhere else, does it matter? Not really."

M ought to know. A former inspector, he now shoulders the burden of maintaining a consistent standard of inspection. In 20 years of professional eating in restaurants, he has had food poisoning six times, once had to sleep in his hotel bath because of bats in his room, and has found himself marooned on remote Scottish islands on several occasions.

One of the strangest episodes in his seven-year inspecting career occurred in a Thai restaurant in South Wales. "Dinner proceeded normally up to the main course, when the staff suddenly vanished and reappeared dressed in normal clothes, sitting at a table in the restaurant. There was an immigration raid. The waiters didn't have work permits and so they transformed into customers while the real customers waited hungrily at their tables until the raid was over."

So how are Michelin inspectors recruited? The guide places an ad in the trade press asking for an inspector. A few basic qualifications are necessary: an HND in hotel and catering is a must, plus substantial experience at managerial level in hotels, and as a chef in a reputable restaurant. Ideally, an applicant would be aged 28-35.

The final three candidates are taken out for a meal and told to write a report in the Michelin style. Once selected, a trainee will shadow an experienced Michelin man for four to six months before being sent out alone.

But what restaurateurs want to know is how to win a coveted star. Not by overt showing off. "I think the most difficult thing in cooking is to create a very elaborate dish but to present it to make it look quite simple," says M. "Most of the dishes at Troisgros, in France, which has three Michelin stars, fit the bill. Their salmon with sorrel appears very simple, but they've raised it to such a height that it becomes a masterpiece. The great chefs refine and refine and refine, taking out any unnecessary flavours."

In the 2000 guide, there were 98 starred restaurants. This year there are 103. Every year there are two dozen or so in the running for a first star. Each will receive a visit from M. All restaurants being examined for a star will be eaten in about six times, by different inspectors choosing different menus at different times.

The Michelin guide has moved on in the past few years. It may surprise some to hear that it boasts more Italian and Indian restaurants than French. It also focuses on value for money, with the "bib gourmand", an award to places where one can eat very well for less than £25 a head.

But the level of secrecy and objectivity remains undiminished, aside from one small (no doubt accidental) confession from the great M himself, who admits he's "not a great fan of olives or anchovies". Not, of course, that he would allow his personal tastes to shape his judgment.

webTitle: Worldwide extent of net baby sales emerges

fields.headline: Worldwide extent of net baby sales emerges
fields.trailText: Last night the extent of the worldwide internet trade in babies began to emerge as the FBI said it had opened a preliminary investigation into the case.
fields.body:
Last night the extent of the worldwide internet trade in babies began to emerge as the FBI said it had opened a preliminary investigation into the case.

The organisation said it was also probing claims that several couples had paid to adopt babies advertised on the net but were then left without a child or their money.

It follows the sale by baby broker Tina Johnson of the six- month-old twins before they were taken back and sold to Alan and Judith Kilshaw.

It emerged that babies are regularly advertised on the web with details of their health, age, and skin and hair colour. Prices start from about £5,000.

America is leading the way with a host of adoption web-sites aimed at attracting couples desperate for a child and willing to pay.

Last night reports told how would-be parents could click onto any state on a coloured map of America and type in requirements. Within seconds row upon row of children appeared, all apparently waiting for adoption.

However, there were comparatively few white, American born babies on the internet market. Most of the new arrivals are flown in from eastern Europe, China, Latin American countries and the former Soviet Union.

An indication of the enormous scale of the US baby market can be gauged by www.adopting.org whose logo is a variation on the Michelangelo fresco in the Sistine Chapel. A tiny baby's hand grips a parent's finger against a background of clouds.

The site has had 2.1m visitors since it was launched four years ago. It offers information on how to contact US-based international adoption agencies, profiles of prospec tive parents, and adoption advice to single parents.

One baby advertised on the website CaliforniaKidsConnection.com is named Elia, a five-year-old described as a "lovely and energetic" Hispanic girl who is legally freed for adoption.

She is described as having a "wonderful sense of humour and will keep you laughing".

The advert warns:"Elia has a cleft palate which impairs her speech.

"She has had two surgeries for her palate and will require more surgery in future. She is in special education classes. Elia needs a loving adoptive home where her special needs will be met."

Last night Liv O'Hanlon, director of the pressure group The Adoption Forum, said she was revolted by the idea of buying a baby over the internet.

"Adoption over the internet just seems revolting from start to finish," she said.

webTitle: Social services take internet twins into care

fields.headline: Social services take internet twins into care
fields.standfirst: Adoptive parents vow to challenge seizure of babies
fields.trailText: Police and social workers swooped on a north Wales hotel late last night and took into care the twin sisters bought on the internet from America.
fields.body:
Police and social workers swooped on a north Wales hotel late last night and took into care the twin sisters bought on the internet from America.

As cameras flashed, the sleeping babies were removed by Flintshire social services staff, following a tense three-hour confrontation with adoptive parents Alan and Judith Kilshaw which also involved police and a paediatrician.

The girls, wearing matching pink fleece hats and wrapped in blankets, did not make a sound as social workers carried them in car seats through a crowd of photographers. They were placed in the back of a red Mondeo and driven away.

Speaking from the Beaufort Park hotel, where the family had been staying, Detective Inspector Nick Crabtree of North Wales police said: "Shortly before 9.50pm tonight an emergency protection order granted under the Children's Act 1989 was served on Mr and Mrs Kilshaw.

"Belinda and Kimberley are safe and well and are now in the care of social services."

Asked whether the Kilshaws had offered any resistance, Det Insp Crabtree replied: "There was no trouble. It was a very difficult situation for them."

An emotional Mrs Kilshaw claimed that her two sons, aged four and seven, had also been removed, although this could not be confirmed.

"They have taken my sons into care," she said between sobs. "People who have met my sons know they are loved, looked after and wanted as the girls were."

Mrs Kilshaw, 47, said she wished she could have fled the country before the girls were taken, adding: "I don't think that they will ever let me see them again."

Speaking from a hotel room littered with baby clothes, she complained: "I didn't break the law and yet I have been hounded like a criminal.

She added: "The gutter press have got what they wanted. I have been made out to be terrible. That's helped the social services in their case."

Mr Kilshaw, 45, appeared more upbeat and said that he and his wife would challenge the order. "I have spoken to a specialist childcare lawyer and we will be making an application to the courts, basically to cancel this order as soon as possible, hopefully tomorrow," he said.

The girls were last night thought to be in the care of foster parents - their fourth set of primary care givers in only six months of life.

Their birth mother, Tranda Wecker, 28, yesterday told CBS News in America that she had received "not a dime" from the adoptions and claimed she wanted to bring the children up herself.

"I really want my babies back. I really do," she said. A third couple also stepped into the row, saying they too had been offered the twins by baby broker Tina Johnson.

The sisters were first placed with Californians Vickie and Richard Allen, who paid more than £4,000 to arrange the adoption. But two months later Ms Johnson and Ms Wecker snatched the babies back and gave them to the Kilshaws, who had paid £8,200.

The couple, from Buckley, Wales, fled California and drove to Arkansas to carry out a fast-track adoption. Its legality was last night being questioned by American experts.

The row has reverberated across the Atlantic, with the prime minister and home secretary both expressing disgust at the trade in international adoptions over the internet. But last night the focus was on what lay ahead for the sisters.

Keith McDonogh, director of education and children's services at Flintshire county council, said in a statement: "After careful evaluation of all the circumstances and available guidance, Flintshire social workers visited the family again today at their hotel and sought the cooperation of the adoptive parents in making further assessments of the well-being of the children."

Friends and relatives of the family left the hotel in tears last night, claiming the removal was unjustified. Barbara Sant, who has looked after the twins since they arrived in Britain, said: "I really don't understand what is happening. The girls have been happy since they got here. I'm astonished that they took them."

Mrs Kilshaw's 18-year-old daughter Cayley, from a previous relationship, was seen running through the hotel in tears.

Before the babies' removal from the Kilshaws, their birth mother had told ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald programme: "I feel that the Kilshaws need to come back to the United States to settle this adoption.

She added: "If the social services put them in foster care, then everybody loses."

Asked whether she wanted the twins back, Ms Wecker replied: "Financially, I cannot give them the world but I love my girls."

A US family lawyer yesterday said the babies must be returned to America so their future could be decided in the courts.

The sisters were first placed with Californians Vickie and Richard Allen, who paid more than £4,000 to arrange the adoption. But two months later Ms Johnson and Ms Wecker snatched the babies back and gave them to the Kilshaws, who had paid £8,200. The couple, from Buckley, Wales, fled California and drove to Arkansas to carry out a fast-track adoption. Its legality was last night being questioned by American experts. The row has reverberated across the Atlantic, with the prime minister and home secretary both expressing disgust at the trade in international adoptions over the internet. But last night the focus was on what lay ahead for the sisters. Keith McDonogh, director of education and children's services at Flintshire county council, said in a statement: "After careful evaluation of all the circumstances and available guidance, Flintshire social workers visited the family again today at their hotel and sought the cooperation of the adoptive parents in making further assessments of the well-being of the children." Friends and relatives of the family left the hotel in tears last night, claiming the removal was unjustified. Barbara Sant, who has looked after the twins since they arrived in Britain, said: "I really don't understand what is happening. The girls have been happy since they got here. I'm astonished that they took them." Mrs Kilshaw's 18-year-old daughter Cayley, from a previous relationship, was seen running through the hotel in tears. Before the babies' removal from the Kilshaws, their birth mother had told ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald programme: "I feel that the Kilshaws need to come back to the United States to settle this adoption. She added: "If the social services put them in foster care, then everybody loses." Asked whether she wanted the twins back, Ms Wecker replied: "Financially, I cannot give them the world but I love my girls." A US family lawyer yesterday said the babies must be returned to America so their future could be decided in the courts. fields.headline: Profile of Lord Laming
fields.trailText: Former chief inspector of social services Lord Laming of Tewin is one of the UK's most distinguished social workers, and a veteran of several government inquiries and policy groups.
fields.body:
Former chief inspector of social services Lord Laming of Tewin is one of the UK's most distinguished social workers, and a veteran of several government inquiries and policy groups.

The row over his appointment to the Climbié inquiry is the second time in the past two months he has found himself at the centre of controversy.

In December last year he stepped down as head of the Harold Shipman inquiry after relatives of the victims of the murderous Greater Manchester GP won a judicial review forcing the inquiry to be held in public.

Health secretary Alan Milburn widened the scope of the inquiry and replaced Lord Laming with senior high court judge Dame Janet Smith.

The Climbié inquiry will examine the conduct of professionals in the NHS, social services, housing departments and police across four London boroughs.

In January last year Lord Laming headed a Home Office inquiry into raising standards at underperforming prisons.

He was born in Newcastle and trained as a probation officer in Nottingham until moving to Hertfordshire county council in 1971.

He was appointed director of social services in Hertfordshire in 1975. He left in 1991 to become chief inspector of social services, retiring in 1998.

He was knighted in 1996 and made a life peer in 1998.

His other posts include vice president of the local government association, treasurer of the parliamentary all-party group on local government, president of the national homecare association and a patron of Coram family, the UK's oldest children's charity.

webTitle: E4 launch night: the industry verdict

fields.headline: E4 launch night: the industry verdict
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Channel 4's new E4 channel launched last night amid a blaze of publicity. MediaGuardian.co.uk asked two ad executives for their verdict, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
E4, Channel 4's brave new channel for disaffected youth, launched last night amid a blaze of publicity.

Apart from the barmy Japanese-style game show Banzai and a few links from Ali G, the first night looked like a Warner Brothers channel - with two episodes of Friends and an hour of ER.

MediaGuardian.co.uk asked two esteemed advertising executives to give their verdict

Martin Smith, chief executive of Grey Worldwide

Mine is a very typical north London middle-class home. Once a year, a frisson of excitement disturbs the usual calm as information on a new series of Friends or ER sends all teenage, female members of my family into a frenzy.

Part of this behaviour is due to the programmes themselves. They're pretty good. Part is due to the sheer joy derived from there being, for once, something other than repeats to watch. So rare.

But more important than any of this, the excitement revolves around whether my kids will see these programmes first before their friends at school, ie before they're on Channel 4 a few weeks later.

Last year, therefore, Sky One was the all-important provider of satisfaction in the intensely competitive world of teeny oneupmanship. This year, it's God Bless E4. (You have no idea how many times in the last few weeks I have been asked by my daughters whether we can receive E4 as part of our cable package. Yes, Yes, YES!).

But is that really all it's about? In reviewing the launch day of this new channel, is there really nothing to say other than they got to transmit the new series of the old faithfuls first this year?

But what else is there to say? I suppose I had hoped that E4 could do for light entertainment programming what FilmFour did for the more serious stuff: become a major provider and creator of new shows. But on the evidence of Night One, I am not holding my breath.

Having said that, I am sure a lot of teenage girls have been made very happy by last night's offering. And anyway, in the words of E4's gangsta presenta, what do I know, Cos iz in da meeja, innit?

David Cuff, broadcast director, Initiative Media

The BBC talks genre-based channels, C4 just does it. Only 18 years old, yet they give birth to their second new channel. Have they laid another golden egg?

C4 scheduled Lost Gardens opposite E4, hoping younger fans would do the right thing. E4 is overtly trying to position itself as the best digital entertainment channel for youth.

This new C4 "variant" is broadcasting more of the mad, bad, studenty programmes that may now irritate the more mature C4 viewers such as the Japanese-style betting show, Banzai, in which viewers are asked to place bets on things like the weight of chef Nancy Lam's breast.

The schedule is bolstered by Friends, ER, Hollyoaks and Dawson's Creek - although ER doesn't fit into E4's youthful and trashy aesthetic. The previewed home-grown programmes are packed with attractive hopefuls trying to be sexy and humorous but strangely I was reminded of the Woodentops.

While E4 hopes for a halo effect from C4's current success with youth, C4 itself risks debasing its own currency with E4. Plus its digital first runs for Friends and others will grate with many viewers.

New TV channels rarely prosper with the personalities or schedules that they launch with but I still expect E4 to eventually earn its place in the portfolio of channel favourites for most youngsters in digital homes.

fields.headline: Glamour girls
fields.standfirst: Afraid of 70s style?  Hadley Freeman on how to make it work for you
fields.trailText: Afraid of 70s style? Hadley Freeman on how to make it work for you
fields.body:
OK, I admit it. I don't like the 70s. I hate the music, I hate the TV shows, I hate the flares. I even hate Bohemian Rhapsody. Or I thought I did until last month, during the party season, when I realised that the previously dreaded decade was actually the backbone of my wardrobe. Shiny satin panelling, gold trims, glittery mules - all of my party outfits, shockingly, undeniably, could have belonged to Marc Bolan's (slightly less outré) younger sister.

This winter the glam influence has been particularly prominent, providing us with sartorial Prozac in the grey cold. After all, who cares about the weather when you're a vision of sparkles? Stand-out items include Clements Ribeiro's glittery striped top, Senzo's gold stiletto ankle boots and the plethora of dangly diamanté earrings. All show the influence of 70s glam applied to more contemporary trends (stripes and ankle boots are very in, don't you know), stopping you looking like a walking anachronism or an extra from the Abba musical.

The forthcoming release of the much hyped Cameron Crowe film Almost Famous, which is set in the 70s rock world, will perpetuate the look. This movie succeeds where many others have failed: it makes the 70s look good. It demonstrates, on the now ubiquitous Kate Hudson, that you can look sexily sparkly without resembling a wannabe five-year-old with a Claire's Accessories habit.

Learn from the past masters on how to carry off glam with aplomb. Have a good rummage through Mum's old wardrobe for selected items. In the currently vintage-crazed fashion world, wearing the genuine article instead of a derivative copy is pretty much the style Holy Grail.

Equally, glam clothes re-interpreted by today's young designers, such as PPQ and Preen, have a pleasingly cutting-edge bite to them. A fitted denim trench or boots in fake snakeskin, for example, show yesterday's timeless classics brushed with today's touch. Just as Kate Hudson looks like an updated, funkier Goldie Hawn, retro-influenced clothes need a similar touch. Remember, it's the best of glam we're after, not the 70s themselves.

So dig out your mum's long satin dresses and tailored blouses, but leave her flares and platforms. Stardust without the Ziggy, if you will. To paraphrase Kim Basinger in LA Confidential, all girls need a little glamour in their lives. Glam - it's how I learnt to stop worrying and love the 70s.

fields.headline: Overexposed...
fields.standfirst: ... the perfect pair of jeans
fields.trailText: ... the perfect pair of jeans
fields.body:
A mere five years ago, jeans seemed doomed to fashion ignominy. Baggy combats were in and denim was passé. But fashion is a capricious creature and we finally realised combats make one's bum the size of a bus and denim is back, on the catwalks and in the stores.

Now every single denim company is promising that they have created The Perfect Pair of Jeans, making you look slim of hip and lithe of limb. Earl, Diesel, McQueen, Katayone Adeli, Levi's Twisted Engineered Jeans - we've heard the same guff from them all and it carries on with the launch of Levi's SuperLows (not yet available here, making them even more desirable), which have had such luminaries as Christine Aguilera and Jennifer Lopez squealing that these are, yes, The Perfect Pair of Jeans.

Shall I let you into a little secret? Shall I? Here goes: everyone is built differently. Your perfect pair of jeans is someone else's fashion and body-image disaster because different styles suit different people. As we all know, jeans are a very personal item of clothing. So anyone who trots out this deeply tired fashion cliché should be treated with as much suspicion as anyone who promises that such and such is "the new black" or "the new pashmina". In other words, they almost certainly work for a fashion PR company. You have been warned.

fields.headline: Virginia
fields.trailText: We love it when fashion and charity mix. You shop and, instead of those irritating pangs of retail guilt, you can give yourself a little pat on the head. How good is that?
fields.body:
We love it when fashion and charity mix. You shop and, instead of those irritating pangs of retail guilt, you can give yourself a little pat on the head. How good is that?

This winter, west London fashion combines with a good cause. On February 9-11, Notting Hill boutique The Cross is holding a charity sale for the Ralph Bates Pancreatic Cancer Research Fund. Sale stock from the likes of Chloe, Lulu Guinness and Martin Kidman will be on offer at 70% off.

Ralph Bates died 10 years ago, just eight weeks after pancreatic cancer was diagnosed. His wife, Virginia, owner of the eponymous vintage clothing shop, set up the fund and all money raised goes to the Ralph Bates Research Laboratory at St George's Hospital in London.

It is 26 years since Virginia began working at the shop to make money between acting stints (you might have spotted her as the temptress in A Clockwork Orange). Virginia was one of Notting Hill's best kept secrets until certain blabber-mouthed supermodels were unable to keep it to themselves. Be warned: once you spot that perfect sequined tulle dress in the shop, you may find yourself grappling with Naomi Campbell, Nicole Kidman, John Galliano or Madonna to get your hands on it. And remember: elegant vintage fashion in mint condition doesn't come cheap. You might be able to dig up something for £80, but most things will have one or two more zeros in the price tag.

But at least you'll be able to afford something equally desirable at the charity sale held by The Cross - Virginia's very generous Notting Hill neighbours.

 The Cross charity sale is on February 9-11, 11am-6pm, at 20th Century Theatre, 291 Westbourne Grove, London W11.
Virginia is at 98 Portland Rd, London W11, 020-7727 9908.
For information on the Ralph Bates Pancreatic Cancer Research Fund, tel 020-7727 9908

fields.headline: Climbié inquiry chief under fire
fields.trailText: Calls for an independent children's commissioner for England were stepped up today after a row erupted over the track record of the former social work director appointed to head the Climbié inquiry.
fields.body:
Calls for an independent children's commissioner for England were stepped up today after a row erupted over the track record of the former social work director appointed to head the Climbié inquiry.

MPs raised questions about the choice of Lord Laming to lead the inquiry into the death of Anna Climbié, who suffered a horrific catalogue of abuse at the hands of an aunt and her boyfriend.

The killers of eight-year-old Anna were sentenced to life imprisonment earlier this month at the Old Bailey.

Concerns were revealed after it emerged that Lord Laming was director of a social services department which was harshly criticised for its handling of a child abuse case.

Former chief inspector of social services Lord Laming headed Hertfordshire county council's social services department at the time of the 1990 case, which led to the local government ombudsman making a finding of maladministration with injustice, the strongest criticism open to him.

Liberal Democrat health spokesman Paul Burstow told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that the issue demonstrated the need for an independent children's commissioner.

He said: "If we are to restore confidence in our child protection system, we have to have an independent children's commissioner who is able to stand outside the system and oversee investigation into child deaths and abuse scandals."

But the Department of Health insisted it was confident that Lord Laming was the right person to head the inquiry.

It called Lord Laming "an immensely experienced professional with over 40 years' service", and said it was "fully confident that he is the right person to conduct the inquiry".

It said: "We are aware that a complaint was made in 1990. Part of this complaint was upheld in a decision by the local government ombudsman in 1995, four years after Lord Laming had moved to another post.

"Whilst in post, Lord Laming took a personal interest in making sure that all complaints were properly addressed."

But Mr Burstow said: "The findings of the ombudsman in the Hertfordshire case must give rise to questions about Lord Laming's appointment to head this inquiry."

Mr Burstow stressed that he was not calling for Lord Laming to be removed from the inquiry, saying that it was possible that his experiences in Hertfordshire might aid his understanding of how social service work can go wrong.

But he added: "If we are to restore confidence in our child protection system, we have to have an independent children's commissioner who is able to stand outside the system and oversee investigation into child deaths and abuse scandals, rather than having the secretary of state involved, and thus questions of this sort arising when it comes to light that a director of social services has a less than flawless record."

Tory health spokesman Liam Fox said: "This is not the best start to a very sensitive inquiry, it puts him [Lord Laming] in a very difficult position in what will be a very difficult inquiry.

"I think the government maybe should have thought twice about this and maybe, even yet, they will think again."

webTitle: Veteran star of MGM musicals dies

fields.headline: Veteran star of MGM musicals dies
fields.trailText: Virginia O'Brien, known as Miss Frozen Face for her deadpan style, was one of the most popular stars during the heyday of the MGM musical
fields.body:
Singer-comedienne Virginia O'Brien has died aged 79. The actress, who was nicknamed "Miss Frozen Face" because of her signature deadpan delivery in the MGM musicals of the 40s, died in hospital on Thursday, reports Reuters. She became famous for her unique singing style, accompanied by an expressionless, wide-eyed stare, which she used to great effect as a comic singer.

The former wife of the late actor Kirk Alyn, the first movie Superman, O'Brien was discovered, aged 17, by Louis B Mayer when she was making her stage debut. Two weeks later she signed a film contract with MGM and she went on to star in nearly 20 of the studio's musicals.

Her most famous movies include Thousands Cheer, starring Gene Kelly, Kathryn Grayson, Mary Astor and Judy Garland, and Dubarry was a Lady, opposite comedian Red Skelton.

She sang Rockabye Baby to the Marx Brothers in The Big Store and The Wild Wild West in The Harvey Girls. She also joined Donald O'Connor for one of his famous comedy films about a talking mule, Francis in the Navy.

While under contract to MGM, O'Brien continued to have voice lessons and also took up the piano and by 1942 she was commanding as much as $5,000 a week for personal appearances. She also made numerous guest appearances on television shows.

O'Brien was married three times. She is survived by three daughters, a son, seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours are wondering whether a large proportion of tabloid journalists have taken the day off
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough hope to sign Bradford midfielder Dean Windass today for £1m.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough hope to sign Bradford midfielder Dean Windass today for £1m.

fields.headline: Advertising under threat says IPA's Howell
fields.standfirst: Nov 20: Trade body acts to block kids' ad ban
fields.trailText:
10.30am: IPA president Rupert Howell has warned that advertising of food, alcohol, cars and ads for children are under threat, writes Claire Cozens.
Nov 20: Trade body acts to block kids' ad ban
fields.body:
Rupert Howell, the president of the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising, has warned the advertising industry to be on its guard against threats to the advertising of food, alcohol and cars and to advertising to children.

Speaking at the annual president's new year reception last night, Mr Howell said 2001 would see swathes of the business under threat from those who did not understand it.

His comments were in part a reference to the growing pressure from certain European Union members for a Europe-wide ban on advertising aimed at children.

"All of our activities depend for their very existence on the freedom to advertise responsibly and without undue restriction, let alone bans," he said.

"We're prepared for threats in areas such as advertising to children and advertising of product sectors such as food, alcohol and cars. We must be robust, because this is a slippery slope," he added.

Mr Howell set out the IPA's programme for 2001, which includes publishing a top 20 income league table, based on advertising agencies' own figures, and revising the IPA's Effectiveness Awards, which have come in for criticism in recent years.

He also cautioned against an overreaction to reports that the advertising market is beginning to slow down.

"It's wise to be cautious, but the only way we'll get into a slump is if we talk ourselves into it," he said.

fields.headline: James Murdoch attacks BBC
fields.trailText: 10am: James Murdoch has launched an extraordinary attack on the BBC, accusing it of abusing its public service status, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
James Murdoch launched an extraordinary attack on the BBC, last night accusing corporation bosses of squandering tax payers money on "commercial broadcasting".

In a heated exchange with Newsnight presenter Jeremy Paxman, the son of Rupert Murdoch and NewsCorp board member savaged the licence fee as "fundamentally wrong".

"Expanding into commercial broadcasting is fundamentally the wrong thing to do with a licence fee. It is the wrong use of tax-payers money.

Last year Mr Murdoch branded the licence fee as "evil and draconian".

Mr Paxman asked Mr Murdoch if his comments were too strong, and under a barrage of questions the Star TV chief executive scaled down his criticism to "not very good".

The BBC yesterday outlined its blueprint for the digital TV era with plans for five new TV services free for viewers.

However, the corporation is also involved with commercial ventures such as UK Gold, which show repeats of its top shows such as EastEnders.

The Murdoch family has a history of discord with the BBC, which began in earnest in 1989 when Rupert Murdoch attacked the corporation for its obsession with snooker and dramas marked by "strangulated English accents" designed to perpetuate rigid class structures.

Mr Murdoch senior went on to say that there would never be a Watergate in Britain because BBC and ITV bosses and journalists were too scared of the "thought police".

Last night Mr Paxman accused James Murdoch of chasing profits and not public interest broadcasting, with Murdoch agreeing that "responsibilty to our shareholders" was the main priority.

When asked if broadcasting at News Corporation was about making profit, he said: "Absolutely".

The head-to-head clash came to an end with Mr Murdoch repeatedly denying any interest in taking over from his father.

"It is not something that I concern myself with. We have a very strong senior management team and the board will make its decision."

An incredulous Mr Paxman could not accept Mr Murdoch's sole priority was Star TV and not the line of succession to the NewsCorp throne, leading Mr Murdoch to state that he "seriously" did not think about taking over the family firm.

fields.headline: Derby's Dean decamps to Leicester
fields.trailText: Leicester have completed the signing of Derby striker Dean Sturridge in a £350,000 deal.
fields.body:
Leicester have completed the signing of Derby striker Dean Sturridge in a £350,000 deal.

Sturridge, who was also a target for Birmingham City, will be unveiled as the Foxes second capture in 24 hours at a lunch-time press conference today at the club's training ground.

It follows on from the signing of Italian legend Roberto Mancini who yesterday signed with City until the end of the season.

Taylor moved to wrap up the deal after Sturridge scored twice for Derby against Leicester in a reserve fixture at the Baseball Ground on Tuesday.

The move was finalised after the 27-year-old player passed a medical and agreed terms late last night.

Taylor confirmed: "We have agreed a fee, he has passed a medical and we have sorted out personal terms. I am delighted to sign Dean."

The City chief is pleased to have added another experienced striker to his squad to help supplement the inexperienced front duo of Ade Akinbiyi and Trevor Benjamin.

And, like Mancini, Sturridge will go straight into the Leicester squad for Saturday's home Premiership clash with Arsenal.

By completing the deal today Sturridge will also be eligible for the FA Cup fourth round tie at Aston Villa on January 27.

The transfer-listed striker, who is out of contract in the summer, has scored 59 goals in 214 games for the Rams including 20 in the promotion season of 1995-96.

But this season he has had only a bit-part in the club's relegation battle, starting just three Premiership matches and being a substitute in 11 others.

webTitle: Hospital admits storing 12 bodies in boilerhouse

fields.headline: Hospital admits storing 12 bodies in boilerhouse
fields.trailText: A hospital in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, last night admitted that it had left 12 bodies in a disused and unrefrigerated boilerhouse over Christmas and promised a full investigation as the row into the storage of corpses escalated. John Carvel and Tania Branigan report
fields.body:
A hospital in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, last night admitted that it had left 12 bodies in a disused and unrefrigerated boilerhouse over Christmas and promised a full investigation as the row into the storage of corpses escalated.

David Fillingham, chief executive of North Staffordshire hospital, said the bodies had been placed in the makeshift morgue between Boxing Day and New Year's Eve. It had been set up a year earlier in case of major incidents during the millennium celebrations.

But he said he had no idea that it was still being used. He added that no more than seven bodies, wrapped in shrouds and resting on rows of tables, had been stored at any one time.

Mr Fillingham said: "While the facility was adequate for the difficult position we could have faced at the millennium, I do not believe it is appropriate for normal circumstances. It is no longer in use and is being dismantled."

The admission came as another hospital accused of leaving dead bodies on an unrefrigerated mortuary floor dismissed the photographic evidence as being outdated. The allegations followed the resignation on Monday of the chief executive at Bedford hospital where bodies were stored on the chapel floor last week.

The allegations that Newham general hospital, east London, had stored corpses inappropriately were made yesterday by the Mirror newspaper. They prompted Dr Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, to complain that inappropriate treatment of corpses in NHS hospitals was widespread and "seriously damaged" the reputation of Alan Milburn, the health secretary.

Newham Healthcare NHS trust said a picture of bodies dumped on the mortuary floor was taken before a reorganisation of the facility and was at least four years old. Kathy Watkins, the chief executive, said no similar problems had been raised since she joined the trust in December 1997.

The Department of Health said: "We have total confidence in the trust. Nothing like that could happen at that trust this winter."

A spokeswoman for Unison said the story was "irresponsible, unfair and dishonest".

Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, said the paper accepted the picture was probably old but said it showed that dumping the dead happened more than once.

fields.headline: CJD risk 'right to know' plan
fields.trailText: Patients could be given more right to know that they may have contracted the human form of BSE from contaminated blood transfusions or surgical instruments following a sustained rise in the number of victims of new varient Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease.
fields.body:
Patients could be given more right to know that they may have contracted the human form of BSE from contaminated blood transfusions or surgical instruments following a sustained rise in the number of victims of new varient Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease.

The current guidance says doctors should not generally inform patients because the uncertainty could blight their lives when there is no test, no cure, and no treatment for the inevitably fatal disease. But the ethical advice is now said to be "under active review".

With 13 of the 88 cases of vCJD in this country now known to have been blood donors, fears are growing about the number of people who could have been contaminated. Directors of haemophilia centres are already offering advice and counselling to patients who used a clotting product dating from 1996-97 that has recently been found to have included donations from a vCJD victim.

The same batch was used in vaccines and blood products exported to nine other countries including Ireland. Karin Pappenheim, head of the Haemophilia Society, said last night: "We are trying desperately to reassure people. We have just had a father in tears (because his) daughter used this product."

Twenty-three people are known to have had transfusions with blood from implicated donors and blood products from those donors have gone into batches used in both vaccines and clotting factors used on thousands of people. Government scientists insist there is no evidence that anyone has yet caught vCJD in this way and that measures introduced in the past three years should have reduced the theoretical risk substantially .

Other changes are on the way with more disposable surgical intruments and even a possible ban on anyone who has ever received a blood transfusion becoming a donor. The blood service is anxious to ensure supplies, since shortages would put far more people at risk, but there is growing recognition that patients should have the right to decide whether they want to know about possible risks, rather than leaving the decision to doctors alone.

The NHS guidance was drawn up three years ago. It suggested that "the general view is that patients will not benefit from this knowledge" but left it open to doctors to decide. A special committee is now reviewing the advice.

Many haemophiliacs were told and help lines offering people the opportunity to find out have been set up in at least two hospitals where contaminated instruments were used.

There is a huge campaign to make England follow the example of Scotland, Wales and Ireland which gives all haemophiliacs synthetic clotting factors. Children under 16 in England get similar treatment but provision for others is patchy.

Campaigners are angry that the NHS is spending millions on changing hospital procedures to reduce vCJD risk while not being prepared to spend the extra money needed for synthetic clotting factors.

The Department of Health said last night that ministers were considering the matter.

 Food standards chiefs last night revealed that remnants of spinal cord had been found in two consignments of beef imported from Germany, in breach of anti-BSE controls. They were discovered at meat processing plants in Newry, County Down.
