webTitle: Britain, 2005: vision of a brighter future - or hostage to fortune?

fields.headline: Britain, 2005: vision of a brighter future - or hostage to fortune?
fields.trailText: An intricate and ambitious portrait of Britain at the end of a second-term Labour government has been drawn up by ministers and civil servants over the past six months. It covers every aspect of government, ranging from asylum policy and the extent to which inequality will be reduced, to the birthweight of newborn babies.
fields.body:
An intricate and ambitious portrait of Britain at the end of a second-term Labour government has been drawn up by ministers and civil servants over the past six months. It covers every aspect of government, ranging from asylum policy and the extent to which inequality will be reduced, to the birthweight of newborn babies.

In what will be seen as Labour's hidden manifesto for the general election, the government has set out more than 200 targets, backed in the last few weeks by a growing number of comprehensive agreements on how the targets are to be defined and delivered.

Critics claim the preciseness of the targets will prove to be a big hostage to fortune. The furore over Labour's failure so far to meet two of its five election pledges underlines the political pitfalls of making measurable promises. Most of the targets are due to be met by 2004 or 2005, the likely date Labour will go to the polls seeking a third term.

Health

Heart disease: Cut deaths from 69,000 in 1997 to 51,500 by 2005.

Cancer: Reduce deaths by 69,000 to 61,000 in 2005.

Suicides: Cut from 4,500 in 1997 to 4,000 in 2005.

Outpatients: By 2005, all appointments will be prebooked.

Waiting lists: By the end of 2005, maximum waiting time for outpatient appointments down to three months and for inpatient treatment to six months. Figures for third quarter of last year show 25% of patients are still waiting more than three months for an outpatient appointment and more than six months for inpatients.

Community care: As many as 130,000 elderly people people to be helped in the community, rather than hospital.

Crime

Vehicle crime: Reduction of 30% by 2004 from the baseline of 1998-9. Will need cut from 1,071,000 to around 700,000.

Burglary: Cut of 28% by 2005 from baseline of 464,000. Latest figures show burglaries at 417,400.

Robbery: By 2005 robbery of personal and business property in London to be cut by 15% from 1999-2000 figures. Cut of 34.1% by 2004 in West Midlands; by 20% by 2005 in Greater Manchester; 15% by 2004 in Merseyside; 21.4% by 2004 in West Yorkshire. Robbery in England's big cities would fall by 14%.

Fear of crime: By 2004, should be lower than levels to be recorded in the British Crime Survey in 2001.

Cost of crime: A target, yet to be agreed, will be issued. The figure is currently estimated at £60bn.

Charges: By 2002, the number of recorded crimes brought to justice would be increased from the 1998-9 figure of 1,202,037 crimes cleared up out of 5,109,110.

Reoffending: Cut of 5% against the predicted rate by 2004; 30,000 offenders to complete accredited programmes and the number of prisoners getting jobs to double.

Asylum

By March 2004, 75% of asylum applicants will be decided within 61 days. The number of removals will rise from 7,850 in 1999-2000 to 37,000 in 2003-4.

Education

Key stage 2: By 2002, 80% of children taking English to achieve level 4; 75% taking maths to achieve level 4. David Blunkett, the education secretary, has already promised to resign if these targets are not met. September 2000 figures showed 75% had reached level 4 in English, up 4% on the previous year, and 72% had reached maths level 4 - up 3%. Figures in 1996 were 52% English, 54% maths. New targets will be set for 2004. No local education authority should have an, as yet unfixed, percentage of pupils failing to reach the new target.

Key stage 3: By 2004, 80% should achieve level 5 or above in maths; 75% in English and IT; and 70% in science. Figures in September 2000 showed 65% reaching the level in maths (up 3%), 63% in English (down 1%) and 59% in science (up 4%). At least 65% of pupils in each education authority to reach this target in English and maths.

GCSE: By 2004, 92% of pupils to obtain five or more GCSEs at grades A to G. In the 500 worst performing schools, 75% should obtain five or more GCSEs at A to C. The current figure in these schools is 18%.

Truancy: A reduction of 10% by an unfixed date on the level achieved in 2002.

Adult literacy: By 2004, the number of adults who have literacy or numeracy problems should be cut by 750,000.

Childcare: A million extra places by March 2004.

Ofsted: Half of schools should have been inspected between April 2001 and March 2004; 500 schools to be monitored because they are lower attaining or in an education action zone. Thirty local education authorities to be inspected every year. Ten special reports, including secondary schools and the usefulness of targets for 14-year-olds.

Children and poverty

Child protection: By 2004, proportion of children aged 0-3 in 500 sure start areas who are re-registered on the child protection register within 12 months should fall by 20%. The measure is designed to see if emotional and social support is improving. No baseline has been established.

Smoking: The number of mothers who smoke during pregnancy in sure start areas to fall by 10%. Baseline to be established in December 2002.

Speech therapy: By 2004 number of children aged 0-3 with speech and language problems requiring specialist intervention will have fallen by 5 points. Baseline to be ready by December 2002. Target also to be prepared for the use of libraries by parents in sure start areas.

Unemployment: By 2004, fewer children aged 0-3 in sure start areas will live in households where no one is working.

Childminders: By 2002 a national register should be established and in the following year daycare providers to be inspected annually.

Welfare

Children: Number of children in low- income households to be reduced by a quarter by 2004. Households with incomes 60% or below the median to be covered. Baseline is 4.2m children in low-income households after housing costs and 3.1m before housing costs.Reform child support scheme for new cases by April 2002 so by the next year the accuracy rate for assessments and reviews is not less than 90%, with payment arrangements established on average within six weeks. The level of compliance should be at least 75%.

Pensions: Reform second tier by 2004 so stakeholder pensions give more people access to good value funded second pensions. Access will be measured by surveys.

Two million carers and 2m disabled people with broken work records have for the first time started to build up a second-tier pension. Fourteen million low and moderate earners have started to build up a better second-tier pension than would be possible under the old state earnings-related pension. Low and moderate earners are defined as anyone earning between £3,432 and £21,600.

Benefits: By 2005 85% of claimants should have their benefits paid into bank accounts. The figure in October 2000 was 33%.

Fraud and error in income support and jobseekers allowance should be reduced by 25% by March 2004. The baseline is £1.38bn fraud and error in September 1998.

Care: By March 2004, anyone leaving care should be 75% as well off in terms of jobs and skills as other 19-year-olds in local authority areas.

Adoption: By 2004-5 the number of looked-after children adopted will be increased by 40% from the 2,700 in 1999-2000.

Acute care: By the end of 2004, the cost of acute care commissioned will have fallen to the level of the currently cheapest and best-performing trusts.

Jobs and the economy

Employment: Over the cycle, increase employment, defined as seasonally adjusted International Labour Organisation employment figure. A baseline will be set in spring 2001. The cycle is judged to have started in mid-1999.

The number of children in households with no one in work to be reduced. A baseline will be set in spring 2001 and progress monitored every six months

Over the three years the relative employment rates of disadvantaged areas and groups should be increased taking account of the economic cycle. The pledge is aimed at people with disabilities, lone parents, ethnic minorities and the over-50s, as well the 30 local authority districts with the poorest initial labour market position. The baseline is spring 2001.

The 30 districts are Hackney, Islington, Newham, Southwark, and Tower Hamlets in London; City of Glasgow, Dundee, East Ayrshire, North Lanarkshire, and West Dunbartonshire in Scotland; Blaenau Gwent, Caerphilly, Merthyr Tydfil, Neath, Pembrokeshire and Rhondda in Wales; Easington, Halton, Hartlepool, Hull, Knowsley, Liverpool, Manchester, Middlesbrough, Newcastle upon Tyne, Nottingham, Redcar and Cleveland, Salford, South Tyneside, Sunderland.

Environment and transport

Air quality: Improvement should be made against seven indicators between 2003 and 2008 with a baseline of 1998. By 2010 reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 12.5% from 1990 levels and move towards a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions by 2010. Emissions in 2000 were already 13.5% below 1990 levels. With existing policies, UK emissions will be 15% below 1990 levels in 2010 and emissions of CO2 8.5% lower.

Household waste: By 2004, 17% to be recycled or composted.

Energy efficiency: Improvement in energy efficiency by 2004 in 600,000 homes so no more than 10% of household income is spent on fuel.

Social housing: Between 2001 and 2004 the number of households living in social housing that does not meet decency standards should be cut by a third. Current estimate is that 29% of housing is not is in a decent state, with 43% in the 841 most deprived wards.

Establish a new target for bringing abandoned houses back into use. By April 2002 reduce the number of people sleeping rough by two-thirds compared with June 1998 when 1,850 slept rough.

Roads and rail: The government has still not established targets or a system of measurement for the reduction of traffic congestion in cities and trunk roads.

Rail use should be increased by half by 2010, measured in passenger kilometres, at the same time as improvements in punctuality and reliability. The first milestone will be to increase mileage by 15% by 2001-2 compared with the 1999-2000 figure of 38.3bn passenger kms. The latest quarter showed mileage rose by 38.4 passenger kms.

Buses: Bus use should rise by 10% from the 1999 level of 3.736 million passenger journeys.

London Underground : Journey times should be cut, but no targets set.

Countryside: By 2005 open up public access. By 2010 bring into favourable condition 95% of nationally important wildlife sites compared with the current 60% of sites.

Housing: By 2008, 60% of new housing will be built on previously developed land or through conversion of existing buildings, up from 57% in 1998.

By 2004 brownfield land will be reclaimed at a rate of over 1,100 hectares a year, with the result that 17% of brownfield land will be reclaimed by 2010. Last May ministers estimated that 57.710 hectares of British land was undeveloped.

Local government: All local councils to have a new constitution by June 2002.

Fire and traffic deaths: Cut number of people killed or seriously injured in accidents by 40% compared with the average for 1994-8, when 47,656 were killed or injured.

By 2004-5 reduce by 15% the days lost from work-related ill-health or injury per 100,000 workers. As a result 3.5m fewer working days will be lost because of work-related ill-health or injury.

By March 2004 reduce by 10% the number of building fires from a base line of 1998-9. By March 2004 annual accidental fire- related deaths will fall to 303 from the current 379.

Culture

By March 2004, introduce at least 12 creative partnerships targeted on deprived areas.

Museums and galleries: By 2004 increase by a third the number of visits by children - a rise from 4.59m in 1999-2000 to 6m by 2003-4.

By 2004 raise by 500,000 the number of people experiencing the arts.

Industry

Business and enterprise: By 2004 narrow the UK productivity gap, measured as output per hour, with France, US, Germany and Japan.

Monitor annually the number of people considering going into business.

By 2010 increase enterprise in disadvantaged communities measured by VAT registrations.

By 2002 ensure lowest cost access to the internet in Europe.

Regions: By 2005 improve the economic performance of all regions measured by the trend in growth of each region's per capita GDP. Core indicator will be the regional variations on GDP.

Energy: By 2004 ensure that gas and electricity prices are in the lower half of the EU average.

By 2003 obtain 5% of UK electricity from renewable sources.

Drugs

Usage: Reduce the proportion of people aged 16-24 reporting the use of class A drugs in the last month by 25% by 2005, suggesting drug use will fall in the age group from 8.3% to 6.2%.

Offending: By 2005, reduce the level of offending twice or more a month among crack- or heroin-using offenders aged over 17 by 25% by 2005 and by 50% by 2008. No baseline exists, but estimates suggest the target will apply to 15% of all people arrested.

Treatment: Increase the participation of problem drug users in drug treatment programmes by 55% by 2004, by 66% by 2005, and by 100% by 2008. No baseline exists.

Reduce the availability of class A drugs by 25% by 2005 and by 50% by 2008.

Criminal justice

Criminal courts: By 2004 reduce the time from charge to disposal of all defendants, first by dealing with 80% of youth court cases within their time targets. Guilty pleas to be dealt with in 70 days; not guilty pleas to be dealt with in 150 days; committals to be dealt with in 125 days.

In addition, halve the time taken from arrest to sentence for persistent young offenders from 142 days - the average for 1996 - to 71 days. This is one of the government's five key manifesto targets.

Civil courts: Between 2001-4 increase the enforceability of civil judgments through a 10% increase in the amount recovered per pound under execu ed warrants in the county courts.

Implement a new annual survey of satisfaction of users of the justice system.

Food

Health: Reduce food-borne illness by 20%.

Salmonella in UK-produced farm chickens should be halved by the end of 2004-5.

BSE should be reduced from 4,312 cases in 1997 to 650 by 2004, on track to 30 cases by 2006.

Europe: Deal on common agricultural policy to be complete by March 2004.

Fishing: Reduce fishing capacity by the end of 2001 by 20% from 1997 levels.

BSE: By 2004, identify the latest offspring of suspect BSE cases and exclude them within two days of the case being reported.

Department for International Development

By 2006, increase the proportion of EU development assistance going to poorest countries from 50% to 70% in 2006.

Ministry of Defence

Meet full manning requirements in March 2004 with RAF in 2001, navy in 2003 and army in 2005.

Set new tour-of-duty limits and increase airlift capacity, as well as establish joint rapid reaction force.

By 2005, ensure a minimum of 90% of rapidly available miliatry units at required state of readiness.

Nuclear weapons: By March 2004, ensure 90% of the 38 remaining parties sign the comprehensive test ban treaty.

Environment: By 2004 negotiate global regulation of the oceans and an international commitment to combat climate change.

Crime: Each year sign four memorandums of understanding on drugs and crime. By 2002, implement action plans with EU accession countries.
fields.bodyText: An intricate and ambitious portrait of Britain at the end of a second-term Labour government has been drawn up by ministers and civil servants over the past six months. It covers every aspect of government, ranging from asylum policy and the extent to which inequality will be reduced, to the birthweight of newborn babies. In what will be seen as Labour's hidden manifesto for the general election, the government has set out more than 200 targets, backed in the last few weeks by a growing number of comprehensive agreements on how the targets are to be defined and delivered. Critics claim the preciseness of the targets will prove to be a big hostage to fortune. The furore over Labour's failure so far to meet two of its five election pledges underlines the political pitfalls of making measurable promises. Most of the targets are due to be met by 2004 or 2005, the likely date Labour will go to the polls seeking a third term. Health Heart disease: Cut deaths from 69,000 in 1997 to 51,500 by 2005. Waiting lists: By the end of 2005, maximum waiting time for outpatient appointments down to three months and for inpatient treatment to six months. Figures for third quarter of last year show 25% of patients are still waiting more than three months for an outpatient appointment and more than six months for inpatients. Community care: As many as 130,000 elderly people people to be helped in the community, rather than hospital. Crime Vehicle crime: Reduction of 30% by 2004 from the baseline of 1998-9. Will need cut from 1,071,000 to around 700,000. Burglary: Cut of 28% by 2005 from baseline of 464,000. Latest figures show burglaries at 417,400. Robbery: By 2005 robbery of personal and business property in London to be cut by 15% from 1999-2000 figures. Cut of 34.1% by 2004 in West Midlands; by 20% by 2005 in Greater Manchester; 15% by 2004 in Merseyside; 21.4% by 2004 in West Yorkshire. Robbery in England's big cities would fall by 14%. Fear of crime: By 2004, should be lower than levels to be recorded in the British Crime Survey in 2001. Cost of crime: A target, yet to be agreed, will be issued. The figure is currently estimated at £60bn. Charges: By 2002, the number of recorded crimes brought to justice would be increased from the 1998-9 figure of 1,202,037 crimes cleared up out of 5,109,110. Reoffending: Cut of 5% against the predicted rate by 2004; 30,000 offenders to complete accredited programmes and the number of prisoners getting jobs to double. Asylum By March 2004, 75% of asylum applicants will be decided within 61 days. The number of removals will rise from 7,850 in 1999-2000 to 37,000 in 2003-4. Education Key stage 2: By 2002, 80% of children taking English to achieve level 4; 75% taking maths to achieve level 4. David Blunkett, the education secretary, has already promised to resign if these targets are not met. September 2000 figures showed 75% had reached level 4 in English, up 4% on the previous year, and 72% had reached maths level 4 - up 3%. Figures in 1996 were 52% English, 54% maths. New targets will be set for 2004. No local education authority should have an, as yet unfixed, percentage of pupils failing to reach the new target. Key stage 3: By 2004, 80% should achieve level 5 or above in maths; 75% in English and IT; and 70% in science. Figures in September 2000 showed 65% reaching the level in maths (up 3%), 63% in English (down 1%) and 59% in science (up 4%). Childcare: A million extra places by March 2004. Smoking: The number of mothers who smoke during pregnancy in sure start areas to fall by 10%. Baseline to be established in December 2002. THE GUARDIAN

Bruce Grobbelaar faces financial ruin after an appeal court overturned an £85,000 libel damages award to the footballer made against the Sun newspaper. P1
The BBC is to spend £300m on digital TV and radio. P9
Channel 4's coverage of the Indian festival Kumbh Mela was under threat last night after the shows producers were accused of offending the Indian population. P15
John Palmer, founder of Letsbuyit.com, has reacted angrily to reports that the company's trustees are planning to brand the company's management "deplorable" in court today. P29
Star TV yesterday unveiled a series of TV stations to woo the British Asian market. P29

THE TIMES

Labour and the Conservatives are drawing up plans for a highly personal election campaign involving attacks on the party leaders. P1
Bruce Grobbelaar faces financial ruin. P1
Star TV is to launch a Mandarin television service for the Chinese population of Europe. P28

MEDIA
Ray Snoddy on the forthcoming battle of the News at Tens. P22
The BBC is planning a series of new dramas to counter ITV's lead. P23
With Melody Maker and Select already dead, can the remaining pop mags survive the threat from the internet? P25

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

Grobbelaar faces £1.2m libel bill. P1
The BBC yesterday disclosed plans to spend £300m on setting up new digital television and radio stations over the next two years. P2
More than 1.5m children and 2m adults listened to Radio 4's all-day Harry Potter broadcast on Boxing Day, according to research commissioned by the BBC. P6

THE INDEPENDENT

The BBC's digital plan provokes anger. P11
Lord Hollick is ready to sell his stake in Channel 5, say analysts. P14

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

Consignia, formerly the Post Office, is to have its prices frozen for two years under government plans being drawn up. P1
Two of Europe's most high-profile internet ventures, E-Loan Europe and E-Loan UK, are being broken up and sold just a year after launch. P23
The Murdoch family yesterday brought its battle with Indian media mogul Subash Chandra to the UK as it launched pay-TV channels to compete with Mr Chandra's Zee TV. P29

DAILY MAIL

The BBC is grooming George Alagiah to take over as the main newsreader on its 10pm news broadcast. P45

DAILY EXPRESS

Dinnerladies star Shobna Gulati is to join the cast of Coronation Street in a story about an arranged marriage. P27
A contestant on Who Wants to be a Millionaire? who missed an earlier appearance on the show because of a panic attack could be Britain's second gameshow millionaire if he gets the final question right. P28
TV presenter Gabby Yorath is to lead a campaign against heart disease after her brother died of the illness. P34
How unknown TV executive Nigel Lythgoe became TV's new Mr Nasty. P40

THE SUN

"Crook Cheat Liar Traitor" is the Sun's description of Bruce Grobbelaar, after an appeal court cleared the newspaper of libelling Mr Grobbelaar. P1
The White Horse, the pub that features in the sitcom Last of the Summer Wine, is being sold. P13

THE MIRROR

The Mirror's 3AM Girls try their luck with Nigel Lythgoe of TV's Popstars. P12

DAILY STAR

Punters are queuing up to place bets on who killed Phil Mitchell after the EastEnders storyline was revealed. P1 Donna Air has been asked to appear in a new holiday series on BBC Choice. P1

AND FINALLY...

Sex shop boss Nick Griffin was fined nearly £4,000 yesterday - because his porn videos were too tame. Trading standards watchdogs swooped after customers complained their movies were not blue enough. The Sun P25

fields.headline: A president without precedent
fields.standfirst: As Bill Clinton prepares to leave office, Martin Kettle assesses the legacy of the 42nd president
fields.trailText: As Bill Clinton prepares to leave office, Martin Kettle assesses the legacy of the 42nd president.
fields.body:
More than four years ago, Bill Clinton had a remarkable conversation with his rogue adviser Dick Morris. Their subject, as recorded in Morris's book, Behind the Oval Office, was one of Clinton's favourites - where he will rank in the history books when he leaves office.

Morris took the initiative in the discussion. Eighteen of Clinton's predecessors deserved to be ranked in the top three categories, Morris suggested.

The first rank of presidents was reserved for those who did great things in great times: Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln, Wilson and Franklin Roosevelt.

The second was for those who did great things but in less compelling eras: Jackson, Polk, Reagan (in Morris's view but not Clinton's), Theodore Roosevelt and Truman.

In the third tier, reserved to presidents who did some great things but whose claim to higher rank is contestable for some important reason, Morris placed Madison, the two Johnsons, Arthur, Cleveland, Kennedy, Nixon and Bush.

"Good list," Clinton responded. "Where do I fit in?"

"Right now, to be honest, I think you are borderline third tier. It's too early to rank you yet, but you are right on the cusp of making third tier," Morris responded.

"I think that's about right," Clinton agreed.

The president then asked Morris what he would need to do over the next four years in order to achieve second tier rank. Morris suggested three big things and four medium things.

The big things were to make welfare reform work, to implement the balanced federal budget and to smash international terrorism.

The medium things were to begin to eliminate cigarette smoking, to establish national standards in school education, to make further progress towards universal health care insurance, and to use the power of the presidency more emphatically on "noneconomic lifestyle issues".

"Good list," Clinton said, for the second time in the conversation. "I've got it down. I'll think about it a lot."

Four years on from that conversation, perhaps the most unexpected thing about it is how realistic it still seems, in spite of all that has happened in between.

Clinton has, in fact, carried out much - though far from all - of Morris's agenda, and has notched up some other positive achievements too.

Welfare reform has been far less painful in the years of plenty than most of its opponents claimed in 1996, although the truest test will come in times of hardship.

The federal budget has been conclusively balanced, again on the back of taxes on prosperity and full employment, which have turned the years of deficit into years of surplus.

Only the international terrorist agenda remains largely where it was four years ago.

On the medium level agenda, the progress has been less obvious. The battle against big tobacco waxed and then waned, leaving Clinton unable to convert major interim victories into a conclusive ending.

US education standards have risen in many respects, as several recent official and unofficial reports have indicated, but the overall picture still remains patchy.

Health insurance reform remains a major area of failure, a challenge that the Bush administration will have to address even though it does not greatly want to.

And Clinton's ability to use the presidential bully pulpit has of course been massively compromised by events since 1996.

Most people would instinctively say that Clinton's second term has consisted of four years blighted by the Monica Lewinsky affair.

Its shadow has lain heavy across the administration for the final year and a half that Clinton has remained in office. No president since Nixon leaves office so synonymous with a major scandal.

And yet Clinton is also leaving office with precedent-defying job ratings. Even now, 65 per cent of Americans approve of the job he is doing (only just short of the peak of approval he reached in the month that the Starr Report was published).

After eight years, his ratings exceed those of Reagan, a point that many Republicans cannot even bring themselves to think about.

What is more, as he himself observed in a recent Rolling Stone interview, there is little doubt that Clinton would have stood for a third term, had the law allowed it, and equally little doubt that he would have easily been re-elected.

In his final year as president, Bill Clinton achieved remarkably little to live in the memory or to bequeath to the history books.

And yet Clinton remains in some strange but important way the absolutely defining figure of modern America.

He has shaped and marked the actions of others, friend and foe, intimate and stranger, even while having little to show for it himself as he leaves the stage tomorrow.

Health insurance reform remains a major area of failure, a challenge that the Bush administration will have to address even though it does not greatly want to. And Clinton's ability to use the presidential bully pulpit has of course been massively compromised by events since 1996. Most people would instinctively say that Clinton's second term has consisted of four years blighted by the Monica Lewinsky affair. Its shadow has lain heavy across the administration for the final year and a half that Clinton has remained in office. No president since Nixon leaves office so synonymous with a major scandal. And yet Clinton is also leaving office with precedent-defying job ratings. Even now, 65 per cent of Americans approve of the job he is doing (only just short of the peak of approval he reached in the month that the Starr Report was published). After eight years, his ratings exceed those of Reagan, a point that many Republicans cannot even bring themselves to think about. What is more, as he himself observed in a recent Rolling Stone interview, there is little doubt that Clinton would have stood for a third term, had the law allowed it, and equally little doubt that he would have easily been re-elected. In his final year as president, Bill Clinton achieved remarkably little to live in the memory or to bequeath to the history books. And yet Clinton remains in some strange but important way the absolutely defining figure of modern America. He has shaped and marked the actions of others, friend and foe, intimate and stranger, even while having little to show for it himself as he leaves the stage tomorrow. fields.headline: Jones quits JWT
fields.trailText: 9am: Chris Jones, the worldwide chief executive of J Walter Thompson, has unexpectedly quit, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Chris Jones, the worldwide chief executive of J Walter Thompson, has unexpectedly quit.

At 45, he was the youngest executive in the history of the company, the fourth largest advertising agency in the world.

An internal memo said Mr Jones was leaving the agency he has headed for nearly five years for "health reasons". Worldwide president Peter Schwietzer will take on his duties.

"I know each and every one of you join with me in wishing him and his family the very best," Mr Schweitzer said in the memo.

"Having spent most of my adult life at JWT, I will do my utmost to fulfill the job to the best of my ability. With your help and support, the team will keep the agency we all revere moving forward," he added.

Mr Jones, who is New York based, became boss of JWT three years ago and will be succeeded by Peter Schweitzer who will add chief executive to his current post of president.

Mr Jones has been ill twice recently and underwent surgery in 1999 for an eye problem. In March he was treated for a blood clot in his leg.

webTitle: BT unbundling speeds up after first phase flop

fields.headline: BT unbundling speeds up after first phase flop
fields.standfirst: Big bond issue rasies £6bn
fields.trailText: Oftel yesterday moved to head off the growing sense of crisis surrounding the break-up of BT's monopoly of the local telephone network.
fields.body:
Oftel yesterday moved to head off the growing sense of crisis surrounding the break-up of BT's monopoly of the local telephone network.

At an emergency meeting with BT and a number of rival operators, the Oftel director general, David Edmonds, won agreement to bring forward the existing timetable for the so called "unbundling of the local loop".

The meeting was called after the first 25 of BT's local exchanges opened for competition attracted only a derisory response from rivals hoping to compete with the erstwhile monopoly. Competition in the local network sector is seen as a vital ingredient for the deployment of high speed internet access in Britain.

Orders for space were placed in only 14 of the 25 BT exchanges, with an average of only one or two operators per site instead of the anticipated seven or eight.

At yesterday's meeting it was agreed that the original timetable for unbundling would be scrapped and that access to BT's most popular exchanges in wealthy urban areas would be accelerated.

Oftel also said it had started an investigation into the prices charged by BT for storing its rivals' equipment in its exchanges.

Anne Lambert, Oftel's director of operations, described the meeting as "constructive". She said: "All who attended were keen to solve the problems that have arisen so that the unbundling process can proceed according to the agreed timetable."

The 25 exchanges that had a deadline for orders of last Friday were part of an original 360 on offer to rivals in the first wave of unbundling. Another 360 in more densely populated areas were to have been in a second wave. Orders for the second tranche can be placed next month.

A BT spokesman accused Oftel of trying to appear the "ringmaster" by calling yesterday's meeting.

"We offered to bring forward the timetable last month and it was turned down, so there was no problem in agreeing to this. BT has hit every deadline and every milestone throughout this process."

The proces of loosening BT's grip over the "last mile" from exchanges to the home or businesses has been plagued throughout by controversy.

Oftel had hoped the telecoms industry would agree terms for co-location in BT exchanges but was forced to intervene in the autumn.

The government had promised "widespread availability" of competition by July this year.

BT's competitors have blamed the low level of demand on the wide dispersion of the chosen exchanges around the country, making it difficult to make business plans. There is also uncertainty about the cost of taking space in BT's exchanges.

Competitors will be able to install DSL equipment, which upgrades the old copper analogue network for high bandwidth use, including fast internet access.

Firms that have expressed an interest in taking space include Energis, Thus and Kingston Communications.

fields.headline: Big bond issue raises £6bn
fields.standfirst: BT unbundling speeds up after first phase flop
fields.trailText: BT yesterday launched its second blockbuster bond sale within two months in a move seen as a successful test of investor sentiment towards the telecommunications sector.
fields.body:
BT yesterday launched its second blockbuster bond sale within two months in a move seen as a successful test of investor sentiment towards the telecommunications sector.

It offered sterling and euro denominated bonds worth a total of €9.7bn (£6.12bn) - the largest bond issue not to include dollar-denominated paper and almost double the amount initially expected. Last month's $10bn (£6.8bn) from BT was the largest dollar-denominated corporate issue.

Banking sources said the amount offered yesterday had been increased because of strong demand from investors. BT confirmed that it had sold bonds to about 1,000 investors.

In common with other telecoms groups BT has run up hefty debts - expected to peak at £30bn - to fund acquisitions and the purchase of third generation mobile telephone licences. The level of spending required to acquire UMTS licences and to roll out 3G networks has caused some concern among investors and hit share prices.

The proceeds of the BT bond issue will be used to repay more expensive short-term debt. "We are exchanging an overdraft for a mortgage," said a BT spokesman. The success of the issue was " a vote of confidence in BT and its strategy".

Analysts welcomed the response to the issue. "It is good news that the telecoms companies can replace their debt in this way. They may have had to pay a bit more than they would have liked and a bit more than they would have expected to a year ago but it is cheaper than loans from the banks," said one analyst.

Bank regulators will be relieved if other companies follow BT's example. Several have warned about banks' exposure to the telecoms sector and will be happy to see more of the debt burden transferred to investors.

webTitle: UK marketeers to challenge EU email ban

fields.headline: UK marketeers to challenge EU email ban
fields.standfirst: Sept 20: ISPs find spam verdict hard to swallow
fields.trailText:
8.30am: An EU proposal to ban unsolicited emails is being fiercely resisted by the British marketeers, writes Claire Cozens.
Sept 20: ISPs find spam verdict hard to swallow
fields.body:
The British marketing industry has begun the fight back against European Union proposals to ban all unsolicited emails.

The Direct Marketing Association, a marketing trade body, has put forward a submission to EU draftsman Marco Cappato outlining its concerns about the proposed directive, which would have serious consequences for marketing companies.

The EU wants to ban companies from sending out any emails to businesses and individuals that have not opted in to receiving them.

"Community data protection legislation already exists to prohibit 'spam' emails, so the introduction of further legislation for an opt-in scheme isn't going to stop unscrupulous marketers from continuing to send them," said Jodi Sangster, legal and public affairs executive at the DMA.

It will instead prohibit responsible marketeers from using this valuable marketing tool," he added.

The DMA is instead lobbying for a system whereby recipients could opt out of receiving emails.

fields.headline: Trend for wacky brand name changes accelerates
fields.trailText: 8.30am: As the trend for silly company names gathers pace even the brand consultants are becoming cynical, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Post Office is the latest household name to fall victim to the brand consultants, but it is in good company.

Syntegra, Sonera and Accenture may sound like the offspring of an over-imaginative rock star, but they are, in fact, the latest new names to hit the stock market.

The Post Office's new brand name, Consignia, won't be used in the UK at all. It is intended to help the Post Office expand abroad, where its existing name would be even more meaningless than the new one it has chosen.

But as the trend for meaningless and frankly rather silly company names gathers pace, even the brand consultants - who get paid to come up with new names for old - are becoming cynical.

"It does seem to be open season on name changes at the moment - if your reputation is suffering a bit, changing your name is seen as the answer and at the moment the trend is to go for something vaguely Latin or Greek.

"But the public's not that stupid. If your reputation is suffering what you need to change is your products or your service levels, the things that actually matter," says Piers Schmidt, strategy director for branding consultancy The Fourth Room.

A recent survey by the brand consultants Enterprise IG showed that a whopping 250 British companies changed their names in 2000, giving us the dubious honour of being Europe's biggest name changers.

Of the companies that adopted new names, just over half did so because of a merger or acquisition. But that leaves 47% who changed their names with no clear reason for doing so.

Terry Tyrrell, chairman of Enterprise IG, predicts a return to more traditional company names over the next year, particularly in the financial sector.

After bombarding customers with wacky-sounding new brands from Egg and Smile to IF and Cahoot, the banks have woken up to the fact that it makes more sense to trade on your existing brand.

"I think we are beginning an era of brand consolidation with a lot of the new dot.coms returning to their mother brands," he says.

"Companies are realising it doesn't make sense to spend money marketing five or six brands and are rationalising their brand architecture."

Of course, no one is saying a name doesn't matter. It does - as General Motors found out when they tried to launch the Nova in Spain, only to find that "no va" means "doesn't go" in Spanish.

But plenty of companies hang onto their old names when they do new things - take De Beers, which is branching out into retailing in a joint venture with French luxury goods brand LVMH.

"If you're well known it makes far more sense to keep your name, even if you do want to change your image," says Mr Schmidt.

"There aren't very many names left that haven't been patented and the trouble with made-up names is that the public finds them very difficult to relate to. And the idea that Accenture is supposed to make you think of an accent on the future is frankly bullshit."

fields.headline: Chris Evans Radio 1 tapes 'missing'
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Chris Evans's on-air tirades from his days at Radio 1 have mysteriously disappeared, report Jason Deans and Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.byline: Jason Deans and Lisa O'Carroll, site editor
fields.body:
Chris Evans' infamous on-air tirades against his BBC bosses and celebrities when he was hosting the Radio 1 breakfast show have been wiped from the archives for ever.

It means that the BBC have no record of what turned out to be the most controversial breakfast show of the station's history.

The absence of audio tapes of the show from the archives emerged this week after a BBC2 doucmentary about former Radio 1 boss Matthew Bannister.

Although it centred on the shake-up at Radio 1, the departure of veteran DJs such as Dave Lee Travis and the arrival of Chris Evans, there were no audio clips on the show.

Blood on the Carpet series producer Nick Mirsky said he was simply told none existed.

A spokesman for Radio 1 said: "Chris Evans' show was an independently produced show and we only have a selection of shows in the archive. But no, we don't have all those famous Evans tantrums in the archive."

Not all radio shows are held in the BBC library and Radio 1 pop shows don't usually lend themselves to archiving.

However, the BBC documentary about Mr Bannister and his head of music Trevor Dann did feature a clip of Dave Lee Travis resigning, just before Evans' arrival in 1995.

"It is amazing that we can find DLT but we don't have Evans on tape. I guess some of Chris' outbursts are best forgotten," said a BBC source.

By the end of his 19 months at the station, Evans had developed a huge ego and was virtually out of control.

But his outbursts are destined for radio oblivion.

Among those that will never be aired again are his hurtful attacks on celebrities.

He branded Anthea Turner's TV show All You Need is Love "a pile of poo"; said Jimmy Hill was "a poof" and described children's TV host Emma Forbes "a nightmare".

Evans continually referred to then Radio 1 controller Matthew Bannister as the "fat controller" and kept his listeners informed of all the ins and outs of their rows and contract negotiations.

In October 1996, after another reprimand from Mr Bannister over a broadcast deemed to have breached bounds of taste, Mr Evans branded him "ungrateful", adding "we saved his job because, frankly, before we joined [Radio 1] he was slipping down the banister".

Other inflammatory on-air comments included telling breakfast show listeners he "loathed" Radio 1 production head Trevor Dann for making his job "difficult".

None of these on-air tirades was included in Walking with Disc Jockeys, according to Mr Mirsky, because both the BBC and the Virgin Media Group - which now owns Ginger, the company that produced Mr Evans' Radio 1 breakfast show - said the recordings no longer existed.

"We contacted Virgin and they said they didn't have anything," he added. "The BBC has a selection of recordings from that time, but not what we were looking for."

Commercial radio stations are obliged to keep all their broadcast output for 60 days under Radio Authority rules.

A Virgin spokesman said recordings from that period were kept on analogue audio tapes that took up considerable storage space and radio stations tended not to keep them. He added: "I very, very much doubt whether these audio tapes still exist."

"Maybe some producer has them stacked up in his garage somewhere and you can find him," the spokesman added.

fields.headline: Benetton ad star gets stay of execution
fields.trailText: 8.30am A killer on death row whose face appeared in Benetton's ad campaign last year, has had an 11th hour stay of execution. By Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
A murderer on death row, whose face appeared in Benetton's highly controversial ad campaign last year, has received an 11th hour stay of execution.

Bobby Lee Harris was due to be executed today in North Carolina but his execution was stayed by a judge. There will be a further hearing in February.

Mr Harris, 34, was convicted for the fatal stabbing of fisherman John Redd in 1991.

His defence suggests Mr Harris's mental ability was short of planning such a murder.

Benetton, which used Mr Harris's photograph in a series of posters featuring death-row prisoners, declined to comment on the news.

The outdoor campaign, which claimed to take a stand against capital punishment, caused an outcry in the US. It prompted Sears Roebuck to delist Benetton stock in 400 stores.

In the UK, the Advertising Standards Authority received 144 complaints, which it decided not to uphold.

Benetton chairman Luciano Benetton eventually apologised to the families of the prisoners photographed.

Shortly afterwards, Olivieri Toscani, Benetton's creative director, quit after 18 years with the fashion company.

webTitle: Channel 4 faces expulsion from the Kumbh Mela

fields.headline: Channel 4 faces expulsion from the Kumbh Mela
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Channel 4's coverage of the Indian religious event, the Kumbh Mela, was in trouble after the producers were accused of 'immorality', writes Luke Harding.
fields.body:
Channel 4's coverage of the Kumbh Mela, India's largest religious event, was in deep and possibly terminal trouble last night after the festival's authorities accused the show's producers of "immorality" and said they had offended Britain's Indian community.

The festival's commissioner, Sada Kant, claimed the Channel 4 team had filmed a 25-year-old Mexican woman who stripped off to bathe in the Ganges during the event's first big bathing day last week. The crew had also taken lewd shots of naked sadhus, or holy men, charging into the water, he alleged.

Mr Kant said the matter was so serious he would be raising it with India's high commissioner to the UK.

He has also demanded that David Mitchell, the executive producer of the Greatest Show on Earth, C4's daily festival programme, appear before him at 12pm today and explain himself. If he was not convinced by Mr Mitchell's answers he would strip him of his press pass, he said.

"We have strong evidence that some media persons have been involved in immoral videography and photography," a Kumbh Mela director, Arvind Narain Mishara, said last night.

"Indians, and Indians in the UK in particular, have complained about C4's and the BBC's coverage."

"Serious action will be taken against anyone who has infringed the terms of the 1938 Kumbh Mela Act," he added.

The trouble seems to have started last Sunday when around 100 photographers and 20 camera crews from around the world gathered before dawn in the north Indian town of Allahabad to record the traditional procession of sword-carrying sadhus who rush naked into the Ganges.

The festival authorities had already served the luxury Cox and King's camp, where the C4 team is staying, with an eviction notice after claiming that foreigners were contravening the event's rules by eating meat and drinking alcohol.

Last night Mr Mitchell denied that there was anything "titillating" in C4's coverage of the festival. He would be inviting the Mela commissioner to examine the tapes of C4's daily 10-minute broadcasts of the event, he said.

Mr Mitchell added: "Our coverage has concentrated on the serious side of Hinduism. Hopefully things will calm down when we show the commissioner the tapes from last week."

The event's organisers have already issued a series of edicts. Close-up photography is banned and TV crews have been told to film from a fixed point.

The trouble seems to have started last Sunday when around 100 photographers and 20 camera crews from around the world gathered before dawn in the north Indian town of Allahabad to record the traditional procession of sword-carrying sadhus who rush naked into the Ganges. The festival authorities had already served the luxury Cox and King's camp, where the C4 team is staying, with an eviction notice after claiming that foreigners were contravening the event's rules by eating meat and drinking alcohol. Last night Mr Mitchell denied that there was anything "titillating" in C4's coverage of the festival. He would be inviting the Mela commissioner to examine the tapes of C4's daily 10-minute broadcasts of the event, he said. Mr Mitchell added: "Our coverage has concentrated on the serious side of Hinduism. Hopefully things will calm down when we show the commissioner the tapes from last week." The event's organisers have already issued a series of edicts. Close-up photography is banned and TV crews have been told to film from a fixed point.

webTitle: BBC to spend £300m on digital TV and radio

fields.headline: BBC to spend £300m on digital TV and radio
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC said yesterday that it was to spend more than £300m on its planned digital television and radio channels, more than half of which will be devoted to youth networks.
fields.body:
The BBC said yesterday that it was to spend more than £300m on its planned digital television and radio channels, more than half of which will be devoted to youth networks.

Publishing its formal application to the Department of Culture, Media and Sport, the corporation said it believed the proposals commanded wide public support.

But its commercial rivals aim to lobby hard against the plans, particularly the proposal for two children's chan nels. They believe the BBC should not spend licence fee money on services offered elsewhere.

The BBC wants to turn two existing digital channels, Choice and Knowledge, into BBC3, devoted to youth, and BBC4, to culture. It wants to launch five digital radio services, including a music station aimed at a young black audience, a speech radio station, an Asian network, and a sports network provisionally titled Five Live Sports Plus.

The corporation said the networks would raise the take-up of digital television and ra dio. Without a wide choice of free-to-air channels on digital platforms, many viewers would not give up their analogue services, it argued.

The government wants to switch off analogue between 2006 and 2010, but there are signs that insufficient viewers will have gone over to digital to allow the switch in that period.

Greg Dyke, the BBC director general, said viewers and listeners would get "imaginative and distinctive services". Sir Christopher Bland, the chairman, said the governors were satisfied the plans met their criteria for new services. But commercial networks, such as BSkyB, said the BBC should launch services only if they were not provided by competitors. Nickelodeon, the children's network, opposes the children's channels. Channel 4, which began its entertainment network E4 last night, is against the plans for BBC3.

In total, the BBC said it would spend £313m on four new digital TV services and five digital radio services between April 2001 and March 2003. The £152m investment in BBC3 is substantial: it would broadcast only from 8pm each night, so pro gramme budgets would be comparable to BBC1 and BBC2 shows. But the £57m over two years for BBC4 is tight, a fraction of Radio 4's £89m annual budget and Radio 3's £64m.

The five digital radio services together would get £22m over two years.

The corporation denied that some proposed services were provided by the commercial sector. "Our proposals will provide a distinctive but complementary alternative to commercial services," a spokesman said. "They will add substantially to viewers' and listeners' choice."

What will be on offer

BBC3

Proposition Aimed at 16- to 34-year-olds, only channel to focus "exclusively on the young and young at heart"

Programmes Hourly one-minute news, daily entertainment news, drama, comedy, music. 80% original content, 90% British

Schedule 8pm to 2am

Budget £57m in 2001-02, £95m from 2002-03

Launch Late 2001 or early 2002

BBC4

Proposition Aimed at "everyone interested in culture, arts and ideas"

Programmes Extended coverage of the Proms, Young Musician of the Year, performances from the Royal Opera House, documentaries "in the spirit of Omnibus, Horizon and Storyville", debates, world cinema. 70% new and British

Schedule 7pm to 1am

Budget £26m in 2001-02, £31m thereafter

Launch date Late 2001

Playbox

Proposition Pre-school children with educative slant

Programmes Series such as Teletubbies, Tweenies, or Bill and Ben

Schedule Daytime

Budget £10m

Launch Summer 2001

Children's B (working title)

Proposition Six- to 13-year-olds, with interactive element

Programmes Drama, comedy and entertainment, Newsround three times a day, daily Blue Peter. Strong web presence.

Schedule Daytime

Budget £31m

Launch date Early 2002

Radio stations

For launch in 2001 and 2002

Network X (working title):

Music, news and factual for young, black audience

Network Y (working title):

Dubbed BBC Gold - music from the 1970s to the 1990s

Network Z (working title):

Speech-based: comedy, drama, stories and features,

BBC Five Live Sports Plus

Dedicated sports station

BBC Asian Network :

Extension of station available only in certain regions

Existing services

BBC1 and 2 get extra £95m in 2001-02 and extra £140m a year from 2002-03

BBC News 24 to continue, also BBC Parliament with more from devolved parliaments

Radios 1-5 Live and World Service will broadcast digital

webTitle: Comment: Stop me and buy one

fields.headline: Stop me and buy one
fields.trailText: Another January, another new term. In the current learning module in my Media Studies course at the University of Oxbridge (formerly Thameside Polytechnic) I am tackling the whole vexed business of Opinions - How to Form, Hold and Couch Them in the 21st Century.
fields.body:
Another January, another new term. In the current learning module in my Media Studies course at the University of Oxbridge (formerly Thameside Polytechnic) I am tackling the whole vexed business of Opinions - How to Form, Hold and Couch Them in the 21st Century.

There has, as we all know, been a remarkable growth in the whole area of opinions over the last decade or so. Where once newspapers employed one or two writers who were capable of holding firm opinions on, say, the rights and wrongs of the nuclear deterrent or the correct way to bake a soufflé, they now maintain teams of seasoned opinionators, all of them able to turn in a closely argued opinion on anything from breast enhancement to fox hunting, via a future for the euro and whither Dale Winton? At the same time, there have been many new openings for those holding all types of opinions on both new and long-established television programmes such as Question Time and Frost on Sunday.

In this opinion-based world, with all sorts of new opinions emerging daily, only those with a special training in opinions are likely to succeed. This is just one reason why my current module is so well subscribed. In this week's class, I introduced students to the development of opinions by reference to a shared area of interest, ie the cat sat on the mat. We then tackled these important questions:

Should the cat have sat on the mat?

What colour is the cat? Is this relevant to any opinion you might form?

If the cat shouldn't have sat on the mat, where should he/she have sat instead?

Or should he/she have remained standing?

Looked at from the mat's point of view, how was the mat effected by being sat upon by the cat?

Surely the mat has its rights too?

What form of penalty should a just society inflict on the cat for sitting on the mat?

Are there effective government controls in place to ensure that this sort of thing doesn't happen again or can we expect a repeat of this incident in years to come?

Is news of the cat's sitting on the mat a) disturbing, b) deeply disturbing, c) upsetting, d) deeply upsetting or e) a savage indictment of the whole contemporary mat-dependency culture that has grown up over the past few years?

Where does the zeitgeist fit in?

I first introduced this exercise to my Media Studies course just three short years ago. In that time, I am delighted to say that no less than three of our graduates have, by virtue of their forcefully held opinions, achieved positions as regular panellists on The Moral Maze, while five others are regularly employed by the Observer and the Independent newspapers to voice their concerns on such vexed issues as the ethics of sanctions against Iraq, the need for restrictions on fish-farming and the rights and wrongs of the recent Madonna/Guy Ritchie wedding.

For the first time ever this term, our module two will be introducing a brand new opinion creation scheme at Easter. The well-known but nevertheless deeply disturbing tale of Jack and Jill will be presented to the students, who will then be given five minutes to form opinions on these related topics:

Are Jack and Jill sending out the right signals as role models for a generation?

Should the hill in future be subjected to regular visits from a health and safety inspector before future water-collecting trips can be sanctioned?

If the pail of water is carbonated, should the subsequent loss of some of the vital health components of non-carbonated water be made clear by law to consumers on the pail itself?

What are the health risks involved in climbing the hill? With young people's lives at stake, is it really worth it?

Should the continued burden that is placed on the police, ambulance and voluntary services by the unthinking actions of the minority who wish to scale the hill really be allowed to continue?

Are we in danger of developing into a climb-the-hill-at-all-costs society, risking everything for the so-called proverbial pail of water?

Inevitably, there are those who argue that my Opinions module at the University of Oxbridge is yet another specious addition to a world already overpopulated with points of view. Well, that is their opinion, and I would fight for their absolute right to argue with me over it, perhaps either on the 7.15am slot on the Today programme or, failing that, on Start the Week with Jeremy Paxman. And you know what? I'd truly love to hear your opinion on the whole issue of opinions. 'Nuff said.

fields.headline: Game over
fields.standfirst:
Bruce Grobbelaar has seen both triumph and tragedy in his career. But yesterday's reversal of his libel victory over the Sun could be the biggest defeat of all. Richard Williams on one of football's most colourful characters
The appeal court ruling
The bribes and the matches
Historic verdict condemns Grobbelaar
fields.trailText: Bruce Grobbelaar has seen both triumph and tragedy in his career. But yesterday's reversal of his libel victory over the Sun could be the biggest defeat of all. Richard Williams on one of football's most colourful characters
fields.body:
With his macho-man moustache, his derisive grin and his wobbling knees, Bruce Grobbelaar went through the 1980s as the pantomime villain of big-time football. While he and his Liverpool team mates were mopping up six league championships in nine years, the Zimbabwean became the green-shirted destroyer of other men's dreams, a goalkeeper whose antics concealed a tradecraft and a courage that provided the foundation for a decade of almost unbroken success.

Grobbelaar's name came up a few days ago, when Liverpool were drawn to meet Roma in the next round of this year's Uefa Cup. Commentators instantly evoked memories of the night, 17 years ago, when the two clubs met in Rome's Olympic stadium in the final of the European Cup, Liverpool leaving as champions after winning an agonising penalty shoot-out. Grobbelaar was at his best on such occasions, his earlier service as a scout in the Rhodesian army, tracking the movements and dodging the bullets of Robert Mugabe's guerrilla fighters, being popularly supposed to have enabled him put mere penalty kicks with plastic-coated footballs into proper perspective.

Yet if Grobbelaar was vital to the triumphs of Liverpool's greatest era, so he was also present on its most tragic occasions: the night in the Heysel stadium when 40 Italian fans were crushed to death before the start of the 1985 European Cup final, just as the team were preparing to defend the title they had won for the fourth time the previous year; and the spring afternoon at Hillsborough in Sheffield four years later when 94 of the Anfield club's supporters suffered a similar fate before an FA Cup semi-final.

Like his team mates, the usually flamboyant Grobbelaar conducted himself through those dark days with notable sensitivity and decorum. But his conduct was not always so admirable. His body check on the hobbling Gordon McQueen of Manchester United in the last minute of normal time in the 1983 League Cup final, the sort of thing known in the game as a "professional foul", was thought to be the worst of its kind since Toni Schumacher of West Germany crashed into Patrick Battiston of France in the 1982 World Cup semi-final - but it kept Liverpool in the game. Instead of being sent off, as he deserved, Grobbelaar was still on the pitch to see his team win 2-1 after extra time. It was an ungallant victory and unworthy of the club's distinguished manager, Bob Paisley, who was taking them to a Wembley final for the last time.

In Rome the following year his decision to disturb the concentration of Francesco Graziani during the penalty shoot-out probably won Liverpool the European Cup for the fourth time. By wobbling his knees on the goal line in a parody of stark terror as the veteran striker prepared to take his kick, Grobbelaar seemed to provoke the Italian into a wild miss. Alan Kennedy, the Liverpool full back, needed only to succeed with the next kick to secure the trophy for the English champions. But Grobbelaar's action, although effective and to some extent amusing, undeniably contravened any definition of sporting etiquette.

When Grobbelaar's powers eventually declined, so did Liverpool's. At 34, after 12 years with the club, his departure from Anfield coincided with the rise of Manchester United, who usurped Liverpool's pre-eminence and established their own hegemonic control of the top level of English football. His relationships with his team mates may not have been uniformly cordial; several years later, at least one refused to appear as a character witness at his trial.

Barely a year after removing his kit from the Liverpool boot room for the last time, Grobbelaar became the central figure in a scandal concerning allegations of match fixing. Soon there were "love rat" revelations in the News of the World, made by a Zimbabwean barmaid and a "leggy Liverpool fan", both of whom dressed up in replica goalkeeping kit for the photographs accompanying the story. But the match-rigging affair, involving Far East betting rings and Grobbelaar's business partner, looked as though it might shake the game to its foundations. Now, following the appeal court's reversal of the verdict in Grobbelaar's libel action against the Sun, it threatens to do so again - particularly in a climate in which, after the Hanse Cronje story, the public no longer clings to a naive belief in the natural probity of sports stars.

Ironically enough, while Grobbelaar's lawyers have been doing battle with Rupert Murdoch's representatives, the former goalkeeper has been earning his living in South Africa, coaching a league team called Supersport United. The club, formerly known as Pretoria City, rechristened itself after it was purchased by MNET, a cable TV network whose Supersports channel carries Rupert Murdoch's Sky Sports programmes in South Africa. His time there has represented something of a return to his roots. Although he is a Zimbabwean, his grandfather was born in Cape Castle at Cape Town, a British stronghold during the Boer war, during which his great-grandfather was a fusilier in the British army. Grobbelaar himself was born in Durban in 1957.

After his service with the Rhodesian African Rifles in the war of liberation he made his way to Canada, where he played for Vancouver Whitecaps in the old North American Soccer League. He had ambitions to play in England, however, and after a brief loan period with Crewe Alexandra (for whom, curiously, he scored his only league goal) in 1979-80 he was bought by Paisley for Liverpool for a fee of £250,000. He was 22 when he arrived on Merseyside and his chance was not long in coming. At the start of the 1981-82 season he made what was to be the first of 627 first-team appearances for the club. For his first five seasons, in fact, he missed not a single league match as a member of a team graced by such great players as Kenny Dalglish, Alan Hansen, Mark Lawrenson, Graham Souness and John Barnes. Eventually he was earning around £4,000 a week - a top wage for the era - and living with his wife, Debbie, a former air stewardess, and their daughters, Tahli and Olivia, in a £250,000 house on the Wirral.

His spell at Anfield, where he also won three FA Cup winner's medals, represented Grobbelaar's only extended sojourn at any football club. After his departure in 1993, following his refusal of a one-year contract which he described as "an insult" and "like a slap in the face", his curriculum vitae over the remaining six years of his playing career reads like an extended plunge into the nether regions of English football. A loan period at Stoke City was followed by spells at Southampton, Plymouth Argyle, Oldham Athletic, Oxford United (where he lasted less than a week), Sheffield Wednesday (another loan period, shortly after he was found not guilty of all charges in the retrial of the match-rigging case), Oldham Athletic, Chesham United (for whom he turned out in a 7-1 victory over Brackley in the Ryman League in August 1998, in front of a crowd of 100), Bury, Lincoln City (who released him two days before Christmas 1998), and, finally, Northwich Victoria, another non-league side, where he was signed in October 1999 as a non-contract player to provide temporary cover for their suspended regular goalkeeper.

So far behind football's front line had Grobbelaar fallen that in 1998 he had been offering his services to Northern Spirit, an Australian league team. Spirit's manager, however, rejected the 40-year-old former European champion, preferring instead to buy Zeljko Kalac, the No 2 goalkeeper for Australia.

While his libel action took its course, Grobbelaar returned to South Africa. His first port of call was Cape Town, where he took on the management of Seven Stars, a club then shortly to be amalgamated with their local rivals, Spurs, to form a new outfit called Ajax Cape Town, with a majority shareholding in the hands of Ajax Amsterdam for whom the club would act as a nursery for talented young players.

Grobbelaar's reign did not survive the merger, however, and instead he moved north, to take over Supersports United, formerly managed by Terry Paine, the ex-Southampton winger. The team currently lie eighth in South Africa's premiership, having won seven, drawn nine and lost five of their matches so far this season. They are not an easy touch: in 21 games they have scored 23 goals and conceded only 18.

'When Grobbelaar arrived, the team were doing very badly," says Julia Beffon, sports editor of the Johannesburg Mail and Guardian. "He turned them around, and got them out of the relegation zone at the end of last season. In that sense he was certainly a success. But since then he doesn't seem to have been able to take them forward. He's quite well thought of, but he certainly isn't one of the top coaches here."

His main problem has its origins in South Africa's history. Supersports United was formed from an amalgamation of two of the city's white clubs, Pretoria City and Arcadia Shepherds. Nowadays the playing staff is almost totally black, but the club suffer by comparison with their local rivals, Mamelodi Sundowns, who have their roots in the townships. Less than an hour down the highway, the Sowetan giants Kaizer Chiefs and Orlando Pirates - the Liverpool and Manchester United of South African football - also exert a greater appeal to talented young players. "They've been trying hard to get into the schools to attract young players," says Beffon, "but they're not one of the glamour clubs. There's too much competition." Thanks to MNET, money is not a problem - although Grobbelaar is believed to earn no more than about 20,000 rand (£2,000) a month.

Tomorrow night in the Caledonian Stadium, the former home of Arcadia Shepherds, the former hero of Anfield's Spion Kop will watch as his team, the team named after a cable TV channel, take on Santos, a team from Cape Town named after the Brazilian club that nurtured Pele, the international symbol of all that is pure and admirable about football - the man, indeed, who called it "the beautiful game".

"My ambition," Grobbelaar told Simon Kuper of the Observer almost two years ago, "is to manage Liverpool." Until yesterday, he might even have believed it possible.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

Ironically enough, while Grobbelaar's lawyers have been doing battle with Rupert Murdoch's representatives, the former goalkeeper has been earning his living in South Africa, coaching a league team called Supersport United. The club, formerly known as Pretoria City, rechristened itself after it was purchased by MNET, a cable TV network whose Supersports channel carries Rupert Murdoch's Sky Sports programmes in South Africa. His time there has represented something of a return to his roots. Although he is a Zimbabwean, his grandfather was born in Cape Castle at Cape Town, a British stronghold during the Boer war, during which his great-grandfather was a fusilier in the British army. Grobbelaar himself was born in Durban in 1957. After his service with the Rhodesian African Rifles in the war of liberation he made his way to Canada, where he played for Vancouver Whitecaps in the old North American Soccer League. He had ambitions to play in England, however, and after a brief loan period with Crewe Alexandra (for whom, curiously, he scored his only league goal) in 1979-80 he was bought by Paisley for Liverpool for a fee of £250,000. He was 22 when he arrived on Merseyside and his chance was not long in coming. At the start of the 1981-82 season he made what was to be the first of 627 first-team appearances for the club. For his first five seasons, in fact, he missed not a single league match as a member of a team graced by such great players as Kenny Dalglish, Alan Hansen, Mark Lawrenson, Graham Souness and John Barnes. Eventually he was earning around £4,000 a week - a top wage for the era - and living with his wife, Debbie, a former air stewardess, and their daughters, Tahli and Olivia, in a £250,000 house on the Wirral. His spell at Anfield, where he also won three FA Cup winner's medals, represented Grobbelaar's only extended sojourn at any football club. After his departure in 1993, following his refusal of a one-year contract which he described as "an insult" and "like a slap in the face", his curriculum vitae over the remaining six years of his playing career reads like an extended plunge into the nether regions of English football. A loan period at Stoke City was followed by spells at Southampton, Plymouth Argyle, Oldham Athletic, Oxford United (where he lasted less than a week), Sheffield Wednesday (another loan period, shortly after he was found not guilty of all charges in the retrial of the match-rigging case), Oldham Athletic, Chesham United (for whom he turned out in a 7-1 victory over Brackley in the Ryman League in August 1998, in front of a crowd of 100), Bury, Lincoln City (who released him two days before Christmas 1998), and, finally, Northwich Victoria, another non-league side, where he was signed in October 1999 as a non-contract player to provide temporary cover for their suspended regular goalkeeper. So far behind football's front line had Grobbelaar fallen that in 1998 he had been offering his services to Northern Spirit, an Australian league team. Spirit's manager, however, rejected the 40-year-old former European champion, preferring instead to buy Zeljko Kalac, the No 2 goalkeeper for Australia. While his libel action took its course, Grobbelaar returned to South Africa. His first port of call was Cape Town, where he took on the management of Seven Stars, a club then shortly to be amalgamated with their local rivals, Spurs, to form a new outfit called Ajax Cape Town, with a majority shareholding in the hands of Ajax Amsterdam for whom the club would act as a nursery for talented young players. Grobbelaar's reign did not survive the merger, however, and instead he moved north, to take over Supersports United, formerly managed by Terry Paine, the ex-Southampton winger. The team currently lie eighth in South Africa's premiership, having won seven, drawn nine and lost five of their matches so far this season. They are not an easy touch: in 21 games they have scored 23 goals and conceded only 18. 'When Grobbelaar arrived, the team were doing very badly," says Julia Beffon, sports editor of the Johannesburg Mail and Guardian. "He turned them around, and got them out of the relegation zone at the end of last season. In that sense he was certainly a success. But since then he doesn't seem to have been able to take them forward. He's quite well thought of, but he certainly isn't one of the top coaches here." His main problem has its origins in South Africa's history. Supersports United was formed from an amalgamation of two of the city's white clubs, Pretoria City and Arcadia Shepherds. Nowadays the playing staff is almost totally black, but the club suffer by comparison with their local rivals, Mamelodi Sundowns, who have their roots in the townships. Less than an hour down the highway, the Sowetan giants Kaizer Chiefs and Orlando Pirates - the Liverpool and Manchester United of South African football - also exert a greater appeal to talented young players. "They've been trying hard to get into the schools to attract young players," says Beffon, "but they're not one of the glamour clubs. There's too much competition." Thanks to MNET, money is not a problem - although Grobbelaar is believed to earn no more than about 20,000 rand (£2,000) a month. Tomorrow night in the Caledonian Stadium, the former home of Arcadia Shepherds, the former hero of Anfield's Spion Kop will watch as his team, the team named after a cable TV channel, take on Santos, a team from Cape Town named after the Brazilian club that nurtured Pele, the international symbol of all that is pure and admirable about football - the man, indeed, who called it "the beautiful game". "My ambition," Grobbelaar told Simon Kuper of the Observer almost two years ago, "is to manage Liverpool." Until yesterday, he might even have believed it possible.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Historic libel verdict condemns Grobbelaar
