The appeal court ruling
The bribes and the matches
fields.trailText: Former Liverpool goalkeeper Bruce Grobbelaar faces financial ruin following yesterday's historic court of appeal ruling overturning an £85,000 libel damages award to the footballer made against the Sun newspaper.
fields.body:
Former Liverpool goalkeeper Bruce Grobbelaar faces financial ruin following yesterday's historic court of appeal ruling overturning an £85,000 libel damages award to the footballer made against the Sun newspaper.

Lawyers said last night that the ruling, which marks the first time in legal history a libel verdict has been quashed by the appeal court, could have far reaching repercussions for future libel cases.

In a devastating judgment, Lord Justice Simon Brown allowed the Sun's appeal and described the libel jury's verdict as perverse, an "affront to justice". Another of the three judges, Lord Justice Jonathan Parker, added that a miscarriage of justice had occurred in August 1999 when Grobbelaar was awarded damages against the newspaper.

Grobbelaar, who brought the case after the newspaper alleged that he was involved in throwing football matches, now faces legal costs of around £1.5m.

The former goalkeeper could also face a possible perjury charge. Hampshire Constabulary, which originally investigated Grobbelaar, did not comment on the case last night.

Grobbelaar was awarded the damages after convincing the jury in a 16-day libel trial that he was not guilty of match fixing and was in fact the victim of a malicious sting operation orchestrated by the newspaper.

Lord Justice Brown added that the "only rational view" was that Grobbelaar took payments to throw matches and that he had to correct the libel jury's verdict.

The judge described Grobbelaar as corrupt. He said he had some misgivings about allowing The Sun's appeal on the defence of justification. But he added: "That, however, is not because I entertain the least doubt about Mr Grobbelaar's guilt but because .. the court must inevitably be reluctant to find a jury's verdict perverse and anxious not to usurp their function."

Grobbelaar, 42, a former Zimbabwe international, said last night that he planned to seek permission to appeal directly to the House of Lords against the landmark decision after being denied leave by the three judges.

He has already undergone two criminal trials and a libel trial with one jury hung and two finding in his favour.

Grobbelaar added: "I am absolutely astounded and absolutely devastated at what's happened, and I feel very sorry for my family who have stuck by me through thick and thin.

"I have never done anything in football to taint the game and I strongly stand by it."

The Football Association and the Premier League announced last night that a full review of betting by footballers would be launched and that talks would also be held with Fifa, world football's governing body, on how to tighten rules.

Yesterday's ruling caught many in the legal world by surprise. Peter Carter-Ruck, the veteran libel lawyer, said last night: "I think it's astonishing. In my experience, which goes back 60 years, I've never known a case before where this has happened."

The Sun, which first published allegations against Grobbelaar in November 1994 last night claimed that it had been vindicated.

Editor David Yelland said: "For the first time in English legal history, a jury verdict in a libel action has been overturned on appeal on the grounds it was perverse and unreasonable..

"The three appeal judges have found unanimously that Bruce Grobbelaar corruptly accepted bribes to throw football matches, that his explanation for the admissions he made on the covertly recorded tapes is incredible, and that the tapes prove his guilt.

"It also vindicates the investigation carried out by the Sun into football match-fixing and the attempts of Far Eastern syndicates to corrupt Premier League football players."

All three judges cast doubt on the libel jury's decision and questioned Mr Grobbelaar's integrity. The appeal court was told the Sun had recorded evidence of Grobbelaar talking about match fixing to his former business partner Chris Vincent in 1994.

Former footballers Hans Segers and John Fashanu were also implicated in the affair but were cleared at Winchester crown court along with Grobbelaar in August 1997. Neither Mr Segers or Mr Fashanu was available for comment last night.

A statement from the Football Association and Premier League issued last night said: "We remain concerned about the way in which sport, including football, can be damaged by the activities of those outside as well as inside its jurisdiction."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: The big gamble that so nearly paid off
fields.standfirst:
He convinced three juries of his innocence, despite video evidence
Richard Williams profile
The appeal court ruling
Historic verdict condemns Grobbelaar
fields.trailText: When Bruce Grobbelaar strolled into a Southampton hotel room, warmly embraced his friend Chris Vincent and slouched in an armchair with a cigarette in his hand, the talk was of bedding women, their days in the Zimbabwean army and throwing football matches.
fields.body:
When Bruce Grobbelaar strolled into a Southampton hotel room, warmly embraced his friend Chris Vincent and slouched in an armchair with a cigarette in his hand, the talk was of bedding women, their days in the Zimbabwean army and throwing football matches.

Unknown to Grobbelaar, who made his name at Liverpool and earned the nickname "the crown prince of goalkeepers" for his zany antics, the Sun newspaper had installed secret recording equipment in the hotel room after a tip-off from Vincent that Grobbelaar was involved in accepting bribes for throwing matches.

For those who saw the video tapes during the two criminal trials involving Grobbelaar and his initial libel trial against the Sun in 1999, the evidence was compelling and threatened to tarnish the entire reputation of English football. Accused alongside Grobbelaar, who was playing for Southampton when he was secretly recorded in October 1994, were Wimbledon players John Fashanu and Hans Segers.

During the recordings, Grobbelaar talked about throwing at least three games and trying to throw others. For one, between Liverpool and Newcastle United in 1993, the Liverpool player told Vincent that he received £40,000 from a betting syndicate. He joked that he missed out on making substantial money in another match, against Manchester City because he accidentally saved the ball.

In a match against Coventry City in September 1994, which Southampton, Grobbelaar's team at the time, won 3-1, Grobbelaar told Vincent he had stood to make a small fortune if his team had lost 1-0 and that he deliberately pushed the ball into the back of the net to concede the first goal.

Following another accidental save against Manchester United, also in 1994, Grobbelaar told Vincent: "I dived the wrong way and it fucking hit my hand.

"In the Man Utd game do you know how much I lost? A hundred and twenty-five fucking thousand pounds in cash."

Vincent and Grobbelaar were former business partners who were involved in a failed safari tours business in their native Zimbabwe. The two were distant acquaintances but their friendship blossomed in 1989 when Vincent arrived in England because of their shared Zimbabwean background, love of nightlife and chasing women.

Vincent had a string of failed businesses to his name and was declared bankrupt in the early 1990s with debts of £90,000. Grobbelaar openly spoke to his friend about match fixing and for Vincent, selling the story to the Sun offered the chance to solve his financial problems. It later emerged that Vincent received £33,000 for his story and stood to make even more if Grobbelaar had been convicted during the two criminal trials at Winchester crown court in 1997.

During the secretly taped conversations in the Southampton hotel room, which were compiled over a period of weeks, Vincent asked Grobbelaar if he would be interested in throwing football matches in return for money.

Grobbelaar is filmed by the Sun accepting £2,000 as part of a down payment. He is also recorded outlining plans to throw the Southampton v Liverpool match to be played at the end of the 1994-95 football season in return for £134,000.

Vincent was recorded telling Grobbelaar that he would receive £2,000 every fortnight until the end of the football season, and £100,000 after any match he managed to fix.

The Sun's exposé of Grobbelaar's alleged involvement in match fixing appeared in November 1994. From the moment the goalkeeper was approached by Sun journalists at Gatwick airport as he made his way to Zimbabwe for an international match, he has protested his innocence.

Yesterday marked the first time in the protracted legal saga, which has so far involved two criminal cases, a 16-day libel trial and an appeal against the libel trial verdict, that a judge has cast doubt on Grobbelaar's innocence.

The Sun handed its evidence to the police and, implicated alongside Grobbelaar, was Fashanu, Segers and Malaysian businessman Heng Suan Lim, who it was alleged acted as the middleman between the footballers and a far eastern betting ring.

Within weeks of the police receiving the Sun's evidence, charges were laid against the footballers and Lim. Football's trial of the century began in January 1997.

Two months later - and with all those charged protesting their innocence - the jury found itself unable to reach a verdict. A re-trial was ordered and all were cleared by the end of the year.

After the criminal trials, Vincent returned to Zimbabwe and has not been heard of since. If Grobbelaar had been found guilty, Vincent planned to publish a book on the affair and had already agreed a £100,000 deal with publishers.

While Segers and Fashanu opted not to pursue the match-fixing allegations any further, Grobbelaar decided to sue the Sun for libel. In July 1999, following a 16-day hearing at the high court, and much to the amazement of those present, Grobbelaar was awarded £85,000 and walked out of court with his reputation intact; for the time being at least.

Grobbelaar's victories in the libel trial and the two criminal trials were as audacious as any of his performances in a Liverpool shirt. Three times he had managed to convince a jury that despite being caught on camera talking about match fixing, accepting £2,000 and plotting to throw other matches, he was in fact the innocent party and was instead trying to entrap Vincent.

Grobbelaar has alleged throughout the past six years that he always intended to return the £2,000 he was caught on camera accepting and that he intended to report match fixing to the authorities. He claimed that the match against Manchester United, when he talks about accidentally making a save, and other references he made to throwing matches were a tissue of lies, designed to entrap Vincent so that he could obtain more information and then go to the police.

Two juries believed him, one could not make up its mind. Yesterday, three judges at the court of appeal decided Grobbelaar was a corrupt, not innocent, man.

The Matches

November 1993 Newcastle United 3 Liverpool 0 Andy Cole scored a hat trick in the match within the opening half-hour. Grobbelaar was accused of taking £40,000 to throw the match. Video replays of the goals he conceded were shown in court but experts , including former Arsenal goalkeeper Bob Wilson, claimed there was little Grobbelaar could have done to stop the goals. For one goal, the ball slipped through Grobbelaar's legs

September 1994 Southampton 3 Coventry 1 Grobbelaar is recorded as saying that he would have "cleared up" if Southampton had lost 1-0. He also says on tape that he pushed the ball into the back of the net after just two minutes to ensure Southampton would concede an early goal. Once again, expert witnesses claimed that there was nothing suspicious

November 1994 Manchester City 3 Southampton 3 Grobbelaar declares on tape that he was promised £50,000 if he helped Southampton lose by one goal. His team were 1-0 up but experts again said little could have been done to prevent Grobbelaar conceding the goals by Manchester City. Former Southampton manager Alan Ball, giving evidence on behalf of Grobbelaar during the Sun libel trial, said he thought it would be impossible for a goalkeeper to throw a match

The Players

John Fashanu Fashanu, 37, was raised in a Barnado's home and has enjoyed a successful career in politics, business and entertainment since retiring from football. His aggressive style earned him the nickname Fash the Bash.

He won the FA Cup as captain of Wimbledon and at one stage was worth £6m. He joined Aston Villa but retired from football in 1996 with a knee injury.

Fashanu has amassed a fortune working in Africa where he has acted as a middleman in business deals. He has also been helping African footballers to find clubs in Europe and was closely involved in South Africa's failed bid to secure the 2006 world cup.

His Nigerian origins have made him popular with politicians in the country and in 1997 he was one of seven sports ambassadors named by Nigeria. In 1995 he married Melissa, the daughter of an African politician.

Fashanu is the brother of former Norwich City and Nottingham Forest striker Justin Fashanu, who committed suicide after he revealed that he was a homosexual.

Hans Segers A Dutch-born goalkeeper, Segers was signed to Nottingham Forest by Brian Clough in 1984. He joined Wimbledon in 1988, becoming a member of the Crazy Gang - as the team was known because of its antics on and off the pitch.

Segers made Britain his home and is involved in a number of business ventures financed by money he has made from football. Following the end of the second criminal trial in 1997, he rejoined Wolverhampton Wanderers, where he was reserve team goalkeeper.

He is currently goalkeeping coach at Tottenham Hotspur and is still registered with the Football Association as a player.

He could be on the substitutes' bench tomorrow for Tottenham's home match against Southampton.

Segers, 39, was accused of being involved in match fixing and specifically charged with accepting £19,000 from John Fashanu.

Segers was cleared of match fixing at the second Winchester crown court trial in August 1997.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

The full text of the three appeal court judges runs to more than 30,000 words. Here are extracts from the conclusions of each

Lord Justice Simon Brown

I come at last to consider the probabilities of the case and it is at this point that to my mind Mr Grobbelaar's story falls apart. He had, as it seems to me, just too much to explain away: his entire dealings with Mr Lim, his remarkable visits to Manchester and to London, his large cash transactions at around the time of the Liverpool-Newcastle match, his confessions on tape, his acceptance of Mr Vincent's first £2,000 payment (his receipt of the second thwarted only by the Gatwick confrontation), his failure during that confrontation or the subsequent telephone conversation with Mr Higgins [editor of The Sun] to offer any sensible explanation for all this, and finally his calculated and sustained deceit even of his own legal team as reflected in his initial Reply - there are simply too many improbabilities piled one upon another inherent in Mr Grobbelaar's case for it to begin to be credible. His whole account of his relationship and dealings with Mr Lim beggars belief at every turn.

I have sought to focus on those relatively few factual issues that seem to me ultimately determinative of the case. On this approach one is left with an inescapable core of fact and circumstance which to my mind leads inexorably to the view that Mr Grobbelaar's story is, quite simply, incredible. All logic, common sense and reason compel one to that conclusion.

It is, of course, understandable how a jury, skillfully deflected from the path of logic, could have accepted Mr Grobbelaar's story or at least been left undecided about it - a result fatal to the defendants upon whom the burden lay.

In this very case, it will be remembered, successive juries at criminal trials could not agree upon a verdict (at least with regard to the second count). It follows logically that at the very least a total of four jurors must have been satisfied beyond all reasonable doubt of Mr Grobbelaar's guilt on the second count. Is it not surprising that against that background the jury in this libel trial should unanimously have found the case unproved against Mr Grobbelaar even to the lesser standard required in a civil action? I think it not merely surprising but unacceptable. The result clearly represented a forensic triumph for Mr Hartley [Grobbelaar's barrister]. In my judgment, however, it represented also an affront to justice. I wouldallow the appeal.

Lord Justice Thorpe:

For all the reasons given by my lords the explanation was quite simply incredible. It was not an explanation which any reasonable jury could have accepted. I can only speculate that the jury's conceded acceptance was probably the product of a failure to properly prioritise the significance of the claimant's actions off the pitch from the elections made on the pitch. Although I recognise and respect the unique function of a jury that heard all the evidence over the course of some 16 days of trial, nevertheless it would in my opinion be an injustice to the defendants to allow the outcome to stand.

Lord Justice Jonathan Parker

I would have no hesitation in rejecting Mr Grobbelaar's explanation of his taped admissions relating to his corrupt arrangements with Mr Lim and Mr Vincent. That, however, is not the relevant question. The relevant question is whether the jury could, acting reasonably, have concluded on the balance of probabilities (and allowing for the fact that, given the seriousness of the allegations against Mr Grobbelaar, the Sun has to prove its case to a higher standard) that Mr Grobbelaar's explanation of those admissions was true.

In my judgment, the jury's verdict in this case represents a miscarriage of justice which this court can and must correct.

webTitle: Murdoch targets British Asian television market

fields.headline: Star turn
fields.standfirst:
Murdoch targets British Asian television market

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A Rupert Murdoch company yesterday joined the growing number of media outfits wooing the British Asian market with the launch of Star TV on Sky digital, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
A Rupert Murdoch company yesterday joined the growing number of media outfits wooing the British Asian market with the launch of Star TV on Sky digital, writes David Teather.

Star TV, Asia's biggest satellite television network, is initially offering two stations on the platform but is planning to import a series of channels to Britain.

By bringing Star TV to this country, Mr Murdoch is opening a new front in the battle against Subash Chandra, the Indian media magnate behind Zee TV. A joint venture between the two ended acrimoniously more than two years ago, and they are now fierce rivals.

Subscribers to the first two Star channels - Star News, which is broadcast in Hindi and English, and Star Plus, a Hindi entertainment channel - will be charged £16 a month.

The launch pitches Star TV into competition with at least 15 other stations catering for the Asian market in Britain, including market leader Zee TV, which has around 150,000 subscribers.

The move is part of a strategy at Mr Murdoch's News Corporation to broaden the reach of its wholly owned Asian TV channels.

James Murdoch, who was made chief executive of Star TV last May, shrugged off the competition. "We have proven our superiority in the domestic Asian market and will prove it again in the UK market for the Asian diaspora."

Mr Murdoch said he expected to sign up 10% of the 500,000 Asian households in Britain within 12 months. There are 1.68m Asians in this country. The company said some 3%-4% of BSkyB's subscribers are Asian.

Most of the content will be imported, although there will be some commissioned from UK-based Asian producers.

Star Plus will include the celebrity-laden Rendezvous with Simi Garewal which includes interviews with film maker Ismail Mer chant (left) and India's most popular film star, Amitabh Bachchan (above).

Mr Bachchan's latest role, as presenter of the Indian version of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire will not initially be screened in Britain. Star at present owns the rights to screen the show only in Asia.

Star broadcasts in 53 countries on 28 channels and in seven languages, and is a key part of Sky Global Networks, the amalgam of News Corps' satellite TV interests due for flotation in the next few months. Other Star channels likely to come to Britain include sports and movie based services.

fields.headline: BBC clinches Olympic boxer deal
fields.standfirst: 6pm: The BBC has signed an exclusive UK TV and radio rights deal with British Olympic super heavyweight boxing gold medal winner Audley Harrison.
fields.trailText: The BBC has signed an exclusive UK TV and radio rights deal with British Olympic super heavyweight boxing gold medal winner Audley Harrison.
fields.body:
The BBC has signed an exclusive UK TV and radio rights deal with British Olympic super heavyweight boxing gold medal winner Audley Harrison.

The deal will give the BBC exclusive live coverage of Mr Harrison's professional fights, which will be broadcast on BBC1 and Radio 5 Live, for up to two years.

Signing Mr Harrision is the first contract BBC director of sport Peter Salmon has negotiated since his appointment in November.

Mr Salmon said: "This is a serious heavyweight win. For the first time for nearly a decade, top class, heavyweight boxing will be available free to air to the whole nation."

The BBC has also secured exclusive terrestrial TV rights to the World Amateur Boxing Championships in June and the Four Nations ABA event in April.

BBC director general Greg Dyke has highlighted boxing as a sport he would like to see coming back to BBC1. In the past decade ITV and BSkyB have dominated live TV coverage of top fights featuring British boxers.

An ITV spokesman said the broadcaster had not bid for rights to Mr Harrison's fights. "He will have to fight to lots of unknowns before a bout that is big box office comes along," the spokesman added.

fields.headline: At this price?  Autonomy
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Mike Lynch, the founder and chief executive of software developer Autonomy, has stepped up his efforts to persuade investors that his Cambridge-based firm will avoid the slowdown in trade facing technology businesses.
fields.body:
Mike Lynch, the founder and chief executive of software developer Autonomy, has stepped up his efforts to persuade investors that his Cambridge-based firm will avoid the slowdown in trade facing technology businesses.

Announcing a licencing deal with Franco-American software firm Business Objects yesterday, he said Autonomy would continue to rely on an increasing number of alliances to place its core technology - data sorting software - across the world.

The statement was designed to answer growing City concerns that Autonomy had not been securing the hoped-for number of heavyweight partners.

Yesterday, the market seemed more than willing to swallow Mr Lynch's upbeat statement, sending Autonomy shares up 170p to £21.85 at the close. However, while the Business Objects deal is undoubtedly welcome news, even house broker Deutsche Bank admitted it was "not yet in the class of the likes of Seibel, SAP or Oracle".

More pessimistic still was yesterday's inaugural note on Autonomy from Merrill Lynch. "Despite the 30% fall in the share price from its highs in November, we find the stock fairly valued at current levels," it said.

Merrill believes the company is relying on signing up partners in a market which is rapidly attracting competitors offering similar technology. It is already fighting hard over some partnership deals with its rival, Verity.

As well as increased competition, Autonomy must also weather a slowdown in IT spending that is beginning to hurt many software firms. But Mr Lynch insists that companies needing to trim costs are likely to spend more on Autonomy software, which automates otherwise labour intensive tasks. It is an argument the analysts are signing up to.

In the meantime, Autonomy remains one of the great hopes of the British software industry, but its rise to the status of global giant is far from guaranteed.

webTitle: Bush considers early visit to calm European nerves

fields.headline: Bush considers early visit to calm European nerves
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George W Bush is considering making a surprise early bridge-building trip to Europe within weeks of his inauguration tomorrow as US president, American diplomatic sources say.
fields.body:
George W Bush is considering making a surprise early bridge-building trip to Europe within weeks of his inauguration tomorrow as US president, American diplomatic sources say.

Mr Bush would not normally be expected to travel to Europe until summit meetings already scheduled for this summer. But European anxieties about the new administration's national missile defence plans have forced a rethink and Mr Bush is now examining a possible pre-emptive diplomatic initiative this spring.

No detailed itinerary for such a visit has yet been discussed, but Britain, Germany and France are all under consideration as stops on what would be a high-profile visit for a new president with little direct experience of Europe.

"An early trip is definitely a possibility," a senior US official said yesterday. "We may not want to wait until the summer summits."

Mr Bush is due to attend an EU-US summit in Gothenburg in June, and to take part in the G7-G8 economic summit in Genoa in July. European leaders are also jockeying for the chance of early visits to Washington to get to know him.

The election of Mr Bush has stirred more than the usual degree of nervous European expectation that accompanies any change of administration in Washington. Several governments fear he may be tempted to rush into the introduction of the controversial missile defence project without taking into account local anxieties about the project.

Although protocol means that members of the new administration should not announce any international plans while Mr Clinton remains in office, it has already become clear that the Bush team will be quick off the mark in taking its message to Europe on defence and trade issues.

The new defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, is expected to be the first senior member of the Bush team to cross the Atlantic. Mr Rumsfeld, a key architect of the missile defence plan, is due to travel to Germany in February to attend a military conference.

The new secretary of state, Colin Powell, is also expected to visit Europe "within weeks rather than months", according to sources.

But the key issue in the US planning is the possible trip to Europe by Mr Bush. His advisers believe such a visit would help to allay anxieties about the new administration's intentions, as well as capturing the public relations initiative from European critics of the missile defence project.

Plans for Tony Blair to visit Washington to meet the new president before the expected general election are already well advanced. Mr Blair is anxious to be among the first world leaders to meet the new US leader and thus to signal that he can transfer his special relationship with Mr Clinton to his successor.

Julian Borger adds: The battle over the nomination of John Ashcroft, a leading member of the radical right, as the new attorney general reached a climax yesterday when a black Missouri judge, Ronnie White, told a Senate committee that Mr Ashcroft distorted his record to prevent his promotion.

Mr Ashcroft, a former Missouri senator, is expected to be confirmed in his post, but not before a bitter ideological exchange. The Democrats depict him as an extremist unfit to run the justice department, but Mr Ashcroft insists he will uphold all laws impartially.

webTitle: Tories accuse Blair of hunting ban ploy

fields.headline: Tory peers accuse Blair of 'cynical ploy' on hunting ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Conservative MPs and peers yesterday warned that they will fight the overwhelming Commons majority in favour of a ban on fox hunting, and accused Tony Blair of a "cynical ploy" to turn it into an election issue.
fields.body:
Conservative MPs and peers yesterday warned that they will fight the overwhelming Commons majority in favour of a ban on fox hunting, and accused Tony Blair of a "cynical ploy" to turn it into an election issue.

As anti-hunting groups and their supporters celebrated another milestone in their long campaign to outlaw hunting with dogs - Wednesday night's decisive 387 to 174 vote for a total ban - police officers accepted Tory claims that a ban would be hard to implement.

The pro-hunting hereditary peer Lord Strathclyde, Tory leader in the Lords, predicted that a cross-party coalition of peers would reject a ban when the bill reached the upper house.

But he insisted ministers knew the bill would run out of time if, as expected, they called an election for May 3 because even uncontentious measures needed six to seven weeks in the Lords, more time than the government could allow if the bill got through the Commons by early February.

"The bill will fall not because of what the House of Lords does but because of the decision the government takes," said Lord Strathclyde. "We can see that right from the very start this has been a cynical ploy by the Labour party to try to blame the House of Lords. This is not a case of the House of Lords blocking it." The prospect of stalemate faces Labour's business managers and campaign strategists with several options, including a manifesto pledge that would turn a "free vote" issue of conscience into official party policy.

That might make it easier to use the 1911 and 1949 parliament acts to push the bill through without Lords consent a year after its December 20 Commons second reading, even though an election has intervened in the meantime.

The 1911 act explicitly allows that to be done, though it has never happened and the Conservatives are poised to accuse Labour ministers of the kind of authoritarianism laid at Lady Thatcher's door when she pushed through the 1991 War Crimes Act. Lord Strathclyde called it a "nuclear weapon".

Behind the scenes peers admit that the Lords pro-hunting lobby was greatly diminished by the expulsion of all but 92 hereditaries in 1999 and that the debate will divide those who take the libertarian view and those who regard it as little better than long-banned bear baiting. They expect a majority in the Lords for the "middle way" option of licensing hunts under strict terms. It was explicitly rejected by 382 to 182 in the Commons this week.

The Association of Chief Police Officers yesterday admitted concern about enforcing a ban.

"There is a lot of concern about other aspects of the law, about crime, and obviously those decisions are all informing our decisions at local level as to where we put our resources," said Tim Hollis, assistant chief constable of South Yorkshire.

webTitle: Britain attempts to limit EU debate before polls

fields.headline: Britain attempts to limit EU debate before polls
fields.standfirst:
Government leans on sceptical Swedes to set tone for future talks

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Government leans on sceptical Swedes to set tone for future talks.
fields.body:
Britain is trying to restrict the terms of a constitutional debate about the future of the European Union and head off Tory attacks in the run-up to the general election.

Diplomats say the government is resisting calls by the European commission and member states for an early launch of substantive talks on the items agreed at last month's Nice summit.

Tony Blair wants Sweden, where the prime minister, Goran Persson, also faces popular Euroscepticism, to set the all-important tone for the talks during its EU presidency, rather than leave that to the integrationist Belgians when they take over in July.

"It'll be a disaster if the Belgians get their hands on it," one well-placed source warned.

Belgium's prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, was an angry critic of the Nice treaty, accusing big countries of selfishly pursuing their own interests in bitter and undemocratic haggling over national vetoes and voting weights.

Mr Verhofstadt, who speaks openly of the need for an EU constitution, wants far wider popular consultation now to prevent that horse-trading.

Robin Cook and other foreign ministers will discuss this sensitive issue in Brussels on Monday, when their Swedish colleague, Anna Lindh, will outline her approach.

Romano Prodi, the president of the commission, told the European parliament on Wednesday that he wanted a more ambitious "fundamental review" to go far beyond what was agreed by Mr Blair and other leaders at the summit.

Nice called for a "deeper and wider debate about "future [EU] development" and a new intergovernmental conference (IGC) to negotiate changes in 2004, by which time countries such as Poland and Slovenia may be ready to join.

Britain, anxious to give a high priority to the enlargement process, wants the next two years spent on public consultation and opposes moving prematurely to talks on issues that are bound to inflame Eurosceptic opinion.

But Mr Blair is strongly against the use of a convention, the 62-member body of MPs, MEPs and government representatives created to draw up the EU's charter of fundamental rights."It has to be something that has more impact on public opinion," said one British official.

Britain insisted that the charter - seen by some supporters as an embryonic EU constitution - must not contain any new social and economic rights and must not be legally binding, although several members want it incorporated into a new treaty.

Finland and the Benelux countries want the Nice agenda discussed by another convention. But Sweden, crucially, backs the British position that this is too narrow a forum to fully reflect public opinion and too broad to reflect government concerns.

Only governments decide the agenda for IGCs and negotiate treaty changes. Mr Blair's agreement to a new IGC was crucial to the alliance he forged with the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder at Nice.

Under the Nice plan, Sweden is to report on progress at the Gothenburg summit in June. In December, Belgium is to issue a declaration on how to carry on.

webTitle: French arms inquest spreads to Cameroon

fields.headline: French arms inquest spreads to Cameroon
fields.trailText: Further evidence of large-scale French involvement in arms-trafficking in Africa emerged yesterday with the revelation that Cameroon, the host of a Franco-African summit this week, also bought weapons from the accused French arms dealer, Pierre Falcone.
fields.body:
Further evidence of large-scale French involvement in arms-trafficking in Africa emerged yesterday with the revelation that Cameroon, the host of a Franco-African summit this week, also bought weapons from the accused French arms dealer, Pierre Falcone.

Mr Falcone, a senior adviser and middleman for Sofremi, the controversial "security equipment" export company run by the French interior ministry, was arrested last month on suspicion of organising the illegal sale of more than £300m-worth of weapons to Angola in the early 1990s.

The daily Le Monde, citing correspondence between Mr Falcone and the Cameroon defence minister, Edouard Mfoumou Akame, said Mr Falcone's company, Brenco, had sold £50m-worth of eastern European rockets, anti-tank missiles and helicopters to the Yaounde government in 1994.

Cameroon was engaged in a border dispute with Nigeria at the time - in which Paris was officially neutral, and which was being debated by the United Nations security council, then chaired by France, even as the exchange of letters got under way.

Judicial sources said magistrates would look into the latest allegations as part of a widening investigation into Mr Falcone's business activities.

fields.headline: UN's anti-drugs effort 'in chaos'
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The United Nations office responsible for fighting drugs and organised crime has been reduced to chaos during the last three years, according to a leaked memo from its Vienna headquarters.
fields.body:
The United Nations office responsible for fighting drugs and organised crime has been reduced to chaos during the last three years, according to a leaked memo from its Vienna headquarters.

The memorandum accuses Pino Arlacchi, the head of the organisation, of a tendency to announce multimillion pound projects aimed at combatting drug production worldwide. Yet, it claims, the money seldom appears and many projects are quietly abandoned.

Mr Arlacchi, a sociologist who established his reputation by fighting the Mafia in Italy, became head of the UN Office for Drug Control and Crime Prevention in September 1997.

He said last night that in every organisation where there is reform, there are people who are unhappy with change. "These are disgruntled people and some of them are spreading false accusations, rumours and garbage," he said.

The confidential memo, sent on December 6 by Michael Schulenburg, director of the operations and analysis division, is scathing. He wrote: "Despite my personal disappointment, I still feel that you are a man with exceptional energies and political qualities. But you are also the worst manager I have come across."

He left the organisation two days after sending the memo. Mr Arlacchi's spokesman, Sandro Tucci, said Mr Schulenberg's contract had not been renewed because of his performance.

Mr Arlacchi, 49, is scheduled to arrive in London on Monday for a press launch of his organisation's world report on drugs. He is to be accompanied by the British drugs chief, Keith Hellawell, and the Foreign Office minister, John Battle.

In the 11-page memo, which has been sent anonymously to selected newspapers in Europe, Mr Schulenburg went through promises allegedly made by Mr Arlacchi.

According to the memo, in 1997 Mr Arlacchi promised Afghanistan's Taliban government a $250m project for alternative development and job creation, to replace drugs cultivation, but none of the funds have been raised. Mr Arlacchi denies making any such promise.

He also disputed Mr Schulenberg's claims that efforts to raise $80m for a project in Laos had raised only $1.8m, saying that in fact the project was a success and that the US and European countries had put up $5m. Laos in the first year had cut poppy production by 30%, he said.

Mr Arlacchi added that most of the projects initiated worldwide were "alive and on-going".

fields.headline: Kremlin insider held in US
fields.trailText: Pavel Borodin, the man who got Vladimir Putin his first job in the Kremlin, was due to appear before a New York court yesterday after being detained on suspicion of money laundering when he arrived in America to attend the inauguration of George W Bush.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Moscow and  Peter Capella  in Geneva
fields.body:
Pavel Borodin, the man who got Vladimir Putin his first job in the Kremlin, was due to appear before a New York court yesterday after being detained on suspicion of money laundering when he arrived in America to attend the inauguration of George W Bush.

Mr Borodin, the former head of the Kremlin's property empire and now the secretary of the Russia-Belarus union, was detained at John F Kennedy airport on Wednesday on the basis of an international arrest warrant from Switzerland. Swiss officials want to question him about allegations of laundering $25m (£17m) through Swiss banks.

"We will be asking the US to extradite Borodin to Switzerland," said Bernard Bertossa, Geneva's chief prosecutor.

The arrest threatened to turn into a major international incident last night. Russia and Belarus demanded his immediate release. Igor Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister, called in the US ambassador in Moscow to protest.

Mr Borodin is alleged to be a central figure in a corruption scandal that plagued Boris Yeltsin's last years in office, amid claims that Mr Yeltsin's family benefited from credit cards provided by a Swiss building firm in return for contracts.

The Russian authorities dropped inquiries into the scandal last month, saying Switzerland had failed to provide adequate evidence.

The Swiss first issued the warrant a year ago when investigating commission payments of $62.5m made by a Swiss-based firm, Mercata Trading, to 14 people, including Russian political figures.

The Swiss alleged that Mr Borodin and his family had received $25m of that amount after Mercata and a construction company, Mabetex, obtained a $492m contract to renovate Russian government property including the Kremlin. Five other people are facing charges in the affair.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott on the European reaction force

fields.headline: Like it or not, the military has its place in politics
fields.standfirst:
The European reaction force will be small, but critical

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: The European reaction force will be small, but critical.
fields.body:
A division, the German general Klaus Naumann said in London this week, "is a tiny thing - you can't do a lot with it." He was speaking of the European reaction force that is supposed to be deployable by 2003 and emphasising what both critics and supporters often overlook, which is the modesty of the proposal. All that we will have, in 2003, if we have it, is a reinforced division, with naval and air components. After all, within living memory literally hundreds of divisions clashed in Europe - a division, then, was something you could lose in a day. Even in a time when technique can greatly magnify manpower, one has to say that if this is going to be a European army, it will be one in miniature. Yet, small though it may be, it could have critical political effects.

The character of the new American administration means that, whether we like it or not, the relationship between the US and Europe in the next four years is going to be even more influenced by military and military-industrial considerations than in the past. The military dialogue, whether over missile defence, the European effort to create a reaction force, the expansion of Nato, policing the Balkans, weapons procurement or readiness to deal with crises in the Middle East, Africa and elsewhere, will be important, sometimes dominant. Controversial trade questions are often connected with the military sphere, as in aviation. Europe and America are in for a rough ride over the next four years. The new administration is likely to be impatient with European concerns and out of tune with European politics. A serious falling out is quite possible.

It is going to be difficult. The US under Bush will increase military spending, in part because of defence industry pressure, exaggerate threats and over-emphasise military solutions while at the same time avoiding or retreating from the use of its military forces in emergencies. Europe, for its part, is likely to continue to talk more about military preparations than to reach into its pocket to pay for them, and the temptation to play around with the reorganisation of European armed forces as a form of political signalling may well not be resisted.

Yet, under all the posturing and the fantasies which so often govern military matters, there is a real requirement for military forces as instruments, among others, needed to deal with future crises. And there is also a real requirement to sustain the relationship between Europe and America which has, for obvious historical reasons, taken such a strongly military form in the past.

The phrase "a simple soldier" probably ought to be banned, since these days soldiers are far from simple, and military affairs have become a branch of international politics. General Naumann is a former chairman of the Nato Military Committee and one of his country's top soldiers. This means he is as well versed in alliance intricacies as he is in tank army manoeuvres. Giving the Prince Friedrich of Prussia Memorial lecture for the British- German Association at the Royal Institute of International Affairs, he offered an elegant solution to at least four different problems. Europe's difficulties with America, Britain's difficulties with Europe, Europe's military backwardness and Russia's difficulties in coming to terms with its reduced circumstances could all be dealt with, he suggested, if Britain took the lead in a new programme of European military improvement.

This would be a burst of effort, with appropriate additional spending, to catch up in certain key technical areas, especially in what is called battlefield awareness. After this push, defence spending could fall back again to more normal levels. With such an effort, the new reaction force would be effective, without it the force would either remain on paper or be inadequate if ever assembled.

How does all this connect with the large questions of strategic relations? In Naumann's view, Britain would represent to the US both the seriousness and the benign nature of the European effort. The technical improvements would restore the faltering inter-operability of American and European forces, which are getting to the point where they find it hard to communicate or go into the field together. The technical and political improvements together would keep America engaged in Europe.

America would then be better able to do a job of critical importance for Europe which Europe cannot do. That is to reassure a Russia which, in spite of its decline, responds seriously only to its old enemy, the US. Everything, in this argument, is thus neatly connected. Although Naumann speaks of adequate preparations for the reaction force as a "litmus test" for Europe, there is something about the way he reasons which suggests that it is the general improvement in capacity rather than the possibility of independent action by the Europeans which is most important to him.

The new force could be useful only in small emergencies, while the technical upgrading, and the political will it would demonstrate, would have the effect of "rebalancing" Nato and ensuring its survival. In all this Naumann is a true Nato soldier, his eye as much on the divisions that constantly threaten to render military capacity useless as on any potential enemy. Certainly, in its 50 years of confrontation with the Soviet Union, Nato had no battles with the Russians but plenty within its own ranks. Senior officers tended always to believe that resolving these internal battles was as much part of the deterrent as were the nuclear missiles or the armoured divisions guarding the Fulda Gap.

General Wesley Clark, the last Nato supreme commander, is one of those who see dangers in even the most carefully managed pursuit of a separate European military capacity. Naumann suggests instead that Nato could be strengthened and the triangular geopolitical relationship between America, Europe and Russia stabilised if it is gone about in the right way.

Within the terms he sets, Naumann's argument is a respectable one. But there must be some doubt about the endless pursuit of ever more advanced military technology, in which America may now set a stiffer pace. For one thing, arms sales tend to transfer some of such technology to potential enemies, necessitating further technical leaps in the advanced countries. For another, the requirement that western forces have overwhelming technical superiority reinforces the casualty sensitivity that is their greatest weakness.

More broadly, in both America and Europe, the military is too often seen as the right response to problems better tackled in different ways. But if military capacity nevertheless has its necessary place, especially that portion of it institutionalised in Nato, then General Naumann's ideas are worthy of consideration.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • A perceptive suggestion from the BBC's internal log of viewers' and listeners' comments receives the diary's full backing. "I enjoy the grilling of politicians on the Today programme, but they never answer your questions," an unnamed listener observes. "Why not ask them a silly question, like 'Do you like custard?', to see if they are even listening?" Sadly, a Today spokesman responds with exactly the lack of imagination we have come to expect from Britain's ruling liberal elite. "We could not rule it out, but custard would have to be relevant, and I can't remember the last time we did an item on custard," he says, declaring himself unmoved by our helpful suggestion that the topic might be included in a weightier report - something on fox hunting, say, or depleted uranium. "If the item was a serious one," he notes, perhaps not inaccurately, "it would be difficult to weave custard in."
fields.body:
 A perceptive suggestion from the BBC's internal log of viewers' and listeners' comments receives the diary's full backing. "I enjoy the grilling of politicians on the Today programme, but they never answer your questions," an unnamed listener observes. "Why not ask them a silly question, like 'Do you like custard?', to see if they are even listening?" Sadly, a Today spokesman responds with exactly the lack of imagination we have come to expect from Britain's ruling liberal elite. "We could not rule it out, but custard would have to be relevant, and I can't remember the last time we did an item on custard," he says, declaring himself unmoved by our helpful suggestion that the topic might be included in a weightier report - something on fox hunting, say, or depleted uranium. "If the item was a serious one," he notes, perhaps not inaccurately, "it would be difficult to weave custard in."

 A fresh hurdle for longtime friend of the diary Taki in his bid to avoid paying his share of Neil Hamilton's legal bill. Ever since a court set a lower limit of £5,000 for donations worth pursuing, the esteemed Spectator columnist has vowed not to reveal the extent of his generosity, "unless forced to, in which case it was £4,999." But now, faced with a court order, Hamilton fundraiser Lord Harris of High Cross has outed him as a donor of more than five grand - prompting Taki to blow several gaskets in his latest Spectator column. He confesses to stumping up £10,000 plus another undisclosed sum - but only, touchingly, because Harris told him "the case would be abandoned unless I came up with some more moolah", in return for which Harris had promised not to name him. "This is an outrage," Taki fumes. "Is an Englishman's word worth as little as that?" After all he's been through, such easily wounded faith in human nature is admirable, and we salute him for it.

 News, finally, of Rolling Stones guitarist Brian Jones, last seen looking pale and lifeless in the swimming pool of his country pile in Sussex in 1969. Brian, according to the latest edition of Psychic News, has reappeared as the spirit guide of unsuspecting Dutchwoman Yvonne Schwarts, infecting her with the spirit of Swinging London. "When I ask why he's with me, he says, 'I want you to feel the 60s'," says Schwarts. Unfortunately, Brian still has some work to do in communicating the feelgood vibe. At the moment, Schwarts writes, "the wild party comes to me in the form of a physical illness."

 A venomous press release arrives to heap condemnation on Sky TV's latest reality show, Temptation Island, in which couples are stranded in the company of frisky singletons and challenged to resist the lure of infidelity. "The most morally vacuous show ever created," it screams, quoting the Christian Institute and Relate's branding of the show as "destructive", "sad" and "a desperate way of getting people to tune in." We'd suspect a genuine groundswell of outrage, if it wasn't for the name at the bottom - Sky press officer Julian Payne. To pre-emptively scotch rumours that Sky is frenziedly trying to create a tide of fury where none exists, we call Julian. "People should have a chance to express their anger, and I would not want to stand in the way of that," he says, and is gone, leaving only the faintest whiff of desperation hanging in the air.

 Public service is, of course, the diary's primary raison d'etre, and it is in this spirit that we announce the results of the Michigan Lawsuit Abuse Watch annual contest to find America's most over-attentive product safety warnings. "Shin pads cannot protect any part of the body they do not cover," the winning entry reads, but we prefer one of the runners-up: "Eating rocks can lead to broken teeth."

"The most morally vacuous show ever created," it screams, quoting the Christian Institute and Relate's branding of the show as "destructive", "sad" and "a desperate way of getting people to tune in." fields.headline: John Rosselli
fields.standfirst: Gifted Anglo-Italian historian and musicologist who brought his intellectual substance to the Guardian and the University of Sussex
fields.trailText: The key to John Rosselli, journalist with the Manchester Guardian, historian and musicologist, who has died aged 73, was his remarkable family background on his Italian father's side
fields.body:
The key to John Rosselli, journalist with the Manchester Guardian, historian and musicologist, who has died aged 73, was his remarkable family background on his Italian father's side. This was mainly Florentine of the Risorgimento, based on wealth from the ownership of mercury mines in southern Tuscany, but sustaining a strong intellectual family tradition.

The political thinker Giuseppe Mazzini passed his last days in the home of one relative; another was a member of the government of the short-lived Venetian republic of 1849. John's grandmother, Amelia, was a cousin of Alberto Moravia and herself a prominent writer.

John's father, Carlo, an academic economist and social democrat, became the founder, funder and driving force of Giustizia e Libertà (both an action movement and a weekly paper), which constituted virtually the only effective opposition to Mussolini in the 1930s. Imprisoned in 1927 for helping anti-fascists flee from Italy, he himself escaped in July 1929 from internment on the island of Lipari and, first organising resistance to the fascists from Paris, raised the Italian contingent to the International Brigade in the Spanish civil war.

For his pains, Carlo and his brother Nello were murdered in France in May 1937. The assassins were French fascists operating on behalf of Mussolini. The funeral in Paris was one of the largest leftwing demonstrations of the Popular Front period. Many Italian towns, especially in the red belt of Tuscany and Emilia, have a boulevard named after the Fratelli Rosselli.

John (in reality Giovanni) Rosselli was deeply marked by these rich and painful antecedents. His father first met him (aged three months) in prison in Savona. His English mother, Marion, a Sussex village postmaster's daughter, joined Carlo on Lipari. On his father's escape, John grew up in Paris among the political exiles and intellectual grand bourgeois , already fluent in Italian, English and French. He was only 10 when his father was killed.

Years later, in 1960, John published a curious article in The Twentieth Century, which tended to show him as cut off from the turbid feelings of the murder. Friends from childhood thought it a kind of exorcism. One remembered that though he was not allowed to attend the funeral, he had nonetheless read all the papers and knew every available detail. Significantly, he wrote that his first thought when his mother burst in with the frightful news was, "We've been ruined."

From that moment on, as the eldest son and a boy of exceptional intelligence, with a mother suffering from heart disease, John bore himself as the family's heir apparent; his sense of responsibility became a dominant feature of his character. All this created tensions at the time with his younger brother, Andrea, and sister, Amelia, the future poet, who committed suicide in 1986.

In Paris, the Rossellis were close to the families of Elie Halévy, the great historian of Victorian England, and Louis Joxe, who later became one of de Gaulle's ministers. They spent the winter of 1939-40 with the Joxes in Nantes. As France fell, Marion announced: "I am not going to hand my children over to the enemy," (her husband's family were Jewish as well as anti-fascist) and left overnight for England and, after a few months, the United States.

In 1942, John went to Swarthmore College, near Philadelphia, where he took a BA in humanities, was assistant editor of the college newspaper, acted in plays reviewed by WH Auden (then a Swarthmore teacher), met a Baltimore Quaker, Nicky Farrar, whom he was to marry a decade later after her divorce from her first husband, and, in 1946, graduated summa cum laude .

At this point he opted to live in England to be with his mother, now seriously ill. He served in the British army - as a sergeant monitoring traffic through the port of Trieste - and, after demobilisation, buckled down to a PhD at Peterhouse, Cambridge, supervised by Herbert Butterfield, his much admired tutor and mentor. His thesis, Lord William Bentinck And The British Occupation Of Sicily, 1811-1814, won the Thirlwall prize and was published in 1956.

By this time, John was already a seasoned journalist. On Butterfield's suggestion to AP Wadsworth, then editor of the Manchester Guardian, he joined the newspaper in 1951, and soon settled in as a prompt, subtle and well-informed leader-writer. His astonishing memory and multilingual range of political, literary and musical interests - more Risorgimento son than product of the interwar age of anxiety - made him, inevitably, literary editor as well (1953-56).

Though his manner was casual enough, John had read all the books, seen all the plays, heard all the operas, kept abreast of all the developments, as if by osmosis. Colleagues with a reverence for culture admired him as an aristocrat of the mind; others, as Geoffrey Taylor admitted in his vivid Changing Faces: A History Of The Guardian 1956-1988, found him dauntingly intellectual. Either way, his voice was heard in the small circle round the editor. This was confirmed when Wadsworth (whom John loved and about whom he wrote a penetrating obituary) died in 1956 and was succeeded by Alastair Hetherington.

In the following years, a new generation took over, including strong-minded characters such as John Cole, John Maddox, David Marquand, Leonard Beaton and John himself. New commercial forces were also changing the milieu. The great issue became the transfer of the paper's headquarters from Manchester to London, to compete as a national.

John's marriage in 1956 took him south as deputy London editor under Gerry Fay, mainly because Nicky had made it a condition that they should live in London - and also have central heating, not quintessentially English at the time. In 1962, he became features editor in London, succeeding Brian Redhead in Manchester.

There was a nasty incident when Redhead organised a round robin signed by his staff to keep Rosselli out of the job. But John soon won his colleagues round, and changed the balance of features - which could have been what Redhead feared. He muted their north country accents and broadened them to a metropolitan, even cosmopolitan, range and diversity of subject matter.

But the split in staff and printing between Manchester and London, and John's own conscientiousness, began to exhaust him. He was also out of sympathy with the way he felt the paper was moving - in imitation of the Daily Telegraph, as he put it - under the commercial and cultural pressures of the 1960s. Against the current, he argued for a Guardian in the style of Le Monde, catering for high intellectual expectations, at a time when the broadsheets were trying to widen their appeal, listening less to writers and more to the marketing department.

This, and the call of the academic life, led John in the autumn of 1964 to the new University of Sussex, whose interdisciplinary approach to teaching (at least in theory) suited his breadth of outlook. He taught political and cultural history, though teaching was only one of his multifarious duties, and his acute sense of responsibility led him to accept a relentless succession of administrative jobs.

As early as 1965-67, he was chairman of the BA preliminary examination board. This was followed by the chair of the senate discipline committee, the chair of the history subject group, the chair of the working party on the future of the school of European studies, the presidency of the lecturers' union in the university, and the deanship of English and American studies (1983-85). He became a reader, but was never appointed to a chair, an omission which surprised a number of colleagues.

Gradually, and at gathering pace, Rosselli built up a body of original work of considerable quality and scope. At first, he concentrated on Lord Bentinck and (with the Einaudi publishing house in Italy) on editing his father's voluminous papers, the first tome of which appeared in 1976. Before that, in 1974, Chatto published Lord William Bentinck: The Making Of A Liberal Imperialist 1774-1839, a biography which moved on from Sicily to the great phase in Bentinck's career, as governor of Bengal in the 1820s, when he introduced policies which influenced the later waves of reform in Britain.

This led Rosselli to an interest in Bengal itself. At least one Bengali colleague considers that he learned (very rapidly) to speak and write exceptionally good Bengali, a feat at the age of 50, and that his work on late 19th-century Bengali culture was original and important. Sitting slim on his bicycle under an umbrella in Calcutta, Rosselli himself joked that he resembled a pandit.

But with research money ebbing away, and limited interest in Bengal in English academic circles, his work in this field gradually dried up and he entered his third and final phase, building on his interest in music to become a historian of opera. He had never stopped writing opera reviews for the Guardian.

From the early 1980s onwards, Rosselli produced a series of studies written ahead of schedule, yet with academic standards of research. Two books, The Opera Industry In Italy From Cimarosa To Verdi: The Role Of The Impresario (1984), and Singers Of Italian Opera: The History Of A Profession (1992), opened up a neglected field, the economic history of opera. He also wrote a number of articles for the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, which led on to four other works. The first was Music And Musicians In 19th-century Italy (1991).

Then came three biographies in the Cambridge University Press series of musical lives, Bellini (1996), Mozart (1998) and Verdi (2000). All were notable for the depth conferred by John's knowledge of the social and cultural background, especially in Italy, and one at least, Bellini, for substantial new findings. His writing in his early years was sometimes a little wooden, but most of this later work is conversational, rapid and relaxed, and sometimes a delight to read.

Within four months of his wife's sudden death in February 1989, John took early retirement, sold his house in Brighton (a town he never liked), moved to Cambridge and, though secular by family tradition, entered the Anglican communion. It transpired that he had been considering this for at least 20 years, but had not done so because his wife felt she could not follow him. In 1995, he moved to a village south of Siena, and latterly to Florence, with a distant cousin, Lisa Sarfatti, a widow of great charm.

With all his activities and interests, John was a very private man with great self- control, who was able to wear, at the age of 70, the evening clothes made for him when he was 18. He was an assiduous friend and devoted family man, with an assumption of closeness perhaps more Italian than British.

He was a liberal of deep moral and intellectual strength, with spiritual leanings he did not wear on his sleeve, a papabile in his spheres, who might have edited a national paper and, some thought, should have held a chair; but he did neither and was too disciplined, and had too many interests, for really keen regrets.

He died in Cambridge and is survived by Lisa and two sons.

fields.headline: I see no evidence of harm
fields.standfirst:
The Ministry of Defence's chief scientific adviser attacks the press

Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Keith O'Nions, the Ministry of Defence's chief scientific adviser attacks the press
fields.body:
The reporting of the effects of depleted uranium (DU) has given rise to misunderstanding and unnecessary anxiety. The facts and evidence surrounding DU are widely available in the public domain and open to review by the scientific community.

DU is less radioactive than natural uranium, but its high density and hardness make it ideal for attacking enemy tank armour. No comparably effective material is available. The Royal Navy uses DU ammunition, but the targets are not armoured, and we do not need the extra penetration provided by DU. In the future, therefore, shells will increasingly be made from tungsten.

DU's relatively weak radioactivity could in theory and over a period of years increase incidence of cancer. DU is also a heavy metal and chemically toxic in the same way as uranium that occurs naturally. The risks are similar to those of lead. Ingested in large amounts, it could lead to kidney failure.

In theory, soldiers might be exposed through handling or being close to DU rounds in a tank. But in practice these risks are very low, and can be guarded against. The very low levels of radioactivity involved are well determined and given the instructions issued by the MoD this risk is near negligible. The risk from toxicity is also very low.

In the immediate vicinity of an armoured vehicle struck by a DU round, individuals might inhale or ingest DU oxide dust generated. So those approaching such vehicles are instructed to wear protective clothing. Because of this there is no evidence from those who served in the Gulf or the Balkans of either acute or chronic kidney damage attributable to DU intake. Some Gulf veterans do have kidney damage, but each case examined has been attributed to other specific diseases and not to their service. No published research links Gulf illnesses to heavy metal poisoning.

In addition, there is a small theoretical radiological risk from insoluble DU lodging in the lungs. The MoD has published estimates of this risk for possible scenarios in the Gulf war. If a soldier spent two to three hours inside a DU contaminated tank on dust-raising activities, without protective measures he might receive a radiation dose which, according to the International Commission on Radiological Protection, could generate an increased lifetime risk of cancer of 12 in 100,000. Around 40% of people in the UK will contract cancer in their lifetime. Recent work published by the US office of the special adviser for Gulf war illnesses before Christmas estimates the potential exposure in this sort of scenario as much lower. In any case the measures the MoD insists personnel take should further reduce this risk to a negligible level.

This is not just the MoD's view. Research published by the Rand Corporation, by the US agency for toxic substances and most recently by the US Institute of Medicine concludes that there is no evidence linking DU and lung cancer at low levels of exposure, or DU and clinically significant renal dysfunction. Nor was there any evidence to link DU to a range of other cancers, nervous system disease, respiratory disease and other health outcomes. US research also includes detailed examination of US veterans who have DU shrapnel embedded in their bodies and who still have no evidence of associated medical problems.

This data is consistent with Gulf veteran mortality. Up to December 31 of over 53,000 Gulf veterans, 477 had died of all causes, compared to 466 in a similar control group who had not been in the Gulf. Of these 168 had died of disease compared to 208 in the control group. Of those, 69 Gulf veterans had died of cancers, (77 in the control group). In both groups the prevalence of cancer was substantially less than to be expected in comparable groups of the civil popu lation in England and Wales of the same age (100-120 deaths). It is untrue that Gulf veterans have evidence of excess mortality from cancer.

There is no evidence to link DU with any illness suffered by any individual. We have always said that DU can represent a low level and well- understood risk. But we have also always made clear that the risks are very small, can be guarded against and are outweighed by the protection DU offers our troops in combat.

Following some of the sensational reporting, to reassure members of the armed forces who remain concerned, it has been decided to put in place an additional appropriate voluntary screening programme, to be constructed with the advice of reputable independent scientific bodies, including the Royal Society. The tests will be carried out by external independent laboratories.

Again I would stress that facts and evidence surrounding this issue are clearly established and in the public domain. Proper scientific and medical debate based on this and any further evidence is to be encouraged and the MoD will remain open-minded. But ill-founded comment, conjecture or assertions derived in an irresponsible manner will serve only to cause distress to serving personnel, veterans and their families.

fields.headline: Patten urges nuclear cleanup
fields.standfirst:
Russia's 300 dumped reactors linked to Kursk aid

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Around 300 nuclear reactors and thousands of spent nuclear fuel rods dumped in the Russian Arctic are an immediate danger to Russians and Europeans alike, and require urgent action, Chris Patten, the European Union's external relations commissioner, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Around 300 nuclear reactors and thousands of spent nuclear fuel rods dumped in the Russian Arctic are an immediate danger to Russians and Europeans alike, and require urgent action, Chris Patten, the European Union's external relations commissioner, warned yesterday.

Speaking to Russian officials and diplomats in Moscow, Mr Patten called on the western European nuclear engineering industry to start cleaning up the world's biggest nuclear graveyard in Russia's far north. But he also feared that Brussels' bid to persuade Moscow to allow in outside remedial teams had run into opposition, not least because of Russian military secrecy.

Russian admirals, in particular, are against external assistance with problems that involve military resources.

The risk of wide-scale radioactive contamination from the reactors in dozens of abandoned submarines, formerly part of Russia's northern and Baltic fleets, were highlighted by Moscow's laboured response to the Kursk tragedy last summer. But Mr Patten, the EU's foreign policy supremo, pointed to a problem that could dwarf the Kursk disaster in its scale.

"In the seas and the shores surrounding the Kola peninsula, there are some 300 nuclear reactors - about 20% of the world's total - and thousands of spent nuclear fuel elements," he said. "The lack of adequate storage or disposal facilities for spent fuel and radioactive waste from the reactors of nuclear vessels is a sword of Damocles hanging over all our futures."

The fjords of the peninsula are littered with scores of inoperable nuclear submarines, abandoned like beached whales. Their hulks lie as testimony to the disastrous decline of the once mighty Soviet navy. The navy dockyards are crumbling, the sailors go hungry and unpaid.

Mr Patten said the problem of nuclear safety in the far north was the most "dramatic" of all the issues on which Brussels and Moscow should seek enhanced cooperation during Sweden's term in the EU presidency.

EU countries are being asked to make a hefty contribution towards the estimated £47m needed to raise the stricken Kursk and its two nuclear reactors next summer. Mr Patten was expected to discuss the Kursk with Russian officials during his two-day trip.

It appeared that Sweden, in particular, was pushing for more ambitious nuclear safety programmes and cleanup operations in the Arctic in return for agreeing to fund the Kursk salvage operation.

fields.headline: Laurent Kabila
fields.standfirst: His lifelong quest for power in Congo was destroyed by ineptitude at home and abroad
fields.trailText: His lifelong quest for power in Congo was destroyed by ineptitude at home and abroad
fields.body:
Laurent-Désiré Kabila, president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, who has been assassinated aged 61, was a cheerful, rubicund rogue, portly in middle age, who spent most of his life in exile, engaged in the illegal diamond trade and wild schemes to overthrow the dictatorship of Joseph-Désiré Mobutu, his immediate predecessor. Along the way, he briefly recruited Che Guevara in 1965, and the armies of Uganda and Rwanda, which helped bring him to power in 1997.

Kabila's survival skills served him well in exile, but deserted him once he had moved into the presidential palace. He had hoped that his wide international contacts would enable him to play the role on the wider African stage that the intrinsic size and importance of Congo would seem to indicate. But political errors on the home front soon brought internal dissension, arguments with his foreign backers, and a return to Congo's endemic civil war. Soon, he was turning to other foreign friends with desperate appeals for military assistance. At his death, wide areas of the country were outside his government's control.

At the dawn of Congo's independence from Belgium in 1960, Kabila was one of the bright young men who might have become a star in his country's politics. Yet after the United Nations intervention and the 1961 assassination of the independence leader Patrice Lumumba, the cream of the radical Congolese were exiled. Kabila, who came from the secessionist southern province of Katanga, studied briefly in Paris and Belgrade, before returning home in 1963.

Briefly an elected assemblyman for North Katanga, when parliament was closed down later in the year, he joined with other Lumumbists in staging a widely-supported rebellion, backed by both the Chinese and the Russians, and half a dozen radical African states.

The rebellion attracted the attention of the United States, then panicking about possible Soviet gains in newly-independent Africa. Averell Harriman and Cyrus Vance masterminded a plan that involved a coup to install a reliable western ally, Moise Tshombe. As well as weapons, the Americans recruited Belgian officers, exiled Cuban pilots, and white southern African mercenaries.

Kabila, who had established himself at Albertville (Kalemie), on the western shores of Lake Tanganyika, was soon forced by the mercenaries to retreat to the borders of Rwanda and Burundi. In Stanleyville (Kisangani), resistance was destroyed by Belgian paratroopers, airlifted in by a joint US-European operation in November 1964.

Forced to retreat, Kabila and his friends turned to the Cubans, and Che Guevara arrived on the Tanzanian-Congo border with a small contingent of guerrilla fighters in April 1965; Guevara recorded that Kabila "made an excellent impression", though he subsequently reconsidered this view.

Although Kabila appeared "quick and charming" - when he deigned to turn up - he was usually engaging in conspiratorial politics in Dar es Salaam, or negotiating with China's Chou En-lai or North Korea's Kim il-Sung. When he did meet Guevara, holed up on a bleak mountain-top, he came with ample supplies of whisky and bevies of attractive women. After six months, the rebellion petered out, the Cubans went home, Mobutu overthrew Tshombe, and Kabila began 30 years in the political wilderness.

He moved between Dar and Kampala, and made occasional forays into the Kivu region of Congo, re-establishing the "liberated zone" of which Guevara had dreamed, and funding his political activities by gold and ivory trading. Later, when finally driven from Congo, he made friends with Yoweri Museveni, then preparing to lead a rebel movement in Uganda.

Kabila did not reappear on the international stage until May 1997, when his forces captured Kinshasa after a 10-day campaign. He was greeted as a liberator as his rebels moved south, supported by the eastern Congo's Tutsis and Rwandan and Ugandan army units.

Mobutu fled before the fall of Kinshasa, and the new President Kabila renamed the country - Mobutu's Zaire - as the Democratic Republic of Congo, and indicated that he would follow in the footsteps of Museveni, who had created a liberal and competent Ugandan government. He then promptly fell out with his Uganda and Rwandan backers, who assisted a new Congolese rebellion in August 1998.

Ugandan-backed rebels again advanced from the north-eastern borders and threatened Kinshasa. Kabila invoked his friendship with Angola, Zimbabwe and Namibia's erstwhile leftist governments, and their troops fought off the rebellion.

But the war continued and had an inevitable impact on his style of government. Deeply influenced by Congo's tragic history of foreign intervention, Kabila resurrected nostrums from his 1960s leftist past. He established a one-party state, promised - but never delivered - elections, and alienated foreign investors by refusing to make payments on the gigantic foreign debt of $14bn incurred by his profligate predecessor. He also ignored UN demands for an inquiry into the massacre of Rwandan refugees in eastern Congo in 1997.

Well-meaning brokers like Nelson Mandela sought to mediate an end to the war, but Kabila refused to take any notice. His mercurial temperament, and his ability to change sides, left him with few friends either at home or abroad. In the end, his early promise was dissipated in his futile attempt to retain Congo as his personal fiefdom, much as Mob-utu had done before him.

He is survived by his wife, and his son Joseph.

 Laurent-Désiré Kabila, politician, born November 27 1939; died January 17 2001
