fields.headline: City briefing
fields.standfirst: Ford | Prudential | Abbey Life | AltaVista | BP
fields.trailText: Ford earnings decline 33%
fields.body:
Ford earnings decline 33%

Ford Motor Company, the world's second largest carmaker, yesterday reported a 33% drop in fourth-quarter operating earnings due to weaker results from its core north American operations.

Ford said it earned $1.2bn (£800m) or 64 cents per share in the quarter, from $1.8bn, or 83 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. The Bridgestone-Firestone tyre recall cost Ford about $250m in the quarter, bringing the total for the year to $500m.

North American automotive earnings, excluding extraordinary items, dropped to $740m from $1.55bn, reflecting a drop in US sales and cuts in vehicle production as the economy softened.

Ford said its revenues fell 3% in the fourth quarter, to $42.6bn from $43.9bn a year earlier.

Pru rules out Equitable bid

Prudential yesterday ruled out any hope that it would reconsider bidding for Equitable Life even though attempts are being made to put a limit on the mutual insurance group's guaranteed annuities.

Equitable this week sent out detailed financial information to parties which have re-expressed an interest in buying part or all of its business. These are thought to include Aegon and GE Capital, although the certainty of a new buyer being found after the last sale was abandoned in December is said to be by no means certain.

Prudential yesterday released sales figures for 2000 which for the first time showed that more than half of its sales came from outside the UK, where its sales of insurance and investment products fell to £2.3bn from £2.5bn. Its total insurance and investment sales rose 13% to £13.9bn.

Abbey Life outsources

British life assurance group Abbey Life, a subsidiary of Lloyds TSB, said yesterday it was outsourcing the administration of its life policies to computer services company Unisys Corporation.

Under the contract, worth more than $300m (£204m) over 10 years, Unisys will support the processing and management of Abbey Life's 1.5m life insurance policies.

Abbey Life will transfer 1,000 of its staff to a new Unisys subsidiary, Unisys Insurance Services.

AltaVista lays off 200 staff

Internet search company AltaVista yesterday said it laid off 200 employees or about 25% of its staff in its latest move to deal with the persistently weak online advertising market on which it depends for revenue. AltaVista is majority owned by internet development firm CMGI, which holds a stake in several internet companies, has been hit hard by the industry's downturn.

BP questions fuel taxation

BP Amoco said yesterday that government fuel taxation policies are driven more by financial income than green ideals.

"We have observed that governments are apparently more driven by revenue than environmental objectives when setting the level of fuel duties," the company said in a written report to Parliament's environmental audit select committee.

webTitle: Baldness cure fails to stimulate a City recovery

fields.headline: Baldness cure fails to stimulate a City recovery
fields.trailText: Plant-based drugs company Phytopharm disappointed dozens of City stockbrokers and traders yesterday by admitting its cure for baldness, which has been on trial in the Square Mile, does not work.
fields.body:
Plant-based drugs company Phytopharm disappointed dozens of City stockbrokers and traders yesterday by admitting its cure for baldness, which has been on trial in the Square Mile, does not work.

The company's scalp ointment, P45, is derived from a family of Mediterranean lilies named drimea. Phytopharm began trials after hearing an "anecdote" about its use in stimulating hair growth in north Africa and southern Europe.

Clinical studies began in 1999 at three trichology clinics - one in Nottingham and two in the City of London. Wealthy, balding brokers were persuaded to spend a year slapping cream on their heads each morning.

The results were described as "weird" by Phytopharm's chief executive, Richard Dixey. P45 stimulated hair growth in 29% of patients. But a control group, who were given ordi nary cold cream, had a success rate of 38%.

Dr Dixey said: "This is a complex story, really.

"A lot of people were regrowing hair halfway through the trial, and were getting very excited about it. But it turns out many of them were in the cold cream group.

"Unfortunately, male pattern baldness is very poorly understood. It may well be that the drug was doing something, but that it was masked by the astonishing placebo result."

The product's failure drove Phytopharm's shares down 132.5p to 730p.

Dr Dixey said: "This really is a very weird result. The size of the placebo effect is greater than any study has ever shown before."

In previous attempts to treat baldness, US firms Merck and Pharmacia reported a steady continuation of hair loss in their placebo groups.

For Phytopharm, one problem was compliance - 75 men began the trial but only 24 stuck with it to the end. A third of those taking P45 complained that the cream made their scalp itch.

In cases where regrowth did take place, Dr Dixey said: "It was significant enough for the poor punter looking in the mirror each morning to be very encouraged."

The firm is waiting for the results of its trials on alopecia totalis - total baldness - before deciding whether to scrap P45 entirely. It still has 12 products in clinical development.

webTitle: Star burst Games firm loses 47% as Genesis-backed site slumps

fields.headline: Star burst Games firm loses 47% as Genesis-backed site slumps
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: A slump in the value of an investment made in a music website backed by Phil Collins and Mike Rutherford of Genesis (above) was a key factor behind SCI Entertainment's surprise decision to issue a profits warning yesterday.
fields.body:
A slump in the value of an investment made in a music website backed by Phil Collins and Mike Rutherford of Genesis (above) was a key factor behind SCI Entertainment's surprise decision to issue a profits warning yesterday.

The announcement wiped 47% off the value of the computer games firm's shares and came just four weeks after it issued a statement reassuring investors that trading for the year to September 30 was "in line with expectations". The shares closed down 137.5p at 177.5p, compared to a year's high of 591p.

SCI is understood to have written off the bulk of a £1m investment it made in music site Music3w.com last January.

The web firm, also backed by the Genesis stars, publisher Keith Young, Hewlett Packard and venture capitalist Elderstreet Investments, has just closed a new funding but at one quarter of the £20m valuation it commanded last year.

Music3w operates official sites for artists such as UB40 and Bryan Adams. SCI is thought to have taken a last-minute decision to carry the value of its investment in its figures, as well as provisions relating to last year's acquisition of rival games publisher Actualize, along with adjustments in the way it recognises revenues in its accounts.

Income from a licence with a US publisher that SCI hoped to book this year will now be recognised in the year to September 30, 2001.

The combination of the various factors mean that an expected £1.8m pretax profit is likely to turn into a loss of around £3m.

The share price slump underlines the controversial way in which some hi-tech and software companies record their rev enues. Many book revenues as soon as an order is taken but accountants prefer them to be recorded once the product is delivered.

SCI's auditor, Arthur Anderson, is thought to have recommended that revenues from the US licencing deal is not recognised until royalties start filtering through from sales.

webTitle: Virgin bid for east coast railway back on track

fields.headline: Virgin bid back on track
fields.standfirst: Treasury considers rescue for Branson's east coast 'value for money' railway
fields.trailText: The Treasury could rescue at the last minute a plan by Sir Richard Branson to build a 120 mile high-speed railway line between London and Yorkshire which was scrapped by Sir Alastair Morton, the chairman of the strategic rail authority, industry sources said last night.
fields.body:
The Treasury could rescue at the last minute a plan by Sir Richard Branson to build a 120 mile high-speed railway line between London and Yorkshire which was scrapped by Sir Alastair Morton, the chairman of the strategic rail authority, industry sources said last night.

The right to operate the east coast mainline was contested by its present operator, Great North Eastern Railway, and a Virgin-Stagecoach joint bid.

GNER planned to upgrade the existing route for 140mph tilting trains while Sir Richard wanted a high-speed line parallel to the existing route to run trains similar to the French TGVs.

Letters circulating within the industry say the decision to scupper Virgin's "value for money" plan was taken by Sir Alastair despite a recommendation from the authority's bid team that Sir Richard's proposal provided better value than GNER.

The letters say the authority's bid team believed the joint bid by Virgin Trains and Stagecoach would save £1.5bn. But the recommendation was overruled by Sir Alastair. Instead, he recommended to ministers that GNER should be granted a 20-year extension.

The SRA would make no comment last night, saying that a decision was still awaited from the government.

The franchise round has seen considerable political infighting. To head off criticism that it has been involved in a fudge, the SRA said that it is interested in the idea of a new line and could set up an inquiry to study its feasibility.

The issue has been in front of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, for six weeks. It has been delayed to allow the Treasury to decide whether Sir Richard's bid provides a better deal.

It comes when the rail industry needs to show initiative after the track repair debacle following the Hatfield crash. It would be built alongside the existing east coast line. Only high speed trains would be allowed to use the dedicated track, and there would be no stops on the way. It would begin near Peterborough and join the existing line near York.

The proposed new line would run mainly through farmland. It would take at least 10 years to build, but could allow trains to travel at speeds approaching 200mph.

The issue reflects badly on the government and the SRA. Before Christmas ministers were letting it be known that GNER had won the bid, despite the praise heaped on Virgin's plan.

The SRA has also failed to provide its own strategic plan for the industry, despite the fact that it has been around for almost two years. Train companies say that the SRA lacks direction and that it is working in a vacuum.

Virgin would make no comment last night. Privately the Virgin team is furious that such an important project should be snatched away from them in this way.

Sir Richard is still smarting from the ruling that the National Lottery should remain with Camelot. He considers the east coast bid the kind of project to win back passengers to the troubled network.

 The court of appeal yesterday rejected an appeal by Railtrack to reinstate signal 109, at the heart of the Paddington rail crash in October 1999. Mr Justice Sullivan said the appeal was ill-advised. A prohibition notice imposed by the health and safety executive would remain in place.

Instead, he recommended to ministers that GNER should be granted a 20-year extension. The SRA would make no comment last night, saying that a decision was still awaited from the government. The franchise round has seen considerable political infighting. To head off criticism that it has been involved in a fudge, the SRA said that it is interested in the idea of a new line and could set up an inquiry to study its feasibility. The issue has been in front of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, for six weeks. It has been delayed to allow the Treasury to decide whether Sir Richard's bid provides a better deal. It comes when the rail industry needs to show initiative after the track repair debacle following the Hatfield crash. It would be built alongside the existing east coast line. Only high speed trains would be allowed to use the dedicated track, and there would be no stops on the way. It would begin near Peterborough and join the existing line near York. The proposed new line would run mainly through farmland. It would take at least 10 years to build, but could allow trains to travel at speeds approaching 200mph. The issue reflects badly on the government and the SRA. Before Christmas ministers were letting it be known that GNER had won the bid, despite the praise heaped on Virgin's plan. The SRA has also failed to provide its own strategic plan for the industry, despite the fact that it has been around for almost two years. Train companies say that the SRA lacks direction and that it is working in a vacuum. Virgin would make no comment last night. Privately the Virgin team is furious that such an important project should be snatched away from them in this way. Sir Richard is still smarting from the ruling that the National Lottery should remain with Camelot. He considers the east coast bid the kind of project to win back passengers to the troubled network.  The court of appeal yesterday rejected an appeal by Railtrack to reinstate signal 109, at the heart of the Paddington rail crash in October 1999. Mr Justice Sullivan said the appeal was ill-advised. A prohibition notice imposed by the health and safety executive would remain in place.

webTitle: Market forces: Takeover talk boosts BG

fields.headline: Takeover talk boosts BG
fields.trailText: BG, the gas exploration and production group, was gripped by takeover speculation which market professionals were not prepared to dismiss out of hand.
fields.body:
It was not the most original tale traders have ever heard. In fact for many, it was tediously familiar. But BG, the gas exploration and production group, was nevertheless gripped by takeover speculation which market professionals were not prepared to dismiss out of hand.

The alluring tale had the group, capitalised at more than £9bn, in talks with US rival Conoco over a 325p-a-share bid and, after employing a bit of lateral thinking, the story seemed to stack up.

BG has been under the speculators' magnifying glass since it demerged its pipeline business - now known as Lattice, off 0.5p at 132.5p - in October. The thinking being, that is, that BG is too small to survive in world dominated by the idea that size is everything.

And Houston-based Conoco is a big player in the global gas industry. Not only does it control Britain's biggest natural gas-condense field, Britannia, in conjunction with Chevron, but it also has gas production operations in the United States, Venezuela, Russia, Norway and Indonesia.

Moreover, its corporate goal is to become a $30bn (£21bn) company by 2003, something which only seems achievable via a big acquisition.

But sadly for the speculators, those with an unfettered view of the sector do not think that Conoco - with a market capitalisation of around $17bn - can afford the sort of price BG is likely to want.

That said, BG shares still ended 7.5p higher at 261p on a day when most of the market was moving sideways.

After Wednesday's 114-point gain on hopes of lower US interest rates, there was a marked reluctance on the part of the big institutions to chase blue chips stocks higher.

Not there was any shortage of good news to latch on to. Overnight figures from IBM matched expectations, a factor which helped the FTSE Techmark 100 close 70.77 points higher at 2,726.64.

Moreover, weak retail and manufacturing data had economists predicting that the next move in domestic interest rates would be down.

But investors remain wary of committing fresh capital until a clearer picture emerges about whether there is going to be a hard or soft landing in the north America. So, after trading in a narrow 45.8 point range, the FTSE 100 index came to rest just 12.5 higher at 6,209.9, with turnover down on recent levels.

Dealers attributed the slight gain to a good showing from market heavyweight BP, up 9p at 578p, which benefited from a steady crude price, and media issues like Pearson, 96p higher at £16.56 and BSkyB, 34p better at £11.58.

The life assurance sector was in good form. Royal & SunAlliance picked up 13p to 521p as dealers looked on the bright side of a mixed trading update, and the Prudential added 27p to £10.27 after reporting a 13% rise in annual sales.

Other risers included Autonomy, up 170p at £21.85, after what analysts were describing as landmark licensing deal with French data analysis outfit Business Objects.

Celltech's recent strong run continued. Up 71p on Wednesday, it added a further 75p to £12 in response to a Merrill Lynch recommendation. The broker reckons Celltech has one of the strongest product pipelines of any biotech firm in Europe.

On the down side, Scottish Power eased 11p to 430p after Dresdner Kleinwort Wassertein took on a line of 5.2m Scottish Power shares for a client at 418.5p and set about placing them in the market.

According to informed market sources, Dresdner managed to place 4m of shares at a price of 422p each and retained the rest.

Lower down the corporate ladder, Nightfreight added 0.25p to 63p on whispers that the parcel delivery company could announce a 75p-a-share offer as early as today.

Casino operator London Clubs International fell 2.5p to 56.5p, hit by dark mutterings about its financial position.

fields.headline: Shops forced to slash prices
fields.standfirst: New statistics show steady growth but retailers continue to feel the pinch
fields.trailText: New statistics show steady growth but retailers continue to feel the pinch.
fields.body:
British retailers were forced to slash prices to attract customers in the run-up to Christmas and even then achieved only modest sales growth, according to official figures published yesterday.

Sales volumes increased by 0.1% in December compared with November, clipping the annual rate of growth to 4.4% from 4.7%, the office for national statistics said.

The headline figure disguised marked differences of performance between sectors, with clothing doing badly but household and "other goods", including mobile phones, enjoying sharply higher sales. However, there was no evidence that demand pressures are forcing up prices.

The so-called "deflator", a measure of inflation on the high street, fell 0.6%, after a 0.3% fall in November, suggesting that retailers' profit margins remain under intense pressure.

The surprisingly weak sales figures boosted hopes in financial markets that the next move in interest rates will be down but some analysts cautioned against reading too much into one month's data.

Ross Walker, of the Royal Bank of Scotland, said: "The vagaries of the seasonal adjustment process tell us that it is rare for both November and December to record monthly gains.

"Excepting last year's bumper millennium sales, the last time consecutive monthly increases were recorded in November and December was back in 1991. Our emphasis would be on the robust rise of 1.3% in the latest three months compared to the previous three, and 4.4% in the latest three months compared to the same three months a year ago."

ONS confirmed that underlying sales growth was in line with the trend throughout 2000. Other evidence that the UK economy is continuing to grow steadily came from the British chambers of commerce which said manufacturing sales and orders in the home market edged forward in the final quarter of last year, though exports remained under pressure from the strength of sterling and competition.

The larger services sector enjoyed a rebound in trade in the home market and exports were stable.

Both manufacturing and services are suffering from skills shortages, suggesting the slowdown in the labour market seen in official figures published on Wednesday may owe more to recruitment difficulties than weakening demand for labour. A record number of manufacturers had difficulty finding semi- and unskilled staff, the BCC said.

Ian Fletcher, BCC chief economist, said: "There are signs that UK manufacturing is climbing out of the doldrums, but smaller firms in particular are continuing to struggle in export markets. The recent fall in the trade-weighted value of sterling should offer some relief to hard-press manufacturers but intense competition will make it difficult for them to restore margins.

"Manufacturing is particularly at risk from a slowdown in US growth and pre-emptive action is needed to help bolster confidence and investment in the sector."

He said an interest rate cut, of 0.25%, would be preferable to corporate tax cuts because the benefits were likely to spread more widely.

But Michael Saunders, economist at Schroder Salomon SmithBarney, said that with no sign that growth was slowing significantly, base rates were likely to remain on hold at 6% for some time.

fields.headline: Bargain basement
fields.trailText: Matalan, the out-of-town clothing retailer and former stock market darling, is still alive.
fields.body:
Matalan, the out-of-town clothing retailer and former stock market darling, is still alive.

Yesterday, for the first time since last week's disappointing Christmas trading update, buyers emerged for its shares, driving them 32p higher to 420p.

Some investors think they have picked up a bargain, just like the clothes Matalan sells.

While there is no doubt Matalan was grossly overvalued before last week's trading update, at 420p (down 307p in six trading sessions) they might represent reasonable value.

Taking into consideration its future growth rate, analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein put fair value for Matalan shares at 500p. Moreover, they say stock availability problems that were behind the fall in like-for-like sales and margins are not fundamental - just those of a rapidly growing company.

fields.headline: CJD risk 'right to know' plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Patients could be given more right to know that they may have contracted the human form of BSE from contaminated blood transfusions or surgical instruments following a sustained rise in the number of victims of new varient Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease.
fields.body:
Patients could be given more right to know that they may have contracted the human form of BSE from contaminated blood transfusions or surgical instruments following a sustained rise in the number of victims of new varient Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease.

The current guidance says doctors should not generally inform patients because the uncertainty could blight their lives when there is no test, no cure, and no treatment for the inevitably fatal disease. But the ethical advice is now said to be "under active review".

With 13 of the 88 cases of vCJD in this country now known to have been blood donors, fears are growing about the number of people who could have been contaminated. Directors of haemophilia centres are already offering advice and counselling to patients who used a clotting product dating from 1996-97 that has recently been found to have included donations from a vCJD victim.

The same batch was used in vaccines and blood products exported to nine other countries including Ireland. Karin Pappenheim, head of the Haemophilia Society, said last night: "We are trying desperately to reassure people. We have just had a father in tears (because his) daughter used this product."

Twenty-three people are known to have had transfusions with blood from implicated donors and blood products from those donors have gone into batches used in both vaccines and clotting factors used on thousands of people. Government scientists insist there is no evidence that anyone has yet caught vCJD in this way and that measures introduced in the last three years should have reduced the theoretical risk substantially .

Other changes are on the way with more disposable surgical intruments and even a possible ban on anyone who has ever received a blood transfusion becoming a donor. The blood service is anxious to ensure supplies, since shortages would put far more people at risk, but there is growing recognition that patients should have the right to decide whether they want to know about possible risks, rather than leaving the decision to doctors alone.

The NHS guidance was drawn up three years ago. It suggested that "the general view is that patients will not benefit from this knowledge" but left it open to doctors to decide. A special committee is now reviewing the advice.

Many haemophiliacs were told and help lines offering people the opportunity to find out have been set up in at least two hospitals where contaminated instruments were used.

There is a huge campaign to make England follow the example of Scotland, Wales and Ireland which gives all haemophiliacs synthetic clotting factors. Children under 16 in England get similar treatment but provision for others is patchy.

Campaigners are angry that the NHS is spending millions on changing hospital procedures to reduce vCJD risk while not being prepared to spend the extra money needed for synthetic clotting factors.

The Department of Health said last night that ministers were considering the matter.

 Food standards chiefs last night revealed that remnants of spinal cord had been found in two consignments of beef imported from Germany, in breach of anti-BSE controls. They were discovered at meat processing plants in Newry, County Down.

webTitle: PM says Ulster peace deal still possible

fields.headline: PM says Ulster peace deal still possible
fields.standfirst: Special report: northern ireland
fields.trailText: There was no sign of a breakthrough in the Northern Ireland political process as Tony Blair left last night after intensive talks with all sides.
fields.body:
There was no sign of a breakthrough in the Northern Ireland political process as Tony Blair left last night after intensive talks with all sides.

But the prime minister claimed a deal was still possible on thorny problems relating to demilitarisation, policing and paramilitary decommissioning. "The political will does exist but there are some very tough issues still to be sorted out," he said.

Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, who met Mr Blair for several hours of negotiations, is under pressure to persuade the IRA to re-engage seriously with General John de Chastelain's disarmament body.

Meanwhile the government is trying to secure broad nationalist support for the new policing arrangements. Mr Blair is also considering further security scaledown, particularly in south Armagh.

Mr Blair denied republican claims that he had reneged on promises made on demilitarisation and policing last May, but Mr Adams was downbeat about early developments. "If people keep to the path they have been on, whatever the terms of the [Good Friday] agreement, the chances of sorting this out are very limited," he said. Another crucial part of the jigsaw will be getting the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, to lift his ban on Sinn Fein ministers attending north/south meetings.

Downing Street rejected suggestions that Mr Blair had gone to ground in Ulster on Wednesday night to avoid the Commons hunting vote, saying he had achieved a breakthrough in the province last May when Ken Livingstone was coincidentally declared London mayor.

fields.headline: Frozen light offers bright future
fields.trailText: Scientists in Massachusetts claim they brought a ray of light to a dead stop in a laboratory experiment - and then started it again.
fields.body:
Scientists in Massachusetts claim they brought a ray of light to a dead stop in a laboratory experiment - and then started it again.

This baffling achievement, beyond the wildest dreams of Star Trek scriptwriters, could one day pay off in incredible computing speeds and power. It could also send physicists into a spin, everywhere.

Light speed is the ultimate barrier, seen until now as travelling at 186,000 miles (300m metres) a second. On that principle, Albert Einstein concluded that at the speed of light, time would stop.

Next week Lene Vestergaard Hau and colleagues at Harvard University and Ronald Walsworth and Mikhail Lukin of the Harvard-Smithsonian Centre for Astrophysics will, in separate papers in Nature and Physical Review Letters, report that they slowed light to a standstill.

Light speed is at its maximum only in a vacuum. In air, or water, or glass, it is slowed a little. Two years ago Dr Hau reported that she slowed light to 38mph by shining it through chilled sodium gas. This time she chilled the gas to within a whisker of absolute zero, minus 273 C, and managed to "freeze" the light beam in the chilled gas for a thousandth of a second.

Dr Walsworth and his colleague achieved the same result in a slightly different way. Their light got fainter and fainter as it slowed, and then stopped. So the researchers flashed a second light through the gas, and revived the first beam.

Stop-go light could be a powerful tool of the future. Quantum theory predicts that, ultimately, matter and energy behave in bizarre ways. These experiments confirm it. The pay-off could be new tools of the future called quantum computers, that could solve seemingly impossibly complex problems at stupefying speeds, and generate quantum communications that could never be intercepted or decoded.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Appeal over double killing
fields.body:
Appeal over double killing

Michael Stone, from Gillingham, Kent, was yesterday given leave to challenge his convictions by three appeal court judges. Stone, now 40, was given three life sentences at Maidstone in 1998 for the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan, six, and the attempted murder of Megan's sister, Josie, then nine.

Pupils fail history test

Education secretary David Blunkett yesterday said he was alarmed by a survey of secondary school pupils, for history testbook publishers Osprey, which showed one in six thought Oliver Cromwell took part in the battle of Hastings.

Police find bombs cache

A cache of bomb making equipment has been found at a house at Wroxham in Norfolk as police hunt for animal rights activists believed to be responsible for a spate of letter bombs in the north of England. Although police confirmed the seizure was not linked to the attacks, it raised fears of a new wave of violence.

Football aids young readers

A scheme was launched yesterday to improve children's reading by getting them interested in books linked with the 20 Premier League clubs.

Asylum seeker killed

A 28-year-old asylum seeker from Maidstone, believed to be a Kosovan, has died after being stabbed as rival gangs clashed in Folkestone, Kent, on Wednesday night. Two men, also believed to be Kosovans, were arrested yesterday.

Lockerbie judges retire

After eight months hearing evidence in the Netherlands, the Lockerbie judges retired yesterday. They will reconvene on January 30. Abdel Baset al-Megrahi, 48, and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, 44, deny murder in the downing of an airliner in 1988, in which 270 died.

Britons held in Japan

Two men holding British passports have been arrested for allegedly smuggling 6,000 ecstasy tablets to Japan from Johannesburg. Craig Brandrick, 26, and Cyleagh Scott, 21, were arrested at Osaka airport on Christmas Eve but news was made public yesterday, the Foreign Office said.

Ex-constable fined over drugs

The constable who arrested Euan Blair for being drunk was yesterday fined £200 by magistrates. Charles Challis, 25, who resigned from the Metropolitan police on Tuesday, admitted possessing cocaine. Charges of possessing cannabis and amphetamines were dropped.

Coronation St shut to visitors

Granada is to stop hosting events at its studios in Manchester, which include the set of Coronation Street, following a drop in bookings. They closed to the general public in 1999. Fans will still be able to see outdoor sequences filmed on dates to be announced.

Appeal clears lord chancellor

The employment appeal tribunal has overturned a ruling that the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, was guilty of indirect sex and race discrimination in appointing a friend as his special adviser.

Seaside cottage for sale at £m

Such is the popularity with TV stars of Southwold, a Suffolk seaside town situated 120 miles from London, that a 17th century two-bedroom cottage is up for sale at £500,000.

Tonnes of china thrown away

Hundreds of boxes containing three tonnes of china have been dumped in Buckinghamshire. Police believe they are an unwanted part of a stolen shipment.

webTitle: Tower of London plaque marking beheadings 'in wrong place'

fields.headline: Tower of London plaque marking beheadings 'in wrong place'
fields.trailText: The plaque in the Tower of London, over the spot where three queens as well as an Earl of Essex lost their heads, is in the wrong place, according to a historian.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The plaque in the Tower of London, over the spot where three queens as well as an Earl of Essex lost their heads, is in the wrong place, according to a historian.

A previously unpublished account of the trial, last days and execution of the Earl of Essex have confirmed Geoffrey Parnell's hunch that the scaffold was not on Tower Green, but on the parade ground, about a hundred yards away outside what is now the home of the crown jewels.

Dr Parnell, the tower's official historian, blames Queen Victoria.

"In 1860 Prince Albert popped in for a visit, and said that his wife would be interested to come and see where Anne Boleyn was executed," he explained.

"She did come the following year, and obviously they had to have somewhere to show her. They seem to have hit on this spot because it was outside the chapel and it looked right."

He added: "The account of Essex's death makes it quite clear that the scaffold was on the parade ground, which was then - and still is - the largest open space inside the tower. We know there were crowds at some of the executions, and it was a far more suitable site."

The document, which gives a poignant account of the gallant end of the handsome favourite - and possibly last lover - of Elizabeth I, came from the collection of William Foyle, of the bookshop-owning family. The huge collection of manuscripts at Beeleigh Abbey, his 14th century mansion in Essex, was scattered at auction last year after the death of Foyle's daughter Christina.

Dr Parnell has published his research in the February issue of BBC History magazine, out today, to coincide with the 400th anniversary of the execution of Essex, in the early hours of Ash Wednesday in February 1601.

Essex, who had been sentenced to death for leading a revolt in Ireland against Elizabeth, put on his best black, crimson and gold embroidered clothes for execution, and was beheaded after a long prayer for the queen's long life. The account said the executioner "performed his office ill, strikinge thrice, howbeit after the blow neither armes, body or head ever stirred".

A Historic Royal Palaces spokesman, which runs the tower, said tourists had been told the executions happened "in the heart of the Tower of London, but we have never said they were all on one precise spot".

HRP will mount an exhibition on Essex next autumn.

fields.headline: Trident protesters found not guilty
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Two anti-nuclear protesters who entered a dockyard planning to disarm one of Britain's Trident submarines with an axe were yesterday cleared of conspiracy to cause criminal damage.
fields.body:
Two anti-nuclear protesters who entered a dockyard planning to disarm one of Britain's Trident submarines with an axe were yesterday cleared of conspiracy to cause criminal damage.

Sylvia Boyes, 57, from Keighley, West Yorkshire, and River - formerly Keith Wright - 45, from Manchester, admitted that they plotted to damage HMS Vengeance while it was docked at Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, in November 1999.

But they denied criminal damage, claiming their actions were justifed because nuclear weapons were immoral and illegal under international law. They argued politicians could not be trusted with Britain's nuclear arsenal, so civilians had to act to stop disaster.

The Manchester jury's verdict, which follows a string of acquittals in cases of sabotage against military equipment was welcomed last night by anti-nuclear campaigners, who described it as highly significant.

"The jury has given the clearest possible decision legally, factually and morally, on the continued possession by Britain of weapons of mass destruction and where governments fail us, of the necessity of direct action", Gareth Peirce, lawyer for Sylvia Boyes.

David Mackenize of Trident Ploughshares said it was the first time the prosecution had brought a conspiracy charge, a notoriously broad indictment, against members of the group. "It will be a superb encouragement for activists", he said.

At Manchester crown court, the judge, Rhys Davies, had earlier told jurors that the two protesters could be seen as "thoroughly decent and ideal istic people" doing what thought was right. But however genuine the activists' beliefs, ideals formed no defence against a criminal damage charge.

Ms Boyes, a former lollypop lady, and River, an Open University lecturer with a master's degree in high energy nuclear physics, were found dressed in wetsuits near the submarine on November 23. They were carrying hammers, an axe and six cans of aerosol varnish.

The protesters, members of the direct action group, Trident Ploughshares, said they aimed to disarm HMS Vengeance which was equipped to carry one quarter of Britain's nuclear arsenal.

A spokeswoman for Trident Ploughshares added: "At last a precedent has been set for English people to follow their conscience and declare Trident illegal.

"This will pave the way for further legal direct action to disarm submarines."

The case is not the first example of direct action protesters walking free from court. At Manchester crown court last year, a jury acquitted two women of spray painting a nuclear submarine at Barrow with anti-war slogans and were unable to reach a verdict on a second charge of criminal damage. The prosecution asked for a retrial.

In 1999, a sheriff in Greenock, Strathclyde, handed down not guilty verdicts against three women charged with causing £80,000 damage to Trident submarine computer equipment at a naval establishment on Loch Goil.

In 1996, a jury at Liverpool crown court acquitted two women charged with causing £1.5m damage to a Hawk fighter jet at a British Aerospace factory.

fields.headline: IVF doctor accuses watchdog
fields.trailText: The agency which licenses Britain's in vitro fertilisation clinics is set to reject a technique for screening embryos which, supporters claim, reduces the danger of failed pregnancies in older women with fertility problems.
fields.body:
The agency which licenses Britain's in vitro fertilisation clinics is set to reject a technique for screening embryos which, supporters claim, reduces the danger of failed pregnancies in older women with fertility problems.

Simon Fishel, head of the Nottingham clinic which applied to carry out the procedure, accused the agency, the human fertilisation and embryology authority, of excessive caution.

"The [HFEA] are either deficient, or inept, in being able to decide on new technology and be broadminded enough to take it forward," he said.

The HFEA said it had not closed the door on the technique which involves screening for abnormalities in the chromosomes of embryos before they are implanted in the womb.

"We won't be rushed, or bulldozed, or forced into action by clinicians," said the HFEA spokesman, James Yeandel.

"We are here to make sure science does not move ahead faster than the public wants."

The HFEA received backing yesterday from one of the scientists involved in research into related techniques, Joy Delhanty of University College London, who said Britain was not technologically ready for the kind of screening.

Dr Fishel, head of the centre for assisted reproduction at the Park hospital in Nottingham, is one of the most outspoken advocates of using the frontier techniques of genetics and cell biology to help couples conceive.

He clashed with the HFEA last year over the case of Alan and Louise Masterton, who wanted to take advantage of existing IVF techniques to choose the sex of their child.

The HFEA said that allowing couples to choose the sex of their child for purely emotional reasons was opposed by the British public.

This latest IVF row highlights the pressure the HFEA is under, caught as it is between the desires of individual couples and broader public unease over the new possibilities of the genetics age.

The HFEA has yet to make a decision on Dr Fishel's application. But last month he was told that a HFEA working party would advise against it.

"The working group did recognise there were potential benefits," said Mr Yeandel. "But the final position at this stage was that this was still seen as quite experimental. There were also concerns at the possibility of misdiagnosis."

IVF treatment involves taking eggs from the mother and fertilising them in the laboratory with sperm from the father. If the fertilisation is successful and embryos begin to grow, one or more are implanted in the mother's womb.

There is evidence that one of the main reasons embryos fail to implant, or pregnancies end in miscarriage, is that the embryo's cells have one too many or one too few chromosomes.

This problem, known as aneuploidy, is more severe with women over 35.

Limited screening of IVF embryos for chromosomal abnormalities already takes place, because an extra 21st chromosome is already known to cause Down's syndrome.

But it is now possible to screen as many as eight chromosomes, greatly increasing the chances of identifying an embryo unlikely to result in successful pregnancy.

Dr Fishel agreed there was still a risk of misdiagnosis but argued that, in the worst case, this would simply leave the patient in the same position as if no test had taken place.

"Data has been published which fundamentally shows you can improve pregnancy rates by 10% and reduce miscarriages by half if you screen embryos before putting them back," he said.

The full range of fluorescent dyes needed to carry out the screening is available only in the US, but Dr Fishel said he had arranged for specialists from the two US clinics involved to carry out the work in Nottingham.

webTitle: Brown urges EU to show global leadership

fields.headline: Brown urges EU to show global leadership
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The Chancellor, Gordon Brown, will today urge the European Union to demonstrate global leadership in the wake of the US slowdown by signalling a determination to keep up the momentum of economic reform and remove all remaining obstacles to embarking on global trade talks.
fields.body:
The Chancellor, Gordon Brown, will today urge the European Union to demonstrate global leadership in the wake of the US slowdown by signalling a determination to keep up the momentum of economic reform and remove all remaining obstacles to embarking on global trade talks.

At the first meeting of European finance ministers under the Swedish presidency, Mr Brown will call for the setting of new targets to complete the single market and a big effort to kick-start the World Trade Organisation talks put on hold in Seattle more than a year ago.

He also wants the EU to unilaterally open its markets to the least developed countries and pursue a bilateral trade agreement with the US and its trading partners in Nafta to open up trade in services.

On internal reform Mr Brown wants new targets set for liberalising capital markets by 2003 and financial services by 2004. He is also seeking to set a target set for liberalising the energy market and boost mobility by persuading EU members to recognise each others' professional qualifications.

The WTO talks foundered on a combination of factors, including the intransigence of some EU member states on liberalising agriculture, but Mr Brown believes that with a new president entering the White House, the EU has an opportunity to demonstrate its commitment towards global growth and open markets.

Forbes Global magazine will publish on Monday a survey showing tax rates are falling in Europe as a whole, fostering entrepreneurial activity and contributing to improved international competitiveness. Tax levels have fallen in 16 of the 19 countries surveyed, particularly in Germany.

However, with the EU unlikely to emerge unscathed from the US slowdown, most economist believe the European Central Bank will be forced to cut interest rates to stimulate activity.

The ECB left rates unchanged at 4.75% yesterday but falling inflation and weakening confidence could provide the opportunity to lower borrowing costs later in the year, said Alison Cottrell, European policy analyst at UBS Warburg.

webTitle: Two-way stretch Actors in hit play go head to head for award

fields.headline: Two-way stretch Actors in hit play go head to head for award
fields.trailText: Actors can be a nasty lot, never more so when it comes to awards. But even in the hard-bitten world of West End theatre there were cries of "foul" and "unfair" yesterday when the two performers who have turned Stones In His Pockets into the most unlikely hit in years were pitched against each other for best actor in the nominations for the Oliviers.
fields.body:
Actors can be a nasty lot, never more so when it comes to awards. But even in the hard-bitten world of West End theatre there were cries of "foul" and "unfair" yesterday when the two performers who have turned Stones In His Pockets into the most unlikely hit in years were pitched against each other for best actor in the nominations for the Oliviers.

Conleth Hill and Sean Campion were complete unknowns on this side of the Irish sea two years ago when they began playing all 15 roles in Marie Jones's comedy set during the shooting of a fictional Hollywood film in Ireland.

Since then such real Hollywood luminaries as Tom Hanks, Dustin Hoffman and Kevin Spacey have come to pay tribute at their dressing room door as the play has moved from the Tricycle in Kilburn, north London, to bigger and bigger theatres in a record-breaking West End run.

While a second cast has taken over at the Duke of York's, Hill and Campion opened to equally ecstatic reviews in Toronto last week and Broadway beckons from April when their unique onstage chemistry will be seen at the Golden Theatre. Even the most envious thespian, however, will have sympathy with the pickle the double nomination has put them in, according to the show's publicist, Sue Higham.

"It's terrible, a real tragedy," she said. "It is fantastic in one way, a real tribute to the show. I have never, ever heard of two Olivier best actor nominations before for the same play, but how can you decide which one is better. It seems cruel, they are both amazing."

Daggers have yet to be been drawn, though a lot could happen between now and the awards ceremony on February 23. Campion already has a bigger dressing room in Toronto, despite playing one character less than Hill.

Competition for best actor is pretty stiff, with Michael Gambon nominated for The Caretaker, Bill Nighy for Blue/Orange at the National Theatre, and Simon Russell Beale the early favourite for his Hamlet.

Neither Kathleen Turner's nor Darryl Hannah's West End debuts in stage versions of famous films, The Graduate and The Seven Year Itch, get a look-in in the best actress category. But Hollywood figures strongly with Jessica Lange and Julia Ormond nominated for Long Day's Journey Into Night and My Zinc Bed respectively. Julie Walters (All My Sons), Helen Mirren (Orpheus Descending) and Harriet Walter (Life x 3) complete the line-up.

The National Theatre has, as ever, dominated the theatre categories with 22 nominations, including six for All My Sons.

webTitle: Animal tests lab may get bank lifeline

fields.headline: Animal tests lab may get bank lifeline
fields.trailText: Royal Bank of Scotland last night appeared likely to give Huntingdon Life Sciences a few more days to complete attempts to find new backers as the government intensified its commitment to keeping open the controversial animal testing laboratory targeted by protesters.
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland last night appeared likely to give Huntingdon Life Sciences a few more days to complete attempts to find new backers as the government intensified its commitment to keeping open the controversial animal testing laboratory targeted by protesters.

With just hours to repay a £22m loan to the Edinburgh-based bank and two unidentified American banks, the Cambridgeshire company was yesterday stepping up efforts to find support from the US.

Meanwhile a Downing Street spokesman took the unusual step of disclosing details of yesterday's cabinet meeting at which the home secretary, Jack Straw, told colleagues that science minister, Lord Sainsbury, "was doing all he could to help in terms of the difficulties HLS were having on the financial side". Such support fell short of financial backing from the government itself.

The Royal Bank has already granted at least five extensions to the loan which officially ran out at the end of August. Its latest extension runs out today and theoretically if the loan is not repaid Huntingdon could go into receivership. However, as most of the negotiations to refinance the company are taking place in the US, the time difference means that any official announcement may not be made until Monday when the stock market opens. A spokesman for Huntingdon insisted it was "confident" of securing a long term financial package.

Royal Bank faces the prospect of a boycott by the pharmaceutical industry if it calls in its debt and yesterday received fresh calls from the government to maintain its support. Downing Street said Mr Straw had warned colleagues there was a real danger pharmaceutical companies would take their business abroad if attacks continued, and it was important the government "did whatever it could" to protect the industry.

Describing Huntingdon Life Sciences as "a very important research establishment we want to continue", he stressed the government had toughened its rules on cosmetic testing on animals since it came to power but "animal testing in this context, medical testing was absolutely essential".

The home secretary also outlined at the cabinet meeting the measures he intended to take to protect employees of animal testing laboratories. The measures will form later amendments to the police and criminal justice bill to be published today.

webTitle: Museum bailed out after visitors fiasco

fields.headline: Museum bailed out after visitors fiasco
fields.trailText: The expansion of the Royal Armouries from the Tower of London to Leeds was compared yesterday to the fiasco surrounding the Millennium Dome in a scathing report from parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office.
fields.body:
The expansion of the Royal Armouries from the Tower of London to Leeds was compared yesterday to the fiasco surrounding the Millennium Dome in a scathing report from parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office.

David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said funding for both attractions assumed "unrealistic" numbers of visitors, leaving both to be bailed out by lottery cash or taxpayers' money. Like the Dome, "there were no contingency plans in place should visitor targets not be met".

The report showed that original figures for the museum predicted 1.3m visitors a year, but numbers started at 324,000 in 1998 and fell to 191,000 the following year.

The new museum in Leeds, to display more of the armouries' military exhibits - one of the first private finance initiatives set up by the last government - involved a private consortium meeting £14m of the £43m cost, with the government giving £20m and the rest coming from Leeds city council and Leeds development corporation.

By early 1999 the consortium's losses exceeded £10m and the government had to step in with an additional £1m per year subsidy. The Royal Armouries took over the running of the museum, leaving the contractor running catering, car parks and corporate hospitality.

The audit office report said: "The end result is that the government, and not the contractor, will pay to keep this museum open."

webTitle: US divided over Clinton legacy of sleaze and success

fields.headline: US divided over Clinton legacy of sleaze and success
fields.trailText: To his enemies, Bill Clinton is one of the most divisive figures in modern American history, a president whose very presence in the White House has disgraced the United States. Yet, as he leaves office tomorrow, Bill Clinton's approval rating stands at 65%, easily a record among departing presidents.
fields.body:
To his enemies, Bill Clinton is one of the most divisive figures in modern American history, a president whose very presence in the White House has disgraced the United States. Yet, as he leaves office tomorrow, Bill Clinton's approval rating stands at 65%, easily a record among departing presidents.

Few presidents are so paradoxical. To some, Clinton is a serious, brilliant figure who understands the transformational character of modern times better than almost any other world leader of his era. To others, he is a man without principle whose only importance may be as a figure of gossip and entertainment.

As America struggles to assess Clinton's complex legacy this week, two sharply different assessments have emerged.

On the one hand, there are those who see Clinton as he sees himself, as a moderniser who reshaped his party and the role of government, and whose pivotal importance will only grow.

On the other, there are those who see him as an emblematic politician of an essentially depoliticised era, in which the presidency is of diminishing importance.

Among most Americans, the conventional view is that he is a bad man but a good president and there are few who can agree on how these two judgments mesh together.

On the success side, he has presided over the best US economy of the 20th century. When he became president, there were some 50 sites on a thing called the world wide web. Today there are billions. When he became president, the stock market index was at 3,241. Today it stands at over 10,500. Almost every societal or economic index has moved in a positive direction.

He has opened up free trade, helped bring peace in Northern Ireland, raised public consciousness about race and made headway on environmental issues, though nothing on the scale that his international critics would like to see.

On the negative side, Clinton failed to reform healthcare and made no dent in child poverty. The gap between rich and poor has widened sharply. Foreign policy has been improvisatory, and is studded with failures.

Pension and healthcare support for the elderly, especially the prospective elderly of Clinton's own generation, remains in desperate need of reform. Instead of raising taxes in prosperous times to prepare for the future, Clinton has supported cutting them for immediate political advantage.

Perhaps the most difficult single question facing all those who try to sum up the Clinton years is the one which only future generations will be able to answer: Did he reinvent and thus save the American progressive political tradition or did he sacrifice progressive ideas and aspirations in favour of the desire to stay in office at any cost?

webTitle: Country pub's grub served with a Michelin star

fields.headline: Country pub's grub served with a Michelin star
fields.trailText: In the days of Steve Reynolds's and Nicola Holland's parents, a pub meal was an elderly pork pie and boiled egg from a glass case on the bar.
fields.body:
In the days of Steve Reynolds's and Nicola Holland's parents, a pub meal was an elderly pork pie and boiled egg from a glass case on the bar.

When Steve and Nicola took over the Stagg Inn, at Titley, near Kington, Herefordshire, things were even more unpromising. "It was a drinkers' pub with no tradition of serving food at all", Nicola said.

But yesterday - only three years later - the inn became the first British pub to win a Michelin star for a cuisine which ranges from seared scallops to rack of Welsh lamb, local beef, hare, and pigeon.

Steve is a chef trained by the Roux brothers. Nicola thought their secret had simply been to tap into a long and discriminating Herefordshire tradition of eating out. "People in London assume that this is the sticks and we are unsophisticated but farmers know about food. Our main philosophy has been to use local produce."

Ludlow, 12 miles away, has in the last few years become the only town outside London to have four restaurants with Michelin stars. At the Stagg, prices range from £6.50 for a duck leg in cider sauce at the bar to around £13 for beef or venison in the restaurant.

At the lush end of the scale, the two Gordon Ramsay restaurants in Chelsea, west London, where set lunch prices start at £28, received Michelin's highest accolade of three stars in the new guide published yesterday.

They joined the Waterside Inn at Bray on Thames as the only restaurants in Britain or Ireland with three stars.

Two other London restaurants - Tamarind in Mayfair and Zaika in Chelsea - also scored well, becoming Michelin's first starred specialists of Indian cuisine.

Three hotels and restaurants managed to retain or win two-star status, one more than last year. Some 88 now have one-star status, up two on last year's guide.

fields.headline: History's verdict
fields.standfirst: Ten Americans on the leader who defined the 1990s
fields.trailText: Ten Americans on the leader who defined the 1990s.
fields.body:
Alistair Cooke

Journalist and broadcaster

Clinton is a total mystery in some ways. He's such a rogue. Yet he's so intelligent. He's on top of issues, I think, better than any president I can remember since Lyndon Johnson. My goodness, we're going to miss him.

It's quite wrong to see him as entertainment, quite wrong. Tell me somebody in the House of Commons who's as good, as articulate, who's got a grasp of so many issues in such detail. I think that he has damaged the presidency. But this is not an isolated thing. An ordered society is collapsing all around us and it's not he who has made this happen.

The consequence of Clinton's experience will be a choice, I suppose, between having only monks and certifiably faithful husbands and wives running for the presidency. Or, as seems to be more likely, we will fall into accepting the attitude described by Edward Gibbon in the first volume of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire when "the people became either indifferent or insensitive to the debauches of the emperor provided that he paved the roads and remitted taxes." I think that's very apt.

Lucianne Goldberg

Book agent and friend of Linda Tripp

He is totally unqualified, undisciplined, a borderline criminal. He has done far more damage than people realise.

I feel ecstatic that he's going. There are those of us, and we are legion, who just can't wait to see the back of these people. We had hoped they would be going out in orange jumpsuits, handcuffed.

Yes, we'll still have Hillary. Hillary will run for president if she possibly can, you betcha. I think the deal has always been eight years for him, eight years for her. Why in the world would any woman with self-respect stay with a husband that did to her what he did unless there were a larger goal?

Camille Paglia

Writer and academic

As a Democrat who voted for Bill Clinton twice and gradually became bitterly disillusioned, I can only say that the Clinton legacy is wormwood and ashes.

Clinton took office in a blaze of idealism as the first president of my post-war baby boom generation. But he governed like a schizophrenic hack, turning diplomacy into photo opportunities.

He divided this nation, abused the military, lived by lies, and pandered to the poor while sucking up to the rich and famous. He coasted on a prosperity he did not create, and he cheapened the office he held. After Clinton, public service has become just another cynical branch of show business.

Hugh Price

President, National Urban League

Clinton's legacy for the African American community is a complicated picture. The extraordinary economic growth has certainly reached into our community, where poverty has begun declining and unemployment is finally on the way down. But as far as the criminal justice system is concerned, he was very late in doing anything about the issues of racial profiling, police abuse, and the differential treatment of black and whites in implementing drug policy.

As a "New Democrat" it would have been easy for him to walk away from the principles of affirmative action. Yet he stuck by that.

Robert Reich

Former US secretary of labour

I think historians looking at the Clinton presidency will sum it up in three ways. The first paragraph will be a wonderful economy. The second paragraph will be skilled politician; kept the Republicans at bay when they ran Congress. And the third paragraph will be scandals, particularly Monica Lewinsky.

In 1992-93 he was in the process of reinventing progressive politics. Rather than Thatcherite social Darwinism, he saw that the goal must be to move forward into the new economy and bring as many people along as possible. But by the time 1996 rolled around his campaign was about nothing. It was about Dick Morris's ideas about school uniforms and V-chips - no real substance. He certainly repositioned the Democrats but it's unclear whether he did it or the Republicans did. I don't know that there's anything progressive about what Clintonism has become.

Studs Terkel

Historian, critic and broadcaster

Forget about all the Monica bullshit. That's not important. What's important is that Clinton had a great chance to be progressive. The country was ready but the word didn't come. He listened to that pimp Dick Morris. He moved the party sharply to the right, and now we have to recover from it. A terrible, terrible missed chance.

The country has never been more ready for universal health insurance. Every family in the country is worried stiff about it. It doesn't matter how rightwing they are, they're all worried.

Arianna Huffington

Author

Over two terms, he let the good times roll, tailoring his priorities to the polls and hoarding his political capital as if he thinks it's redeemable for something when he leaves office. Now, in the sobering light of the morning after, he's taking stock.

It's as if while packing up the Oval Office he discovered a trove of his idealistic campaign speeches. Unfortunately, there seems to be a massive disconnect between the crises he bemoans and his role in allowing or even promoting them. He's much better at sounding like a great president than being one.

Jody Williams

1997 Nobel Peace Prize winner

He could have done so much more. He could have signed the international landmine ban treaty. He has repeatedly said it was one of the bitterest disappointments of his presidency that he couldn't. I'm not sure why he bought the military argument.

I think he was a brilliant man but Shakespeareanly flawed. When I won the peace prize, I said the same things I have always said: that the US could have and should have signed the treaty, that the commander-in-chief should be a commander-in-chief.

Steve Forbes

Magazine publisher. Republican presidential contender

For all the theatre, Clinton's was a failed presidency. He failed to reform our horrific tax code, Medicare, social security and our troubled schools. He degraded the justice department as no president has done before him. He failed to provide a coherent direction for our post-cold war foreign policy.

Opportunistic photo ops, not principle, was his diplomatic guide stone. Ironically the 1994 Republican surge saved his presidency, curbing spending, cutting taxes and forcing Clinton to sign an historic welfare reform bill. Wisely, he left GOP-appointed Greenspan in place and alone. The economy boomed.

Dick Morris

Ran Clinton's 1996 election campaign

By day, he solved every problem America faced when he took office. By night, he enmeshed himself in such scandal as to drown it all out.

By day, he transformed a huge budget deficit into a surplus that will pay off our entire national debt in a decade. By night, he hired detectives to dig up dirt on women, troopers who had guarded him, and political opponents.

By day, he reduced poverty in the US by almost 20%. By night, he lowered even further faith in government integrity.

By day, he cut smoking, controlled guns, cut crime, catalysed the peace initiative in Ireland, stopped Milosevic in Kosovo and the Balkans, restored democracy in Haiti and brought North Korea in from the cold.

By night, he broke the heart of the nation by proving himself to be a flawed man in a job for which he lacked the maturity.

webTitle: Bankers go in at Land's End owner's biotech firm

fields.headline: Bankers go in at Land's End owner's biotech firm
fields.trailText: Fresh questions were raised yesterday about the financial position of Kevin Leech, the millionaire owner of Land's End and John O'Groats, following an announcement that his biotech company, ML Laboratories, had called in bankers to conduct a "strategic review".
fields.body:
Fresh questions were raised yesterday about the financial position of Kevin Leech, the millionaire owner of Land's End and John O'Groats, following an announcement that his biotech company, ML Laboratories, had called in bankers to conduct a "strategic review".

The review will consider all options, including putting the company up for sale. A planned US flotation of ML's respiratory division has been delayed pending the outcome.

Mr Leech owns 48% of ML, which is capitalised at £163m. Recent reports have suggested that he has suffered heavy losses on dot.com investments - particularly in his incubator Ci4net.com - and he is fighting potentially expensive litigation related to it.

He has pledged that he is "not a seller" unless the company is taken over.

ML's chief executive, Stuart Sim, yesterday insisted the review, which will be carried out by NM Rothschild, was unconnected with Mr Leech's position. He said it was a reaction to the disappointing recent performance of the company's shares, which fell 10.5p to 103.5p having failed to flourish in last year's biotech boom. Mr Sim said: "We don't feel the real value of the business is being reflected in the share price."

He blamed "a bit of confusion in the market about what we're about". Some analysts feel that ML's activities are too diverse - its products include kidney dialysis solutions, inhalers and gels to prevent post-operative adhesions.

Mr Sim said: "Rothschild are coming in to review from the bottom up what we're doing in terms of the product portfolio and where we're at."

The exercise will include examining corporate activity, including a division of the business, disposals or an outright sale. He said: "Everything is an option, although we certainly haven't appointed them specifically to put us up for sale."

ML Laboratories' full year losses widened from £6.9m to £11.8m, hit by increased research spending and marketing costs associated with several product launches. The bottom line was also hit by the firm's acquisition of Cobra Therapeutics, a loss making gene therapy business exploring potential cancer treatments.

The firm is awaiting clinical trial results of promising products for prostate cancer and pain relief. Sales of its founding product, a kidney dialysis solution named Extraneal, were sharply up.

ML was co-founded by Mr Leech, a former funeral director, in 1987. His other interests include assets such as the Snowdon Mountain Railway and the Needles Pleasure Park.

Mr Leech has been hit by a collapse in the shares of Ci4net.com, his internet investment firm listed on Nasdaq, and he is involved in a complicated financial dispute with Ellen Milner, the widow of ML's co-founder.

fields.headline: Airtours buoyant despite losses
fields.trailText: Airtours warned yesterday that its losses would be greater than £80m in the first half of the year, despite a 16% increase in winter bookings from the UK.
fields.body:
Airtours warned yesterday that its losses would be greater than £80m in the first half of the year, despite a 16% increase in winter bookings from the UK.

The country's second largest tour operator said British bookings for this summer were up 11% compared to 8% globally and had increased 6% for the winter.

Despite this "excellent" start to the year, chairman David Crossland admitted the increased scale of its operations combined with losses of newly acquired businesses would leave it further in the red.

In the first half of 1999-2000, Airtours ran up a £75.3m loss which will have to be restated to around £80m due to changes in accountancy rules. The group ended the year with pretax profits before exceptionals at £101.3m, down from £131.5m.

Airtours claimed to have made significant progress towards turning around the loss-hit German subsidiary Frosch Touristic (FTi), which has been a major drag on its share price.

Mr Crossland told shareholders that FTi's profitability was improving.

Airtours shares, which were languishing around the 210p level last week, rose 2.25p to end the day at 244.25p.

webTitle: Hard core porn claims that failed to stand up

fields.headline: Hard core porn claims that failed to stand up
fields.trailText: A shopkeeper's brief career as a porn baron came to an ignominious end yesterday when his Sensuous Nurses and Sex Maniac's Confessions were condemned by a court as too tame - generally available with an 18 certificate.
fields.body:
A shopkeeper's brief career as a porn baron came to an ignominious end yesterday when his Sensuous Nurses and Sex Maniac's Confessions were condemned by a court as too tame - generally available with an 18 certificate.

Antics shown on videos, sold for up to £70 as "special hard core", were so mild that they contravened the Trading Standards Act, magistrates in York ruled. Nicholas Griffin, 30, who pleaded guilty, was fined £3,800 with £2,000 costs.

The court heard that his Little Amsterdam shop might as well have sold films of tulip bulb fields, according to angry customers.

Colin Rumford, head of York trading standards department, said: "They expected a particular type of product which they valued a lot. Instead they got something that as far as they were concerned was certainly not worth the money they had paid."

fields.headline: Byers sparks jobs row
fields.standfirst: Unions angered by rejection of EU directive
fields.trailText: Trade and Industry secretary Stephen Byers last night ran into a row over plans to overhaul laws covering consultation over redundancies.
fields.body:
Trade and Industry secretary Stephen Byers last night ran into a row over plans to overhaul laws covering consultation over redundancies.

The British system has come under heavy fire in the wake of large scale redundancies at Ford's Dagenham plant and the planned closure of Vauxhall's Luton operation, with union leaders arguing that it is easier and cheaper to make workers redundant in Britain than elsewhere in Europe.

But the UK is reluctant to adopt an EU directive on the issue, and the DTI said yesterday that it planned to review existing UK legislation in consultation with both the TUC and the CBI.

Mr Byers said: "There are concerns about the way employees find out about large scale redundancies and the lack of consultation. I share these concerns.

"It is unacceptable for people to learn from a local radio station that they are to lose their jobs. Our legislation does set down requirements for consultation, but I want to look at whether it is effective and whether it could be improved."

But Mr Byers initiative was immediately dismissed by TGWU general secretary Bill Morris. "At best, this review is a clumsy attempt to reinvent the wheel; at worst it is a cynical diversion. The suggested review on redundancy consultation is no more than a sticking plaster on a broken arm."

The review was an attempt to water down the EU directive on information and consultation, and he urged the government to sign up for the directive immediately. The Commons industry select committee is gathering evidence on motor job losses and its conclusions are expected to include criticism of the government for leaving workers exposed.

Tony Woodley, T&G motor industry negotiator, told the committee last week that legally binding agreements forcing management to consult with workers' representatives before plans were set in stone should be introduced in Britain.

webTitle: There's gold in those Arcadian hills

fields.headline: There's gold in those Arcadian hills
fields.standfirst: Notebook Executive picks a real winner
fields.trailText: Notebook Executive picks a real winner.
fields.body:
Well done, Charles Wilson, newly installed executive director of stores group Arcadia. He is obviously an extraordinarily insightful stock-picker.

Mr Wilson was wooed away from supermarket group Iceland by his former boss, Stuart Rose, when Mr Rose was installed as chief executive of Arcadia.

To ease his passage to the ailing fashion retailer he was awarded a handsome golden hello of some £220,000 to make up for gains he would have made on Iceland options - had he decided to stay with the Deesside grocers. He then nobly splurged the lot on Arcadia shares, presumably as a token of his commitment to the task of turning around the underperforming outfitter.

He then raided his own personal piggybank for £100,000 to buy another 105,000 or so shares. Obviously, he still did not think that was enough to demonstrate that he was deadly serious about aligning his interests with those of other shareholders, and a couple of days later wrote out another cheque - this time for north of £85,000 - for another 92,000 Arcadia shares.

His total commitment? A chunky £407,000. Obviously Mr Wilson had no special insight into Arcadia's recent trading figures, released yesterday, but as it turns out he has picked a winner.

Arcadia's shares have been motoring in the last week as rumours spread that the firm might be about to break with recent tradition and actually report some good news - and yesterday they did. The 4.3% improvement in like-for-like sales added a little more spice to the shares, and they closed up 7p at 125p.

The net result so far for the canny Mr Wilson is a profit of more than £120,000 - in a week. The company says no rules were breached, it was not a closed period and that the trading was approved by Mr Rose. But Mr Rose should also beware. On present form, his righthand man must surely be considering giving up his day job to concentrate on share dealing.

Name game

One has to marvel at Powergen's sense of timing. The day after it confirmed that it could be swallowed up by Germany's second largest utilities group, it announced a new corporate advertising campaign. It then revealed that it was having its brand name valued for the first time. This decision, somewhat late in the day, was taken to help decide how to use the name to best effect.

At the beginning of 1999, electricity generation accounted for 90% of Powergen's business. Now it accounts for only 10%. In the intervening years, the group has sold off generating capacity and plunged into retailing electricity, gas, fixed and mobile telephony and financial services. All of these except financial services are now being marketed under the Powergen name - with customers having the option of receiving only one bill for all the services.

The group believes that it has created a national utilities brand name - not least through its sponsorship of television weather forecasts. But the group's new front means that the catchy "Powergen - power, whatever the weather" slogan which accompanied the forecasts has now been replaced by the leaden "Powergen - gas, electricity and telephone"

The launch yesterday of Powergen's new branding has been overshadowed by Tuesday's announcement that Germany's E.ON was considering a bid for the group. By the time Interbrand completes its valuation of the Powergen name, it could all be over bar the shouting. The issue, by then, may be the value of the name E.ON.

Bald facts

On one of his increasingly rare visits to the planet earth, Phytopharm's chief executive Richard Dixey yesterday conceded defeat in his battle to cure baldness with an exotic concoction of Mediterranean herbs.

Few will be surprised that the effort was a flop. But in keeping with Phytopharm's quirky tradition, its figures contained an apparent gem: a daily dab of cold cream, or some other moisturiser, restored hair growth in 38% of its balding stockbrokers.

This is either an astounding medical breakthrough or the result of a distinctly dubious clinical trial. The clue lies in the small print, which reveals that only 24 out of 75 patients turned up to have their heads photographed at the end of the trial.

It seems that Phytopharm doled out four months' supply of cream to each patient, giving them no particular incentive to turn up for appraisals. Presumably only those pleased with the results bothered to go back.

Phytopharm's decision to test baldness drugs on City analysts was, in itself, odd - given their influence over the firm's share price.

The company's trial designers will have to do better than this if Phytopharm wants to be taken seriously.
