fields.headline: Insurer doubles storms estimate
fields.trailText: Royal & SunAlliance yesterday doubled its loss estimate for the floods and storms that battered Britain in the autumn to £200m, prompting analysts to sharply downgrade profit forecasts for the insurer.
fields.body:
Royal & SunAlliance yesterday doubled its loss estimate for the floods and storms that battered Britain in the autumn to £200m, prompting analysts to sharply downgrade profit forecasts for the insurer.

In November, RSA said it expected losses from storms and floods of about £80m-£110m, but yesterday said the further round of bad weather that hit the country in December had forced it to raise its loss estimate to £180-£200m. The figure includes losses in western Europe and Canada, but RSA said the vast majority of payouts were in Britain.

RSA insures about 15% of homes in Britain, and its loss estimates suggest the total clean-up bill from the floods is likely to far exceed the £500m expected by the Association of British Insurers.

UBS Warburg immediately cut its forecast for RSA's profits for 2000 from £573m to £490m. Analyst Roger Hill said: "Most people thought that the initial estimate was a bit low, and that RSA had an ongoing problem. They seem to be pretty good at finding bad weather."

The rising bill has prompted fears of steep increases in premiums in flood-prone areas or widespread withdrawal of cover. Yesterday, RSA's group chief executive, Bob Mendelsohn, said: "Although rates will rise, we do not expect a dramatic change in rate levels in the areas affected by storms and flooding as prices will continue to adjust over time."

He revealed that in north America, RSA had successfully pushed through premium increases of 20%.

Building insurance rates have remained static in Britain for several years but are expected to rise at above the rate of inflation over the next couple of years.

A spokeswoman for CGNU said: "We have instructed underwriters not to decline insurance or raise rates purely on the basis of autumn's experience, but where there is evidence of regular flooding, premiums will increase."

The prospect of premium increases in the domestic and motor markets helped the stock market to shrug off the immediate impact of flood and storm losses, and RSA shares ended the day up 2.5% at 521p.

Nine months ago the shares were trading at about 300p amid concern that the benefits from the merger of Royal with Sun Alliance was failing to deliver the expected benefits.

UBS Warburg is pencilling in a rapid recovery in RSA's profits in 2001 to £835m, rising to over £1bn in 2002.

"We are at that point in the insurance cycle where a big profit upturn is about to happen. RSA has done a lot to restructure and it is now coming into the right point of the insurance cycle ... although it has had four years of sub-optimal profits," said Mr Hills.

Despite the severity of the floods and storms, 2000 was a relatively benign year for insurers.

The £500m-plus bill compares well against the £2.5bn bill from storms and floods in 1991 and £1bn from the hurricane in 1987.

The wetter weather has also cut subsidence claims - which make up the bulk of building insurance payouts.

webTitle: What the VW Passat ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the VW Passat ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the VW Passat ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
A man drives his shiny new Passat to a rural area, parks it, then gets out to walk his dog. We see the animal having a lovely time, trailing messily through mud and jumping in puddles. At the end of the walk, the pair return to the car but there's a taxi waiting beside it. The man opens the taxi door, lets his dog hop in, then shuts it and offers the driver a tenner to take the filthy animal home for him as he returns to his own pristine motor. "The beautifully crafted all-new Passat. You'll want to keep it that way," reads the endline.

The jargon:
VW has radically revamped its large saloon Passat, giving it more chrome, restyling the front, improving safety and introducing snazzy new gadgets. This commercial promotes the new launch by moving on from the previous Passat ads which focused on the attention to detail that goes into the car - remember the Car Born Out Of Obsession and German For Detail campaigns? Instead it imagines the lengths that a proud owner would go to in order to look after their Passat.

Personality:
You're male, probably in your 40s, with a decent job. Around 70% of Passats are sold as company cars, so you're fairly senior in your company - less ostentatious than those who might opt for a BMW, a little more sophisticated than colleagues wanting a Ford Mondeo.

Financial status:
Your income is likely to be, on average, around £45,000. So you're probably earning rather more than rival large saloon drivers like Vauxhall Vectra Man or Renault Laguna Man.

Telling lifestyle detail:
You play golf, you holiday a lot, and you're thoroughly middle class - married, with kids, living in a major town somewhere in the UK.

Other relevant data:
The dog is called Alfie and he's Spanish, the star of numerous commercials back home, despite the fact that he's very badly behaved and was almost impossible to handle on set.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Ballad Of Cable Hogue | The Cars That Ate Paris | Happiness | Night Of The Hunter
fields.body:
The Ballad Of Cable Hogue

(Sam Peckinpah, 1970)

10am, 6pm, Sky Cinema

Jason Robards makes a fine, deep-creased westerner who's left for dead in the desert by fellow prospectors Strother Martin and LQ Jones. A waterhole proves a life-saver, and a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for happiness with a good woman played by Stella Stevens. But the revenge-obsessed Hogue spurns all of this in one of Sam Peckinpah's end-of-the-trail westerns, minus the slow-mo blood-letting and plus a wry brand of humour, epitomised by the cruel joke that finishes the hero.

The Cars That Ate Paris

(Peter Weir, 1974)

2.05am, FilmFour

Weir's spectacular debut is close in spirit to George Miller's Mad Max movies, creating a similarly nightmarish vision of an isolated, lawless community. Terry Camilleri plays the lad trapped in Paris, Australia, after a car smash kills his brother; the citizens seem normal but hide ghoulish secrets, while young tearaways in cars-cum-spiked-chariots rule the roads.

Happiness

(Todd Solondz, 1998)

3.20am, Sky Premier

Roughly speaking, this is the story of three modern American sisters and their encounters with some peculiar males of the species. It's a brilliantly perceptive, sympathetic comedy of sexual manners; but with one of the sisters happily married to a psychiatrist who's a paedophile, it's also an emotionally challenging, near despairing work, incorporating what's perhaps the blackest joke in cinema. Quite exceptional.

Night Of The Hunter

(Charles Laughton, 1955)

3.45am, FilmFour

Laughton's one film as director is a dark, delirious drama about the eternal struggle between good and evil. The latter is represented by Robert Mitchum's terrifying preacher, the man with Love and Hate tattooed on his knuckles, who menaces two children (Jane Bruce and the extraordinary Billy Chapin) who know the whereabouts of their murdered father's ill-gotten loot. With mother Shelley Winters putty in his hands, it's down to hardy old Lillian Gish to protect the innocents.

fields.headline: Whitehall's bread and butter
fields.standfirst: Statutory instruments cover everything from units of measurement to grey squirrels and sausage making, but few are widely publicised
fields.trailText: Statutory instruments cover everything from units of measurement to grey squirrels and sausage making, but few are widely publicised.
fields.body:
Steve Thoburn, the market trader in Sunderland magistrates court this week for selling fruit in pounds and ounces alone rather than along with metric measures, was not prosecuted under the law as it is usually understood - a statute passed after deliberation by MPs and peers. He was done under "delegated legislation". The case was brought under the Units of Measurement Regulations 1994 - which came into effect in 2000.

Parliament passed 3,412 similar regulations last year. MPs have only been back at work a few days after the Christmas break and already they have passed 60 of them. While parliament gets to "see" them, all but a handful go through on the nod. Few have even the remotest chance of being debated, let alone defeated.

There is nothing new about governments' use of statutory instruments or SIs - even if, as the chart shows, the annual average has been rising in recent years. (Annual records began in 1895.) The Tories were committed to lightening the regulatory load but Thatcher and Major presided over a very big increase.

Such orders can only be made under a pre-existing act of parliament. Sometimes statutes can give very broad licence, such as the 1972 European Communities Act under which the metric regulation was issued.

These are laws made by civil servants. A minister, usually not the secretary of state, does see and approve them but the crucial decisions about what should be in regulations, their timing and indeed whether they should be made at all, are taken within Whitehall, not usually by the senior civil service but many grades below.

As citizens and taxpayers we would probably object to our MPs spending too much time immersing themselves in the detail of the Thames Estuary Cockle Fishery Order 1994 or the Baking and Sausage Making (Christmas and New Year) Regulations 1985 and the thousands like them passed each year. But they are not all a matter of routine. The issues behind some other regulations make frontpage headlines such as the supply of arms to Sierra Leone (the Sierra Leone [UN sanctions] Order 1997) and whether butchers should be allowed to sell beef on the bone (the Beef Bones Regulations 1997). And there are very many more big issues (such as sentencing criminal offenders or eligibility for social security benefits) that do not make the frontpages.

Of course, just because bureaucrats write them, this does not mean that they should not be on the statute books. In general, civil servants are a conscientious bunch who do not ban things just for fun. In the case of Mr Thoburn and his apples and oranges, they were "only obeying orders" in the form of EU council directives (80/181 and 89/617). If they did not pass the law, the government might be sued in the European court while the directives would not go away.

At other times, civil servants react to public pressure. They were not acting as killjoys when they proposed the Wireless Telegraphy (Control of Interference from Videosenders) order 1997 which banned mini-transmitters to plug into the back of videos so you could pick up the signal on any televi sion in your house. A reason for the ban was that these gadgets caused interference and could impede emergency services radio frequencies. People power was another reason. A videosender owner used his machine to beam hardcore pornography to his bedroom on a Sunday night during Songs of Praise. People in the neighbourhood complained when freak atmospheric conditions meant that the pornographic signal drowned out the religious worship.

Whitehall makes an effort to consult. Though interest groups consulted do not always have the time to deal with the mass of detail, over two-thirds of them think that the system works well and say that they are consulted regularly and frequently.

So what is the problem with these type of laws? For the most part, nothing. As long as these regulations do not embody major political decisions, we would want the system to beaver away on regulations bearing on, say, grants to former apple orchard owners, without bothering us or our MPs. Government should not expect to make really big decisions by means of these regulations and imagine people will not notice. Big issues will out as some of the key SIs on genetically modified foods, beef on the bone and lone parent benefit (all covered by SIs) show us. It is the regulations in between the routine and the eyecatchingly political that should worry us more.

There is simply no mechanism for airing the collective choices that are made every day on our behalf. Matters such as which particular bits of crime sentencing legislation should actually be brought into effect, whether discriminatory legislation preventing women entering the fire service should be removed and exactly how far we need to go to implement this or that European directive are the bread and butter of everyday government in Whitehall.

Such topics are rarely raised by politicians, press, radio or TV. There are plenty of reasons why - they may be technical issues, they may appear at first sight to affect only a few people or, like weights and measures laws, they might seem to be a long way off.

But once they are on the statute books they can come back to haunt us because they are not always easy to remove. The Grey Squirrels (Prohibition of Importation and Keeping) order 1937 is still technically in force. It requires "the occupier of any land, who knows that grey squirrels, not being grey squirrels kept by him under licence, are to be found thereon shall forthwith give notice to the appropriate department".

I have not yet tried phoning the Ministry of Agriculture about the squirrel that eats nuts from our bird table. I hope it will not land me in court like Mr Thoburn.

fields.bodyText: Steve Thoburn, the market trader in Sunderland magistrates court this week for selling fruit in pounds and ounces alone rather than along with metric measures, was not prosecuted under the law as it is usually understood - a statute passed after deliberation by MPs and peers. He was done under "delegated legislation". The case was brought under the Units of Measurement Regulations 1994 - which came into effect in 2000. Parliament passed 3,412 similar regulations last year. MPs have only been back at work a few days after the Christmas break and already they have passed 60 of them. While parliament gets to "see" them, all but a handful go through on the nod. Few have even the remotest chance of being debated, let alone defeated. There is nothing new about governments' use of statutory instruments or SIs - even if, as the chart shows, the annual average has been rising in recent years. (Annual records began in 1895.) The Tories were committed to lightening the regulatory load but Thatcher and Major presided over a very big increase. Such orders can only be made under a pre-existing act of parliament. Sometimes statutes can give very broad licence, such as the 1972 European Communities Act under which the metric regulation was issued. These are laws made by civil servants. A minister, usually not the secretary of state, does see and approve them but the crucial decisions about what should be in regulations, their timing and indeed whether they should be made at all, are taken within Whitehall, not usually by the senior civil service but many grades below. As citizens and taxpayers we would probably object to our MPs spending too much time immersing themselves in the detail of the Thames Estuary Cockle Fishery Order 1994 or the Baking and Sausage Making (Christmas and New Year) Regulations 1985 and the thousands like them passed each year. But they are not all a matter of routine. The issues behind some other regulations make frontpage headlines such as the supply of arms to Sierra Leone (the Sierra Leone [UN sanctions] Order 1997) and whether butchers should be allowed to sell beef on the bone (the Beef Bones Regulations 1997). And there are very many more big issues (such as sentencing criminal offenders or eligibility for social security benefits) that do not make the frontpages. Of course, just because bureaucrats write them, this does not mean that they should not be on the statute books. In general, civil servants are a conscientious bunch who do not ban things just for fun. In the case of Mr Thoburn and his apples and oranges, they were "only obeying orders" in the form of EU council directives (80/181 and 89/617). If they did not pass the law, the government might be sued in the European court while the directives would not go away. At other times, civil servants react to public pressure. They were not acting as killjoys when they proposed the Wireless Telegraphy (Control of Interference from Videosenders) order 1997 which banned mini-transmitters to plug into the back of videos so you could pick up the signal on any televi sion in your house. A reason for the ban was that these gadgets caused interference and could impede emergency services radio frequencies. People power was another reason. A videosender owner used his machine to beam hardcore pornography to his bedroom on a Sunday night during Songs of Praise. People in the neighbourhood complained when freak atmospheric conditions meant that the pornographic signal drowned out the religious worship. Whitehall makes an effort to consult. Though interest groups consulted do not always have the time to deal with the mass of detail, over two-thirds of them think that the system works well and say that they are consulted regularly and frequently. So what is the problem with these type of laws? For the most part, nothing. As long as these regulations do not embody major political decisions, we would want the system to beaver away on regulations bearing on, say, grants to former apple orchard owners, without bothering us or our MPs. Government should not expect to make really big decisions by means of these regulations and imagine people will not notice. Big issues will out as some of the key SIs on genetically modified foods, beef on the bone and lone parent benefit (all covered by SIs) show us. It is the regulations in between the routine and the eyecatchingly political that should worry us more. There is simply no mechanism for airing the collective choices that are made every day on our behalf. Matters such as which particular bits of crime sentencing legislation should actually be brought into effect, whether discriminatory legislation preventing women entering the fire service should be removed and exactly how far we need to go to implement this or that European directive are the bread and butter of everyday government in Whitehall. Such topics are rarely raised by politicians, press, radio or TV. There are plenty of reasons why - they may be technical issues, they may appear at first sight to affect only a few people or, like weights and measures laws, they might seem to be a long way off. But once they are on the statute books they can come back to haunt us because they are not always easy to remove. The Grey Squirrels (Prohibition of Importation and Keeping) order 1937 is still technically in force. It requires "the occupier of any land, who knows that grey squirrels, not being grey squirrels kept by him under licence, are to be found thereon shall forthwith give notice to the appropriate department". I have not yet tried phoning the Ministry of Agriculture about the squirrel that eats nuts from our bird table. I hope it will not land me in court like Mr Thoburn.  Edward C Page is professor of politics at Hull university. fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
Our dachshund sleeps on a stobby mat in front of our Aga, made by a lady working with old rags on a rack in her cottage. "I'll do you a clouty next," she promised, deftly hooking strips of material in and out with the tool she'd inherited from her mother.

The 60s saw the decline of many traditional rural skills considered archaic. "Now we've come full circle," our farrier told me. "Horses are an important local industry and conservationists are looking at the old skills of ditching, hedging, walling and mole-catching." He likes his horses hotshod, and I watched him plunge a horseshoe into the brooding, red-hot coals of his smithy fire.

Expertise comes down through the generations; no modern tool can replace a craftsman's inherited ability to do a job right. This blacksmith knows the size and make-up of every equine hoof he's responsible for. He laid the red-hot shoe on my horse's hoof, while pungent, acrid smoke filled the forge.

The tools the hedger requires are minimal; our village hedger uses a switch knife and chainsaw, his concession to progress, and admits it's a big improvement on the axe his father wielded.

I spoke to a mole-catcher, busy baiting mole traps with poisoned worms, and there's a lady in Whittingham who repairs rush, seagrass and cane-seated chairs and stools.

Kippers are smoked at Craster in the traditional way, and a few fishermen at Boulmer and Seahouses still make crab pots and trawling nets.

Stick dressing is one of the oldest country skills. Sticks must be balanced with as little taper as possible in the shank, and if it's a working crook it must be wide enough to go round a sheep's neck.

fields.headline: Too good to be true
fields.trailText: The West Wing | Shipwrecked
fields.body:
It's a shame for Mrs Landingham, PA to Potus. He - the President Of The United States - shouts at her, albeit in a generous, loving way. She's irked by fast-talking, speed-walking members of his staff, particularly when they almost swear ("You know how I feel about talk like that in the Oval Office," she tells Leo McGarry, Chief of Staff). And she's way behind CJ, sassy press secretary Donna, the Gwyneth-a-like secretary and even Mary Marsh, the religious fundamentalist, in the glamour stakes. It's as plain as she is that Mrs Landingham suffers.

Yet does she get her name in the opening titles of The West Wing (Channel 4)?

She certainly does not. It's tucked away, alongside Reporter £1, Economist £2 and Maid in the always-too-fast end credits of the US drama. For all its right-on, liberal, feelgood values, The West Wing could be a bit nicer to Mrs Landingham.

Too busy to bother with the feelings of a character actress in the late summer of her life, The West Wing is occupied with illustrating just what marvellous people liberals are. (We at The Guardian already know how smashing liberals are, but it's rather off-putting to see it on TV, especially as it's force-fed to the audience. With a straw. Up their nose.) While nasty folks on the religious right make veiled anti-Semitic remarks to Jewish members of the White House staff, President Josiah Bartlet (a hammy Martin Sheen) and friends demonstrate again and again that they're on the side of the angels. Making his grand entrance, he hobbles in quoting the Bible before telling the aforementioned religious types to "Get your fat asses out of my White House." Firm but fair.

And how fair the West Wing workers are. From the President down to assistants, everyone who works there is bubbling over with conviction, passion and human kindness. Rather than the cynical, selfish power-players who've been corrupted by the system, everyone on Potus's staff seems to have trained at the Maria Von Trapp Graduate School For Aspiring Political Types.

And they're so darned articulate - like Dawson (of Creek fame) and his friends all grown up. In Bartlet, America - or at least America's Democrats - has a President of whom it can be unashamedly, 100% proud. Full of homespun wisdom and mature world views, he's a moral leader, a loving husband, father and grandfather. Above all, he's A Good Man, the Potus with the mostest. Bartlet is not the kind of bloke to indulge in fellatio in the Oval Office. (Mrs Landingham would probably have a conniption fit at the mere mention of the word).

Yet for all its shiny optimism and liberal love-ins, The West Wing is smart, snappy and instantly engrossing. As a trauma-in-the-high-pressure-workplace, it operates in the same way as ER (with whom it shares an executive producer, John Wells), with engaging characters emerging from tumultuous camera work, the spaghetti of multiple plot lines, and sparky, speedy dialogue. It verges on the corny at points - especially when Sheen's Bartlet is spinning some folksy story with a Moral - and its theme tune is awfully turgid, but The West Wing succeeds by focusing less on Bartlet and more on those around him. The West Wing may not enchant audiences here quite like it has in the States, but it's undoubtedly must-see TV.

How's that for shiny optimism?

The second series of Shipwrecked (Channel 4) began with the selection process which, quelle surprise , selected an awful gang of twentysomethings - including Gay Stuart, Punk Vicky, Fat Michael, Dykey Lucy and a host of blandly good-looking blonde boys and girls - to maroon on a desert island. Unfortunately, they'll be bringing them all back. Meanwhile, however, everyone will make friends, fall out and some may even fall into bed together. (Who Gay Stuart is going to pull is anyone's guess, so it's safe to assume he's only been chosen to test the liberalness of his fellow castaways.)

Precision-engineered to appeal to E4 viewers - in the first episode we've already had mass snogging, some boy's bare arse, and the seeds of an all-out bitch fight in the making - we live in hope that one of the Shipwrecked gang will start murdering the others as they opt for a Lord Of The Flies-like atavistic descent. Some have less distance to descend than others but, whatever happens, it's the island I feel sorry for.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Discovery | Classic FM In Concert
fields.body:
Peter Evans launches a three-part series for Discovery (8.05pm, BBC World Service; 2.05am Radio 4) about pioneer genetic researchers. His first guest is Dr Maxine Singer, a young biochemist in 1953 when Watson and Crick finally unravelled DNA. Her boss advised her to move into this field, and she's stayed for 40 years. One of her great moments was discovering the jumping gene, a molecule able to shift its position in a DNA sequence, regarded as a central mechanism of evolution.

In Classic FM In Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) Nicholas Tresilian offers recorded performances of Mahler's Seventh and Prokofiev's Scythian Suite, conducted by Sir Simon Rattle (pictured). He's marking Rattle's 46th birthday and the 30th anniversary of his first lessons at the Royal Academy of Music. It's been unrelieved triumph since Rattle won his first competition in 1974. Next year he attains the awesome height of chief conductor to the Berlin Philharmonic.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Poor old Vanessa Feltz. You might not agree, but we should spare a thought for her pneumaticness this week - she's been the centre of attention for being dropped like the proverbial hot spud by the BBC not once, but twice.

Stories that the BBC wouldn't be renewing Feltz's rumoured £2m exclusive contract began circulating again this week - despite the fact that the news had first emerged last August. And why the cruel insistence on repeating the story? Some hack had thought to ask ITV whether Feltz would be welcomed back to the commercial network where she used to host a daytime chat show. She won't, was the reply.

Feltz left ITV when execs allegedly failed to meet her demands for a pay rise. She then began to host a chat show on the BBC, only to be beaten in the ratings by Trisha on ITV.

The battle of the daytime divas came to an end in December, however, and now Feltz is left without a regular gig at either channel.

But all is not lost. According to the Daily Telegraph, following up the story yesterday - several days after the tabloids - Feltz is planning a career as a freelance TV presenter (sounds as if she doesn't have much choice) and writing a health column for OK! magazine. The same OK! magazine that last week featured "Vanessa Feltz Inside Her Amazing Home" over some 19 pages.

Perhaps the best thing about the picturefest - and for those who haven't seen it, there are several gems, such as Feltz posing in teddy-bear dressing gown in her daughter's bedroom (why?) - is an advert that's snuck between the picture spreads. It shows two outsize packets of crisps (one from Sainsbury's and one from another supermarket) with the words "Any body can tell the difference". Surely this has nothing to do with Feltz's marvellous new diet?

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Private Lives
fields.standfirst: How can we prevent our mentally ill daughter from destroying our lives?
fields.trailText: How can we prevent our mentally ill daughter from destroying our lives?
fields.body:
In 1980 our elder daughter, then 13, developed permanent tinnitus. This was a terrible strain. Then, aged around 21, she showed increasing signs of mental illness. She was sectioned three times and eventually went into a care home, which she left to do a degree.

She demands attention from us almost daily, by agitated phone calls or hours of sobbing or shouting. She cannot make friends normally, organise or plan ahead, and often loses money, keys, etc. She is verbally and sometimes physically aggressive. She does not hallucinate but lacks empathy and, though articulate, has problems with rational discourse, so we suspect her diagnosis should lean towards Asperger's syndrome rather than schizophrenia, but she resists professional help.

Our health has been severely damaged by her illness. She could fail or abandon her college course this year and return to our house, making normal life impossible. What future for her - or us as we enter our 60s?

Don't label her

Our eldest child is 25, and we have always found her rather difficult. Very academically able, but anxious and socially withdrawn; at an early age it was suggested she had autistic problems, but this was not followed up. At 14, she developed mild anorexia. A relationship problem at university, combined with exam stress in her final year, resulted in severe bulimia, self-harming and shopping problems. Since then there have been suicide attempts, disappearing acts, a breakdown in her first job and a return home. She stole from us and talked of S&M sex. There was continuing rejection of professional help, though some trials were initiated, particularly in response to the suicide attempts. She manifested symptoms of every possible psychiatric label at some time, and I know this was manipulative.

I am now indescribably relieved that she is alive and we are friends. She has worked for nearly four years, and is professionally qualified, but problems continued until recently. Two years ago we insisted she left home as we were exhausted and it wasn't helping anyway. This was very risky, but it worked. She said that her disappearances, "walking out of her life" at intervals, helped her to get a sense of proportion. I think it helped her to get a sense of control and to be aware of her own resources. She now has a formidable personality, and I believe that I was an over-conscientious mother who unconsciously suppressed its emergence because of echoes of my own mother. Our generation had not yet heard of "good enough" parenting.

Young people want more autonomy from their parents, and fear autonomy if lacking self-confidence. In your daughter's case, the tinnitus served to reinforce dependency at this stage. With regard to various diagnostic labels, we still do not know the extent to which many are organically based, or simply descriptive of behaviour. Asperger's syndrome, for example, could be applied to many introverted, studious people. Limiting labels can undermine self-confidence.
Name and address withheld

Be positive about her

I sympathise with your position. As someone who has suffered from mental health problems for the past six years, I am well aware of the distress and concern such difficulties can cause those close to the sufferer. I wonder if you've considered attending a carers' group. Many Mind centres run them, and if your local branch doesn't, they should direct you to other sources of help.

I am struck by the fact that in your letter you say nothing positive about your daughter. You focus entirely on what you perceive as her failings, never mentioning her attributes at all. But she must have some! It's so easy when someone is ill to see only their problems, and ignore all the other bits of them. But once a sufferer starts believing she only exists as an illness, this can make it very hard for her to get better. To break out of the mental health system and go to college, as your daughter has done, requires determination and courage. I know because I did it myself, graduating from UEA last summer with an MA in creative writing. Yet all you can say is that she may well fail or drop out. Why not celebrate instead her tremendous achievement in getting there at all? Maybe she will fail, and maybe she won't, but I can hardly believe this attitude is helping.

The future doesn't have to be as bleak as you imagine. The mentally ill have a huge contribution to make to society. Too often their efforts are compromised not by any fault of their own, but by the failure of others to see beyond their illness.
Clare Allan, London

Next week

Fifteen years ago my former husband's mother, with whom I had always been on very good terms, suddenly moved and cut herself off from everyone for no reason that I could figure out. For a while I tried to contact her, but without success. Then last year I discovered her address on a CD-rom that we had on trial at work.

My dilemma is whether or not to write to her. The thought that she might be a lonely old lady tempts me to do so - she was widowed before we lost touch and had no other relatives, having quarrelled with all her sisters long before I ever knew her. She now has two little great-grandchildren that she does not know about, but I do not want to do anything that might mean re-establishing contact with my ex-husband. He was violent, always lied, was sometimes in trouble with the police and my son would never forgive me if I did anything to bring him back into our lives. It may be because of him that she disappeared.

Should I leave well alone, or risk contacting her? I thought of using a PO box number, but that seems a bit devious. What do other readers think?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020- 7239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

I am struck by the fact that in your letter you say nothing positive about your daughter. You focus entirely on what you perceive as her failings, never mentioning her attributes at all. But she must have some! It's so easy when someone is ill to see only their problems, and ignore all the other bits of them. But once a sufferer starts believing she only exists as an illness, this can make it very hard for her to get better. To break out of the mental health system and go to college, as your daughter has done, requires determination and courage. I know because I did it myself, graduating from UEA last summer with an MA in creative writing. Yet all you can say is that she may well fail or drop out. Why not celebrate instead her tremendous achievement in getting there at all? Maybe she will fail, and maybe she won't, but I can hardly believe this attitude is helping. The future doesn't have to be as bleak as you imagine. The mentally ill have a huge contribution to make to society. Too often their efforts are compromised not by any fault of their own, but by the failure of others to see beyond their illness. Clare Allan, London Next week Fifteen years ago my former husband's mother, with whom I had always been on very good terms, suddenly moved and cut herself off from everyone for no reason that I could figure out. For a while I tried to contact her, but without success. Then last year I discovered her address on a CD-rom that we had on trial at work. My dilemma is whether or not to write to her. The thought that she might be a lonely old lady tempts me to do so - she was widowed before we lost touch and had no other relatives, having quarrelled with all her sisters long before I ever knew her. She now has two little great-grandchildren that she does not know about, but I do not want to do anything that might mean re-establishing contact with my ex-husband. He was violent, always lied, was sometimes in trouble with the police and my son would never forgive me if I did anything to bring him back into our lives. It may be because of him that she disappeared. Should I leave well alone, or risk contacting her? I thought of using a PO box number, but that seems a bit devious. What do other readers think?  Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. webTitle: Hollywood reporter:  Ciao, Tin Pan Ollie

fields.headline: Ciao, Tin Pan Ollie
fields.standfirst: We can only hope that news of Oliver Stone's impending retirement hasn't been exaggerated
fields.trailText: We can only hope that news of Oliver Stone's impending retirement hasn't been exaggerated
fields.body:
God knows I love late Christmas presents, but I wasn't expecting anything as nice as the announcement by Oliver Stone in Premiere that he'll retire from film-making after completing two more features. My blissed-out reactions to Stone's offer ranged from "promises, promises" to "can we get a notarised signature on that, Oliver?"

I hope he means it. Because for me Stone has long represented everything overrated, bombastic and mendacious in modern Hollywood - the only place on earth where an emotional fascist like him could seriously be considered a paragon of the left. He is also, thanks to the "countermyth" of JFK, the father - or prime disseminator - of brain-dead conspiracy-theorising, a headlong flight from, rather than an embrace of, serious political engagement.

Why is he retiring now anyway? Have his creative juices dried up since last year's drug bust made him clean up? Or is there some regret for the rubbish he's unleashed on us in the last 20 years? I doubt it. This is the man who gave us Natural Born Killers, the wildly overrated Platoon and the raw tedium of Any Given Sunday. Add to that his scripts for Eight Million Ways to Die and The Year of the Dragon, and you have a CV that can only be read while wearing a gas mask.

"My final film," Stone said, "will be my funeral oration"; proving that his Napoleonic delusions remain intact. I think his final film should be a threnody for the million detached retinas, perforated eardrums and de-enlightened minds his films have caused. Farewell, Ollie - and I don't mean "au revoir".

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | Food on the net | Just out | On the menu
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Mumtaz, Great Horton Road, Bradford BD7 3HS. Tel: 01274 571861

Bustling but unhurried, bright but not garish, Mumtaz is the prime exponent of the phenomenon that is the Bradford curry. Kashmir-influenced, these are dishes of substance, unabashed in their use of dark, warm spices, the chilli heat flowing through without overpowering the raw ingredients. Chats, puris and deep-fried stuffed chillies among the starters (55p - £2.60), chicken masala desie (drumsticks), lamb sookha bouhna, paneer shahi, chana khoya among the mains served by weight (£4.10 - £5.50 for 220g, £7.50 - £10.50 for 440g). An alcohol-free zone compensated by probably the best lassi in Europe.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Kashmir , 27 Morley Street, Bradford. Tel: 01274 726513

Every now and then we all yearn for a primal blast of energy and flavour. That's the Kashmir for you. Forget lightweight, perfumed curries, relaxed, slow eating, and cutlery. This loud and brazen basement is for folk looking for a full-blown onslaught on the tastebuds. A landmark on the city's curry scene, the crowded kitchen serves up seriously sauced platefuls of chicken, lamb and veg with smoky, chewy chapatis included in the price (£2.80 - £4.80). Toothsome kebabs and bhajis for starters (50p - £2.20), Kashmiri specials, kofta, lamb trotters, quail for main courses. A five-sense experience, they don't come any better, hotter, cheaper or quicker than this.

Food on the net

www.cobrabeer.com

Cobra Beer's selling point is that it makes the perfect accompaniment to curry. The website is basically an extension of the Team Saatchi ad campaign, featuring Curry Dave. Here we are given a guided tour of Dave's new "Naansion", which has a sort of Cluedo-style layout but sadly no lead piping or candelabra. You'll find links left, right and centre, telling you all about the beer, the company and its entrepreneurial founder. And some nice snapshots of Curry Dave with his lovely lady, Amanda.

Here comes the science bit: Because Cobra Beer is less fizzy than most European beers, it allows you to eat more curry - instead of filling up on gas, you can guzzle more peshwari. Eureka!

Just out

Merchant gourmet organic sun-dried tomatoes

Form:
Reddish-brown shrivelled ears.

Flavour:
Meaty; salty; sort of ultra-condensed tomato.

Verdict: According to the bumph, these are grown on a Sicilian farm, dried for three to five days in the sun with the help of some sea salt, and then certified organic according to QC&I International, the European certification body, whatever that might be. I'm not sure that the organic business adds anything to the flavour, which is at the aggressive end of the spectrum. Probably one to add to soups and stews rather than salads and sandwiches. In other words, the effect needs to be tempered.

On the menu
Coco beans

Oh come on, a bean is a bean is a bean. Isn't it, old bean?
Not when you have moth beans, runner beans, azuki beans, mung beans, soya beans, butter beans, haricot beans, kidney beans to name but a few, all of which are used for different dishes.

OK. So what's with this coco bean?
It's small, white, and like a small version of an haricot bean or an even smaller version of a cannellini bean, only rounder.

Taste?
Quite like a haricot bean or a cannellini bean, to be honest.

What's so special about them?
They're a bit more delicate, and a bit creamier, and they go very nicely with confit of duck or roast cod.

That's it?
'Fraid so.

fields.headline: The wrong stuff
fields.standfirst: Not even the incomparable Connery can save Gus Van Sant from his descent into brainlessness
fields.trailText: Not even the incomparable Connery can save Gus Van Sant from his descent into brainlessness
fields.body:
Gus Van Sant's new movie Finding Forrester prompts two troubling questions. First, how can a dreary, predictable chamber piece like this be so bad, despite a superlative performance by roughneck aristocrat Sean Connery? And second, what happened to Gus Van Sant anyway?

To put it simply, success happened to Gus Van Sant; Hollywood happened to Gus Van Sant. Ten years ago he made one of the first and most enduring masterpieces of the 1990s, Drugstore Cowboy, whose brittle tenderness and romantic pessimism remain undiluted a decade later. Then he blew it with two chaotic flops, My Own Private Idaho, which was judged more as an important film made by a gay man (and in that respect it was a landmark) than as a controlled work of cinema (which it was not), and Even Cowgirls Get the Blues, which felt like more of the same, or more precisely, less of the same. To Die For, a smug satire on the media by Buck Henry, brought Van Sant closer to the centre, and set him up for his present role in the system.

Next came Good Will Hunting - to which, I note with muted horror, I awarded four stars on its release. Let me now take three of them back and say that Van Sant's first box-office smash was a bimbo of a movie, one that looked awful pretty if it caught you in a forgiving mood. It made stars of Matt Damon and Ben Affleck - two of the least charismatic actors of our time. Then came Van Sant's Psycho remake, of which I will say nothing at all, if only to keep my blood pressure in check.

And now we have Finding Forrester, which is little more than a ghetto version of Good Will Hunting. It's about a 16-year-old black kid named Jamal who has an amazing talent for writing. He's taken under the wing of William Forrester, a reclusive writer who wrote one novel in the early 1950s which has since achieved the status of "Great American Novel" - even though its author is Scottish.

That would be Sean, of course, his performance riffing on JD Salinger, the great absent presence of the American teenage novel, and other secretive scribes past and present. (Which reminds me of the lady who approached the publicity-shy Don DeLillo at a party and said, "I know you! I've read all your books! You're William Gaddis!" To which DeLillo replied, "No, I'm Thomas Pynchon.") Forrester lives on his royalties and never leaves his apartment in a rundown Brooklyn neighbourhood, preferring the solace provided by a bottle of J&B.

Connery fills Forrester with rage and sadness, sensitivity and gruffness and, by doing so, makes his own scenes very compelling. Jamal, played by gifted non-pro Rob Brown, is Will Hunting Redux. Despite his impoverished background, he's got it all: he's brainy, he's a great writer (albeit one who can't speak in sentences and paragraphs), he's a knockout on the basketball court, the chicks are all over him and, in the end, he gets every reward, wins every prize and saves the errant Forrester from himself. Van Sant, the ex-poet of Drugstore Cowboy, here surrenders himself wholesale to the Hollywood machine and its dread gospel of remakes and retreads.

Still, that leaves us with another fine Connery performance to add to his bulging portfolio. The man really does endure - he was named Sexiest Man Alive by People magazine when he was pushing 70 - so he must be doing something right. These days, if you need someone to play God, don't think twice, give Connery a call. Something deep in his Caledonian soul pours out through those animal eyes and persuades you that this is a man of gravitas and ironclad self-assurance, someone you seriously shouldn't mess with.

Allied to this sense of threat is his panther-like grace, still evident in his eighth decade, and that hinterland of guaranteed manliness and sexual authority that underpinned his stint as 007. He moaned about the superspy connection for years after relinquishing the role to Roger Moore, but our folk memory of the gentleman/thug Bond - wigs notwithstanding - is a shorthand for elegant machismo and feral grace. There are stories that back this up, such as the time on the set of Another Time, Another Place when he laid out Lana Turner's vicious boyfriend Johnny Stompanato with a single punch.

When I look back over his career it's not Bond that stays in my mind, or his Oscar-winning Irish cop in The Untouchables. It's tiny details such as the young Sean dancing like a dervish in Cy Endfield's 1957 Hell Drivers, his tamed rapist Mark Rutland in Marnie, the slap he gives Candice Bergen in The Wind and the Lion ("My name is Ali-Ben Raisuli. Do not laugh at me"), or his brutalised sergeant in Sidney Lumet's The Hill, my own favourite Connery turn.

He also gave masterclasses in how to age gracefully a long time before Clint Eastwood. In Dick Lester's elegiac Robin and Marian he plays an ageing Robin Hood, grunting and panting through his swordfights with an equally geriatric Robert Shaw.

Finding Forrester sees him using all that stored-up power, and a face that, in close-up, is one of cinema's great shifting human landscapes. Long may the movie rot, but long may its great star twinkle - and darkly, always darkly.

webTitle: Saffron Burrows' film diary of Tempted

fields.headline: 'Word comes through that another punch-up has taken place. Blimey. It's only day three...'
fields.standfirst: When  Saffron Burrows  agreed to star in an improvised movie as Burt Reynolds' wife, she had no idea quite what she was letting herself in for
fields.trailText: When Saffron Burrows agreed to star in an improvised movie as Burt Reynolds' wife, she had no idea quite what she was letting herself in for
fields.body:
September 2000

I am sent a script of Tempted, an improvised film, to be shot in New Orleans. It is for the role of Lily LeBlanc, wife of Charlie - Burt Reynolds - a nouveau riche property developer. In fact, it is a non-script; it is a 60-page treatment of a contemporary thriller, with no dialogue on the page, hence the improv. Each scene is simply a description of what, emotionally, takes place.

Charlie LeBlanc is a man eaten up with jealousy, obsessed with the idea that, given half a chance, his wife may cheat on him. A young character called Jimmy is paid to attempt to seduce Lily. Charlie promises more money if he's successful than if he's not. Over the course of five or six days, the trio's lives fall apart. They are all morally ambiguous and deception goes deep.

Tempted's writer-director Bill Bennett made Kiss or Kill, an Aussie road movie, in this improvised fashion. I call Bill in New Orleans where he's prepping, and he tells me that Kiss or Kill was shot completely out of sequence, and entirely looped. The whole thing. This horrifies me. In orthodox film-making, you never shoot sequentially - but with improv, obviously every move you make has a knock-on effect; it is a cumulative process. I have improvised, on the non-scripted Timecode. It can become entirely indulgent: actors smashing crockery and competing verbally. Nothing wrong with that, but it's probably exhausting.

Turns out Bill's background is in photography and documentary. He's keen for me to meet him & his wife and discuss concerns. We agree to have lunch in LA in a week's time.

Saturday September 23. An Italian restaurant on Melrose

I meet husband & wife team, Bill and Jennifer. She produces; she's also clearly Bill's mate, dramaturge, his everything. I feel shy, but it's OK. The Bennetts are clever and non-hysterical. We talk for several hours and I express some worries: will Burt and I be a coherent couple on screen?

Sunday September 24. Cocktails with money men

I am to meet the financiers in a very dark bar in the Beverly Wilshire hotel. Drinks and light chatter. Except, there are 12 of them and one of me, so my manager comes too. Bill's very softly spoken, and the French aren't quite catching his introductions. We sit, peering at each other, in the low light. Bill kicks things off by saying: "Well, we had lunch with Saffron yesterday, and she pointed out that the script is rather erotic." From a three-hour lunch, this is what he focuses on. And then Jennifer, to my left, chimes in: "Yes, I thought that was rather a strange thing to say!"

Excuse me, but have I invented the five love scenes, one shower scene plus a blowjob involving four different characters? As the writer/producers of this drama, I got the impression they were going for a vaguely sensual psychological thriller. I give up, and speak French to the French, asking them about their families. After 90 minutes, we're all conversing, and eventually we bid farewell with slaps on backs, saying: "We see you in New Orleans." Jennifer clasps me to her and says: "I don't know how you do it, how you do it." I wonder what? "Talking to them like that, fabulous."

I drive away feeling bemused.

Now I have to decide whether this is an interesting challenge, or merely suicide. Decide to give it a go.

Monday October 9. More drinks

Tonight I am to meet Peter Facinelli, who is to play Jimmy. So watch The Big Kahuna, a three-hander with Facinelli, Kevin Spacey and Danny DeVito. Peter's very good in it; disingenuous and devoutly religious, nice, alongside their cynicism.

We meet in yet another bar. He happens to be stunning, elements of Cruise and Paul Newman in his face. I am keen to meet Burt, too, but he's in Florida, so I guess I've taken the plunge, sight unseen. I hope we get on. I expect him to be macho, right-wing, and have little time for us. Bill assures me that Burt is unpretentious, clever, complex, and looking forward to improvising. His stories do precede him, though. I am a little fearful.

Tuesday October 24. New Orleans

We're rehearsing in the house of Francis Ford Coppola. The entire Aussie directing department is living there. The kitchen's impressive, bottles of his wine all over the place. Coppola has this place as an occasional home, and specifically wants film-makers to make use of it. It is a tall, dark, stone house, hidden behind shutters.

There's a courtyard where we base ourselves. Peter, Bill and I sit around a garden table. It is quiet and a little stiff at first. Peter does not speak much, lots of smoking and flashing eyes. So I think of the heart of the story: Charlie's devastatingly destructive jealousy.

I mention Leontes. I don't go quite so far as to pluck extracts, for I can see this is not going down well. My voice withers and tails off. I assure them that I'm not well-versed in the classics. Sure they're thinking: "Bloody Europeans."

Peter eventually opens up and we start to work our way through the script, just in broad strokes. All goes well until a car park sequence. Peter suggests the choreography of a shot, as well as the dialogue: "Well, Lily's walking back to her car and I'm filling my trunk and maybe the audience spot me before she does and the camera's over her shoulder, her POV of me in fact..."

Bill just stares, and is terribly quiet. Us actors exchange looks. Eventually he says: "I am the director, you are an actor, you never, ever discuss Camera. Cameras are nothing to do with you, do you understand?" There is a silence. I feel we have established something.

Monday October 30. Burt's in town

Today we rehearse, as a complete cast, at Coppola's. Burt walks in, stylish in black, and grasps my hand firmly: "I've been having a little festival of your movies in my room, and you just keep getting better 'n' better." He has more charm in his little finger than most of us encounter in a lifetime. I feel immensely shy, and full of angst at the thought of what he might have seen. We all have our skeletons.

George DiCenzo, a razor-sharp, east coast Italian, plays Burt's private eye. George is America's foremost drama teacher, and dramaturge. When he can't take class, De Niro steps in for him. I imagine that he would be every non-neurotic director's dream. George exudes a formidable intelligence, and a discerning eye. He mentions Leontes, and I love him.

Mike Starr, a large Irish New Yorker, plays Burt's warm but lethal right-hand man. He is a puppy around George and Burt. I enjoy the lack of machismo in the air. There is a sense of competing, but on a level of verbal wit which is amusing to observe.

My first impressions of Burt are of a schism existing between the gentle and the fiery. His eyes are troubled, but incredibly warm. Most apparent is his eloquence, his love of literature, and of the south. He gives me a James Lee Burke special edition, given to him by Burke. And a southern booklist.

The improvisation worries us all. Bill assures us that by the end of the week, when we get to work, we will all find a voice. He says he's seen it happen with actors time and again, working in this way. And once we stop, he's sure that we won't want to work in any way but this.

I'm not surprised that Burt is anxious; he has, perhaps, the most to lose.

Thursday November 2. Raw Hide

Today we sit on sofas and an actor playing the attorney pops in to meet us. Burt's got his don't-fuck-with-me black cashmere on. We discuss detail: intimate elements of Charlie, Jimmy, Lily, the LeBlanc marriage, and the like. Then things escalate in a certain way: Jimmy's vocal, Charlie's vocal, voices are raised and, suddenly, detail becomes contentious. Bill suggests to "Charlie" that they step outside. Rather a brave idea I think.

"Oh, you're asking the wrong person to step outside," he responds, hitching his sleeves, plus a hoik of the trousers, and they're off, into the courtyard. Me, Peter and the attorney who just walked in sit in stunned silence.

For 45 minutes.

We hear a thud at one point, but realise it's just a fist hitting a wall. We then witness, through the French windows, the two men embracing, and in they come, saying roll on Sunday, first day of filming. We all then embrace, of course, cashmere on cashmere, and off we go to spend several days in a state of lonely anxiety.

Friday November 3

Burt has invited me to dinner. We go to a French place, and, as we enter, the diners sing Keep Those Wagons Rolling. He has great tales from his days as a young New York theatre naif. Tennessee wanted to sleep with him, and he unwittingly declined Garbo. And like LL Cool J, he has met every president. Many Reagan/Clinton/Carter stories later, he invites me to a boxing match in Biloxi. Another thing that Lily loves, of course.

Monday November 5. First day

Have obviously peaked by the time I reach the make-up trailer. They began yesterday without me, so feel shy around the crew; a newcomer. Watch "Charlie" kick the shit out of "Jimmy" in rather a well-choreographed punch-up. The atmosphere is good and calm. We are shooting in the French Quarter's magnificent marble courthouse, where JFK was made. Six hours later it becomes clear that the tropical storms have flummoxed us and shooting cannot continue. I get out Deliverance and go home to watch it. Feel I have some catching up to do as I've only seen Burt in The Mean Machine.

Tuesday November 6. Back to the courthouse

Lunch with Burt and Big Mike Starr. Do you know, they have drive-through daiquiri bars here. At around 4pm it becomes clear that trouble is afoot. The make-up trailer is a hotbed of gossip. I've yet to shoot and word is that production has ground to a halt. We speculate on the hold-up when word comes through on the walkie that another punch-up has occurred. Blimey. It's only day three.

Transpires that the male leads, both of whom I'm rather fond of at this point, have had crew members confused, blurring the edges between rehearsal and reality. The stills woman has got great shots apparently, but the negative may have to be destroyed. The director also bore the brunt a little, and again I marvel at his fortitude. Hours of discussion in trailers ensue, and I go and talk to a fellow actor about anger management.

Finally, in near-dusk, I do a shot of my foot stepping out of a car and crossing a construction site.

Thursday November 9. Shrapnel damage

We're on to nights - and in Lafayette cemetery. Because of the city's geological make-up, bodies are never laid to rest below ground. Beautiful tombs abound.

There are firearms involved tonight. An attacker shoots Burt, I shoot the attacker. I have a fabricated cleavage, and wear very little, Savannah-style. There is a character in Savannah, the TV series, who has a great sashay, and says "Pish-posh" a lot. She is my motivation. Pity no one here's seen the show.

A discussion is held, in the dark, over whether to use full loads [of explosive] in the guns. Burt shows us a trick he does, loved by his 11-year-old. Holding his nose, he blocks one ear, and the sound of a wet, snotty coastline can be heard, whistling through his passages - he had one ear drum blown out in Italy, the other in Mexico, and most of an eyeball in Spain. He urges the director not to use a full load. We all listen, the stunt guys take note, and I am deeply impressed. As union reps go, you could not find a better one.

So, we shoot in the cemetery with quarter loads. The balaclava-clad man fires, Burt falls, and I aim at the attacker's heart. However, Burt's squib explodes, and I think that half my face has fallen off. I look around for sympathy/assurance/blah-de-blah. The nurse pulls me to her bosom, and puts out the smouldering embers. The camera op's nose is burnt, and my cheek is radiating heat. Poor Bill, who's not used guns before, is appalled. They wrap me in a duvet, and layer on more foundation over the burn.

On to the next shot. The camera op gets to wear a plastic visor for the ensuing set-ups. He and I are veterans and have bonded. I, by now, am so scared of the squibs that I turn away each time Burt's chest explodes, anticipating, and turning before he's shot.

Monday November 13. Chez LeBlanc

I am in the LeBlanc house today, with Burt. We're here all week and it's a good, grand environment. Very like the sets in Savannah, which still no one has seen. There is a creaky start, but by the evening the scenes are becoming something. I'm not sure what, but I have a vocabulary that is not my own.

It is slightly trance-like, working in this way. Burt is formidable; very much alive. He thinks this is the most exciting way of working; like flying when it's good, inviting suicide when bad.

I had thought, back in rehearsal, I would be up all night writing very clever monologues and then attempting to casually slip them in. But no, maybe I'm too lazy, or maybe I've decided to trust Bill.

Thursday November 16

I have the first of several "love" scenes today, and more next week with two other men.

Friday November 17. Boxing in Biloxi

Burt has hired a 14-seater, sparkly white limo/people carrier, stocked with oysters, Golden Goose rum and Po-boy sandwiches. We drive to Biloxi in a storm with a driver who gets lost. We almost reach Florida, and do a U-turn. Anxious phonecalls come through from the fight promoter saying they can't start until we get there. Blimey, no pressure.

Finally we hear the prelims have begun, which is a shame because I'm dying to see George Foreman's daughter: she's due to fight Ali's offspring soon. We miss her. And then we miss a bloke called Potato-head or Pickle or something. My boyfriend is here, a Newcastle man, and he's decided, from the poster, that the guy must be a Geordie. And then we hear that former world heavyweight Larry Holmes is in the ring. This is getting desperate. He's the one who invited Burt. I'm thinking this is like an exotic school trip, with sandwiches and everything. We've crossed into Mississippi, when sirens approach and we're given a police escort right into the arena. Burt tells us he will now become a complete redneck, and apologises for it in advance.

As we take our ringside seats, they announce Mr Reynolds' arrival over the tannoy. He is a god in Biloxi. The crowd erupts. Holmes is on round eight, the sweat's flying and I'm loving the buzz of it. Holmes glances over at Burt, and knocks the guy out. We've been in our seats for 30 seconds and it's all over. There are girls in fur bikinis all over us to get a Burt thigh to perch on for a photograph. We've driven through a storm, across a state, and the fight's over. And the girls keep coming.

They wear little white towels around their thongs, presumably for warmth, and then whip them off when they reach Burt. He's a little embarrassed, having told me about the campaigning he did for Gloria Steinem in the 1970s.

We go to the shabby backstage rooms and Holmes embraces Burt, saying: "Where were you man? I couldn't hold that bum up for much longer."

Sunday November 19. The Artist Formerly Known As

We have drinks with Burt & friends, then dinner, then more drinks. At a late point, a young woman sashays up and says to Reynolds: "Oh you are one sexy motherfucker..." Grins all round. She continues: "There's a guy outside that I wanna screw and I was wond'rin' if I could have your autograph for his mama." She then steps outside, with the signature, leans against the glass window, and gyrates against this guy.

Tuesday November 21

It is now clear Burt is a socialist at heart; not merely the Steinem involvement, but also the American Indian Movement, and more. Little did I know back in September.

Thursday November 30. Bouffant blues

Burt has wrapped now, so it's me and Jimmy here on in. We are at the Saturn bar, one of many roach-infested haunts we spend our days shooting in, with me just loving it all, the whole vibe; each place full of stinky musician history.

In this scene, Jimmy and Lily are on a platonic first date. I notice that Jimmy's hair resembles David Ginola's in the L'Oréal ads. Remarkably clean and soft and zzhussy. I then see him grab the mirror before each take and zzhussh it some more. By now it's got great volume, in fact it's added inches.

Wednesday December 6. Scenes from a mall

We are at the car park; the scene which was much discussed the ominous day one of rehearsal. I have not dared refer to "Camera" from that day on. Occasionally I ask the director of photography about lens size.

We're on a tight two-shot. The image is: over my shoulder on to Jimmy's face, I am in my Lexus, leaning out, he's resting his chin on the wing mirror, so the camera holds my reflected image in frame, just below Jimmy's. As they set up, I see him swinging the wing mirror in and out, turning the reflection away from camera, and then back again. By now I do not find him disingenuous. We go for a take and, lo and behold, halfway through he swings the mirror in, and the rest plays as a tight single. When we cut, I thank him for obscuring my image for half the scene. Oh, he says, sorry, I didn't mean to do that. I then watch him for a while. See the cogs going, and catching me clocking him, he comes over to fess up, saying: "You know what, I did mean to do it; I thought it would be a neat shot."

Sunday December 10

I have a day off and Facinelli comes to see me when he's wrapped. I like him in these quiet moments when he doesn't have a cinematic agenda. He is a fine actor, and will be wonderful as Jimmy. Agitated, and concerned about the music chosen for our Cajun dancing, he's had an altercation with one of the producers. She's basically told him where to go, and to let her produce. He comes to my room a little shaken, saying: "And I thought Burt was frightening." I think of making the producer a badge: "Scarier than Burt." Think she'd like that. Better wait until the last day though.

Tuesday December 19. It's a wrap

Tonight is the coldest Louisana's had for 10 years. What happened to the steamy, sultry south? We set up for another shoot, this time in the swamp. Loath to relive my squib experience, I work out a way of firing my gun at very close range, thereby obscuring it from view, avoiding the need for bullets, or gunpowder of any sort. Am immensely relieved.

We then have a shot of Big Mike Starr firing a pump action at me. I'm wearing a skirt and T-shirt. The crew are wrapped in blankets with visors across foreheads. I look around, as I dive for the door, note the self-protective efforts of the crew, and then feel a cannonball force blow the wall to pieces. We are in a wooden hut that now has to be rebuilt. The crew, post-shot, are covered in great chunks of wood and plaster. I'm a bit scared. They always save these shots for the last night.

We work until 11 on Wednesday morning, and sing carols on the barge, all the way back to unit base. Even I have a hot toddy at this point.

Thursday December 21. Texas

Waiting for a connecting flight to London, I sit in Houston Airport watching George W Bush on CNN stand down as governor of Texas. It is depressing how the crowd adores him. I am laden down with books from Burt and Bill. Southern literature to last me a lifetime. I feel several years older. And, of course, terribly fond of everyone. Bid Peter farewell yesterday at the House of Blues Gospel wrap party. Almost shared his cigar as an expression of friendship.

Have slept for three hours since Monday. Am deranged with fatigue. Perhaps that is the only way to leave this place.

On your back.

 Tempted will be released in the autumn.

Each scene is simply a description of what, emotionally, takes place. Charlie LeBlanc is a man eaten up with jealousy, obsessed with the idea that, given half a chance, his wife may cheat on him. A young character called Jimmy is paid to attempt to seduce Lily. Charlie promises more money if he's successful than if he's not. Over the course of five or six days, the trio's lives fall apart. They are all morally ambiguous and deception goes deep. Tempted's writer-director Bill Bennett made Kiss or Kill, an Aussie road movie, in this improvised fashion. I call Bill in New Orleans where he's prepping, and he tells me that Kiss or Kill was shot completely out of sequence, and entirely looped. The whole thing. This horrifies me. In orthodox film-making, you never shoot sequentially - but with improv, obviously every move you make has a knock-on effect; it is a cumulative process. I have improvised, on the non-scripted Timecode. It can become entirely indulgent: actors smashing crockery and competing verbally. Nothing wrong with that, but it's probably exhausting. Turns out Bill's background is in photography and documentary. He's keen for me to meet him & his wife and discuss concerns. We agree to have lunch in LA in a week's time. Saturday September 23. An Italian restaurant on Melrose I meet husband & wife team, Bill and Jennifer. She produces; she's also clearly Bill's mate, dramaturge, his everything. I feel shy, but it's OK. The Bennetts are clever and non-hysterical. We talk for several hours and I express some worries: will Burt and I be a coherent couple on screen? Sunday September 24. Cocktails with money men I am to meet the financiers in a very dark bar in the Beverly Wilshire hotel. Drinks and light chatter. Except, there are 12 of them and one of me, so my manager comes too. Bill kicks things off by saying: "Well, we had lunch with Saffron yesterday, and she pointed out that the script is rather erotic." From a three-hour lunch, this is what he focuses on. And then Jennifer, to my left, chimes in: "Yes, I thought that was rather a strange thing to say!" Excuse me, but have I invented the five love scenes, one shower scene plus a blowjob involving four different characters? As the writer/producers of this drama, I got the impression they were going for a vaguely sensual psychological thriller. I give up, and speak French to the French, asking them about their families. After 90 minutes, we're all conversing, and eventually we bid farewell with slaps on backs, saying: "We see you in New Orleans." Jennifer clasps me to her and says: "I don't know how you do it, how you do it." I wonder what? "Talking to them like that, fabulous." I drive away feeling bemused. Perhaps that is the only way to leave this place. On your back.  Tempted will be released in the autumn.

webTitle: Labour admits failures on policy targets

fields.headline: Labour admits failures on policy targets
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Two Labour key policies - ending the blight of drugs and cutting traffic congestion - were in disarray last night after Whitehall was forced to admit it had no way of judging whether it was meeting its targets.
fields.body:
Two Labour key policies - ending the blight of drugs and cutting traffic congestion - were in disarray last night after Whitehall was forced to admit it had no way of judging whether it was meeting its targets.

The admission comes in a series of papers released by government departments on the details of broad public service targets published in the summer, and how they will be met. Together the targets, most of them set to be met in 2004-05, amount to an early release of Labour's second-term manifesto.

But Labour will be embarrassed by the revelation that four years after pledging a crusade against excess car use, the Department of Environment is still working both on how to measure changes in traffic congestion and what targets should be set.

The Cabinet Office also conceded that the drugs tsar, Keith Hellawell, had no way yet of gauging whether he was making progress in meeting his key targets in the fight against drugs.

The four main targets, including cutting drug use among young people by a quarter by 2005 were set two years ago. Even if this target were to be met, more than 6% of 18- to 25-year-olds will take class A drugs in 2005.

The other drugs targets centre on cutting reoffending by drug users, reducing the availability of drugs and increasing participation by young people.

The Cabinet Office said civil servants were still working on how to measure progress. The lack of any reliable statistical base raised the question of how the drugs tsar set the targets in the first place and how the government can know if its policies are working.

The pledge to cut traffic congestion was also in doubt. Early in the parliament, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, asked to be judged on whether he reduced the number of car journeys.

Ministers have now changed tack and promised by 2010 to reduce traffic congestion on the inter-urban trunk network and in large urban areas. The Department of Environment admits "the methodology for collection" of such figures is still to be finalised.

The targets also reveal the extent to which ministers recognise the scale of the struggle ahead in raising stan dards in schools. By 2004, 75% of schoolchildren in England's 500 worst performing schools will still not achieve 5 GCSE at grades A to C.

In all, ministers have set more than 200 measurable targets, many of which may come back to haunt the government if they are not met by the target date. The government has already suffered criticism for not yet meeting two of its five key election pledges.

fields.headline: Violent end to online 'romance'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: An Israeli teenager went to the West Bank to see a young Palestinian woman he had met on the internet, and ended up dead, his body full of bullets.
fields.body:
An Israeli teenager went to the West Bank to see a young Palestinian woman he had met on the internet, and ended up dead, his body full of bullets.

Opinions were divided last night on whether the couple was a modern Middle Eastern version of Romeo and Juliet or whether the boy was lured to his death.

The boy's body was handed over to Israel yesterday, more than 24 hours after it was discovered near the city of Ramallah. Reports on Wednesday had suggested that the body was that of a Palestinian.

The dead teenager is believed to have been 16, and to have run away from his home in the coastal city of Ashqelon on Tuesday, carrying a large sum of money.

He becomes the 367th victim of the violence that has engulfed Israel and the Palestinians for the last 16 weeks. But this death appears to have badly shaken the authorities on both sides.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, last night described the murder as "cold-blooded". A spokesman for Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority said it condemned all killings of Israeli civilians.

Israel army radio reported that the boy may have been deliberately lured to the West Bank so that he could be robbed and murdered. The radio said that no money was found on the body.

Israel's Channel Two television reported that soldiers had seen the boy walking on the edge of Ramallah with a young Palestinian women. It said a car had pulled up alongside the couple, carrying several men in civilian clothes who opened fire.

For Mr Barak, the killing by suspected Palestinian assailants of a second Jewish male in less than a week is bound to test his determination to pursue a new round of diplomatic activity. The prime minister is trying desperately to close the gap on a nearly 20-point lead by his hardline rival, Ariel Sharon, in an election now just three weeks away.

For Mr Arafat, who yesterday spoke out in favour of intensifying diplomatic efforts to reach a settlement, the killing was a further reminder that his administration's authority is slipping, and that gunmen are now in the ascendancy.

Yesterday, a group unknown before the onset of the intifada, the Palestinian Brigades of the Martyrs of al-Aqsa, claimed responsibility for the killing of one of Mr Arafat's proteges: the Palestinian television chief.

Hisham Mikki was shot dead at a Gaza beachfront hotel as he was waiting for his lunch companions. In a statement, the group said he was killed because he had "practised sex, stolen money, and was corrupt".
