webTitle: Jesse Jackson quits after aide has his child

fields.headline: Jackson quits after aide has his child
fields.trailText: The black civil rights leader the Rev Jesse Jackson said yesterday he was temporarily leaving the public stage after admitting fathering a child in an extramarital affair with a member of his staff.
fields.body:
The black civil rights leader the Rev Jesse Jackson said yesterday he was temporarily leaving the public stage after admitting fathering a child in an extramarital affair with a member of his staff.

"This is no time for evasions, denials or alibis. I fully accept responsibility and I am truly sorry for my actions," Mr Jackson said in a statement released when it became clear that some US tabloids were planning to run stories about his "love child".

The child's mother, Karin Stanford, 39, is a former assistant professor of politics from the University of Georgia who Mr Jackson hired in 1997 to run the Washington office of his Rainbow Coalition organisation.

She gave birth to a baby daughter in May 1999. After DNA tests proved the girl was Mr Jackson's child he agreed to pay child support of $3,000 (£2,000) a month. He also reportedly provided $40,000 in "moving expenses" for Ms Stansford when she left Washington in 1999 to have her baby in her home state of California.

"As her mother does, I love this child very much and have assumed responsibility for her emotional and financial support since she was born," Mr Jackson said.

"My wife, Jackie, and my children have been made aware of the child and it has been an extremely painful, trying and difficult time for them."

Press reports yesterday focused on the irony that the baby was conceived in summer 1998, when Mr Jackson went to pray with Bill Clinton's family when the president confessed to them about his affair with Monica Lewinsky.

"The nation must take the test: if there are any among us who have not known the trials and tribulations and temptations, then throw a rock," the baptist preacher and former presidential candidate said at the time. "At some point we have to forgive, redeem and move on."

A few months later, in December 1998, he took the then-pregnant Ms Stanford to visit Mr Clinton in the Oval Office, where they posed for a group photograph.

The 59-year-old populist leader and former aide to Martin Luther King said he would be "taking some time off to revive my spirit and reconnect with my family before I return to my public ministry".

It was unclear yesterday what impact the scandal would have on planned protests by Mr Jackson's supporters against irregularities in the November elections. He was due to lead a march in Florida to coincide with President-elect Bush's inauguration tomorrow.

His spokesman, John Scan lon, said the black leader would "honour some earlier commitments" but said it was too soon to give details.

Royal Marshall, a black radio talk show host in Atlanta, said his callers had been talking about little else.

"There are a lot of people who feel he is being hypocritical, [that] he is a reverend, and should not be in situations such as this."

Ms Stanford and her daughter now live in Los Angeles, where Mr Jackson reportedly visits them when he is in California.

His biographer, Marshall Frady, told the New York Post yesterday he was not surprised by the news as he said that, like Martin Luther King, Mr Jackson "is a passionate being and has never been skilled in applying calculated economies to his emotions".

In his statement Mr Jackson pointed out he had also been born out of wedlock.

He said: "I was born of these circumstances and I know the importance of growing up in a nurturing, supportive and protected environment so I am determined to give my daughter and her mother the privacy they both deserve."

webTitle: Armed hijackers 'said they would blow up plane'

fields.headline: Armed hijackers 'said they would blow up plane'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Stansted hijack
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: Twelve Afghan men who hijacked a Boeing 727 and held its passengers and crew hostage at gunpoint at Stansted for four days threatened to blow up the aircraft unless their demands were met, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Twelve Afghan men who hijacked a Boeing 727 and held its passengers and crew hostage at gunpoint at Stansted for four days threatened to blow up the aircraft unless their demands were met, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Armed with automatic pistols, hand grenades, impact detonators and knives, the men took control of the Ariana Airlines flight 15 minutes after it had taken off from the Afghan capital, Kabul, on what was supposed to be a 40 minute internal flight to the northern town of Mazar-i-Sharif. They had hidden the weapons in their socks to bypass cursory security checks at Kabul airport, which does not have x-ray machines or metal detectors.

The aircraft, carrying 173 passengers and 14 crew - in cluding 21 young children, touched down in Tashkent, the Uzbek capital, Kazakstan and Moscow before arriving at Stansted at 2am on February 7 last year.

After three tense days of negotiation on the tarmac, during which four of the flight crew escaped by climbing down a rope from the cockpit window, the hijackers gave themselves up and the remaining hostages were freed.

Opening the case for the prosecution, Bruce Houlder QC said the majority of the men claimed to belong to a group called the Young Intellectuals of Afghanistan, who were committed to freeing their country of the ruling Taliban regime, restoring democracy and improving the lot of Afghan women.

Mr Houlder told the jury that during the trial they would hear harrowing accounts of the brutality of life in Afghanistan, but warned the seven women and five men to "keep their feet on the ground".

He said: "Those who chose to oppose the Taliban or plot against them are dicing with death, with their lives and the lives of their families.

"Remember what they are - a group of people who follow a particularly extreme form of Islamic fundamentalism.

"Fundamentalism takes a perverted form in some men and some in the Taliban are capable of the most extreme cruelty and barbarity."

But he added: "It would take a cold heart to remain unmoved by the plight of these defendants. The fact that their lives have become a misery in their country and they have suffered deprivation - stories of how their homes and businesses were either bombed or burgled - does not provide justification for the crime committed.

"Sympathy is something all of us will no doubt experience - for the passengers and the accused. But keep it in its proper place."

He said that by taking over the plane by force using firearms and hand grenades the accused had put the lives of every person on board at risk. He added that the 12 men, many of whom had family on board, were no ordinary asylum seekers who surrendered themselves to the authorities on reaching British shores.

Instead they had kept more than 150 people hostage in the most extreme conditions for more than three days.

The prosecution said the jury would hear evidence from a number of those on board the aircraft during the hijack, including a passenger who would describe how the hijackers had threatened to shoot them unless they stayed in their seats and kept their heads down.

Mr Houlder said that various acts of violence had been committed by the hijackers, the most serious of which occurred after they discovered the flight crew had escaped.

Describing how "bedlam had ensued", Mr Houlder said the remaining crew were rounded up, trussed and beaten as they lay on the aircraft floor.

The hijackers threatened to kill them, and all of the passengers on board, unless the escapees returned. The remaining stewards "begged" negotiators to "do something to help".

One steward, who suffered a head wound in the alleged attack, was later shoved out of the plane with his hands still tied behind his back.

While at Stansted airport the "hysterical" hijackers frequently threatened to throw the bodies of their hostages from the plane if their demands were not met.

At one point, the gang's spokesman allegedly gave negotiators a one minute ultimatum to remove armed police from around the plane or they would kill some of the hostages.

The trial was adjourned and continues on Monday.

webTitle: Hospital admits storing 12 bodies in boilerhouse

fields.headline: Hospital admits storing 12 bodies in boilerhouse
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A hospital in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, last night admitted that it had left 12 bodies in a disused and unrefrigerated boilerhouse over Christmas and promised a full investigation as the row into the storage of corpses escalated.
fields.body:
A hospital in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, last night admitted that it had left 12 bodies in a disused and unrefrigerated boilerhouse over Christmas and promised a full investigation as the row into the storage of corpses escalated.

David Fillingham, chief executive of North Staffordshire hospital, said the bodies had been placed in the makeshift morgue between Boxing Day and New Year's Eve. It had been set up a year earlier in case of major incidents during the millennium celebrations.

But he said he had no idea that it was still being used. He added that no more than seven bodies, wrapped in shrouds and resting on rows of tables, had been stored at any one time.

Mr Fillingham said: "While the facility was adequate for the difficult position we could have faced at the millennium, I do not believe it is appropriate for normal circumstances. It is no longer in use and is being dismantled."

The admission came as another hospital accused of leaving dead bodies on an unrefrigerated mortuary floor dismissed the photographic evidence as being outdated. The allegations followed the resignation on Monday of the chief executive at Bedford hospital where bodies were stored on the chapel floor last week.

The allegations that Newham general hospital, east London, had stored corpses inappropriately were made yesterday by the Mirror newspaper. They prompted Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, to complain that inappropriate treatment of corpses in NHS hospitals was widespread and "seriously damaged" the reputation of Alan Milburn, the health secretary.

Newham Healthcare NHS trust said a picture of bodies dumped on the mortuary floor was taken before a reorganisation of the facility and was at least four years old. Kathy Watkins, the chief executive, said no similar problems had been raised since she joined the trust in December 1997.

The Department of Health said: "We have total confidence in the trust. Nothing like that could happen at that trust this winter."

A spokeswoman for Unison said the story was "irresponsible, unfair and dishonest."

Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, said the paper accepted the picture was probably old but said it showed that dumping the dead happened more than once.

fields.headline: When grown men weep
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Mead  on New York sports fever
fields.trailText: Rebecca Mead  on New York sports fever
fields.body:
Over the next week or so, the streets of New York will be filled with people in blue-and-white woolly hats, all smiling goofily at other people wearing blue-and-white woolly hats. The New York Giants, the local American football team whose team colours are blue and white, trounced the Minnesota Vikings in a game on Sunday, with a stunning result of 41-0.

This means that the Giants are off to the Superbowl at the end of the month. Even if you're not a football fan - and I can watch these cartoonish guys in oversized shoulderpads and buttock-revealing tights for about 10 minutes before my fascination with their physiques is overwhelmed by my lack of incomprehension of the rules of the game - in New York, you have to know what's going on, sports-wise. On Sunday evening, I happened to ride my apartment building's elevator in the company of an elderly man in a Giants bomber jacket who volunteered that he'd wept at the end of the game. If I hadn't been able to agree with him about how amazing the result had been he might have started the weeping all over again.

New Yorkers are as fiercely proud of their sports teams as they are of anything that features the words "New" and "York" in its name. (There is, admittedly, a certain hostility to the Giants in some quarters because Giants Stadium is actually in New Jersey.) Last October, the World Series featured both New York baseball teams, the Mets and the Yankees. It was the first "subway series" in 44 years, and made for a weirdly magical week in the city, with every television in every bar tuned to the nightly games. The Yankees won, but the long-standing rivalry between the two teams was rendered irrelevant, more or less, by the romance of the thing, and by the pure pleasure for New Yorkers of shutting out the rest of the country.

Supporting the local teams is an essential qualification for any would-be New Yorker, so even though Hillary Clinton was ridiculed early in her Senate campaign for saying that she'd always been a Yankees supporter - she'd long been known as a fan of the Chicago Cubs - she had to do it. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is a die-hard Yankees fan, and when the Yankees were honoured by a ticker-tape parade through lower Manhattan, the famously discipliarian mayor took the unusual step of letting it be known that schoolchildren should feel free to play truant for the day in order to attend. Giuliani was front and centre at last weekend's Giants victory, and he has promised a ticker-tape parade for them, too, should they win, which should delight New York's school-age residents.

If the Giants are New York's confident, swaggering ego, the Knicks, New York's basketball team, are the city's id - messy, complicated, and passionate. Latrell Sprewell, the team's charismatic star player, will always be notorious for once choking the coach of his old team, the Golden State Warriors, which earned him a one-year suspension; and this past Monday, Marcus Camby, the team's 6ft 11in centre, accidentally flattened his own coach when he swung furiously at another player and headbutted the wrong guy. (The coach, Jeff Van Gundy, needed at least 12 stiches; Camby was suspended for five games.) The Knicks began this season playing like bums, as the local expression has it; but in recent weeks they've had a streak of victories, giving New Yorkers a slim hope that they might make it to the playoffs.

Last season, the Knicks got as far as the Eastern Conference finals before losing to the Indiana Pacers, after which there was a palpable depression in the air for days. One sportswriter for the New York Post, though, found a way to claim victory in defeat: he wrote that it was the Pacers who actually were the New York team, because several key players are native New Yorkers. Besides, the Pacers' play was so brash and skilful - what else could they be but New Yorkers?

Even if you're not a football fan - and I can watch these cartoonish guys in oversized shoulderpads and buttock-revealing tights for about 10 minutes before my fascination with their physiques is overwhelmed by my lack of incomprehension of the rules of the game - in New York, you have to know what's going on, sports-wise. On Sunday evening, I happened to ride my apartment building's elevator in the company of an elderly man in a Giants bomber jacket who volunteered that he'd wept at the end of the game. If I hadn't been able to agree with him about how amazing the result had been he might have started the weeping all over again. New Yorkers are as fiercely proud of their sports teams as they are of anything that features the words "New" and "York" in its name. (There is, admittedly, a certain hostility to the Giants in some quarters because Giants Stadium is actually in New Jersey.) Last October, the World Series featured both New York baseball teams, the Mets and the Yankees. It was the first "subway series" in 44 years, and made for a weirdly magical week in the city, with every television in every bar tuned to the nightly games. The Yankees won, but the long-standing rivalry between the two teams was rendered irrelevant, more or less, by the romance of the thing, and by the pure pleasure for New Yorkers of shutting out the rest of the country. Supporting the local teams is an essential qualification for any would-be New Yorker, so even though Hillary Clinton was ridiculed early in her Senate campaign for saying that she'd always been a Yankees supporter - she'd long been known as a fan of the Chicago Cubs - she had to do it. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is a die-hard Yankees fan, and when the Yankees were honoured by a ticker-tape parade through lower Manhattan, the famously discipliarian mayor took the unusual step of letting it be known that schoolchildren should feel free to play truant for the day in order to attend. Giuliani was front and centre at last weekend's Giants victory, and he has promised a ticker-tape parade for them, too, should they win, which should delight New York's school-age residents. If the Giants are New York's confident, swaggering ego, the Knicks, New York's basketball team, are the city's id - messy, complicated, and passionate. Latrell Sprewell, the team's charismatic star player, will always be notorious for once choking the coach of his old team, the Golden State Warriors, which earned him a one-year suspension; and this past Monday, Marcus Camby, the team's 6ft 11in centre, accidentally flattened his own coach when he swung furiously at another player and headbutted the wrong guy. (The coach, Jeff Van Gundy, needed at least 12 stiches; Camby was suspended for five games.) The Knicks began this season playing like bums, as the local expression has it; but in recent weeks they've had a streak of victories, giving New Yorkers a slim hope that they might make it to the playoffs. Last season, the Knicks got as far as the Eastern Conference finals before losing to the Indiana Pacers, after which there was a palpable depression in the air for days. One sportswriter for the New York Post, though, found a way to claim victory in defeat: he wrote that it was the Pacers who actually were the New York team, because several key players are native New Yorkers. Besides, the Pacers' play was so brash and skilful - what else could they be but New Yorkers?

fields.headline: Blackouts bring gloom to California
fields.standfirst: Homes, industry, hospitals and traffic hit (but not Hollywood) as power cuts spread chaos
fields.trailText: California has declared a state of emergency, with rolling blackouts spreading from north to south, shutting down parts of Silicon Valley, bringing traffic to a standstill in some towns and prompting pleas that people eat their evening meals by candlelight.
fields.body:
California has declared a state of emergency, with rolling blackouts spreading from north to south, shutting down parts of Silicon Valley, bringing traffic to a standstill in some towns and prompting pleas that people eat their evening meals by candlelight.

Further blackouts were predicted over the weekend as governor Gray Davis introduced desperate measures to stop one of the richest parts of the world descending into chaos.

Hospital emergency rooms had to close in some areas and others had to switch to emergency generators. In Silicon Valley, firms like Apple and Hewlett Packard lost their power and in San Francisco, people were trapped in lifts, businesses closed early and - hardest of all for some Californians to countenance - bars and restaurants ran out of ice. Some businesses operated by candlelight.

Governor Davis, looking weary and shaken, finally declared a state of emergency on Wednesday night as it became clear that the long-predicted blackouts had arrived. The state, which has the richest square footage and is the 10th largest economy in the world, was saved from further darkness and embarrassment by Canada which supplied extra power at the 11th hour.

Around half a million homes and businesses were affected in the first wave of blackouts but Californians were warned to expect more extensive outages over the next few days. Gas suppliers also warned that they might be unable to fulfil all consumer demands.

Christmas lights

Despite appeals for everyone to cut down their use of electricity, the Christmas lights still twinkled cheerfully in Hollywood throughout the night and no one was anticipating that last night's premiere of the Guy Ritchie film, Snatch, taking place in the heart of the film industry would be suddenly halted by the projector cutting out. The entertainment industry, itself heavily dependent on power - both electric and metaphorical - has so far not been affected.

While there was much joking about the fact that one of the most resource-rich areas on the globe should find itself in such a dilemma, the blackouts bring with them serious political and economic ramifications.

Governor Gray Davis has been tipped as a likely Democratic presidential candidate for 2004 and the way he handles the crisis is bound to weigh heavily in the minds of the party's power brokers. So far, his public statements have seemed stilted and he has drawn criticism for not acting soon enough to deal with the inevitable blackouts. Economically, there are fears that, unless the problem is sorted out speedily, businesses may be tempted to other states that offer cheaper property rates and a more secure form of power supply. "There is significant concern among businesses in Silicon Valley," said Michelle Montague-Bruno of the Silicon Valley Manufacturing Group, which represents a coalition of hi-tech firms.

"Some have even told us of plans to move manufacturing out of Silicon Valley, and even out of state, if we do not see some sort of resolution to reliable energy supplies."

In an attempt to head off such action, leading Silicon Valley business figures were invited to the state capital of Sacramento for special briefings aimed at reassuring them that the problem would be solved.

While some power officials made light-hearted requests to the public to consider having candelit dinners, others warned that there was no speedy solution in sight. "We are going hour by hour here," said Patrick Dorinson, a spokesman for the California Independent System Operator, which oversees the state's power supplies.

Governor Davis signed an emergency proclamation which allows the state to spend money from the department of water resources to buy power. He took his action after being told that four out-of-state power plant owners had warned that they would bring bankruptcy proceedings against California's two main utility companies, Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison.

Both utility companies have already defaulted on hundreds of millions of dollars owed to bondholders and other creditors and their credit ratings have been downgraded to junk bond level.

Deranged driver

The governor also instructed the state legislature to appropriate the funds necessary to help pay for the state's electricity for another week to 10 days. The process was complicated when the state senate had to move venues because a deranged truck driver had driven his vehicle at top speed at the Capitol building, incinerating himself in a fireball as a result. Republican state senator Bill Morrow described the new measures as "rearranging the chairs on what could be the Titanic."

Last week, in his state of the state address, the governor asked all Californians to cut their electricity use by 7% and to turn off all unnecessary lights, a request that many in Los Angeles clearly feel does not apply to them. There is resentment in northern California, which has been hit hardest, that southern Californians have ignored requests to economise.

California is no stranger to disaster real or imagined. In his book, Ecology of Fear, Mike Davis, noted that Los Angeles featured in more disaster novels and films than anywhere else on earth. While nuclear attacks (49) and earthquakes (28) were the most commonly featured methods of destruction in books and films in the last century, a mighty blackout that closes down Silicon Valley and Multi-Media Gulch must now offer an unmissable opportunity to an imaginative screenwriter.

webTitle: Why the lights are going out in California

fields.headline: Why the lights are going out
fields.trailText: "We are borrowing $1m an hour to keep the lights on," an official at a Californian utility observed last week. It was hard to tell if he was boasting or desperate.
fields.body:
"We are borrowing $1m an hour to keep the lights on," an official at a Californian utility observed last week. It was hard to tell if he was boasting or desperate.

But now the money is running out and the lights are going out as the power industry drama which has dogged the state for weeks becomes an emergency.

At the heart of the saga of power, politics and a deregulation programme gone badly wrong are two privately owned utility companies, Southern California Edison and Pacific Gas & Electricity, which supply much of the state's power.

When California's energy market was deregulated under legislation that came into effect in 1998, the two companies were forced to sell off most of their generating capacity - much of it to out-of-state groups.

Under the new regime they had to buy in the bulk of their electricity supply and then sell it on to consumers. The snag was that while the price at which the utilities can sell electricity is tightly controlled, the wholesale market through which they purchase electricity has no such capping mechanism.

Arguably, such a system was always an accident waiting to happen. Last month it did. Prices in the wholesale market rocketed to 10 times their level the previous December. The utilities were forced to sell electricity at levels well below what they were having to pay. They did eventually get permission to raise prices but by nothing like the amount they wanted.

The utilities accuse the generators of exploiting a breakdown in the market system. The generators argue that they are part of the solution, not the problem, and that they, too, have bills to pay.

While the arguments raged, the utilities ran up uncovered costs - the gap between what they were paying and receiving - put at more than $12bn. Efforts to find a solution by California's governor, Gray Davis, the Clinton administration's energy team, the utilities, the generators and the regulators have been going on for weeks.

This week, the inevitable happened. On Tuesday SCE said that to conserve cash it would not meet almost $600m of debt and interest payment that had fallen due. The default meant the credit rating agencies slashed the rating on SCE and Pacific Gas & Electricity to junk status. On Wednesday Pacific Gas & Electricity also defaulted on part of its debt. It warned that it had debt payments totalling well over $2bn falling due in the next few weeks but had only $700m in its reserves.

Chal Barnwell at the energy risk management systems company KWI said: "It's lack of infrastructure - there hasn't been any significant plant built in California in 10 years - and an uncertain regulatory structure that has put them where they are."

The week's events have pushed the two companies close to bankruptcy. It has made suppliers concerned about whether they will get paid for electricity they sell to the utilities. Coming on top of power shortages, blackouts were inevitable. The situation has also aroused concerns about the consequences forbanks that have lent heavily to the utility sector.

The governor has authorised $400m to be spent buying electricity. Fortunately for California, the Canadian province of British Columbia has power to spare.

Critics say short-term expedients will not solve the problem. That requires agreement over long-term supply contracts and who will foot the final bill - the generators, the utilities or the California taxpayer. So far no one is volunteering.

America's richest state

 The state's economy is equivalent in size to that of the world's 10th largest country. The average income is $20,500 (£13,700); unemployment stands at 6.3%. The average house is worth $221,000

 California has a Democratic governor and two Democratic senators. In the 2000 presidential election it voted for Al Gore. It has produced two former presidents, both Republican: Ronald Reagan and Richard Nixon

 At the cutting edge of new technology (Silicon Valley), and the heart of the entertainment industry (Hollywood), California was also the starting point of the radical and black power movements of the 60s. The writer Scott Bradfield described California as "America squared"

 The first use of the name California was by the Spanish explorer Juan Cabrillo in 1542. By 1850 it had become the 31st US state

webTitle: 'Astonishing' decision casts cloud over libel jury trials

fields.headline: 'Astonishing' decision casts cloud over libel jury trials
fields.standfirst: Lawyers stunned by unprecedented judgment that libel verdict was 'affront to justice'
fields.trailText: The court of appeal's unprecedented ruling yesterday overturning as "perverse" the verdict of the libel jury that cleared Bruce Grobbelaar of taking bribes to fix matches has stunned lawyers, who say it could be another nail in the coffin for the jury in libel trials.
fields.body:
The court of appeal's unprecedented ruling yesterday overturning as "perverse" the verdict of the libel jury that cleared Bruce Grobbelaar of taking bribes to fix matches has stunned lawyers, who say it could be another nail in the coffin for the jury in libel trials.

"Miscarriage of justice" is a term uttered sparingly enough by judges in criminal cases. To hear Lord Justice Jonathan Parker say in the context of a libel case that "the jury's verdict in this case represents a miscarriage of justice which this court can and must correct" is amazing - particularly when the victim of the miscarriage of justice was a tabloid newspaper.

The veteran libel lawyer Peter Carter-Ruck, now in his 80s, said: "I t's astonishing. In my experience, which goes back 60 years, I've never known a case before where this has happened."

Nor had Grobbelaar's counsel or the QC who appeared for his opponent, the Sun.

The three-judge court that upset the jury's verdict included two of the country's most senior appeal court judges, Lord Justice Simon Brown and Lord Justice Thorpe. A less experienced bench of judges might well have taken what the former acknowledged would have been the easy and predictable way out, refusing to interfere with the judgment of a jury who had heard all the evidence and could weigh up the witnesses.

Richard Rampton QC, a libel lawyer for 35 years, said: "I think it's an extraordinarily bold decision."

The trouble was that the jury had got it badly wrong. They had been befuddled by the smooth advocacy of Richard Hartley QC and the evidence of an expert witness who argued convincingly that the videos showed Grobbelaar doing his best to stop goals. Lord Justice Simon Brown noted that the verdict was "a forensic triumph for Mr Hartley", all the more so because the QC was battling not only against the recorded words of Grobbelaar damning himself out of his own mouth, but the fearsome cross-examiner George Carman QC, who died earlier this month, too soon to see his side vindicated.

The judges cited the libel lawyer's bible, Gatley on Libel and Slander, which says: "The jury are the constitutional tribunal for the decision of libel or no libel, and only in an extreme case will their verdict be set aside as unreasonable."

Until now, no case had been extreme enough - at least, not within living memory. But the Grobbelaar decision was, said Lord Justice Simon Brown, "an affront to justice".

The Sun had tapes of Grobbelaar admitting taking bribes. The paper's defence to the libel action was justification: that the allegations were true. To succeed, Grobbelaar would have to produce convincing explanations for his behaviour. But his story was "simply incredible. All logic, commonsense and reason compel one to that conclusion", the appeal court concluded.

Juries are inscrutable and, unlike judges, don't have to give reasons for their decisions. They can be surprisingly gullible. The media solicitor Mark Stephens said: "One of the wider implications of this case is that the court of appeal have now taken to themselves additional powers which would enable them to overturn the jury's verdict much more easily." Extensive research from New Zealand on juries in criminal cases found that jurors often feel at sea and fail to grasp key points of law and evidence.

The appeal court judges surmised that Grobbelaar's defence, particularly the evidence from his expert witness that videos of the matches showed him to be doing his best, deflected the jury from the crux of the allegations- not that he threw the matches, but that he was corrupt and took bribes.

Juries have all but disappeared from the civil courts, where defamation cases - libel and slander - are among the few types of action that still retain them. They hold sway there because ordinary people are thought to be the best judges of whether someone's reputation has been besmirched in the eyes of onlookers by whatever was said or written about them.

But judges may dispense with a jury and hear the case themselves if the trial is likely to be long and the evidence complex. In recent years judges have become more ready to do without juries, as they did in the "McLibel" case brought by McDonald's against two environmental activists and in the Irving v Penguin Books Holocaust denial case.

Jonathan Aitken's case against the Guardian, which collapsed after the former Tory minister committed perjury, had gone ahead without a jury, although the evidence did not seem particularly complex.

Trials without juries are shorter and there are strong pressures in the civil courts to save time and costs. The Grobbelaar case is likely to make judges think twice about whether the jury is up to the task if the evidence in a case is at all complex. Juries are no longer the powers they were in libel cases. Changes in the law and the growing role of judges in case management mean fewer libel cases go to trial.

Juries have had their freedom to award huge damages curbed. Judges can now suggest brackets to them, and since 1991 the court of appeal has had power to slash jury awards.

The threat of a libel action once provided easy pickings for rich claimants, whether the allegations against them were true or false. But the climate is changing. Mr Stephens said: "Following the Guardian's victories against Neil Hamilton, Aitken and police officers, there has been a chilling effect on greedy libel claimants coming out and looking for money from deep media pockets."

Even juries must be growing less susceptible to the plausible claimant and the silver-tongued QC. Where they reach a verdict which defies all logic, the judges have now shown that they will step in.

As Lord Justice Simon Brown acknowledged: "It is, I think, the experience of all of us that juries from time to time do arrive at perverse verdicts." The judges have now recognised that to let them stand would bring the courts into disrepute.

fields.headline: No: 1804
fields.standfirst: Liam Gallagher
fields.trailText: Liam Gallagher
fields.body:
Age:
28.

Appearance:
Hello darlin'. Are you single?

That's none of your business...
You've got a lovely behind.

I'll thank you to keep your hands to yourself sir.
Fancy joining the mile- high club with me?

That's it, I'm calling my lawyers.
Sorry, I just got a bit too in character. Where were we? Ah yes, appearance. Well think Planet of the Apes on a bad-hair day.

And what's the wild man of rock been up to now?
His charming manner has got him in trouble again.

Don't tell me he's cheated on new love Nicole Appleton already?
Not exactly. fields.headline: Mr Blair ducks out
fields.standfirst:
This decision has little to do with principle
Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText: This decision has little to do with principle
fields.body:
Tony Blair's rejection of the BBC/ITV proposal for televised three-way debates between party leaders during the coming election campaign is the kind of event which gives politics a bad name. That is not because the need for TV encounters is irrefutable or universally agreed. Our columnist Isabel Hilton made a spirited case against them on Wednesday. She feared they would dumb down elections. Good politics and good television, she argued, were not the same thing. TV debates were all about image, not issues. Unlike the United States, where the choice before voters was Gore or Bush, Britain was picking a parliament, not a president - so the parallels usually quoted did not apply. Labour's defence of Mr Blair's refusal echoes that. The debates would detract, it was said, from Labour's policy message, from the issues which really matter to people. Legal difficulties might arise if the nationalist parties were not included. And Britain, the prime minister's spokesman Lance Price irrefutably added, was not the US.

But it wasn't the US on November 16 either - the day when the PM's chief press spokesman, Alastair Campbell, spoke of TV debates as " a perfectly good thing in principle". Neither was it the US on January 7, when Mr Blair told Sir David Frost that he was "committed in principle". Nor is the potential distraction factor any greater today than it was then. These objections to the principle of TV debates come much too late in the day to carry conviction. The most likely explanation is this: that Mr Blair has been hauled back by advisers who reminded him of the old political rule -never give your opponents a platform. The Conservatives took the same line when they were on top. Politicians may talk about principle, but in the end it always comes down to what suits their own political convenience.

Elections should be run for the people, not for the politicians. And one part of that ought to be the voters' right to see those who aspire to lead them taking each other on. They may not be running for president, but in practice once in office they act more and more presidentially. The principle of primus inter pares no longer applies as it did. In a leaked memo last July, Mr Blair insisted not just that there needed to be initiatives on crime, defence and asylum but that he must be "personally associated" with them. There is always the risk that debates might descend into the sort of raucuous vacuity which characterises prime minister's questions. There is little hope that they'd prove as enlightening as those radio debates where the politicians take on the voters direct, like the one in 1983 when Mrs Diana Gould put Margaret Thatcher on the spot over the sinking of the Belgrano. Yet the fact that TV debates may fail to match that is no justification for saying they should not happen. If you ruled out every election device which politicians might try to misuse, there might not be very much left.

As things stand, we can confidently expect that the same charade will take place in the general election of 2005, or whenever. Again, a great wall of irrevelancies will be erected against TV debates by those who fear they might lose from them, with all sorts of bogus technical issues raised about the formats. By then, though, Mr Straw's new electoral commission will be in business, and ideally equipped to frame a neutral and fair set of rules for such occasions. It may never be possible to force recalcitrant politicians to accept obligations which they fear might disadvantage them. But the chance of shaming those who duck out have never been better.

fields.headline: Virtual lovers win Japanese hearts
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Bandai, the Japanese firm that gave the world the Tamagotchi electronic pet, has come up with a different breed of cyber-chick: the virtual girlfriend.
fields.body:
Bandai, the Japanese firm that gave the world the Tamagotchi electronic pet, has come up with a different breed of cyber-chick: the virtual girlfriend.

Chatty, coquettish and guaranteed to return your messages, the new brand of computer-generated lover has won the hearts of more than 30,000 men, who have signed up to the Love by Email service.

Using internet-capable mobile phones, the men pay 300 yen (about £1.70) each month for a relationship with one of seven "fantasy" women, who include a teacher, a barmaid and a nightclubbing student.

Each day, the men exchange up to three emails with their partner in an attempt to chat her up. The women's responses - determined by computer program - alter according to the time of day, the season and the kind of questions asked.

Declarations of love after just a few emails are dismissed with contempt, while any discussion of sport gets short shrift. But ask the right question at the right time and the girlfriend melts into intimacy.

"I'm sorry, I didn't get back to you sooner, but I was in the bath. You should see my tub. It's enormous and there's a big window in front of it. Message me soon," writes cabin attendant Katsuko Shinjo.

There is never any hanky-panky. Progress is measured on a chart that shows how many of the woman's 52 secrets the man has been able to uncover and what percentage of her heart he has won.

At the end of the relationship, which can last from one to three months, a successful lover will be given an everlasting commitment of love. An insufficiently attentive suitor is dismissed as a creep.

Bandai says Love by Email is one of its most popular mobile internet games with a strong following among men in their 30s. Some customers have become so enamoured, that they have called the company asking for their electronic lover's phone number.

"Men don't get as many emails as women so they appreciate this service, which ensures that there is always an interesting message in their in-box, even if it is from a virtual companion," said Toru Itabashi of Bandai Networks.

He said a version launched last month for women -My Prince Charming - fared less well, attracting only 1,000 subscribers in its first three days.

Such businesses are an offshoot of the explosive growth of the mobile internet in Japan. Thanks largely to the popularity of NTT DoCoMo's i-mode service, about 30m people have an internet-compatible cellular phone.

Such phones enable users to buy airline tickets andbuy shares online, but most consumers use them for games, fortune-telling and exchanging emails with friends - both real and virtual.

fields.headline: Cruelty to animals (and scientists)
fields.trailText: Your leader (January 17) criticises animal rights protesters for their unjustified intimidation of Huntingdon Life Sciences (HLS). The protesters are not, however, solely to blame.
fields.body:
Your leader (January 17) criticises animal rights protesters for their unjustified intimidation of Huntingdon Life Sciences (HLS). The protesters are not, however, solely to blame. This unpleasant campaign has been going on largely unchecked for years. To date any condemnation of their tactics has been feeble and they could be forgiven for believing they had some level of tacit support from those in government.

Interestingly, the tactics of the protesters differ little from some of the more extreme attacks on hunt supporters and others even loosely connected with animals and the countryside. The firebombing in Surrey and the nail and letter bomb outrages in recent weeks are evidence of that. The pro-hunt lobby will therefore be pleased that many of your leader's comments in support of HLS could be applied to their case.

The prime minister's lack of firm leadership against extremism in both these emotive issues, in favour of giving oxygen to the unacceptable tactics of special interest groups, is highly regrettable. Such unprincipled appeasement may win the next election but it will return to haunt both government and country thereafter. David Lowes
Stamford, Lincs

 What a pity the feature (To the slaughter, G2 January 17) detailing the suffering of various species pre-death did not include laboratory animals particularly, perhaps, primates. This might in part have countered the untruths contained in your leader and Polly Toynbee's OTT defence of HLS (Running scared, January 17).

Every movement or cause attracts extremists, and to send letter bombs is clearly indefensible, but Polly Toynbee should not classify all animal rights campaigners as "animal madmen". The groundswell of concern regarding HLS is made up of thousands of ordinary people who, like myself, regard the sacrifice of the lives of 500 intelligent, sentient beings every day with great dismay. That many of these creatures end their lives in abject misery is revealed by papers leaked by undercover investigators.

Ms Toynbee asks if people would choose to be human guinea pigs? Well, that's exactly what they are whenever they accept a new drug treatment. The passing as safe of drugs after animal tests has led to many tragedies over the years. My information is that, far from saving lives, the main areas of research at HLS are on pesticides, herbicides, food colourings and so on. If Greg Avery and his colleagues make us question our right to treat other species as "tools" and cast a spotlight on the relevance or otherwise of such use, more power to their collective elbow!
Cynthia Clubacz
Leek, Staffs

 How depressing that once again the saga of HLS is being drawn along the lines of the biotechnology industry versus animal rights protesters (Blair "on side of science" over animal research, January 17) or in the overly simplistic terms of animal testing being a necessary evil. Neither is an accurate portrayal. There is no "government legislation that requires a new medicine to be tested on rodents and a non-rodent species". The law only requires companies to use "the best available methods" to ensure the safety of new drugs. Evidence increasingly shows that experimenting on animals does not lead to cures for human diseases, rather they produce inaccurate, misleading, inconclusive or inapplicable results.

Britain has a massive opportunity to lead the world in developing drugs and research techniques which do not rely on animals. The market for such products would be vast. Thus, HLS's fate should be analysed in the context of the overall future of animal testing.
Stephen Brend
International Primate Protection League, London
ukrep@ippl-uk.org

 I completely agree with Polly Toynbee. In 1938 I contracted polio; if only the vaccine had been available then. Have the members of animal rights groups refused all vaccines for themselves and their children? If taken ill would they refuse any treatment that had ever been tested on animals?

In the 30s people were frightened to stand up to the emerging fascists and we know the result. Let the names and details of all the animal rights cowards be published. If they are so convinced of their arguments then they should make them openly.
Peter D Rowe
Stockport

 What a welcome change to read an article by a Guardian journalist which vigorously trumpets the merits of animal research and also applauds the efforts of David Sainsbury (never a favourite of journalists) in combating the madness associated with the attacks on HLS, its staff and all who support its work.

Many scientists are appalled at the ease with which some commentators have been prepared to take on undigested the slogans and prejudices of those who can only be termed the "primitive pseudo-greens". Is it really socially responsible and ethical to stop the development of new cancer treatments and to prevent poor farmers in the developing world from obtaining crops which are disease resistant?
Prof Willie Russell
Chair of Scientists for Labour Harrow, Middlesex

fields.headline: Waugh of words
fields.trailText: Auberon Waugh (Obituary, January 18) was a racist bigot and escaped being punished for such behaviour because of his influence in high places.
fields.body:
Auberon Waugh (Obituary, January 18) was a racist bigot and escaped being punished for such behaviour because of his influence in high places.

About nine years ago I was asked my opinion, as an ethnic minority member of the Kent education authority, of a Ted Hughes story about a brown and a white polar bear, which was used in the 11-plus test in Kent. Many headteachers, educationalists and I thought it inappropriate. There was some publicity in the national media and without grasping the facts, Waugh, in the name of Peter Simple, wrote a nasty, vicious personal attack on me which was published in the Sunday Telegraph.

I received a copy of the article, together with a death threat from an anonymous bigot. In my 16 years in public life, this is the only time such a distasteful racist incident has occurred.
Dai Liyanage
Gillingham, Medway

 Charles Moore relates that Waugh reckoned that he was the only person in the whole of Britain, apart from the IRA, who wished that Mrs Thatcher had been killed in the Brighton bombing. I think Mr Moore is on dodgy ground in trying to use that as evidence of Waugh's eccentric, out-of-touch opinions.
Paul Hardy
Croydon, Surrey

 The sight of the wallpaper peeping out from behind Waugh's bookshelves reminds me of Oscar Wilde's reputed last words: "One of us has got to go".
Alastair Gilmour
Newcastle upon Tyne

webTitle: Letters: Crouching Tiger, not very well hidden prejudices

fields.headline: Crouching Tiger, not very well hidden prejudices
fields.trailText: Charlotte Raven (Crashing bore, G2, January 16) writes of Ang Lee's movie, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: "Because they were oriental, everyone presumed this was understatement, rather than woodenness." Only in Britain are pundits commenting on oriental "inscrutability". American critics have preferred to engage with the story on an emotional and cinematic level.
fields.body:
Charlotte Raven (Crashing bore, G2, January 16) writes of Ang Lee's movie, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: "Because they were oriental, everyone presumed this was understatement, rather than woodenness." Only in Britain are pundits commenting on oriental "inscrutability". American critics have preferred to engage with the story on an emotional and cinematic level.

"In Chinese, delivered inscrutably, it seemed to contain multitudes." Well, to this "inscrutable" oriental (thanks for the 19th-century stereotyping, by the way) it did just that. This story, set in a country and an age in which the gender war was a life and death struggle, touched on the King Lear premise: great man gives up his power and women learn what they are up against when they try to use it.

Michelle Yeoh's beautifully subtle performance exuded warmth, power, maturity and intelligence, expressed primarily through her "immobile" face. No prizes for guessing why Raven missed that. Hint: it's in the eyes. Anna Chen
London

 "The day they make a film located in suburbia that shows happy people living honestly," writes Charlotte Raven, "that's when I'll commend a director's originality." How about a seasonal romantic comedy - The Family Man - in which pampered, egotistical Manhattan banker Nicolas Cage learns to love a cash-strapped parallel existence in which he is married with two children, drives a battered van and makes an honest living selling car parts? This paean to suburban family life was released at UK cinemas four weeks ago.
Charles Gant
Film editor, Heat magazine
charles.gant@ecm.emap.com

 Charlotte Raven is absolutely right about Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. It really irritates me to see critics run out of superlatives for a foreign language film of no greater merit than a Jackie Chan B-movie. There was a tangible air of disappointment in the (full) cinema where I saw it. The recent pasting of Cast Away, on the other hand, is typical of critical hostility towards a movie, simply because it was in English, came from a Hollywood studio, and had a star lead. The Guardian, I note, gave these films five stars and one star respectively.
Rupert Cousens
Oxford

 "No other art form is so sketchily remembered," writes Derek Malcolm (It's a wrap, G2, January 18). Really? How about television? One need only turn a few pages to John Patterson's piece about the film Traffic. Anyone who had seen the 1989 Channel 4 serial Traffik, on which it is based, would know that the "heavily determined" visual style that Patterson is so impressed by is a straight imitation of the original. Traffik was directed by Alastair Reid and written by Simon Moore: I don't suppose you've ever run double-page spreads about their TV work, have you?
John Davies
Cardiff

"In Chinese, delivered inscrutably, it seemed to contain multitudes." Well, to this "inscrutable" oriental (thanks for the 19th-century stereotyping, by the way) it did just that. This story, set in a country and an age in which the gender war was a life and death struggle, touched on the King Lear premise: great man gives up his power and women learn what they are up against when they try to use it. Michelle Yeoh's beautifully subtle performance exuded warmth, power, maturity and intelligence, expressed primarily through her "immobile" face. No prizes for guessing why Raven missed that. Hint: it's in the eyes. Anna Chen London  "The day they make a film located in suburbia that shows happy people living honestly," writes Charlotte Raven, "that's when I'll commend a director's originality." How about a seasonal romantic comedy - The Family Man - in which pampered, egotistical Manhattan banker Nicolas Cage learns to love a cash-strapped parallel existence in which he is married with two children, drives a battered van and makes an honest living selling car parts? This paean to suburban family life was released at UK cinemas four weeks ago. Charles Gant Film editor, Heat magazine charles.gant@ecm.emap.com  Charlotte Raven is absolutely right about Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. It really irritates me to see critics run out of superlatives for a foreign language film of no greater merit than a Jackie Chan B-movie. There was a tangible air of disappointment in the (full) cinema where I saw it. The recent pasting of Cast Away, on the other hand, is typical of critical hostility towards a movie, simply because it was in English, came from a Hollywood studio, and had a star lead. The Guardian, I note, gave these films five stars and one star respectively. Rupert Cousens Oxford  "No other art form is so sketchily remembered," writes Derek Malcolm (It's a wrap, G2, January 18). Really? How about television? One need only turn a few pages to John Patterson's piece about the film Traffic. Anyone who had seen the 1989 Channel 4 serial Traffik, on which it is based, would know that the "heavily determined" visual style that Patterson is so impressed by is a straight imitation of the original. Traffik was directed by Alastair Reid and written by Simon Moore: I don't suppose you've ever run double-page spreads about their TV work, have you? John Davies Cardiff

webTitle: Letter: The seller's pack for home buyers

fields.headline: Seller's home brew
fields.trailText: John Sutherland's article (To live and buy in LA, G2, January 15), misrepresents and misunderstands the measures to help home buyers and sellers in the homes bill. The seller's pack has huge advantages for both buyers and sellers, writes Nick Raynsford MP.
fields.body:
John Sutherland's article (To live and buy in LA, G2, January 15), misrepresents and misunderstands the measures to help home buyers and sellers in the homes bill. The seller's pack has huge advantages for both buyers and sellers. It will bring together, at the very start of the process, important information which at present is collected in dribs and drabs after terms have been agreed, the very problem that concerns John Sutherland. This will greatly reduce the risk of renegotiation, failed transactions and abortive costs.

The seller's pack will not cost an extra £700. The only additional cost is the home condition report, in those cases where currently there is no survey. All the other items in the seller's pack would have to be provided at some stage in the transaction anyway. And as the vast majority of sellers are also buyers, they will enjoy corresponding savings when buying another home. Our policy has not been devised on the back of an allegedly "dodgy" pilot scheme in Bristol. The Bristol pilot study was carried out by independent researchers, and clearly demonstrated the practicality and value of the pack.

The Scottish system favoured by John Sutherland would not work well in the more active housing markets in England and Wales. The upfront costs would result in more wasted expense for unsuccessful buyers. It would also lead to greater dependence on bridging loans and temporary accommodation. This is not what buyers and sellers in England and Wales want.
Nick Raynsford MP
Minister for housing and planning

fields.headline: California in the dark
fields.standfirst: This is what came of deregulation
fields.trailText: This is what came of deregulation
fields.body:
California has long been the place where the future begins, not just for the rest of the US but the Anglo-Saxon west at large. This was the birthplace of the famed "tax revolt" (with Howard Jarvis and proposition 13 in 1978) that helped propel Margaret Thatcher and later Ronald Reagan to office. Now California may be pointing in the opposite direction.

Its history was, of course, never a tale of pure free enterprise. Development in the semi-arid south of the state depended on big government spending on dams and water pipes, of which Polanski's movie Chinatown offers a decent account. The state's economy was boosted by defence money (Oakland, Long Beach and the Los Angeles hinterland) and public support of education (spin-off from the University of California is huge) and agriculture (in the central valley).

But California is also where property taxes provoked the famed revolt and though the state's congressional delegation remained relatively liberal, the state did not escape the advance of the right in the 80s, for example in the passage of English-only laws for schools and public business. This time, the problem is Republican law passed in Sacramento in 1996 to deregulate the energy market and implemented in 1998. The aim was competition and consumer choice. The result has been sporadic darkness.

Power used to be supplied by municipalities or the likes of Pacific Gas and Electricity, private sector local monopolies subject to tight and transparent regulation. Production and distribution have now been sundered - shades of Thatcher - and the sums do not add up, partly because of lack of investment and of any overarching American policy for energy use, not least one that promoted conservation. The resulting brown-outs are far more serious than the seasonal shortages which have always beset electricity supplies in the far west. The free market turns out to be serving voracious Silicon Valley badly and the state's economic well-being is under threat.

Democrat governor Gray Davis is making even more political capital from events now that his party are out of it in Washington. And there are lessons for all of us living amid the debris of privatisation. What follows the failure of markets is the new century's impending question. Public ownership of some kind increasingly looks like part of it - or, what looks possible in California, a return to the good old days of regulated monopoly.

fields.headline: Grobbelaar nil
fields.standfirst: It was right to overturn this libel verdict
fields.trailText: It was right to overturn this libel verdict
fields.body:
Any newspaper editor who has the misfortune to spend any time in the royal courts of justice soon wearily comes to accept what he or she had often been told by older and wiser hands: libel is a lottery. The stakes are huge, the ground rules perverse. In the end reputations and millions of pounds hang on the say-so of a jury.

Yesterday's decision by three court of appeal judges to reject a jury verdict in the libel action brought by Bruce Grobbelaar, the former Liverpool goalkeeper, against the Sun, will subtly change all that. In future the losing side - claimant or defendant - will be able to argue that the jury simply got it wrong.

It is an extraordinary judgment. But the judges went out of their way to emphasise the extraordinary nature of the case. There is unlikely to be a torrent of appeals in which judges will follow the precedent set by Lord Justice Brown and his colleagues. But any extra weapon in the limited armoury of a newspaper de fending a libel action is to be welcomed. The tenacity of the Sun in defending its story is commendable.

Of equal significance is the judges' refusal to allow the newspaper any protection under the so-called Reynolds Rules. These were guidelines formulated just over a year ago by Lord Nicholls for stories which might merit qualified privilege. The appeal court judges, perhaps using these guidelines a touch over-literally, decided that the Sun's story deserved no special protection, though it dealt with an important subject in the public interest. The way in which the Nicholls rules were interpreted should act as a warning to all investigative reporters and editors.

A pattern is now emerging of claimants dishonestly using the libel laws to line their pockets. Judges can overturn jury verdicts in criminal cases where they think there has been a miscarriage of justice. It is good that it has been extended to wrongful libel verdicts.

webTitle: Sketch: Another odd job for the government's Teflon Tel

fields.headline: Another odd job for the government's Teflon Tel
fields.trailText: I popped into the culture select committee yesterday to see the new mandarin class in action. Sir Humphrey would have been to one of the cleverer public schools (Winchester or Westminster, perhaps, though not Eton or Harrow) and most likely to Oxford, an institute where majestic obfuscation has been highly regarded for centuries.
fields.body:
I popped into the culture select committee yesterday to see the new mandarin class in action. Sir Humphrey would have been to one of the cleverer public schools (Winchester or Westminster, perhaps, though not Eton or Harrow) and most likely to Oxford, an institute where majestic obfuscation has been highly regarded for centuries.

Lord (Terry) Burns, by contrast, went to a grammar school in Houghton-le-Spring and to Manchester University. He has a haircut that looks like a wig, except that nobody would buy a wig like that, a piping voice and a slight northern accent, so that apart from his glittering glasses, one is slightly reminded of Jimmy Tarbuck.

His nickname is Teflon Terry, because of the way he escaped blame for the various economic disasters while he was permanent secretary to the Treasury.

He is - and this tells you everything about the changes at the top of British society - a Queens Park Rangers fan, and possesses his own anorak.

He didn't last long at the Treasury under Gordon Brown, but since then he has become the new establishment's chief odd-job man. Whenever there is a problem of, say, shelving - when an issue needs to be shelved, such as fox hunting or the national lottery - then Lord Burns is called for. He prepares a report on hunting with dogs (which included the memorable line in which he pointed out that being torn to pieces by ravening hounds "seriously compromises the welfare of the fox"), and, voila! , the issue was delayed until it was probably too late to get a bill through.

The lottery commission bizarrely decides not to renew the Camelot franchise; the commission chair is fired, Lord Burns is appointed in her place, and hey presto! Camelot is back. "There you are, mate, sorted!" as Lord Burns might put it.

Yesterday he didn't want to say much, and he succeeded triumphantly. In this way the new mandarins precisely resemble the old. "It is not inevitable that there will be legislation, but it would be a mistake to say that there cannot be legislation," was one of his snappier responses.

Was he too keen to avoid risks? he was asked. "Life is about taking risks, the managment of risk, trading between risk and certainty, the costs of getting it wrong bersues the cost of getting it right _" On and on he went. Teflon Tel might sound like a modern northern lad, but his ability to say nothing at all at tremendous length would have brought a tear to Sir Humphrey's eye.

Later I went along to hear Ann Widdecombe speak about the police force. Some 16 months ago, she made an impressive speech on crime and punishment at the Tory party conference. In this she failed to mention hanging, thought that some criminals should be let out early, and honestly admitted that she had not yet worked out a policy on policing rural areas. Yesterday we got it.

Her problem is that her party insists on having oodles more police, but on keeping taxes down. The answer? "Police should spend time doing necessary paperwork in local villages, instead of whizzing through and going back to the station."

So that's it! Clearly this masterplan is an extension of her "cops in shops" wheeze, which would have policemen sitting in Woolworth's on the off chance that someone would like to report a crime. Except that they'll be in rural settings. Cops in tea-shops! The Old Bill in barns! Pigs in pigsheds! Bobbies on bar-stools, the Filth in tilth! Something for nothing!

Miss Widdecombe would have been a dazzling war-time improviser, sewing clothing made out of egg-boxes and making nutritious stews from acorns and mud.

Police ready for all comers on Bush's big day, page 18, International, January 13, we mistakenly gave the impression that Van Morrison was scheduled to perform at a concert at the White House for George W Bush. Mr Van Morrison's office has asked us to say that reports to that effect were absolutely false. He was never scheduled to appear at this event and had no intention of doing so.

In a report headed Quick fixes give fillip to East End experiment, page 11, we referred to the leader of Newham Council as Sir Robin Wells. He is in fact Sir Robin Wales. Apologies.

In a column, page 7, Sport, January 15, recalling the prowess of the Australian cricketer, Jack Iverson, we referred to the Third Test match at Sydney in 1951. However, it was not Lindsay Hassett who scored an undefeated 145 on that occasion, but Keith Miller.

The city near Tolstoy's estate, Yasnaya Polyana, page 16, January 16, is Tula, not Tulna.

webTitle: Polio returns to threaten world plan for eradication

fields.headline: Polio returns to threaten world plan for eradication
fields.trailText: A small group of sick children in the Dominican Republic and Haiti could pose a threat to one of the World Health Organisation's most cherished plans - the eradication of the crippling and often lethal disease poliomyelitis, or polio.
fields.body:
A small group of sick children in the Dominican Republic and Haiti could pose a threat to one of the World Health Organisation's most cherished plans - the eradication of the crippling and often lethal disease poliomyelitis, or polio.

Since October, there have been 45 cases of paralysis on the Caribbean island of Hispaniola, six years after the Pan American Health Organisation declared polio eradicated in the Americas.

Laboratory analysis of the infections, according to the science journal Nature yesterday, produced an alarming find: The polio cases could have developed not from the virus that doctors tried to eradicate, but from a mutated form of their vaccine.

In 1979 the WHO, charities, scientists and national health groups combined to wipe out one of humanity's most terrifying scourges: smallpox. In 1988 the WHO launched a similar assault on another virus that replicates only in humans: polio.

The aim was to vaccinate every child on the planet by 2000 and declare the virus extinct by about 2005, a few years after the last recorded case.

The timetable, however, slipped - interrupted by civil and national wars, natural disaster and political upheaval. But the cases of polio were reduced to around 2,000 last year from 350,000 in 1988.

Teams of experts and volunteers "swamped" whole regions of Asia, Africa, the Pacific and South America in an effort to immunise all children on the same day with an oral vaccine developed by Albert Sabin more than 40 years ago.

The vaccine was a "weakened" form of the virus, which multiplies and triggers resistance against itself, before spreading into the local water supply; polio is a waterborne disease. The theory was, in places with poor hygiene, any children who missed immunisation would "catch" the weakened virus rather than the dangerous one, and be immunised as a result.

But according to Nature, seven new cases of polio have been confirmed on the island of Hispaniola: six in the Dominican Republic, and one across the border in Haiti.

Their discovery led the US Centres for Disease Control (CDC) in Atlanta, Georgia, to conclude that they were caused by a mutation in the vaccine. That is, the weakened version had not only regained its virulence, it had recovered the ability to spread from person to person.

The next step for WHO chiefs is to work out how it happened. There have been very few such cases in four decades of oral vaccination.

Only one child in five in the Constanza region of the Dominican Republic received any of the three doses needed for immunisation; there was a large, vulnerable population.

"My assumption is that this is an unusual event," Donald Henderson of Johns Hopkins University, the architect of the smallpox eradication programme, told Nature. "It can't be occurring with great frequency otherwise we would have seen it a long time ago."

But the implication is that polio may be more difficult to eliminate than anyone had thought. "Clearly," Roland Sutter of the CDC said, "this is raising a red flag."

webTitle: Business: fruit company loses on e-commerce

fields.headline: E-plans go pear shaped for Fyffes
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Fruit producer Fyffes has become the latest company to slip on the e-commerce banana skin.
fields.body:
Fruit producer Fyffes has become the latest company to slip on the e-commerce banana skin.

Worldoffruit.com, which offered "24-hour secure online trading and the latest industry news and views" on the global fresh fruit and vegetable market, is scaling back operations a year after launching.

Trading apples and pears online or bidding for boxes of bananas in internet auctions has not caught on in the way the company had hoped.

Offices in the UK, France, Holland, Spain and Italy will be closed and plans to open outposts in South Africa, South America and Asia have been abandoned.

Worldoffruit.com, which once employed 40 people, will be maintained by a staff of 10 from a small office in Dublin. Last year Fyffes spent €15m (£9.6m) on the project which claimed to have 500 registered users in 35 countries.

"Expenditure going forward will be significantly below that envisaged in the company's original business plan and staff numbers have been reduced accordingly," Fyffes said in a statement.

"It is expected that Worldoffruit.com will continue to operate, but on a significantly reduced scale, and costs in 2001 are not expected to be material in a group context."

The cost cutting exercise underlines the difficulties business to business internet exchanges are encountering.

Worldoffruit aimed to make the trade of fruit more efficient and competitive through a centralised marketplace. It estimated that 20% of the world's fruit would be bought and sold over the internet by 2004.

However, it failed to deliver on the promise still posted on its website last night: "Reality has now replaced a lot of hype in e-commerce, and we believe that Worldoffruit.com will survive and prosper as a result of the dedicated and streamlined service we provide."

Offices in the UK, France, Holland, Spain and Italy will be closed and plans to open outposts in South Africa, South America and Asia have been abandoned. Worldoffruit.com, which once employed 40 people, will be maintained by a staff of 10 from a small office in Dublin. Last year Fyffes spent €15m (£9.6m) on the project which claimed to have 500 registered users in 35 countries. "Expenditure going forward will be significantly below that envisaged in the company's original business plan and staff numbers have been reduced accordingly," Fyffes said in a statement. "It is expected that Worldoffruit.com will continue to operate, but on a significantly reduced scale, and costs in 2001 are not expected to be material in a group context." The cost cutting exercise underlines the difficulties business to business internet exchanges are encountering. Worldoffruit aimed to make the trade of fruit more efficient and competitive through a centralised marketplace. It estimated that 20% of the world's fruit would be bought and sold over the internet by 2004. However, it failed to deliver on the promise still posted on its website last night: "Reality has now replaced a lot of hype in e-commerce, and we believe that Worldoffruit.com will survive and prosper as a result of the dedicated and streamlined service we provide."

webTitle: Murder appeal for woman to hang in Botswana

fields.headline: Murder mystery appeal for woman facing Botswana hangman
fields.trailText: British and African judges yesterday began hearing an appeal by a white South African woman sentenced to hang in Botswana for murdering her best friend in order to marry the victim's husband.
fields.body:
British and African judges yesterday began hearing an appeal by a white South African woman sentenced to hang in Botswana for murdering her best friend in order to marry the victim's husband.

Marietta Bosch's lawyers argue that the Botswana appeal court judges - who come from England, Scotland, Zimbabwe, Ghana, Nigeria and South Africa - should overturn the conviction because the state wrongly gave immunity from prosecution to a leading suspect in the killing in return for him agreeing to testify against Bosch.

But the prosecution, which characterised the case as embracing the "four Ls of murder - love, loot, lust and loathing", says the evidence against Bosch is overwhelming.

If she is executed, she will be the first woman hanged in Botswana in three decades.

Bosch was sentenced to death a year ago after being convicted of murdering Maria Wolmarans in June 1996. The prosecution alleges that Bosch began an affair with Wolmarans' husband, Tienie, after the death of her own spouse.

When Mr Wolmarans failed to deliver on a promise to divorce his wife, Bosch borrowed a gun from a friend in South Africa and shot her victim.

The police investigation made no progress for several months until Bosch made two mistakes. She ordered a wedding dress after Mr Wolmarans secretly agreed to marry her, and she gave the murder weapon to her brother-in-law whose wife was said in court to loathe Bosch.

When the woman found out about the gun and the dress she drew her own conclusion and took the weapon to the police.

At her trial, Bosch said that she had brought the gun into the country on behalf of Hennie Coetzee, the general manager of a firm where Maria Wolmarans was financial manager.

The defence claimed that Mr Coetzee shot Wolmarans on the eve of a company audit because she was about to disclose financial irregularities for which he was responsible.

After Bosch's arrest, Mr Coetzee moved to Ghana. He returned to Botswana only after he was granted immunity from prosecution in return for testifying against her. But the defence was not told about the agreement before the trial.

Yesterday, Bosch's British barrister, Desmond de Silva QC, who has won a reprieve from the hangman for more than 35 people around the globe, said that the prosecution's failure to disclose the deal was detrimental to a fair trial.

"The defence should have been served with a copy of the immunity. The witness had demanded and got an immunity which did not even specify he had to tell the truth as far as I can see. It is astonishing," he said.

The hearing is expected to last up to three days.
