webTitle: Investors fret as Photo-Me profits fizzle

fields.headline: Investors fret as Photo-Me profits fizzle
fields.standfirst:
Blunders leave shareholders feeling vulnerable

More net news
fields.trailText: Investors in Britain's leading photo-booth operator, Photo-Me International, looked a little startled yesterday after another piece of bad news from the troubled company which warned of a £3m profits' shortfall and an unexpected £24m write-off.
fields.body:
Investors in Britain's leading photo-booth operator, Photo-Me International, looked a little startled yesterday after another piece of bad news from the troubled company which warned of a £3m profits' shortfall and an unexpected £24m write-off.

A little over a year ago, Photo-Me was being hyped as the next big internet stock following a deal with BT that enabled people to access the internet from its booths.

Since then, a flurry of missed financial targets, controversial related party transactions, overseas legal claims and boardroom resignations have left investors feeling a little overexposed.

The introduction of internet enabled mobile phones and increased domestic internet use have also reduced the likelihood of the BT venture ever generating substantial revenues.

Shares in Photo-Me have underperformed the FTSE all-share index by 77% over the last year, and yesterday they fell a further 5p to a new low of 84.5p. Jean-Luc Peurois, the finance director, blamed the latest bad news on a combination of the autumn fuel crisis and the need to write off the value of some old analogue photo-booths.

"September and October are our most important trading months because students are getting new identity photos, but the fuel disruption meant the trains and coaches were not running to the stations where our booths are and business was slower than usual," Mr Peuroissaid.

The write down was taken on the advice of the company's auditor, Ernst & Young, appointed last year to improve the firm's financial controls. Because Photo-Me is rolling out new digital photo booths with advanced features, the old ones are in effect worthless.

"It's a constant stream of bad news and a pain in the ass, but we're sticking with them," a big institutional shareholder said.

Investors are pinning their hopes on two key factors: the ability of newly appointed deputy chairman Vernon Sankey to improve Photo-Me's corporate governance, and the long-term prospects of DKS minilab, a patented digital photo processing technology.

Digital cameras are becoming increasingly popular with consumers but there are only two companies with technology to turn the images on a computer screen into old-fashioned prints: Fuji and Photo-Me.

Kodak has signed a wide ranging deal to use DKS minilabs, and others are thought to be interested. If Photo-Me's production facility at Grenoble, in France, can satisfy demand, analysts believe the shares could recover. The world market for the $40,000 (£27,000) minilabs is 150,000 to 200,000.

Photo-Me is at present producing between 80 and 90 a month, but hopes to raise that to 150 by the summer. Analysts say on that basis, DKS sales should reach £40m by the end of this financial year and grow at 30%-40% annually.

That should also help offset an expected decline in demand for "fun" photo booth pictures. Some of the next generation of mobile phones will have built-in cameras that will enable users to message each other snapshots, and younger users are likely to prefer those to photo-booths.

"The Photo-Me story is changing: the DKS minilab is the future of this company," an analyst said.

"There's a lot of promise but they have to get rid of this unfortunate knack of slipping up every six months."

That is where Mr Sankey comes in. He was employed in October to avert a share holder revolt against chairman Dan David, who was under pressure following revelations that Photo-Me had not disclosed it had sold divisions to a firm in which Mr David and another director, Philippe Wahl, had an interest.

Mr Sankey held the top job at Reckitt & Coleman for nine years and has served as chairman of Thomson Travel. Advisers and shareholders hope that he will bring a strong, independent hand to Photo-Me and improve the company's battered image in the City.

Investors have already been impressed by Mr Sankey's decision to buy shares at 150p. Stockbroker Cazenove, appointed in May, is doing its best to help him make the business more investor friendly.

But some shareholders still want Mr David and Mr Wahl out. Negotiations to force 71-year-old Mr David to leave will be tricky - he owns 18% of the company.

"We'll be meeting with Sankey to make our views known," one of the firm's major shareholders said.

Serge Crasnianski, the French nuclear physicist who is Photo-Me's biggest shareholder, is likely to remain at the helm. Clever, passionate about the business and distinctly colourful, he is a rare thing: someone who has made money out of the company in the last year. He sold £28m worth of shares last January when it was a hot internet stock.

Investors will be hoping he and Mr Sankey can help spread the wealth.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: AOL | NBC | Bright Station
fields.body:
 Licensing link Media group AOL Time Warner announced yesterday a licensing agreement with mobile phone maker Nokia to provide an internet browser for wireless devices. Under the multiyear agreement, AOL will develop and market a Netscape-branded version of the telecommunications equipment maker's existing browser, known aswap, for use across a variety of mobile communications devices. AOL Time Warner also said Jim Bankoff would replace Jim Martin as president of Netscape Communications .

 Net job loss Provider of search and directory, content and e-commerce and entertainment services NBC Internet has said it will cut its workforce by 30% as the result of a revenue shortfall due to a softer advertising market - the latest online media company to cut jobs in a sector that is struggling to turn a profit.

 Successful search Software maker Bright Station has signed two new partners for its WebTop search subsidiary - games portal Media and Games Online Network and monitoring group Vigil Technologies .

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.trailText: High Fidelity | Those Who Love Me...
fields.body:
High Fidelity

Rental and DVD rental

Buena Vista Cert 15

****

In essence, not much change here in Hornbyworld: after the selfish football fan with a relationship problem, we have a selfish music fan with a relationship problem. For David Rocastle and Michael Thomas, read the Sir Douglas Quintet and the Smiths. But where Fever Pitch made a shockingly turgid film, High Fidelity is very enjoyable viewing, thanks to director Stephen Frears's light touch and some memorably relaxed acting: John Cusack is reliably fine in the lead role, and extrovert Jack Black and pale, sensitive Michael Stipe lookalike Todd Louiso as his fellow musketeers of musical taste (these guys won't even sell you a record unless it meets certain criteria) make a terrific team.

Black has most of the witty lines and gets to do a fantastic boogaloo with proudly displayed builder's bottom. He must surely become better known soon. These characters come over as real people, not stereotypes, and as Cusack's on-off girlfriend, Iben Hjejle gives a nicely nuanced, understated performance. Although the film moves the action to Chicago, it's still an authentically small-scale, intimate affair and balances funny and sad moments astutely. Many of us have maintained Cusack and co's adolescent list-mania and indulgent musical arguments to an advanced age, and if you can't see yourself in any of these characters, you'll recognise old friends and acquaintances.

Frears includes sly little cameos from Tim Robbins, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Lisa Bonet (sexier by far than Mrs Douglas, on this showing) and it's all so affectionately put together that it doesn't occur until after its surprisingly old-fashioned feelgood ending that Barry Levinson summed up this whole "music trivia as central core of life" state of mind more succinctly in Diner all those years ago. And what is a film lecturing us on musical taste doing allowing Queen and Elton John on the soundtrack? Tsk.

Those Who Love Me...

Retail (£15.99) and DVD (£19.99)

Artificial Eye Cert 15

***

Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train, to give it its full title, hurls you on to a Paris-Limoges express with very little by way of introduction to your fellow travellers - a cantankerous bunch on their way to a funeral while another mourner drives madly, trying to keep up on a parallel road with the coffin on board. They turn out to be friends, lovers, relatives and enemies of the newly deceased painter.

At first it's an exhilarating journey, with Patrice Chéreau's camera whirling around like one of the argumentative protagonists, though there barely seems room for it to move. But as the journey ends with a chaotic funeral in an equally crowded and extremely ugly graveyard ("185,000 dead but the population's 140,000", as the local cab driver says), it becomes apparent that very little is going to be resolved.

We're trapped for two hours with a collection of people full of disgust and despair, squabbling interminably, breaking out into the odd fist fight (and a bit of gay sex in the train loo, though that turns out to be more trouble than it's worth). So, despite a hint of dignity from the veteran Jean-Louis Trintignant, some fine acting from the ever intense Charles Berling and a truly touching performance from Vincent Perez as a transsexual ("a prince who became a frog"), this is a depressing trip. Perez's presence is a reminder that he was a leading light in Chéreau's sumptuous and bloodthirsty La Reine Margot, which won him the Cannes jury prize. Chéreau won a best director César here, too.

webTitle: Cartoon movies are finally to get their own Oscar

fields.headline: That's not all, folks
fields.standfirst: Full-length cartoon movies are finally to get their own Oscar. About time too, says  Steve Rose
fields.trailText: Full-length cartoon movies are finally to get their own Oscar. About time too, says Steve Rose
fields.body:
'I'd like to thank Tom Hanks for voicing me, John Lasseter and the guys at Pixar for creating me, my agent, Buzz, Jessie, Mr Potato Head and the rest of the team - it was great working with you guys." That won't happen this year but we could be hearing Oscar acceptance speeches like this, perhaps complemented by computer-animated tears, in years to come.

For the first time in 20 years, a new Academy award has been created: best animated feature. It will probably come into effect in 2002, for films of more than 70 minutes' length that are "primarily animated". Up until now, only animated short films - of which Creature Comforts and The Wrong Trousers are outstanding examples - could expect Academy recognition. But the new award means next year's crop of full-length animations are, for the first time, true Oscar contenders.

Animators have been campaigning for years for Oscar recognition, but also harbour reservations about the award. "It's a double-edged sword," says Dave Sproxton, managing director and co-founder of Britain's Aardman Animations, producers of last year's Chicken Run. "It's a sign that animation is back on the agenda, and should mean we see more players in the field. But it could also relegate animated films to their own little ghetto, so they stand against each other and don't interfere with the 'real' pictures."

In critical and box-office terms, animation is already giving "real" pictures a run for their money. Toy Story 2 was one of the top-grossing films worldwide last year, as well as a critical triumph; while Chicken Run and Dinosaur both took more than $100m in the US. But despite matching live-action films in the marketplace, animation has never come close at the Oscars. Animators often spend years crafting their product, only to see Phil Collins or Tim Rice walk off with an Oscar for best song. Only one animated feature has ever received a best picture nomination: Disney's Beauty and the Beast in 1991. It, too, won only in the music categories.

Since about 1960, Disney has been the only studio regularly producing feature-length animation so, until recently, any Oscar would have been a one-horse race. Disney is the only studio to have received real Academy recognition for its features. Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs received an honorary award in 1939 for having "pioneered a great new entertainment field", and, three years later, Fantasia received another.

Disney's dominance once destroyed competition in the past, but its recent renaissance has had the opposite effect. Once the Mouse House bounced back with hits such as Aladdin, Beauty and the Beast and particularly The Lion King - which took more than $760m worldwide - Disney's colossal revenues prompted other Hollywood studios to take another stab at the genre.

Most have mimicked Disney's family-musical formula but few have consistently made it click. Fox put its weight behind Disney defector Don Bluth, whose Phoenix studio found sporadic success with Anastasia and An American Tail. However, last year's sci-fi epic Titan AE failed to recoup much of its $80m budget, sending Fox Animation into untimely closure. Warner Bros, still productive in TV animation, has experienced similar difficulty when apeing the Disney formula (Quest for Camelot, The King and I), but found critical success with original work (The Iron Giant). DreamWorks has fared better with The Prince of Egypt, The Road to El Dorado and Antz, while TV tie-ins such as Rugrats, Pokémon and South Park have also performed well at feature length.

"We've spent three or four years debating this award, but we had to wait until the industry was big enough to make it worthwhile," says John Pavlik of the Academy. "That time is judged to have come, though the rules have been carefully calibrated to ensure competition." The best animation feature Oscar will only be given if eight or more eligible films are released in a year, and it will require a minimum of 16 releases to secure five nominees. The average number of US-produced animated features over the past decade, including the year 2000, has been seven.

What the Oscar will hopefully encourage is variety, giving a financial boost to riskier projects and small or foreign players, as it has with live-action features. Japan, for example, has a fully fledged animation industry, producing everything from apocalyptic sci-fi adventures such as Akira and Ghost in the Shell to contemporary character dramas such as Perfect Blue and offbeat fantasies such as the widely acclaimed Princess Mononoke (the highest-grossing picture in Japan apart from Titanic). Many of these have gone on to find a niche in Western video markets (Mononoke even had a limited US theatrical release), but their technical sophistication and mature themes could have made them strong contenders for Oscar success.

With a $240m Hollywood deal to their name, Aardman Animations is living proof of the difference an Oscar can make to a smaller player. "We can't deny that the three Oscars Nick [Park] won from the Wallace and Gromit films helped pave the way to our deal with DreamWorks," says Dave Sproxton. Its forthcoming reworking of the tortoise and the hare fable could be a contender for the first award in 2002.

Whatever the effects on the industry, there could be more problematic repercussions from the new Oscar stemming from the tricky term "primarily animated". With computer-generated images (CGI) increasingly blended into live-action films, the dividing line between the genres is likely to become more and more indeterminate. Take a movie such as Star Wars - The Phantom Menace. Real characters and virtual ones populate a combination of CGI and live sets. What percentage of the film is animated? How would such a percentage be determined? By drawing a firm line between the two, the Academy might be laying the ground for future legal disputes and bitter statistical warfare on a par with the US presidential elections.

Producer Dennis Edwards, at Warner Animation, has already faced this problem. His latest project, Osmosis Jones (directed by the Farrelly brothers), about the struggle against the cold virus inside a human body, mixes animation with live action and is set for release this summer. "I think our film meets the requirements and it doesn't really matter to me if it doesn't, but I'm sure it's going to get more difficult now that CGI is so widely used. To me, the film-making world is already a multimedia event. You take the best of all these worlds, live action, CGI, traditional hand-drawn animation, and combine them to make a new art form. I believe that's the future."

"That's definitely one of the wickets that's still sticky," says the Academy's John Pavlik. "The original proposal has detailed guidelines about the way the competition will work, but the rules about what constitutes 'primarily animated' haven't been written yet."

Animators often spend years crafting their product, only to see Phil Collins or Tim Rice walk off with an Oscar for best song. Only one animated feature has ever received a best picture nomination: Disney's Beauty and the Beast in 1991. It, too, won only in the music categories. Since about 1960, Disney has been the only studio regularly producing feature-length animation so, until recently, any Oscar would have been a one-horse race. Disney is the only studio to have received real Academy recognition for its features. Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs received an honorary award in 1939 for having "pioneered a great new entertainment field", and, three years later, Fantasia received another. Disney's dominance once destroyed competition in the past, but its recent renaissance has had the opposite effect. Once the Mouse House bounced back with hits such as Aladdin, Beauty and the Beast and particularly The Lion King - which took more than $760m worldwide - Disney's colossal revenues prompted other Hollywood studios to take another stab at the genre. Most have mimicked Disney's family-musical formula but few have consistently made it click. Fox put its weight behind Disney defector Don Bluth, whose Phoenix studio found sporadic success with Anastasia and An American Tail. However, last year's sci-fi epic Titan AE failed to recoup much of its $80m budget, sending Fox Animation into untimely closure. Warner Bros, still productive in TV animation, has experienced similar difficulty when apeing the Disney formula (Quest for Camelot, The King and I), but found critical success with original work (The Iron Giant). DreamWorks has fared better with The Prince of Egypt, The Road to El Dorado and Antz, while TV tie-ins such as Rugrats, Pokémon and South Park have also performed well at feature length. "We've spent three or four years debating this award, but we had to wait until the industry was big enough to make it worthwhile," says John Pavlik of the Academy. "That time is judged to have come, though the rules have been carefully calibrated to ensure competition." The best animation feature Oscar will only be given if eight or more eligible films are released in a year, and it will require a minimum of 16 releases to secure five nominees. The average number of US-produced animated features over the past decade, including the year 2000, has been seven. What the Oscar will hopefully encourage is variety, giving a financial boost to riskier projects and small or foreign players, as it has with live-action features. Japan, for example, has a fully fledged animation industry, producing everything from apocalyptic sci-fi adventures such as Akira and Ghost in the Shell to contemporary character dramas such as Perfect Blue and offbeat fantasies such as the widely acclaimed Princess Mononoke (the highest-grossing picture in Japan apart from Titanic). Many of these have gone on to find a niche in Western video markets (Mononoke even had a limited US theatrical release), but their technical sophistication and mature themes could have made them strong contenders for Oscar success. With a $240m Hollywood deal to their name, Aardman Animations is living proof of the difference an Oscar can make to a smaller player. "We can't deny that the three Oscars Nick [Park] won from the Wallace and Gromit films helped pave the way to our deal with DreamWorks," says Dave Sproxton. Its forthcoming reworking of the tortoise and the hare fable could be a contender for the first award in 2002. Whatever the effects on the industry, there could be more problematic repercussions from the new Oscar stemming from the tricky term "primarily animated". With computer-generated images (CGI) increasingly blended into live-action films, the dividing line between the genres is likely to become more and more indeterminate. Take a movie such as Star Wars - The Phantom Menace. Real characters and virtual ones populate a combination of CGI and live sets. What percentage of the film is animated? How would such a percentage be determined? By drawing a firm line between the two, the Academy might be laying the ground for future legal disputes and bitter statistical warfare on a par with the US presidential elections. Producer Dennis Edwards, at Warner Animation, has already faced this problem. His latest project, Osmosis Jones (directed by the Farrelly brothers), about the struggle against the cold virus inside a human body, mixes animation with live action and is set for release this summer. "I think our film meets the requirements and it doesn't really matter to me if it doesn't, but I'm sure it's going to get more difficult now that CGI is so widely used. To me, the film-making world is already a multimedia event. You take the best of all these worlds, live action, CGI, traditional hand-drawn animation, and combine them to make a new art form. I believe that's the future." "That's definitely one of the wickets that's still sticky," says the Academy's John Pavlik. "The original proposal has detailed guidelines about the way the competition will work, but the rules about what constitutes 'primarily animated' haven't been written yet."

fields.headline: The Peppered Moth by Margaret Drabble
fields.standfirst:
Viking, £16.99
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at a discount from BOL
fields.trailText: Three generations of Yorkshire women strive for their own matrilineal genetic mutation
fields.body:
Is this a novel? See the hall where the Cudworths clans are gathered to hear a lecture on DNA and matrilineal descent. Sitting next to a tired old spinster is a genuine bobby-dazzler. Could they be related? Let's read on and find out.

Here we are in Breaseborough, a Yorkshire mining town, in 1912. Bessie is the gifted member of the family. Her mother and father are slightly in awe of her. She is prone to illness, and her sister Dora has to tiptoe around her. Now let's move forward some years. She's the pride of her teachers; will she make it to Cambridge? She does. She retires to her bed as her exams approach. Could it be that she is frightened of failing and needs an excuse? Perhaps. But she passes anyway.

Bessie dreams of leaving her roots, but there is nowhere to go but Breaseborough. There she marries Joe Barron, the youngest son of the local glass magnate. We do not know how he proposed and we will not enquire. We must suppose they fell in love.

Bessie gave birth first to Robert, who will not feature much in our story, and then to Chrissie, who will. Chrissie was born in 1940, and Joe was soon off fighting abroad. At least that's what Bessie always said he was doing. Joe tried to be a good husband but he could never do enough for Bessie, even though they moved south to Surrey.

Chrissie yearned to escape her mother's hypochondriac, manipulative embrace. She toyed with getting pregnant; instead she went to Cambridge to read archaeology. How rebellious she was, and yet how hard it is to shake off one's genes! There she met Nicholas Gaulden, the face of the 60s. She knew he was unreliable and tried to escape him by spending the summer in the Faroes, but he followed her and made her pregnant.

Faro hates being named after a Portuguese airport, and despises her mother for her second marriage to conservative, dependable Donald Sinclair. Chrissie likes her cocoon and still feels relief at her mother's death. Faro is brilliant, yet unfulfilled. Will she waste her life on the parasitic Sebastian or step out with earthy Steve? She wakes with Steve. Is she free of the mitochondria at last? PS. Bessie is based on my mother.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: Three generations of Yorkshire women strive for their own matrilineal genetic mutation

fields.headline: Bounce
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This film really is the opposite of sex: nothing so earthy or enjoyable livens up this teary, solemn film, clearly designed, machine-tooled and focus-grouped as a "chick's movie".
fields.body:
This is a weepie romance of such glucose mawkishness it is difficult to credit that it was written and directed by Don Roos, who brought us the stylish The Opposite of Sex two years ago. This film really is the opposite of sex: nothing so earthy or enjoyable livens up this teary, solemn film, clearly designed, machine-tooled and focus-grouped as a "chick's movie".

Gwyneth Paltrow is in her straight-hair-looped-behind-ears mode as Abby, the young suburban widow with two perky kids. Ben Affleck's face is permanently and unbecomingly crumpled with suppressed tears playing Buddy, the ad man who falls in love with her. Buddy had, in a sense, killed her husband by giving him his ticket on a flight that crashed. So he seeks her out with obscure intentions of apology and naturally ends up falling for her.

It's all so terribly sad that there's no chance of the lovers "meeting cute" in the classic Hollywood style, nor ever leavening their relationship with much fun. Gwyneth and Ben give honest performances, but it's all such heavy going, especially as Buddy is also a recovering alcoholic, who gets quite a bit of tough love from his gay male assistant.

fields.headline: Beautiful Creatures
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Misfiring comedy thriller in which the alleged thrills are supposed to make up for the lack of laughs, and the supposed comedy is an alibi for the absence of thrills.
fields.body:
This never comes together, being at once too nasty for a Thelma and Louise feelgood adventure, and too nice for a grimy noir thriller. Susan Lynch and Rachel Weisz are Dorothy and Petula, both women abused by their worthless boyfriends, and thrown together when Dorothy saves Petula from being beaten half to death by Brian, her sinister paramour, by hitting him fatally over the head with an iron bar.

Strangely, director Bill Eagles shows a very uncertain touch in developing the relationship between the female stars, and he allows the men to steal the show with intense performances in jarringly unpleasant roles: Iain Glen as Dorothy's junkie pervert boyfriend Tony, Alex Norton as bent copper Hepburn. Like many a Lottery-funded British movie, this is a misfiring comedy thriller in which the alleged thrills are supposed to make up for the lack of laughs, and the supposed comedy is an alibi for the absence of thrills.

fields.headline: Vertical Limit
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Over and over again, people fall twangingly down to the limit of their safety rope, and swing back and forth over the digital abyss screaming at each other.
fields.body:
Here is an example of that deservedly neglected genre, the mountaineering action picture, promising thrills and spills at head-spinning heights. (Anyone remember Sylvester Stallone in the 1993 movie Cliffhanger?) Maybe Tom Cruise's semi-faked free-climbing sequence at the beginning of M:I-2 has awakened interest in the glamour of crampons.

Anyway, Chris O'Donnell is Peter, a young climber who has to rescue his feisty sister Annie (doe-eyed young Demi Moore-lookalike Robin Tunney) from peril atop K2. Vertical Limit means the extreme height at which the body can function - but sadly, the term could apply to the quality of this film: at the Vertical Limit's, erm, other end.

The inescapable fact is that climbing is essentially dull and undramatic: its self-congratulatory machismo is tiresome, and interest can only be sparked by having someone fall off a sheer rock face. So over and over again, people fall twangingly down to the limit of their safety rope, and swing back and forth over the digital abyss screaming at each other. As in The Perfect Storm, there is a lot of tedious, unintelligible hollering over the roaring elements, and they might just as well be rowing over the last square of Kendal's mint cake.

fields.headline: The Lost Lover
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Creaking with half-baked good intentions, but the script and much of the acting are just leaden and unconvincing.
fields.body: A film with Anglo-Italian backing set in Israel: unhappily, it is the sort of weirdly stilted co-production which makes everybody sound like English is their second language, English and non-English-speakers alike. Ciaran Hinds is Adam, the Jewish owner of a flourishing auto repair shop who employs Na'im (Erick Vazquez) the brother of an Arab terrorist. And meanwhile, a Romeo and Juliet situation is developing between Na'im and Adam's daughter Dafi (Clara Bryant). It's a movie creaking with half-baked good intentions, but the script and much of the acting are just leaden and unconvincing.

fields.headline: Quills
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Michael Caine is excellent as the humourless - and sadistic - doctor who torments Sade and Geoffrey Rush gives a showstopping turn as the old devil himself.
fields.body:
"You write more than you read - the sure sign of the amateur!" Thus the Abbé Coulmier, the progressive young priest of the Charenton hospital, addresses his most famous inmate, patient and congregant: the grinningly unrepentant Marquis de Sade, surrounded by his filthy books, lewd manuscripts and cheesy phallic curios.

It is a rare moment of literary shrewdness in this movie. Pasolini might have extrapolated from Sade a dark conflation of political tyranny and sexual cruelty, and Peter Brook saw in his final incarceration a refinement of the theatre of the absurd. But in Quills, adapted by Doug Wright from his stage play, director Philip Kaufman treats the great man both more leniently and less seriously.

He finds in the final years a bizarre yet oddly sentimental farce, taking as its springboard Sade's reputed tendresse for a 17-year-old girl working in the asylum laundry. It is the kind of romp that Stoppard might have cooked up; it's the kind of romp that Peter Schaffer did cook up in Amadeus - and like Amadeus, Quills has that sine qua non of the period madhouse scene: the mad naked fat old gibbering woman with enormous breasts. There's a hint of Dangerous Liaisons in the belle-lettristic adulteries and an unfortunate touch of Carry On Don't Lose Your Head in the historical set-dressing.

Kate Winslet is the hearty young laundress who lustily smuggles the Marquis's incendiary manuscripts out of prison for publication, allowing the author a chaste kiss but slapping his face when the old brute tries anything else. She is notably uncorrupted by reading Sade's stuff, though, sharing a bed only with her blind old mum (Billie Whitelaw). Joaquin Phoenix is the caring yet troubled Abbé, and a very absurd performance it is too, with an English accent that he has evidently imported from Harrods, claiming VAT back at the airport. "Hler," he says, instead of "Hello" adding things like "We must guard against our own cwuption!"

But Quills is partly redeemed by the two heavyweights in the cast. Michael Caine is excellent as the humourless - and sadistic - doctor who torments Sade. And Geoffrey Rush gives a showstopping turn as the old devil himself: a hilarious display of hauteur, mordant wit and lizardly, lip-licking cunning. It's worth seeing for Rush's louche performance, but he is imprisoned in a rather shallow comedy: all periwig and no bite.

fields.headline: The best Coney Island scene
fields.standfirst: Requiem for a dream
fields.trailText: Requiem for a dream
fields.body:
Coney Island, New York. Tyrone (Marlon Wayans) and Harry (Jared Leto) sit at the counter of an all-night doughnut shop, sipping hot chocolate. Tyrone turns to Harry.

"You know what we oughta do, man? We oughta get a piece of this Brody shit, cut it and off it."

Harry nods enthusiastically.

"Right. This stuff's good enough to cut in half. We could double our money. Easy."

"And then we buy a couple more pieces and we got a whole something else goin' on."

"And in no time we could get a pound of pure straight from Sal the Geep."

"A pound of pure. That sure would be righteous."

A hulking figure takes a seat beside them. Looking up, they realise it's a cop. Tyrone and Harry fall silent, staring down at their hot chocolates. Glancing up, Harry notices the cop's gun. Carefully, he leans over and pulls it from its holster.

"Hey!" the cop cries out, getting up from his seat.

As the cop charges toward Harry, he throws the gun over the cop's head to Tyrone. Tyrone catches it; the cop chases Tyrone. Tyrone and Harry throw the gun back and forth between them, until the cop finally collapses prostrate on the ground.

Harry jerks back to reality. The cop is still sitting beside him, his gun in his holster. The waiter looms over Harry and Tyrone.

"Anything else?"

"No," Harry mumbles. "Just the check."

See also: The Warriors

Don't see also: The Wiz

Pointless trivia: The majority of films contain around 600 cuts, whereas Requiem For A Dream features over 2000.

fields.headline: Living in oblivion
fields.standfirst: Hubert Selby Jr's parable of drug addiction has been made into an extraordinary, unflinching movie, says  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The excursion into the progressive circles of hell is recorded by Aronofsky with such precision that the whole film is unsettlingly like a gruesome yet compelling vivisectional experiment.
fields.body:
Orson Welles is said to have examined Shakespeare plays with the connoisseurship of a huntsman picking up a rifle. The energy, consistency and utter mastery of technique that Darren Aronofsky shows in his adaptation of Requiem for a Dream reminded me of that legendary confidence. His agonising and unflinchingly grim portrait of drug abuse, taken from a novel by Hubert Selby Jr (with whom Aronofsky co-wrote the screenplay), is a formally pleasing piece of work - if pleasing can possibly be the right word; it shows an engaging young man's descent into heroin addiction at the same time as his elderly mother becomes hooked on diet pills in the grotesquely forlorn hope of regaining her youthful figure in order to appear on a TV game show.

It's a repulsive and yet somehow elegantly considered symmetry of ironies, pre-figured by Aronofsky's split-screen argument through a locked door between Harry (Jared Leto) and his mom Sara Goldfarb (Ellen Burstyn), who is refusing to let Harry hock the TV to buy drugs. Gradually, inexorably, Harry and Sara's lives unravel, as do those of Harry's buddy Tyrone (Marlon Wayans) and his lover Marion (Jennifer Connelly). Their excursion into the progressive circles of hell is recorded by Aronofsky with such precision that the whole film is unsettlingly like a gruesome yet compelling vivisectional experiment.

Burstyn gives a superb performance as Sara, a sweet old lady deeply concerned for her boy: similar in many ways to her appearance in James Gray's The Yards. Living a life of genteel poverty in Brighton Beach in Brooklyn, she lives for nothing more than an appalling gameshow-cum-QVC-infomercial hosted by the oily Tappy Tibbons (Christopher McDonald, who since Quiz Show has cornered the market in this sort of role). Sara gets madly over-excited when informed that she has been "pre-approved" for contestantship and starts manically dieting to fit into her decent red dress. As in Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia, the TV game show is a vivid exemplar of a certain type of cultural squalor, and also a ghastly parody of "family".

At the same time, Harry and Tyrone have big dreams of cutting some sweet deals, making it big, getting rich quick, getting out of the drug business and taking up their new residence on Easy Street. With quickly chopped sequences, Aronofsky shows the drill of getting high: the snorting, the shooting, the eye-dilation, and with extended, almost Koyaanisqatsi-type time-lapse photography he shows Sara's frenetic excitement about her upcoming TV stardom.

Some early successes in the drug trade mean that Harry can underwrite Marion's attempts to become a fashion designer. But it all ends horribly: Harry's arm gets horrifically infected injecting his own wares and Marion ends up putting out at sex parties to feed her habit, all thoughts of designing dispersed to the four winds. In the slipstream of their headlong rush to the abyss, Mrs Goldfarb goes ga-ga with her speedy diet pills, and ends up as a bag lady in hospital getting ECT while fully conscious. (A little excessive, this: ECT is given to patients only under heavy anaesthetic.)

So where did it all go wrong? Was this calamity inevitable or not? And what exactly is the "dream" for which this is a requiem, and what is the implied parable of disillusion? Here the film is enigmatic, and it is difficult to locate the morality and meaning to which Requiem for a Dream appears to be gesturing.

It could be that Selby's 1978 novel comes from a time which pre-dates modern cinema's more complex view of drugs: a straightforward message to the effect that drugs are always wicked and always lead to hell was easier to carry off. To that extent, Requiem for a Dream is, arguably, serviceable Just Say No propaganda suitable for showing in schools.

But how does that explain Sara Goldfarb's terrible decline? She has not dabbled in the evil drug trade; she doesn't deserve it, surely? Sara is just a lonely, vulnerable person, a decent person who only wanted to go on a TV show. And yet Aronofsky, with relentless, almost aesthetic cruelty, shows her fate as exactly equivalent to her son's.

Evil and horror are not explained; they are just placed before us with sphinx-like calm. Somehow, a spore or germ of evil has entered their universe, and fatally infected everything and everyone, like the needle in Harry's arm. Finally, the one moment of ordinary, wholesome human compassion comes when Sara's neighbour Ada (Louise Lasser) comes to visit her in hospital and sobs outside afterwards, helplessly, with another neighbour. Everything else is ennui and torpor.

With spareness and unremitting cruelty, Aronofsky shows his characters' accelerated slide to destruction. It's an almost unbearably bleak view and its lack of any obvious redemptive moral message will revolt some.

But without it, Aronofsky's film is chilling, and diamond-hard.

The energy, consistency and utter mastery of technique that Darren Aronofsky shows in his adaptation of Requiem for a Dream reminded me of that legendary confidence. His agonising and unflinchingly grim portrait of drug abuse, taken from a novel by Hubert Selby Jr (with whom Aronofsky co-wrote the screenplay), is a formally pleasing piece of work - if pleasing can possibly be the right word; it shows an engaging young man's descent into heroin addiction at the same time as his elderly mother becomes hooked on diet pills in the grotesquely forlorn hope of regaining her youthful figure in order to appear on a TV game show. It's a repulsive and yet somehow elegantly considered symmetry of ironies, pre-figured by Aronofsky's split-screen argument through a locked door between Harry (Jared Leto) and his mom Sara Goldfarb (Ellen Burstyn), who is refusing to let Harry hock the TV to buy drugs. Gradually, inexorably, Harry and Sara's lives unravel, as do those of Harry's buddy Tyrone (Marlon Wayans) and his lover Marion (Jennifer Connelly). Their excursion into the progressive circles of hell is recorded by Aronofsky with such precision that the whole film is unsettlingly like a gruesome yet compelling vivisectional experiment. Burstyn gives a superb performance as Sara, a sweet old lady deeply concerned for her boy: similar in many ways to her appearance in James Gray's The Yards. Living a life of genteel poverty in Brighton Beach in Brooklyn, she lives for nothing more than an appalling gameshow-cum-QVC-infomercial hosted by the oily Tappy Tibbons (Christopher McDonald, who since Quiz Show has cornered the market in this sort of role). Sara gets madly over-excited when informed that she has been "pre-approved" for contestantship and starts manically dieting to fit into her decent red dress. As in Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia, the TV game show is a vivid exemplar of a certain type of cultural squalor, and also a ghastly parody of "family". At the same time, Harry and Tyrone have big dreams of cutting some sweet deals, making it big, getting rich quick, getting out of the drug business and taking up their new residence on Easy Street. With quickly chopped sequences, Aronofsky shows the drill of getting high: the snorting, the shooting, the eye-dilation, and with extended, almost Koyaanisqatsi-type time-lapse photography he shows Sara's frenetic excitement about her upcoming TV stardom. Some early successes in the drug trade mean that Harry can underwrite Marion's attempts to become a fashion designer. But it all ends horribly: Harry's arm gets horrifically infected injecting his own wares and Marion ends up putting out at sex parties to feed her habit, all thoughts of designing dispersed to the four winds. In the slipstream of their headlong rush to the abyss, Mrs Goldfarb goes ga-ga with her speedy diet pills, and ends up as a bag lady in hospital getting ECT while fully conscious. (A little excessive, this: ECT is given to patients only under heavy anaesthetic.) So where did it all go wrong? Was this calamity inevitable or not? And what exactly is the "dream" for which this is a requiem, and what is the implied parable of disillusion? Here the film is enigmatic, and it is difficult to locate the morality and meaning to which Requiem for a Dream appears to be gesturing. It could be that Selby's 1978 novel comes from a time which pre-dates modern cinema's more complex view of drugs: a straightforward message to the effect that drugs are always wicked and always lead to hell was easier to carry off. To that extent, Requiem for a Dream is, arguably, serviceable Just Say No propaganda suitable for showing in schools. But how does that explain Sara Goldfarb's terrible decline? She has not dabbled in the evil drug trade; she doesn't deserve it, surely? Sara is just a lonely, vulnerable person, a decent person who only wanted to go on a TV show. And yet Aronofsky, with relentless, almost aesthetic cruelty, shows her fate as exactly equivalent to her son's. Evil and horror are not explained; they are just placed before us with sphinx-like calm. Somehow, a spore or germ of evil has entered their universe, and fatally infected everything and everyone, like the needle in Harry's arm. Finally, the one moment of ordinary, wholesome human compassion comes when Sara's neighbour Ada (Louise Lasser) comes to visit her in hospital and sobs outside afterwards, helplessly, with another neighbour. Everything else is ennui and torpor. With spareness and unremitting cruelty, Aronofsky shows his characters' accelerated slide to destruction. It's an almost unbearably bleak view and its lack of any obvious redemptive moral message will revolt some. But without it, Aronofsky's film is chilling, and diamond-hard.

webTitle: Miramax releases film for rental on Internet

fields.headline: Miramax releases film for rental on Internet
fields.trailText: Guinevere, starring Stephen Rea and Sarah Polley, is the first of twelve films that Miramax plans to release on the Internet
fields.body:
Miramax is to become the first major studio to provide a feature film for rental via the Internet. According to Reuters, Guinevere, which was first released in America in September 1999, will be distributed by SightSound Technologies from Monday for 24-hour rental at a cost of $3.49. Distribution will be via the film's own website and Miramax and SightSound's websites.

Guinevere, starring Stephen Rea and Sarah Polley, is the first of twelve films that Miramax will be releasing on the Internet under its agreement with SightSound Technologies. The titles and release dates of the remaining 11 movies are still to be determined.

Using the Microsoft Corporation's video compression technology, SightSound say the film, which is safeguarded against piracy, can even be sent to friends.

The fear of a "Napster for movies" rearing its head has prompted many Hollywood studios to invest in providing feature films via the Internet, according to industry sources who expect Sony to begin offering movies on the Web by the spring. Studios are said to be quickening their pace to avoid finding themselves in the same boat as the music industry, which has been criticized for lagging in the on-line arena as free services like Napster have attracted millions of fans.

"We can prevent for movies what Napster did for music," said Scott Sander, president and chief executive of SightSound. Users will have to download the movie to their hard drive, but before it can be viewed, they will be sent to an e-commerce site and asked for payment. If they try to watch the film again after 24 hours, they will automatically be sent back to the e-commerce site.

fields.headline: Estrada given ultimatum
fields.trailText: Beleaguered Philippine president Joseph Estrada has been given until 10pm GMT tonight (6am Saturday, Philippine time) to stand down by his political opponents.
fields.body:
Beleaguered Philippine president Joseph Estrada has been given until 10pm GMT tonight (6am Saturday, Philippine time) to stand down by his political opponents.

Senator Raul Roco, speaking on behalf on the opposition, made the announcement. If Estrada refuses, protesters conducting an overnight vigil in the Manila streets would march on the Malacanang presidential palace, he said.

Estrada's earlier offer of a May presidential election, in which he would not run, was rejected by vice-president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, who is constitutionally in line to succeed Estrada. The president then demanded five days' hiatus and a full pardon before he would relent, according to opposition spokesman Roberto Pagdanganan.

Military commanders and cabinet ministers withdrew their support from the president this morning and joined the tens of thousands of anti-Estrada protesters.

Military chief General Angelo Reyes and defence secretary Orlando Mercado joined the 150,000 massing at a Manila monument to the 1986 revolt against dictator Ferninand Marcos, to call for an end to the political turmoil caused by Estrada's impeachment on corruption charges.

Reyes told demonstrators that Estrada and his family should be allowed to "exit with dignity".

"Let us not be vindictive, let us not be persecutive in mood," he said. Mercado also appeared at the gathering and hours earlier, had urged Philippine soldiers to stay out of the fray.

"Let's begin the healing process, because our country has been so deeply divided," said vice-president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, in line to succeed Estrada.

Estrada was furthered rocked by other government defections, including those of his finance secretary and the national treasurer.

Education minister Andrew Gonzales, another dissenter, told reporters: "It's over... the continuation of the present administration is no longer viable."

National police chief and formerly staunch ally General Panfilo Lacson also withdrew his support. "I told him I am very sorry but I have talked with senior officers and we arrived at a unanimous decision," he said.

The president's foremost ally in the senate, Francico Tatad, agreed it was time for the leader to "do the honourable thing" and end the nation's "crisis of epic proportions".

Earlier in the day, Estrada aides frantically denied that the former movie star had already fled the country. A US embassy spokesman also claimed he was unaware of any talks between Washington and Manila about possible asylum for the president in the event of his exile.

Private Manila radio station dzMM had earlier reported planes were waiting to fly the Estrada family out to Kota Kinabalu in Malaysia, en route to the United States

The address was broadcast just before news of the defections. Estrada maintained, "My conscience is clear" and urged lawmakers restart his impeachment, saying he was willing to let prosecutors open bank records that had been previously blocked.

The president has been accused of profiting from an illegal numbers game and skimming provincial tobacco taxes. The scandal also drew attention to mansions he allegedly bought for some of his acknowledged mistresses.

Feeling in the Philippine military is predominately against Estrada. 60 members of the Philippine Military Academy class of 1962 urged his departure in a newspaper advertisement, saying that the country's soldiers "know what to do during the critical days ahead as they have done in the past for the good of their country and their people."

But Estrada retains considerable support among impoverished Filipinos, whose cause he has championed. There have been minor clashes between protesters and pro-Estrada factions.

webTitle: When your neck's on the line, two heads are better than one

fields.headline: When your neck's on the line, two heads are better than one
fields.trailText: The man at the top has the last say, but every manager needs a Tord Grip to help bring out the best in his team.
fields.body:
Given that the manager takes the plaudits when things are going well and the flak when results turn nasty, it's easy to overlook the importance of the No2. But anyone unsure just how valuable a trusted assistant is should look at a couple of incidents this season.

It is not mere coincidence that Derby's results have picked up since Jim Smith appointed Colin Todd. And the fact that Tord Grip is known in Sweden as "one half of Sven-Goran's brain" sums up how much of a team he forms with Eriksson.

I think Jim would be the first to admit that bringing in someone with Colin's reputation and defensive experience has helped, and just having a new face around can make a difference.

Players tend to switch off when they hear the same voice the whole time, particularly if things aren't going well. A fresh voice, even if he's saying the same things, can have a real impact.

That's one reason I liked to give my No2s responsibility. Sometimes when the team went on a trip for a few days to a health farm, for a bit of sunshine or whatever, I stayed behind. I would tell my assistant: "You take them. I'll have a break from them and they can have a break from me." You get a fresh impact from not living in the players' pockets, and it gives you a chance to put your mind to certain things.

Of course the role the No2 has on the training ground will differ according to the manager. Leicester players have said they rarely saw Martin O'Neill during the week, whereas I loved working with the team.

But I always had my coaches with me and expected them to look after the ship if I was out of town. On a day-to-day basis they might have had certain jobs if we split a session and I always thought it was valuable to step back and let them run things. By pulling away, a manager can get a more objective view of his players.

Yet the value of a good No2 will run deeper. Probably the best partnership of all time was Brian Clough and Peter Taylor, and Cloughie would give Taylor full marks for his ability to spot talent. Similarly, Grip has been Eriksson's eyes and ears in England and will carry on doing that.

You have to trust the judgment of the person you work with, and a good partnership will have the right good-guy-bad-guy balance which is part of the art of management.

Players who were involved with them say Cloughie was the disciplinarian and Taylor was often lifting people behind the scenes when they'd been volleyed. It's similar at a lot of clubs. A No2 can afford to be a bit closer to the players than the manager, and when I've given someone a right blasting I've sometimes told my assistant to have a quiet word.

I was lucky to have good assistants such as Mick Brown, who is now the chief scout at Manchester United, Colin Addison, Peter Shreeves, Andy Gray and Richie Barker. And although a club must have only one dominant figure, the manager, I believed in having a lot of easy-going meetings with my coaching staff.

After training I might get a big pot of tea and invite them into my office for a chinwag. I wanted people to have a voice, but when we left that room everyone had to follow the official line. Players will sense a split and that can cause ripples throughout a club.

Of course I would take fresh ideas on board. At one time when we were struggling at Sheffield Wednesday I was still tempted to be ultra-positive and go for teams, although we probably weren't good enough. I remember Richie, who had very different opinions from me at times, saying we had to concentrate on being hard to beat, and it helped when we went that way for a time.

Then again, sometimes you have to stand your ground. Once at Manchester United we had a staff meeting before a game at Brighton and I mentioned a 16-year-old centre-forward I had seen in the youth team. "He should go in the first team," I told them.

My staff insisted it was too early, although they agreed he was going to be a super player, but at the end I stood up and said: "I don't care what anybody says, I know it's right to put him in." I brought him on as a substitute against Brighton and then saw him score on his full debut. It was Norman Whiteside.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Royal London to pay millions in compensation to 30,000 investors

fields.headline: Royal London to pay millions in compensation to 30,000 investors
fields.standfirst: FSA eager to be seen cracking down on endowment crisis <A Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Two businesses in the Royal London insurance group were yesterday fined £700,000 for rule breaches, including the mis-selling of endowment policies, and are set to pay £31m in compensation to 30,000 investors who have lost out.
fields.body:
Two businesses in the Royal London insurance group were yesterday fined £700,000 for rule breaches, including the mis-selling of endowment policies, and are set to pay £31m in compensation to 30,000 investors who have lost out.

The penalty imposed on United Friendly Insurance and Refuge Assurance is one of the largest announced by the financial services authority, which has been keen to show it is committed to tackling the endowment mortgage crisis which could potentially affect millions of homeowners.

The firms were each fined £350,000 for a string of rule breaches relating to sales of endowment savings policies, but expect to pay compensation to some customers who were sold mortgage endow ments that are designed to repay a home loan.

The two companies - part of the United Assurance group, acquired by Royal London last April - were guilty of giving some customers bad advice, resulting in people buying policies that were not appropriate for their needs.

While a visit to the firms by the regulator originally uncovered problems concerning savings policies, it also appears that some people with mortgage endowments may have lost out, and the companies are reviewing sales of these to see what redress may be due.

A Royal London spokesman said all those affected would receive compensation averaging £1,000 each by the end of this year.

The cost of this would be met from the two firms' life funds and would not have an impact on Royal London members, he added.

The FSA said the firms had given unsuitable advice in that they "failed to ensure that the contract was affordable to the customer and establish that the customer needed the contract".

They also did not keep proper records to show that the recommendations made were suitable, failed to maintain a proper system of compliance control, did not adequately monitor the conduct of their staff and failed to ensure that customer complaints had been properly investigated. The breaches occurred between August 1997 and July 1998.

Compensation totalling £31m was expected to be offered to more than 30,000 people, said the FSA. The firms were also ordered to pay £23,800 costs.

United Friendly, Refuge Assurance and Royal London have committed themselves to a "radical and thorough overhaul" of the businesses.

Yesterday's fine comes less than two months after Royal Bank of Scotland subsidiary Royal Scottish Assurance was fined a record £2m and landed with a £50m compensation bill for failings mainly involving mortgage endowments.

Mike Yardley, the chief executive of Royal London, said the firms accepted the regulator's findings and "regret any distress caused" to customers. An investor helpline has been set up on 01625 605908.

The FSA yesterday revealed the name of the person who will be its human face in court - David Mayhew, a partner in law company Clifford Chance. Mr Mayhew, 47, has been appointed the financial services authority's leading advocate.

fields.headline: La Ribot
fields.standfirst:
South London Gallery
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
South London Gallery
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The Spanish soloist La Ribot has presented most of her shows on conventional stages but for her current project, Still Distinguished, she has transferred to gallery spaces. The move brings with it a different way of looking, a different relationship with her audience, and it makes much better sense of her material. In the theatre, I saw the witty but narcissistic contrivances of a dancer who was very good at taking off her clothes. What I saw in the South London Gallery was an artist using her naked body to project a range of deft visual conceits, and to pack a concentrated lesson in how we look at bodies, at women and at other people.

Not that La Ribot is denying her dance background. Few women without serious training could be so pragmatic about stripping naked so close to a bunch of strangers. And the curiously ageless La Ribot, with her slightly worn face and girlish slenderness, has the kind of body that doesn't blush under the most fascistic or voyeuristic gaze.

The first piece, Pa amb tomaquet, is a video depicting a bizarre rite of preparation. La Ribot crumbles up a garlic clove and scrubs it vigorously over her body. She then smears on ripe tomatoes, and finally gives herself a thorough drizzling of olive oil. It's a fusion of cookery, ablution and erotic foreplay which becomes a joke about women getting ready for consumption, but it also primes us for the see-sawing relationship we develop with La Ribot during her live show, a relationship both intimate and neutral.

When she takes off her clothes during the next piece, she lays them out on the floor, along with several assorted objects, in precise order of size. The mix of striptease and task is perfectly judged - La Ribot allows us to stare at her breasts, genitals and skin, but her efficient activity flatly defuses any sexual charge.

Frequently, she allows herself to look vulnerable, even grotesque. In Outsized Baggage she ties herself tightly with cord - a female parcel packed for air freight - and the rope makes her flesh redden and bulge. Later she binds her joints with wooden splints to become a stiff parody of a ballerina. Yet her fine concentration allows her to retain magisterial control of her effects, and of us.

We follow her obediently around the gallery and respond with almost childlike promptness to her cues - grinning as she smiles at us, feeling collective emotions of shock, scepticism, interest.In her final piece, having drunk a litre of water, La Ribot wraps herself in foil and lies on the floor. We all, simultaneously, wonder if she's going to pee. By the time we realise she isn't, we're all thinking that it wouldn't be such a big deal if she did.

La Ribot's use of herself as prime material and the potentially confrontational nature of her approach suggest easy comparisms with Tracey Emin. Actually, the discipline she brings to her performance and the meticulousness with which she thinks through her ideas leave Emin floundering.

Until Sunday. Box office: 0870 840 1961.

She then smears on ripe tomatoes, and finally gives herself a thorough drizzling of olive oil. It's a fusion of cookery, ablution and erotic foreplay which becomes a joke about women getting ready for consumption, but it also primes us for the see-sawing relationship we develop with La Ribot during her live show, a relationship both intimate and neutral. When she takes off her clothes during the next piece, she lays them out on the floor, along with several assorted objects, in precise order of size. The mix of striptease and task is perfectly judged - La Ribot allows us to stare at her breasts, genitals and skin, but her efficient activity flatly defuses any sexual charge. Frequently, she allows herself to look vulnerable, even grotesque. In Outsized Baggage she ties herself tightly with cord - a female parcel packed for air freight - and the rope makes her flesh redden and bulge. Later she binds her joints with wooden splints to become a stiff parody of a ballerina. Yet her fine concentration allows her to retain magisterial control of her effects, and of us. We follow her obediently around the gallery and respond with almost childlike promptness to her cues - grinning as she smiles at us, feeling collective emotions of shock, scepticism, interest.In her final piece, having drunk a litre of water, La Ribot wraps herself in foil and lies on the floor. We all, simultaneously, wonder if she's going to pee. By the time we realise she isn't, we're all thinking that it wouldn't be such a big deal if she did. La Ribot's use of herself as prime material and the potentially confrontational nature of her approach suggest easy comparisms with Tracey Emin. Actually, the discipline she brings to her performance and the meticulousness with which she thinks through her ideas leave Emin floundering. Until Sunday. Box office: 0870 840 1961.

webTitle: Why do-it-yourself benefits are taking off

fields.headline: Why do-it-yourself benefits are taking off
fields.trailText: If you're worried about having to rely on state benefits to cover your health, housing and pension needs, check out if you can buy cheaper insurance through your company.
fields.body:
If you're worried about having to rely on state benefits to cover your health, housing and pension needs, check out if you can buy cheaper insurance through your company.

A growing number of insurance companies, looking to capitalise on the trend for self-provision, are looking to provide benefits for staff in lower paid jobs as part of so-called voluntary schemes.

These mean that staff, while still having to pay for the cover themselves, receive cheaper deals because of bulk buying and less administration for the insurer.

Private employee benefits have traditionally been the preserve of those in better paid jobs and are funded by the employer to maintain loyalty. But, many of those in blue-collar jobs or those who work for smaller companies do not have access to these.

Stakeholder pensions, which launch this April, are seen as the catalyst for self-provision and insurers are hoping they will prompt employers to think about other benefits, such as life insurance, critical illness and income protection.

Stakeholder pensions are currently the subject of a major Government advertising campaign and are aimed at workers earning £9,500 and £21,600.

All businesses, employing five or more staff, will have to provide information and access to one of these pension plans, which are lower cost and more flexible than traditional pensions.

They are being launched because the Government does not believe there will be sufficient money in the pot from National Insurance Contributions to provide adequate retirement income for the current working population.

On the back of stakeholder pensions, insurer Legal & General is launching a voluntary life insurance plan this month. It offers benefit in units of £10,000 up to a maximum of £150,000.

Jane Dale, managing director of the insurer's group risk division said: "With the introduction of stakeholder, many employers will be introducing a benefit for the first time. This should be a good opportunity also to offer life insurance and arrange for payroll deductions. Our plan means the employer provides access but no funding and we are confident the price for employees will be considerably less than if they bought the insurance elsewhere."

The new policy will only be available to companies that have 100 or more employees, but there is no minimum take up rate.

"We think it will appeal to the blue collar sector and also those who work for companies that might employ hi-tech staff. These people might be on higher salaries, but not have access to benefits," said Ms Dale.

She added that the insurance would also be offered to part-time workers and possibly those on long-term contracts.

Employee benefits expert, Martin Thompson of Sedgwick Independent Financial Consultants said: "Legal & General is stealing a march on other insurers with this launch. The one area I think employees should be careful in is to make sure they check the price really is competitive. There is no point in buying a product that is not good value and they may only be offered limited advice by the employer."

The state of the NHS and waiting lists has also prompted more interest in voluntary private medical insurance schemes that pay for access to prompt treatment in private hospitals.

Specialist broker, Andrew Green of Green Denman said: "There is growing demand for these, but some insurers have reservations. They think that only those who have existing medical problems will want to join the scheme."

Mr Green says if an employer can secure a good deal, they should make sure it is well marketed, with the benefits and any cost implications emphasised, to ensure maximum take up.

Insurer Swiss Life is also tapping into the voluntary benefits sector. It has a dedicated business division called Partnering. Manager John Ritchie says: "It is not just either one thing or the other. Employers can also partly sponsor a benefit if they want to bring down the cost even more."

Swiss Life is the market leader in the group critical illness market, much of which is sold on a voluntary basis. Critical illness insurance pays out a lump sum - typically enough to cover a mortgage - if the policyholder is diagnosed with one of specified list of serious diseases such as heart attack, cancer or a stroke.

Ritchie added: "We have recently set up a deal to provide critical illness on a voluntary basis for one of the major supermarkets. They obtain it much cheaper than if staff bought it individually."

He said staff were receptive to this type of insurance. "People can understand it. They can see it possibly happening to them, whereas with other types of insurance that cover disability like income protection, it is more abstract."

fields.headline: New York Faust a triumphant failure
fields.standfirst:
Doktor Faust
Metropolitan Opera
New York
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Doktor Faust
Metropolitan Opera
New York
Rating: *****
fields.body: The words "neglected masterpiece" have hung around the neck of Ferrucio Busoni's opera Doktor Faust for so long that it is reasonable to ask whether they are truly appropriate. After three quarters of a century, perhaps its general absence tells us there is something irreducibly problematic about it. The admirable performances being given at the New York Metropolitan Opera under Philippe Auguin, the first in the company's long history, fail to provide a definitive answer. In Peter Mussbach's production, Doktor Faust emerges as an intellectually impressive and often fascinating work, which mounts towards a kind of grim greatness. Yet it is also a long and elusive evening, in which Busoni's dogged adherence to his own rigorous, aesthetic principles outlasts his sense of theatre. Throughout the 10 years he worked on his opera - it was still unfinished when he died in 1924 - Busoni was determined to strip away the sentimentalities of the Faust legend and create an alternative to the mysticism invested in it by European artists, from Goethe to Mahler. Busoni's Faust returns to the unromanticised German puppet-show character of the pre-Goethe era. It is closer to Marlowe than Mahler. Crucially, there is no place for Gretchen/Marguerite, or for the metaphysics of eternal womanhood that resolve Goethe's final version. The result is an opera that is deliberately episodic. It has a beginning, of sorts, and it certainly has an end (two, in fact), but what comes in between is discontinuous and far from conventionally depicted. Musically, Busoni is determined to avoid mere entertainment. He resists many of the temptations of tonal progression and operatic tradition, though his writing is never other than harmonically grounded. It is also extremely colourful, though his palette is more Sibelius than Ravel. And it is inescapably dark-toned, since Faust is sung by a baritone and there is no major female role in the opera. The problem with Busoni's opera could almost be called Faustian. Intellectually and aesthetically, it is hugely stimulating. It demands and provides a degree of serious engagement that few other operas can rival. On the other hand, theatrically and structurally, it is almost deliberately unsatisfying as a result of Busoni's refusal to compromise his principles. The production takes him on his own terms, which has inevitable consequences. The characters are striking but cryptic, and often detached, like human puppets. The chorus is masked, ghostly and ominous, dressed like a harlequinade. The lighting, by Konrad Lindenberg, is especially fine. Only Faust, unstintingly and imposingly sung by Thomas Hampson, is required to relate to the audience. The audience's involvement therefore reciprocates. It seemed somewhat distant, primarily intellectual rather than emotional. A lot of people left at the interval. In the end, the judgment on Doktor Faust is as paradoxical as the work. It will never establish itself in the core repertoire, yet will never be forgotten. It stands as a triumphant failure, compelling and yet alienating, neither an end of an old era nor the start of a new one.

fields.headline: Cool Sicilian passion at the Barbican
fields.standfirst:
La Lupa
Barbican Centre
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
La Lupa
Barbican Centre
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
At first it seems completely wrong. The Barbican Pit's all-white set hardly conjures up a Sicilian farmyard. But this bare and spare look proves a striking counterpoint to the all-consuming passion at the heart of Giovanni Verga's 1896 play. In this instance cool turns out to be the new hot.

At least it does for part of the evening. The first 15 minutes of Simona Gonella's production are thrillingly good. It is the end of harvest. The villagers are exhausted but relaxed, and spend the evening drinking, singing and dancing. But tension rises as the young widow Pina makes clear her desire to bed, and maybe wed, the casual labourer Nanni, the outsider in the group.

Gonella takes her time in detailing every nuance, every unspoken thought and the relationships of the villagers. This opening scene is almost anthropological. All the intimacies of this close-knit community are laid bare: the way it has cast each of its number a role that they must play, how they all know the rules of the game. It is fascinating and unbearably tense to watch because what is not said is as important as what is spoken. David Lan's adaptation knows this, too, and allows space for the drama to swell naturally.

But if in this terrific piece of foreplay Gonella's production makes the clear connection between sweat and sex, the land and other more earthy desires, it never reaches the expected orgasm in the drama that follows, as Pina's desperation leads her to offer Nanni an appalling deal in which he gets to marry her daughter while sleeping with the mother. In accepting, Nanni damns himself.

Of course the play's attitude towards women is prehistoric, and the Catholic Sicilian code of honour that leads to the final inevitable tragedy remains obscure, despite all Gonella's and Lan's efforts. But it is not these difficulties that scupper the evening. It is the casting. As the lusted-after Nanni, Declan Conlon is just far too bland and seems peculiarly matter-of fact-about his own damnation. And Brid Brennan, a seriously good actress but not one to whom you'd apply the word smouldering, is completely miscast as the sexy, voracious Pina. Together, they struggle to generate the level of electricity you would find in a power cut.

 Until February 24. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

webTitle: Classical Review: Bruno Canino and Friends

fields.headline: Bruno Canino and Friends
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall
London

Rating: **
fields.body:
The Italian Bruno Canino is best known as an interpreter of contemporary music, particularly in duet with his fellow pianist Antonio Ballista. In a pair of concerts at the Wigmore Hall this week Canino and some of his close colleagues, including Ballista, are providing a potted history of Italian music since the turn of the 20th century, from Busoni right up to a brand new work by a composer still in his 20s. It's a useful reminder of those figures who were active between the two world wars, after Puccini and before the avant-garde generation of Berio and Nono. The names may be familiar, but not much of their music.

The trouble is that it is hard to warm to much of this music, sometimes for extra-musical reasons (Alfred Casella, for instance, was an unabashed fascist) but more often because the style - parched neoclassicism or strangulated romanticism - is congenitally uninteresting. For all Canino's energy, Casella's two-piano Ricercari on the name of Bach from 1932 never seemed to get to the point, while the combined musicianship of Ballista, the violinist Gabriele Pieranunzi and cellist Giovanni Sollima couldn't make Giorgio Ghedini's Seven Ricercari for piano trio (1943) anything but terminally dull.

A pair of vocal works, with the excellent soprano Alda Caiello, were more engaging. Dallapiccola's 1948 songs on poems by Antonio Machado are a bejewelled set of miniatures, without a wasted note, while Malipiero's Dialogo No 3, for soprano and two pianos from 1956 was a real discovery - settings of a pair of medieval devotional poems that are uncomplicatedly direct in their lyricism and full of harmonic subtlety and delicate colours.

Then it was back to 1922, for Busoni's massive Fantasia Contrappuntistica, which was designed as a two-piano completion of Bach's Art of Fugue. Canino and Ballista showed that they have lost none of their almost telepathic understanding, or any of the verve that has always typified their performances, but trying to weld this rambling, 40-minute monster into a coherent and lucid musical argument proved beyond even their powers of persuasion.

Further concert in the Wigmore Hall tonight. Box office: 020-7935 2141.

fields.headline: Lou Donaldson/Lonnie Smith
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Cafe
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Jazz Cafe
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
"Glad y'all appreciate classical singing," Lou Donaldson said after delivering his lurching, strangled-parrot blues Whisky Drinking Woman. He said it the same way, in the same place, and after the same song last year. Donaldson, a good-humoured 75-year-old alto saxophonist from Carolina, stopped trying to reinvent himself around 1967, when he had his biggest hit with the soul-jazz anthem Alligator Boogaloo. It hardly matters. The show still works.

As last year, Donaldson is accompanied by his Dr Lonnie Smith, a Methuselah-bearded, turban-topped Hammond organ player, and it's still Smith's stagey juggling with the dynamics and shrewd pacing of the organ's firepower that dominates. On Wednesday Donaldson restricted himself to perfunctory summaries of the catchy, stripped-down riffs of his hit tunes, and occasional bursts of the sharp-toned double-time bop runs that tip a hat to Charlie Parker. But, as a group performance, it was a much more varied and animated affair than a year ago. Even Donaldson's, seen- it-all physiognomy registered satisfaction with his young audience's obvious affection.

Grant Green-like guitarists are essential to the 1960s organ/sax band sound and, in Randy Johnston, Donaldson had an excellent one, succinct and percussive on the chord-playing and fleet and light on the solos. Meanwhile, Donaldson sang as much as he played, sounding like Jools Holland with laryngitis.

Smith displayed some sly stagecraft on the ensemble's staple fare, the mid-tempo funk groove. He likes a murmuring, bass-heavy tone while building up a solo, as well as much repetition of a few churchy sounds. Recycling figures and trills emphase that all-important jazz-funk landmark, the big, don't-miss-it chord-change. These overtures make even a noisy audience crane to listen, and when Smith finally bursts out of the shadows into the scorching daylight of a flat-out Hammond blast, theimpact of the pyrotechnics is redoubled.

He demonstrated considerable uptempo virtuosity as the set progressed, and confirmed his walking-bass prowess on the pedals in a special request for the gospelly Reverend Moses. An increasingly effervescent Donaldson threw When the Saints Go Marching In into that, and Flight of the Bumble Bee (a favourite Donaldson quote) into Turtle Walk. That, by the way, is a new release, and it's a piece of... well, I'll be damned... mid-tempo jazz-funk. Hallelujah.
