webTitle: The silly way to say 'you're fired'

fields.headline: The silly way to say 'you're fired'
fields.trailText: The accountancy firm with the world's silliest name yesterday came up with the silliest way of saying that it is firing 100 of its senior staff.
fields.body:
The accountancy firm with the world's silliest name yesterday came up with the silliest way of saying that it is firing 100 of its senior staff.

PricewaterhouseCoopers, the world's biggest accounting and consultancy firm, said that "just under 10% of its UK partners will be leaving to pursue careers elsewhere".

These 100 employees have not resigned en masse to take up new challenges with new employers - they are being selected for compulsory redundancy during the next three months.

Kieran Poynter, senior UK partner, said: "We had too many partners in certain areas. A number will therefore be leaving us to pursue alternative career options".

The partners selected for redundancy will have their shares compulsorily purchased and will be offered outplacement services to help them find new jobs. Mr Poynter added, however, that the firm was still hiring and "looks forward to a large number of new partners joining the partnership in the coming year".

PricewaterhouseCoopers was formed after a 1998 merger, and has been criticised for failing to reap the full benefits of merger by cutting out duplication.

But the firm's decision to axe partners came as it reported a 15% increase in global revenues to $21.5bn last year.

Revenues from business advisory services, PwC's largest unit, rose almost 11% over the year, with global revenues of $8.4bn. Management consulting generated revenues of $6.6bn, an increase of 14%.

fields.bodyText: The accountancy firm with the world's silliest name yesterday came up with the silliest way of saying that it is firing 100 of its senior staff. PricewaterhouseCoopers, the world's biggest accounting and consultancy firm, said that "just under 10% of its UK partners will be leaving to pursue careers elsewhere". These 100 employees have not resigned en masse to take up new challenges with new employers - they are being selected for compulsory redundancy during the next three months. Kieran Poynter, senior UK partner, said: "We had too many partners in certain areas. A number will therefore be leaving us to pursue alternative career options". The partners selected for redundancy will have their shares compulsorily purchased and will be offered outplacement services to help them find new jobs. Mr Poynter added, however, that the firm was still hiring and "looks forward to a large number of new partners joining the partnership in the coming year". webTitle: Ailing Arcadia's shareholders attack new chief's millions

fields.headline: Ailing Arcadia's shareholders attack new chief's millions
fields.trailText: Shareholders in Arcadia, the stores group which came close to collapse last year, yesterday lambasted the multi-million pound pay package offered to new chief executive Stuart Rose.
fields.body:
Shareholders in Arcadia, the stores group which came close to collapse last year, yesterday lambasted the multi-million pound pay package offered to new chief executive Stuart Rose.

Mr Rose joined the company in autumn when former chief executive John Hoerner was ousted. He is being paid £550,000 a year plus a cash bonus and was given a £330,000 signing-on fee. He was awarded 6.5m share options which could generate more than £14m if performance targets are met.

At the group's annual general meeting in London yesterday one shareholder described the pay deal as "an unsavoury package of goodies" and said: "How on earth can this be justified?"

The group's shareholders have had a rough ride in the last three years. The shares tumbled from more than 500p to 39p, though they have recovered some ground since Mr Rose's appointment. Last year, hit by savage price cutting and a crippling rent bill, the company plunged to a £152m loss, announced plans to close 450 stores and axed its dividend.

Chairman Adam Broadbent defended the package saying he had secured the best man to engineer the turnaround required and was paying only the rate for the job. Arcadia's pay policy, he said, "is not to pay more than is necessary, but we do have to pay enough".

The attack on Mr Rose's remuneration came as the first signs emerged that Arcadia may be turning the corner.

The group, which is Britain's second largest clothing retailer and operates 12 brands including Top Shop, Miss Selfridge and Burton, said like-for-like sales had climbed 4.3% in the 20 weeks to Jan 13. Margins have improved by up to 1.5%.

Finance director Nigel Hall said the group had benefited from "the disarray of our competitiors, particularly Marks & Spencer and Bhs", and from consumers trading up from discounters in search of better quality. He admitted much of the improvement, was down to a restructuring strategy called Brandmax put in place by Mr Hoerner. "There is some validity to that view", he said.

Mr Rose is working on another restructuring within Arcadia, which analysts believe could mean the sale or closure of up to six Arcadia businesses. Wade Smith, Miss Selfridge, Racing Green, Hawkshead, Principles and Warehouse are seen as most vulnerable. "There are no sacred cows," Mr Rose said.

The group is expected to cut head office costs and could launch a rights issue. "We can't rule it out and we won't rule it in", said Mr Hall.

webTitle: American hi-tech results offset sector's doom and gloom

fields.headline: American hi-tech results offset sector's doom and gloom
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Leading US technology companies provided some much-needed cheer for sector investors last night with quarterly results which either met or exceeded expectations.
fields.body:
Leading US technology companies provided some much-needed cheer for sector investors last night with quarterly results which either met or exceeded expectations.

Microsoft met already reduced earnings expectations and beat revenue estimates for its second quarter. John Connors, the group's chief financial officer, welcomed "strong customer demand" in the period before adding: "We re main guarded about the near term economic outlook and its impact on PC demand and technology spending."

In spite of such short term caution, the market welcomed the record results as a sign that personal computer sales were not slowing quite as sharply as feared. Shares in Microsoft rose almost 10% in after hours trading to almost $60 (£41). But even at this level, the company is still valued at almost half its record high of a year ago after being crushed by its legal battles with the US government and signs of a sharp economic slowdown.

The company also said that it expected third-quarter revenues to be between $6.3bn to $6.4bn, with earnings at between 42 cents and 43 cents a share, slightly below estimates after an accounting change.

The market enthusiasm for Microsoft's earnings was topped by its welcome for those of EBay. The online auction site announced fourth-quarter earnings of nine cents a share, or $23.9m, almost five times the level of a year ago. Analysts had been expecting more than seven cents a share.

Shares rose 17% in after-hours trading after the results were announced as EBay offered an upbeat assessment of the current year.

Meg Whitman, company chief executive, said that revenues could reach $665m this year, compared with $431.4m for 2000 as a result of more members with a broader range of goods to barter.

Some 3.5m new members were added in the three months to the end of December, bringing the total number using the services of the company to 22.5m. EBay also expects revenues for the first quarter of 2001 to approach $150m. Faye Landes, internet analyst at Sanford Bernstein, told CNBC: "These numbers look very, very strong."

EBay refused to revise its earnings expectations for the current quarter in spite of the better than expected revenues, stating that it intended to reinvest in the company.

Sun Microsystems, the server and workstation group, also announced quarterly earnings up 8% last night, in line with expectations. However, the company's revenues were slightly below expectations of $5.3bn after increasing 6% in the year.

The company offered some cheer by announcing a 32% increase in orders and its shares rose 8% in a buoyant after-hours trading.
